headline: Outbreak Prompts Travel Warning in Asia
abstract: Hundreds of people in Vietnam, Hong Kong and China have been stricken by a mysterious respiratory illness, worried officials of the World Health Organization said today.

headline: Mutual Funds Report; Been Down So Long, You Call This Up?
abstract: Sharpness of stock market decline in first three quarters of 2002 caused third consecutive year of losses despite strong fourth-quarter performances by stock mutual funds; average domestic equity fund lost more than 20 percent of its value in 2002; drawing (M)

headline: Software; Said Simple Simon To the Spyman
abstract: Spyware, or adware, is software that tracks Web surfing habits and uses Internet connection to report results back to data-collection server; most common way for computer to become infected with adware is downloading shareware program, where offending program may piggyback on main program and install on system like parasite; program called Spy Sweeper by Webroot can unmask, disable and remove adware; photo (M)

headline: ARAMARK SELLS CENTERS TO KNOWLEDGE LEARNING CORP.
abstract: Aramark Corp sells its Educational Resources unit to Knowledge Learning Corp for $225 million in cash and $40 million in subordinated note (S)

headline: French Move Toward Curbs on Smoking by Minors
abstract: French Senate approves bill to ban cigarette sales to children under 16, bans cigarette giveaways to minors and require high schools to educate students on hazards of smoking (S)

headline: Not Enough Supplies or Money, Relief Groups Say
abstract: Relief organizations, anticipating US war with Iraq, say they have neither sufficent supplies nor enough money to cope with millions of injured, displaced and starving people that could result; say if fighting is prolonged, particularly in and around cities, at least half of Iraqi civilian population of 25 million people might be left struggling for food and water; Pres Bush has promised to make relief assistance priority of any campaign in Iraq; photo (M)

headline: Merrill Lynch Cut Pay for O'Neal in 2002
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co cuts pay of its chief executive, E Stanley O'Neal, by third in 2002, to $14.3 million; compensation for chairman, David H Komansky, falls 11 percent, to $14.4 million; pay for other top officers noted (S)

headline: Chirac Keeps Iraq Stance at Meeting With Blair
abstract: France resisted appeals to soften its opposition to war with Iraq after a one-day summit meeting here today between Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain and the French president, Jacques Chirac.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.25   4.25   4.75       Discount rate   0.75   0.75   1.50       Federal funds   1.31   1.24   1.69       3-month T-bills   1.17   1.17   1.56       6-month T-bills   1.21   1.22   1.60       10-yr. T-infl.   2.27   2.30   3.37       10-yr. T-note   4.06   4.08   4.83       30-yr. T-bond   4.97   5.00   5.34       Telephone bd.   6.13   6.15   7.42       Municipal bds.   5.13   5.14   5.27          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Shares of Food Companies Fall on Scandal Fears
abstract: Shares of food makers fall after Royal Ahold, Dutch supermarket company, says it overstated earnings at its US Foodservice unit, prematurely booking profits from vendor promotions and trade allowances; investors fear food companies may have been willing participants in huge cover-up (M)

headline: Antismoking Campaign Shifts Media Account
abstract: American Legacy Foundation shifts media part of its 'Truth' antismoking account to Media Head from Arnold MPG (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Texas Instruments Expects Chip Sales  To Rise
abstract: Texas Instruments Inc expects sales of semiconductors to builders of cellular networks to rise 50 percent in 2003 as operators introduce faster wireless services; sees sales rising to about $150 million; graph (S)

headline: Remarks by Spain's Foreign Minister to Security Council
abstract: Following is the transcript of the statement by Ana Palacio, the foreign minister of Spain, to the Security Council today as recorded by the Federal News Service.

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: A Retirement At Bp; SPAIN: Bank Stake Is Acquired; FRANCE: Loss At Water Company;.

headline: The Fantasy of the Corner Office
abstract: Readers describe what they would do if they could be chief executive of major corporation for day; drawings (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: I.B.M. Plans Servers With Faster Chip
abstract: IBM plans to sell server machines based on Power5 computer chip that operates at four times speed of current one; new chip will be introduced in 2003 (S)

headline: Turkey Seeks Troops in Iraq And May Allow U.S. Flights
abstract: Turkish government insists on its right to send troops into Iraq if it needs to, despite deep American concern about potential consequences; Turkish government fears rise of autonomous Kurdish state in northern Iraq, which could rekindle separatist demands among Kurds in southeastern Turkey; government is also worried about tide of refugees crossing from northern Iraq into Turkey and wants its military to be abe to halt any flow; these concerns are discussed in delicate meeting in Ankara between Turkish government officials and Iraqi Kurdish leaders; meeting is led by Bush administration's special envoy to Iraqi opposition, Zalmay Khalilzad, who is working to ease tensions between groups (M)

headline: Harvard-Templeton Settlement
abstract: Harvard endowment and Templeton Asset Management settle dispute over future of two closed-end China funds run by J Mark Mobius; agree to drop suits against each other; Harvard will liquidate its investments in funds at price near their net asset value and abandon efforts to oust Mobius and Templeton from fund management (S)

headline: A New Division At Colby & Partners
abstract: Colby & Partners creates division on marketing

headline: Bitterness Follows French Chef's Death
abstract: Apparent suicide of Bernard Loiseau, one of France's most celebrated chefs, follows downgrading of his highly rated Hotel de la Cote d'Or in Salieu in Burgundy by influential and respected Gault-Millau restaurant guide and reports it faced similar downgrade by Michelin Guide; his death has caused bitterness within nation's restaurant industry and revived debate over powerful guides, on whose highly subjective annual ratings food lovers base decisions on where to go for excellent meal; Paul Bocuse, France's most famous chef, and others comment; photo (M)

headline: Tenants Vie With Landlords As Commercial Vacancies Rise
abstract: As downtown office markets weaken across most of the country, property owners are discovering new and formidable competitors, right in their own buildings.    Their own tenants have put more than 39 million square feet of space on the market at discounts as steep as 45 percent, brokers and analysts say. The tenants can afford to undercut their landlords because subleasing, even at a sharp discount from expenses, is better than continuing to pay full rent for unused space.

headline: Still more brand names to get star roles in a Fox sports show.
abstract: Labatt USA will be beer sponsor for The Best Damn Sports Show Period beginning Jan 7 on Fox Sports Net; deal calls for cameos by bear mascot featured in recent Labatt Blue commercials; Home Depot will follow next month via new set simulating backyard deck where hosts, including Tom Arnold and Chris Rose, will regularly talk sports; deal is valued at $1 million to $2 million; photo (M)

headline: Musharraf Facing Decision In the Security Council Soon
abstract: Pres Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan may face difficult decision in Security Council: should his country support resolution, unpopular at home, that would back American-led attack on fellow Muslims in Iraq; or should he risk wrath of United States, his vital but possibly fickle ally; most Pakistanis have little love for Saddam Hussein, but they are deeply suspicious of American goals in Middle East and strongly oppose attack on Iraq; Musharraf faces agitation from emboldened, hard-line Islamic groups (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Lucent Reaches Settlement With Former Executive
abstract: Lucent Technologies reaches settlement in breach-of-contract claim with Nina Aversano, former president of sales for North America, ending dispute over money she claimed Lucent owed her; separate whistle-blower claim by Aversano under New Jersey Conscientious Employee Protection Act--in which she contended that she was forced to resign in 2000 after arguing in detailed presentation that sales targets were unrealistic--is dismissed; Aversano's assertions helped fuel debate over 'channel stuffing,' business practice of shipping products not to real customers but to distribution channels; terms of settlement undisclosed (S)

headline: Companies in U.S. Sing Blues As Europe Reprises 50's Hits
abstract: European copyright protection is expiring on collector's trove of 1950's jazz, opera and early rock 'n' roll albums, forcing American record companies to consider deals with bootleg labels and demand new customs barriers; European Union copyrights last only 50 years, compared with 95 in US, even if recordings originated in US, so that recordings by singers like Maria Callas, Elvis Presley and Ella Fitzgerald are entering public domain in Europe; photos; distribution of such albums is theoretically limited to Europe, but US outlets routinely stock imports; industry, already reeling from illegal downloads, vows to fight piracy; Neil Turkewitz of Recording Industry Assn explains position (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: G.I. Shot Himself
abstract: German police say American soldier who sú

headline: Manhunt for bin Laden And Top Aide, Zawahiri, Continues to Be Fruitless
abstract: For months American troops and covert operatives have combed the rugged outlands of eastern Afghanistan and western Pakistan in search of Osama bin Laden and his principal deputy, Ayman al-Zawahiri.    The fruitless manhunt serves as a reminder of the Bush administration's inability to achieve one of the main goals of its antiterror effort, the capture of Al Qaeda's leaders. Mr. bin Laden and Mr. Zawahiri are not only at large, but apparently are the sources of recent taped exhortations urging followers to carry out more violence.

headline: INTERPUBLIC, AN AD AGENCY COMPANY, WILL SELL BONDS
abstract: Interpublic, An Ad Agency Company, Willï

headline: Burlington Industries Bid Stalls
abstract: Bid by Berkshire Hathaway, investment company led by Warren E Buffett, to pay $579 million for Burlington Industries stalls when Federal Bankruptcy Judge Randall Newsome rejects sales procedures that favor Berkshire; Buffett and financier Wilbur L Ross Jr, whose W L Ross & Co holds 25 percent of Burlington's unsecured debt, have been vying for control of company (M)

headline: BAGHDAD RESUMES DISMANTLING ARMS, BUT LISTS DEMANDS
abstract: Iraq resumes destroying its short-range missiles while issuing defiant list of demands to United Nations, in further attempt to exploit deep divisions among world's powers over war; Iraqi government statement, glossing over negative aspects of latest report by weapons inspectors, concludes that country has been declared sufficiently free of weapons of mass destruction to warrant cancellation of sanctions imposed after Persian Gulf war; sense in Baghdad is that United States and Britain are on defensive because of strong resistance by France, Russia and Germany to use of force against Iraq; diplomats at United Nations say Britain is more interested than US in finding compromise that might attract more international support for new resolution two nations put forward, which would give Iraq until Mar 17 to disarm completely as demanded in Resolution 1441, passed unanimously in Nov; Bush administration officials give no indication they would entertain any compromise that would extend deadline for Iraq's disarmament beyond Mar 17; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Green Light For U.S. Missile Shield
abstract: British Defense Secretary Geof Hoon tells House of Commons that government will likely approve US missile shield program for Fylingdales Royal Air Force station in North Yorkshire; decision is viewed by some, including former Defense Minister Peter Kilfoyle, as diminishment of British authority in order to comply with US policy (S)

headline: Gotham Sold Shares After Urging Others To Buy Stock
abstract: Regulatory filing by David P Berkowitz, Gotham Partners hedge fund manager, shows that Gotham sold about 500,000 shares of Pre-Paid Legal Services Inc by Dec 31, 2002, less than five weeks after issuing research report recommending that investors buy stock; New York State Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer is investigating whether Gotham improperly used research to try to move stock prices (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Profit For Retailer
abstract: South Korea's

headline: Offsetting Environmental Damage by Planes
abstract: Several organizations, including Better World Club and American Forests in US and Future Forests in Britain, allow environmentally minded air travelers to mitigate release of carbon dioxide, a greenhouse gas, for which they are responsible by paying $11 to $22 per flight to have trees planted or energy-saving light bulbs installed in developing countries or making similar investment in energy-efficient school heating systems; number of Americans who avail themselves of service is still negligible, but those that do have strong views and believe airlines should be pitching in; photo (M)

headline: Officials Press Ahead With Smallpox Shots
abstract: Federal health officials say that government's smallpox vaccination program will proceed as planned despite concerns about lack of safeguards raised in expert advisory group's report and calls for delay by unions representing health care workers; Institute of Medicine report, written as confidential draft at request of federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, contains 23 recommendations and was obtained and first described by New York Times on Jan 16; federal program calls for vaccination of up to 500,000 health care workers in coming weeks; second phase calls for innoculating 10 million more people; eleven states are ready to begin vaccinations which are part of biodefense program, not public health program, and, unlike other innoculations, offer risk but no benefits to recipients in absence of attack, since smallpox has been eradicated (M)

headline: A Whopper Joins Las Vegas's Convention Lineup
abstract: Las Vegas's new 1.4-million-square-foot, $235 million Mandalay Bay Convention Center complex promises to be successful despite brisk construction of competing convention space and drop in demand; photos; graph of demand for North American convention and exhibition space (M)

headline: Critics Say U.S. Lacks Legal Basis for Attack
abstract: Diplomats who failed for last two months to agree on unified approach to Iraq crisis meet at United Nations; foreign ministers of France, Germany and Russia offer angry post-mortems on diplomatic debacle and argue that planned American-led invasion to disarm Iraq and oust Saddam Hussein has no basis in international law (M)

headline: It's Never Too Late
abstract: Lainey Feingold letter comments on digital piano training (Jan 2 article)

headline: Britain and the Continent Part Ways on Rates; Bank of England Cuts Lending Rate to Lowest Level Since 1955
abstract: Bank of England unexpectedly cuts its benchmark interest rate quarter point, to 3.75 percent, lowest level since 1955; says over next two years, prospects for demand are somewhat weaker than previously anticipated; graph (M)

headline: Nervous Day in the Pit For Traders of Crude
abstract: Oil prices fluctuate on New York Mercantile Exchange on news of events of war in Iraq; reports of well fires in Iraq drive up prices, but start of full-scale bombing later in afternoon brings them down; April crude futures close at $28.61 per barrel; graph; chart; photo of Energy Sec Spencer Abraham with Sens Carl Levin and John McCain before briefing Senate Armed Services Committee on state of oil supplies (M)

headline: Group Program Manager Bids Flippant Farewell to Microsoft
abstract: David Stutz, respected technical thinker at Microsoft, leaves company with parting e-mail that critiques company's Windows-centric strategy; photo (S)

headline: Investing; Pixar's Box-Office Glow Makes Stock Look Rosy
abstract: Outlook for Pixar stock discussed in light of animation studio's success at box office and on Wall Street; many investors are betting Pixar will negotiate better deal with either Walt Disney Co, which distributes its films, or another studio; stock price graph (M)

headline: São Paulo's Fancy Hotels Feature Bargain Rates
abstract: Glut of hotel rooms is bad news for established hotels in Sao Paulo; even high-end hotels around Avenida Paulista, main banking district, have seen occupancy rates drop to levels as low as 30 percent and are lowering their prices drastically; competition is good news for bargain-hunting business travelers; photo (M)

headline: South Korea Delays Vote On Sending Troops to Iraq
abstract: South Korea's Parliament delays for second time vote on sending personnel to Iraq; Pres Roh Moo Hyun, who was elected on wave of protests against American military presence, is trying to bridge gap between his electorate and his desire to retain 37,000 American troops posted in South Korea (M)

headline: With Smaller Operation Than First Planned, U.S. Opens Northern Front
abstract: United States opens long-awaited northern front, but initial operation is smaller than originally planned because Turkish Parliament rejected plan to let troops operate from Turkey; mission to secure Harir airfield is undertaken by 1,000 paratroopers from 173rd Airborne Brigade supported by attacks on surface-to-surface missile and Iraqi front-line positions; photo (M)

headline: U.S. and Mexico Coordinate Military Efforts for Mutual Protection Against Terror
abstract: United States and Mexico are coordinating military missions to protect their common border from terrorist attack; Mexico makes unprecedented move of sending thousands of its soldiers to patrol border and help secure it against threats (M)

headline: Iraqi Opposition to Form Leadership Team to Prepare for a Transition to Democracy
abstract: Iraqi opposition leaders, defying American wishes, decide to form leadership committee to help prepare for transition to democracy if Pres Saddam Hussein is ousted, and to dispatch delegation to Ankara to try to dissuade Turkey from sending troops into northern Iraq during war; both steps seem aimed at enhancing status of Iraqi National Congress, umbrella opposition group that aims to be nucleus of future representative government of Iraq; Zalmay Khalilzad, Pres Bush's special envoy to Iraqi opposition, sought unsuccessfully to get group to create political task force that would have largely advisory role; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: I.B.M. and Advanced Micro Form Chip Venture
abstract: IBM and Advanced Micro Devices from joint venture to develop chip-making technologies for use in high-performance microprocessors of server computers and powerful workstations (S)

headline: Qaeda Aide Slipped Away Long Before Sept. 11 Attack
abstract: Investigation into manhunt for terrorist Khalid Shaikh Mohammed reveals evidence that top government officials in Qatar tipped him off as FBI closed in on him in early 1996 after his involvement in botched terror operation in Philippines; many US officials now believe that, as result, they missed their best chance to prevent September 11 terrorist attacks on New York and Washington; only rebuke against Qatar was stinging letter from then-FBI director Louis Freeh (M)

headline: Phone Units Join in Effort For Seamless Wireless Net
abstract: Motorola, Proxim and Avaya are expected to announce they will jointly develop technology to allow wireless communications to jump between networks without interruption; analysts call plan most ambitious wireless roaming plan yet to try to take advantage of spread of communication hubs known as Wi-Fi; Motorola says it has made offer to acquire 26 percent of Next Level Communications it does not own for $30 million (M)

headline: Instant Messaging Leaves School for Office
abstract: Instant messaging is moving into workplace with impact that has started to rival e-mail and cellphone; Forrester Research says number of instant messages has grown by more than 50 percent, so that nearly one-third of American adults are now instant messaging; growth is driven in part by availability of free software on Internet, as companies like Microsoft, AOL Time Warner and Yahoo use it to lure customers to their other services; some companies are seeking to clamp down on technology, which allows employees to message several dozen friends while gazing into their computer screens; graph; photos (M)

headline: Iraq Says U.N. Teams Have Found No Weapons
abstract: Iraq says UN weapons inspectors who have visited some 230 sites have thus far failed to find any weapons of mass destruction or evidence of other prohibited programs (S)

headline: Top U.N. Inspector Still Sees No Iraqi Commitment to Disarm
abstract: Hans Blix said today that full compliance by Iraq was still not evident, though there were some new signs of Iraqi cooperation.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Terrorism Suspect Denies Charges
abstract: Alexandros Yiotopoulos, suspected leader of Greek terrorist group Nov 17, denies multiple charges of murder linked to group's violent campaign beginning early in 1970's; photo (S)

headline: With Rise in Foreign Aid, Plans for a New Way to Give It
abstract: Bush administration's State Dept budget for 2004, to be unveiled Feb 3, will call for largest increase in foreign assistance in two decades; it will also introduce new program that would begin over hauling way America distributes aid to poorest countries; new program, called Millennium Challenge Account, will demand that recipient states be accountable for American tax dollars they spend; plan would operate in tandem with existing aid programs; experts say it reflects ambitious effort by Pres Bush to place Republican stamp on foreign aid; in particular, plan attempts to answer longstanding conservative complaint that foreign aid has become global welfare that is abused by corrupt regimes, squandered on ineffective projects and laxly monitored by liberal bureaucrats; Bush's budget calls for allocating $1.3 billion to Millennium Challenge in 2004, $2.6 billion in 2005 and $5 billion annually after that (M)

headline: JONES APPAREL SAYS IT WILL LAY OFF 2,100 WORKERS
abstract: Jones Apparel Group will lay off 2,100 people, or 14 percent of work force; says 1,500 job cuts will be made in Mexico, where it is closing three plants; also closing warehouses in El Paso; will convert some stores to lower-price brand (S)

headline: Bids Scarce, Sotheby's Takes Itself Off the Block
abstract: Sotheby's Holdings and its largest shareholder, A Alfred Taubman, agree to take auction house off the market after getting no firm bids in eight months; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Lists 3 Chechen Groups As Terrorist and Freezes Assets
abstract: US State Department spokesman Richard Boucher announces designation of three rebel groups in Chechnya--Riyadus-Salikhin Reconnaissance and Sabotage Battalion of Chechnen Martyrs, Special Purpose Islamic Regiment and Islamic International Brigade--as 'terrorist organizations' linked to Al Qaeda and freezes their assets in US; Russian Foreign Min Igor Ivanov welcomes decision (M)

headline: Despite Accord, Reconciliation Proves Elusive in Ivory Coast
abstract: Talks on so-called national reconciliation in Ivory Coast continue as both sides attempt to hammer out agreement determining how much power each side would wield; peace accord struck nearly six weeks ago in France envisions power-sharing between Pres Laurent Gbagbo government, which controls southern half of Ivory Coast, and rebel groups that control north and much of west; rebels have agreed to drop claims to two key cabinet posts but seek concessions, including guarantee of safety of their leaders and ceding of prime minister post to veteran politician Seydou Diarra; map (M)

headline: NIKE REPORTS DROP IN EARNINGS FOR QUARTER
abstract: Nike Inc says earnings fell 1.3 percent in fiscal third quarter ended Feb 28; net income fell to $124.7 million, from $126.3 million year earlier; sales climbed 6.2 percent, to $2.4 billion, from $2.26 billion (S)

headline: Americans Turning Eagerly to Gibes at the French
abstract: Many Americans have notably unleashed verbal vitriol at France and Germany, European allies that have challenged Washington on war with Iraq; acid is being flung at France in particular, because of its resistance to imminent military action; Europe is becoming target of vitriol and black humor in US; photo of New York Post front page portraying French and German representatives at Security Council as weasels (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Air Link To China
abstract: Chinese officials approve first commercial flights between Taiwan and mainland since end of China's civil war in 1949; China Airlines, Mandarin Airlines and Far Eastern Air Transport Corp say two round-trip charter flights apiece from Taipei to Shanghai have been approved; each plane will stop in Hong Kong, 4-hour detour that Taiwan says it insisted upon because of concerns that direct flights across Taiwan Strait could be used for attack by China (S)

headline: Investors in Philippine Pyramid Scheme Lose Over $2 Billion
abstract: About 2 million Filipinos lose over $2 billion in collapse of 3 pyramid companies; officials call it biggest pyramid fraud in Philippine history (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: This Mother-In-Law Is No Joke
abstract: Italian appeals court concurs with decision granting woman divorce on grounds of excessive meddling by her husband's parents, particularly her mother-in-law (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ulster: Arrest In Omagh Bombing
abstract: Irish police arrest Seamus Daly, who is suspected of being member of Real IRA paramilitary group and of being involved in 1998 car-bombing of Omagh, Northern Ireland (S)

headline: Candies and Aspirin For Those Who Fled Their Embattled City
abstract: Marines deliver cases of their own rations and water to tiny camp of people displaced by fighting from nearby Nasiriya; mission is designated 'hearts and minds'; one marine distributes candies to crowd, while others hand out medical supplies and perform simple first aid; photo (M)

headline: Killing of U.N. Aide by Israel Bares Rift With Relief Agency
abstract: Breakdown of trust between Israeli government and United Nations Relief and Works Agency is laid bare by death of Iain Hook, British supervisor for agency, who was shot by Israeli soldier in West Bank town of Jenin on Nov 22; UN workers in West Bank and Gaza Strip accuse Israeli Army of senseless and wanton behavior and catalogue what they say are repeated abuses and humiliations at hands of troops; Israel maintains officially that soldier was returning fire when Hook was shot, but unofficially it contends that agency's operations provide cover for Palestinian terrorists; UN officials say Israel has yet to give agency any evidence that it tolerates subversion (M)

headline: F.B.I. Is Investigating HealthSouth Trades
abstract: FBI opens criminal investigation into trading of shares of HealthSouth Corp, nation's largest chain of rehabilitation hospitals and clinics; FBI spokesman Craig Dahle says agency is investigating 'possible securities law violations'; company confirms that it has been served with subpoena from US attorney's office; HealthSouth's chairman-chief executive Richard M Scrushy has been accused in number of shareholder lawsuits of acting on insider information and selling about $100 million in HealthSouth shares in weeks before company made announcement that caused its stock price to drop sharply; Scrushy reiterates denials of any wrongdoing; photo (M)

headline: HealthSouth Inquiry Looks For Accounts Held Offshore
abstract: Federal Bureau of Investigation explores whether HealthSouth chairman Richard M Scrushy established offshore bank accounts as tax haven; also seeks further understanding of July 30 suicide of Scrushy's colleague William Massey Jr, about three months after he made quick business trip to Bahamas; expected guilty plea by company vice president and assistant controller Emery Harris would follow fraud admissions by former chief financial officers Weston Smith and William Owens, who described schemes to falsely inflate company revenues by at least $1.4 billion and exaggerate assets at Scrushy's behest; government officials pursue separate investigations into several other ventures Scrushy conducted; April 1 deadline for HealthSouth credit payments of about $350 million suggests possibility of its filing for bankruptcy protection (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: INDIA: Software Profit Increases 24%; JAPAN: Sharp Predicts Doubling Of Tv Sales;.

headline: At the Afghan Border, Warnings of Attacks Tied to Iraq War
abstract: Hundreds of Qaeda fighters and Taliban supporters--now living with families in rugged tribal areas of South Waziristan in Pakistan--are said to be planning to intensify their attacks on Afghan territory if war breaks out in Iraq; claim is made by three residents of tribal area, who slip across border to Afghanistan; their statements heighten concerns of security officials in Afghan border village of Ungorada, where American soldier was killed by hostile fire on Dec 21; photo; map (M)

headline: An Antiwar Democrat Leaves Room To Wiggle
abstract: Democratic Presidential aspirant Howard Dean, widely known as antiwar candidate whose swift denunciation of Pres Bush's Iraq resolution set him apart in Democratic field, says he will support US invasion if approved by UN; differs from other Democratic contenders on whether US should proceed against Iraq with multinational force even if it fails to win UN support; says US should not unless it finds there is immediate threat (M)

headline: New Delhi Journal; Clean, Modern Subway, Efficiently Built. In India?
abstract: The trains arrive with a whisper, speak with a computerized voice and at times are driven by women. Passengers board quickly and quietly at stations that are clean and airy, with graceful 30-foot arched ceilings and computerized entryways.    In a city of 14 million people that otherwise tends toward controlled anarchy, it is a pride-inspiring marvel.

headline: Morgan Backs Out of Settlement
abstract: Morgan Stanley backs out of potential settlement of federal lawsuit accusing it of discrimination against women; collapse of talks prompts Judge Richard Berman to summon Morgan Stanley's chairman Philip J Purcell and Equal Employment Opportunity Commission head Cari M Dominguez to his courtroom; former bond seller Allison Schieffelin, whose complaint led to EEOC's complaint, charged she was unfairly denied managing director post and is seeking financial damages; complaint was filed on her behalf by EEOC in September 2001 (M)

headline: Bombarding Baghdad, Deaths in Battle, and Rising Support for Bush
abstract: Overview of day's events in war in Iraq (M)

headline: Man Who Made '60 Minutes' To Make Way for New Blood
abstract: Don Hewitt, 80-year-old founder and executive producer of 60 Minutes, says he will step aside to make way for 60 Minutes II producer Jeffrey Fager after next television season; will then become paid, emeritus news division executive with tenure through age 90; reaches compromise with CBS, which has been trying to ease him out in search of new blood; created 60 Minutes 35 years ago; CBS hopes to freshen leadership of program, which is fading in ratings, though still most-watched news-magazine program; median age of its audience is nearly 60; part of Fager's charge will be to increase program's appeal to younger audience; photo (M)

headline: Flying Between Enemies, Hoping to Land in a New Iraq
abstract: US envoy Zalmay Khalilzad, National Security Council official in charge of Central Asia and Persian Gulf, travels between Kurdish and Turkish leaders trying to ensure that Turkish military will not enter northern Iraq; photo (M)

headline: 2 U.S. Banks Trim Operations in Brazil
abstract: Despite Brazil's smooth transition to a left-leaning government, two major American banks -- J. P. Morgan Chase and Bank of America -- announced today that they were reducing their operations in the country.    J. P. Morgan Chase said it was selling J. P. Morgan Fleming Asset Management, with 7 billion reais ($1.9 billion) of assets, to Banco Bradesco. It did not disclose the sale price. Morgan Fleming is based in São Paulo.

headline: The Importance of Being a Bush, Any Bush
abstract: Fredy Bush, chief executive of Xinhua Fina

headline: Health Screening Is Sought for Some Airports
abstract: World Health Orgn, seeking to control spread of mysterious respiratory illness known as SARS, urges airports in affected cities to ask international passengers about their health at check-in and to discourage those with fever within previous 24 hours from flying; WHO is focusing on flights leaving places where disease is spreading locally: Toronto, Singapore, Hanoi, Vietnam; Hong Kong, Taiwan, and in Beijing, Shanghai and Guandong Province in China, where it is believed to have first spread, last Nov (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Dissident's Strong Critique
abstract: Myanmar opposition reformer Daw Aung San Suu Kyi denounces government attempts to disrupt her recent trip to Rakhine State; released last May after 19 months of house arrest, she accuses government of breaking promise to meet and discuss reforms; photo (S)

headline: South Korean President Names Cabinet and Faces New Challenge
abstract: President Roh Moo Hyun faced his first major challenge in the form of claims by Washington that North Korea had restarted the nuclear reactor.

headline: Sprint Is Sued by BellSouth and Cingular
abstract: BellSouth and its affiliated mobile-phone operator, Cingular Wireless, say they are suing Sprint over its effort to hire BellSouth's vice chairman, Gary D Forsee (S)

headline: Chechens Turn Out in Huge Numbers for a Vote on a Moscow-Backed Constitution
abstract: Chechnya's voters turn out in large numbers to cast their ballots on new constitution that would bind republic to Russia, but it remains unclear how that might translate into end of war with rebels, who show no sign of giving up their fight; photos (M)

headline: INVESTING WITH: Larry J. Puglia; T. Rowe Price Blue Chip Growth Fund
abstract: Carole Gould profile of T Rowe Price Blue Chip Growth fund and its manager, Larry J Puglia; photo; graph (M)

headline: 3 Americans on Search Mission Killed in Colombian Plane Crash
abstract: United States government plane crashes in jungles of southern Colombia, killing three Americans who were carrying out search for three other Americans kidnapped last month by Marxist rebels after their plane went down in same area; official of United States Embassy says three who died were working for private company under contract to US government; Americans who were captured are identified only as employees of California Microwave Inc (M),

headline: BANKRUPTCY COURT APPROVES FAO EXECUTIVE PAY PLAN
abstract: FAO, owner of FAO Schwarz and Zany Brainy toy store chains, wins court permission to pay $1.1 million in bonuses to keep several managers through its bankruptcy reorganization (S)

headline: Europe Shows a Growing Distaste for Genetic Foods
abstract: No matter what the outcome of U.S. efforts to sell genetically modified foods in Europe, public revulsion there runs deep.

headline: German News Channels Come of Age As Reports on War Rivet Big Audiences
abstract: Ratings for Germany's two all-news TV channels, N-TV and N24, skyrocket during first week of war in Iraq; place less emphasis on tactics or troop movements than CNN, which is also available to German audiences, concentrating on antiwar protests, humanitarian problems of war and risks of conflict spreading to neighboring nations; photo (M)

headline: A Disc That Will Hold A Bigger Bite of Data
abstract: Q. I have heard that new DVD's are being developed that can hold more than 20 gigabytes of datA. How is that accomplished, and when will these discs be on the market?    A. A new type of high-capacity disc similar in physical size to DVD's and compact discs is being developed and is expected to hold 27 or 54 gigabytes of datA. It is called a Blu-ray disc, and the technical standard for it is a joint effort by major companies, among them Philips, Hitachi, Sony, Pioneer, Samsung, Sharp and Panasonic's parent company, MatsushitA.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Reshuffle In Chechnya
abstract: Chechnya's Prime Minister Mikhail V Babich resigns after public disagreement with local official Akhmad Kadyrov over finances; after only three months in office, Babich is replaced by Anatoly A Popov, who heads reconstruction efforts in Chechnya; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bank Fined In Tax Case
abstract: Germany's Deutsche Bank is fined $63.5 million for helping customers evade taxes by placing money in accounts abroad; bank to appeal fine (S)

headline: FleetBoston Settles Inquiry By Regulators
abstract: FleetBoston Financial Corp will pay $28 million to securities regulators to settle charges that Robertson Stephens, its investment banking unit that is closed, illegally shared in profits of customers from trading hot new stocks; agrees to pay additional $5 million to end investigation into recommendations made by former stock analyst Paul Johnson, who does not settle; Securities and Exchange Commission files suit against Johnson, accusing him of issuing fraudulent research reports; regulators contend that sales representatives at Robertson Stephens accepted, and in many cases demanded, inflated commissions on stock trades as kickbacks for allocations of shares they received during new-stock boom in 1999 and 2000 (M)

headline: New Group to Oppose Proposals on Digital Piracy
abstract: Some technology companies and consumer organizations are planning to announce that they have formed lobbying alliance to oppose technology regulations that are favored by motion picture industry; idea for new organization Alliance for Digital Progress was born last year when Sen Ernest F Hollings introduced bill intended to prevent consumers from exchanging unauthorized copies of movies over Internet; members of group include Microsoft, Intel, Cisco Systems and Digitalconsumer.org; will be led by Fred McClure (S)

headline: 5 Wounded In Fighting Reach Spain For Treatment
abstract: Five American soldiers wounded in Iraq are brought to US field hospital at Spanish naval base in Rota, first combat casualties to arrive for treatment in Spain; soldiers are all in stable condition, mostly suffering shrapnel or bullet wounds; photo (M)

headline: Patents; The Viagra counterpart for women is on its way, and it addresses a clinical condition new to the popular lexicon.
abstract: NexMed Inc is awarded patent for cream containing hormone prostaglandin that causes vasodilation in women's genitalia to remedy female sexual dysfunction due to lack of arousal (M)

headline: Hardening His Tone, Hussein Challenges Inspectors and Talks of War Readiness
abstract: Pres Saddam Hussein delivers belligerent speech, accusing United Nations weapons inspectors of spying against Iraq and declaring that Iraqi people are ready for any sacrifices required by another war; uses occasion of his annual Army Day address to serve notice that Iraq is primed to fight; Hussein's hostile language is reminiscent of Iraqi attitude during inspections from 1991 to 1998, when confrontations periodically led to American bombing raids on Iraq; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Central Bank's Bond Risk
abstract: Governor of Bank of Japan, Masaru Hayami, says one-percentage-point rise in long-term bond yields would shave trillion yen ($8.4 billion) off central bank's portfolio; bank has been buying 1.2 trillion yen a month in government bond markets and politicians have been calling for more purchases; photo (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: SAP Lays Off 174 In U.S.
abstract: Technol

headline: Bush's Middle East Move Gives Hard-Pressed Blair Some Badly Needed Relief
abstract: Beleaguered British Prime Min Tony Blair welcomes US Pres George Bush's announcement of plans to publish long delayed Middle East peace plan; majority of Britons oppose Blair's hard-line stance on Iraq, his dispatch of troups to Persian Gulf and his close alliance with Bush; any decision to go to war without UN Security Council authorization is expected to prompt resignations of high-ranking Labor government members; Blair, in televised statement, says show of even-handedness towards Middle East is top priority; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Lithuania: New Leader To Uphold Europe Plan
abstract: Lithuanian Pres-elect Rolandas Paksas will not advocate reopening talks on terms of European Union membership; Paksas won upset victory in runoff against Pres Valdas Adamkus, who led effort to join union (S)

headline: Off With Her Crown! Miss Brazil Hid a Vital Statistic (Marriage)
abstract: Joseane de Oliveira yields her Miss Brazil crown to Taiza Thomsen after admitting she is married; photo (S)

headline: Blair and Bush Agree That Time Is Running Out for Iraq
abstract: President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair said they think alike in how to deal with terrorism and weapons of mass destruction.

headline: Pilots Learn To Overhaul Flight Plans, And Attitudes
abstract: American pilots' changing role, from conducting surgical strikes to providing close air support for ground troops, has required retooling of plans and attitudes; change in status has left some gung-ho pilots feeling sidelined (M)

headline: New Deposit on Aluminum Cans Tests German Sense of Order
abstract: German government is about to test public's patience with refuse and red tape by imposing mandatory deposit on aluminum cans and small bottles, which are not covered by other recycling plans; starting Jan 1, shopkeepers will add 25 or 50 cents to price of nonreusable cans and bottles, depending on size; to get deposit back, customers must return empties to shop where they bought them--proving it by showing receipt or original packaging (M)

headline: Rome Journal; Italians Give Thumbs Up to Wireless Messages
abstract: Life in Rome, Italy, is being dominated by expanding cellular universe of SMA, form of elliptical text messaging; for tens of millions of Italians, fabled habit of talking with their hands has taken on new meaning in high-tech wireless times; terse text exchanges known as SMA, for short message service, have yet to catch on much in United States, but they are so pervasive in Italy that even Pope John Paul II recently signed on; subscribers have option of daily SMS texts of thoughts and prayers from him; photo (M)

headline: What if a Pension Shift Hit Lawmakers, Too?
abstract: Congressional Research Service study finds virtually every member of Congress would lose out, in some cases by hundreds of thousands of dollars, if current Congressional pensions were switch to controversial cash-balance pensions proposed for other workers; Bush administration has proposed rules on how companies could convert traditional plans to cash-balance variety; companies nationwide have been replacing traditional plans with less costly ones that in many cases yield smaller benefits or transfer all risks to workers; graphs of pension plan data; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Symantec Will Be Added To S.& P. 500
abstract: Symantec Corp will be added to Standard & Poor's 500 index after close of trading March 28; will replace Household International, which is being acquired by HSBC Holdings (S)

headline: Justices Say F.C.C. Wrongly Seized Wireless Licenses
abstract: The Supreme Court ruled today that the government wrongly seized more than 200 lucrative wireless licenses from a bankrupt telecommunications company.

headline: Lord Aberconway, 89, Met With Göring Secretly in '39
abstract: Charles Melville McLaren, former industrialist known as Lord Aberconway, dies at age 89; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zambia: Ex-President Questioned By Police
abstract: Police in Zambia question former Pres Frederick Chiluba; he has been accused of stealing government money while in office, charge he has denied (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Novellus Discloses Chief's 2002 Salary
abstract: Novellus Systems Inc

headline: With Incessant Postings, a Pundit Stirs the Pot
abstract: Glenn Reynolds, University of Tennessee law professor, posts to Weblog as frequently as 30 times per day at instapundit.com; shares his thoughts and libertarian-leaning philosophy about variety of subjects; some sample postings noted; photo (M)

headline: S.E.C. Approves New Credit Rater
abstract: Dominion Bond Rating System wins recognition from Securities and Exchange Commission as credit rating company (S)

headline: Stocks End Modestly Lower
abstract: Stocks rebounded from early declines today after President Bush and British Prime Minister Tony Blair defended the pace of the war against Iraq.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Phone Concern's Sales Rise
abstract: France Telecom's revenue increases 8.4 percent in 2002, to 46.6 billion euros ($50 billion); customer base grows 8.1 percent, to 111.7 million (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Higher Bid For Toll Company
abstract: Italy's Benetton family raises value of its bid for Autostrade SpA, Europe's biggest operator of highway tolls, after fewer than 4 perent of shareholders sell their stock in first two weeks of tender period; Benetton-controlled company Schemaventotto raises bid 5.3 percent, to 10 euros share in cash; previous offer was 9.5 euros per share; graph (S)

headline: Japan Seeks Ways to Aid Its Stocks
abstract: Japanese lawmakers from ruling Liberal Democratic Party proposes several measures meant to prop up stock market and soften its effect on country's troubled banks; proposals are new effort by lawmakers to delay or roll back policies introduced over last few years by Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi to impose harsher financial discipline on banks and on government's own budget (M)l

headline: Spain's Chief, on Bush's Side, Comes Under Attack at Home
abstract: Prime Min Jose Maria Aznar of Spain is being attacked at home for his strong support of Pres Bush's policy on Iraq; Aznar has been unable to build cross-party consensus on issue; he has accused opposition of 'opportunism'; opinion polls show around 70 percent of Spaniards oppose war with Iraq (M)

headline: New Economy; A nerdy entrepreneur dreamed of a better place. Now he's made one, using $33 million and some virtual dune buggies.
abstract: Tom Melcher and Will Harvey raise $33 million to develop There Inc's virtual reality role-playing computer game; interactive situations provide less hostile, more comfortable virtual communal gathering place for individuals seeking appreciation and stimulation of their deeper, less competitive selves; photo (M)

headline: Reliance on Promotional Allowances Can Result in Shortfalls
abstract: Payments that caused problems at US Foodservice division of Royal Ahold are among most common, and most perilous, in industry known for variety of cash transactions; payments, known as promotional allowances, are made by manufacturers of band-name products to retailers so that they will encourage their customers to buy those products; payments usually translate to discounts for customers (M)

headline: Economy Can No Longer Count On the Consumer
abstract: market watch: econo

headline: Profit Rise for Idex
abstract: Idex Corp expects to report that fourth-quarter profit almost tripled, but was less than analysts had forecast; says net income will be $11.5 million to $12.5 million, up from $4.3 million year earlier; sales and orders rose to about $190 million each (S)

headline: POWELL, IN EUROPE, NEARLY DISMISSES U.N.'S IRAQ REPORT
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L Powell comes close to dismissing crucial United Nations report on Iraq weapons on eve of report's publication; says United States will go to war against Iraq alone if its divided European allies will not join the fight; promises that Bush administration will study report's findings, but indicates that it would be useless to give weapons inspectors more time; Powell brings case for military action to deeply skeptical audience of political, business and religious leaders attending annual World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland; says Saddam Hussein has repeatedly violated trust of UN; renews administration contention that Hussein has ties to Al Qaeda and terrorists; his remarks deepen sense of inevitability among those at conference; King Abdullah of Jordan says prospects for peaceful resolution are fading; Powell's pledge to study inspectors' report and consult with other members of Security Council before acting is seen as modest concession to qualms of Europeans about what many describe as Washington's stampede toward war; Powell's speech at Davos is part of campaign by White House, culminating in Pres Bush's State of the Union address Jan 28, to rally public opinion at home and abroad; photos (L)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Samsung In Share Buyback
abstract: Samsung Electronics plans to buy $820 million worth of its own stock in effort to increase share price; decision reflects frustration of company's board as share prices have fallen 22 percent in recent months (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Speak Russian and Don't Swear
abstract: Lower house of Russian Parliament passes legislation making Russian national language and banning use of foreign words unless they do not have Russian equivalent; law also forbids use of profanity, but violation of law requires no penalty and use of obscenity, even in Parliament, is fairly common (S)

headline: Briefly Noted
abstract: PROBATION IN FAKE I.D. CASE A Superior Court judge in Paterson, N.J., excoriated a naturalized United States citizen for his "reckless and callous disregard" for the safety of others in selling fake identification cards to two of the Sept. 11 hijackers, but she let him walk free today based on a plea agreement of last month.

headline: Is Verizon Flying Too High Above Its Valuation?
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Market Watch column questions validity of current share price of Verizon Communications; cites Friedman Billings Ramsey telecommunications analyst Susan Kalla's opinion that company's business is eroding and its stock is overpriced despite compelling 4 percent dividend; graph of share price since June 2002 (M)

headline: White House Upset Over Russian Sale of Weapons to Iraq
abstract: Moscow denied that Russian companies have been selling night-vision goggles, anti-tank missiles and other hardware to Iraq.

headline: More Than a Little Bit Country
abstract: Graphs of record album sales, cookie and candy sales, hotel occupancy rates, transportation costs and other economic indicators of recent months

headline: A Practice Run at Bulldozing Through the Iraqi Border With Kuwait
abstract: Army's main ground forces are in desolate desert in northwestern Kuwait, beginning practice run for opening moments of war with Iraq that could begin within days; engineers have built exact replica of internationally patrolled border between Kuwait and Iraq, including heavily fortified system of berms, ditches and electrified fences; attacks will occur in darkness and begin with overwhelming air and artillery barrages (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Honda Debt In Review
abstract: Moody's Investors Service puts debt rating for Honda Motor Co on review for possible upgrade (S)

headline: Executive Life; A Business Travel Perk: Art on the Go
abstract: Business Committee for the Arts, founded in 1967 by David Rockefeler to generate corporate support for arts and cultural institutions nationwide, has one program that provides executives at member corporations with last-minute house tickets to sold-out concerts, plays and operas, and anytime-of-the-day passes for art exhibitions that generally issue tickets good only for specific hours; photo (M)

headline: Microsoft Moves to Strengthen Its Position in Digital Media
abstract: Microsoft said on Monday that it would license its Windows Media technology to consumer electronics makers at lower prices than its main competitors.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CURATIVE HEALTH SERVICES, Hauppauge, N.Y., said it had acquired MedCare, a specialty pharmacy, for $6.6 million.    BROWN-FORMAN CORP., Louisville, Ky., maker of Jack Daniels whiskey, is offering up to $606 million to buy back 8.3 million of its shares.

headline: In Hussein's Words: 'Victory Is Very Close and at Hand'
abstract: Excerpts from Pres Saddam Hussein's televised speech, in which he claims 'victory is very close and at hand' (M)

headline: Iraqi Dissidents Reassured in a Talk With Bush About the Post-Hussein Era
abstract: Iraqi opposition figures express satisfaction after meeting at White House in which Pres Bush tells them he favors sweeping transition to democracy in Iraq and short military occupation after Saddam Hussein is out of power; photo of Ahmad Chalabi (M)

headline: Your Taxes; That 'Marriage Penalty' Defies an Easy Solution
abstract: Ending 'marriage penalty' that affects couples with similar incomes proves elusive, although 2001 tax law reduces penalty; 'penalty' is actually 'bonus' when one spouse earns all or most of income; table (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Serbia And Montenegro: The First President
abstract: Serbia and Montenegro Parliament names Svetozar Marovic as new country's president (S)

headline: NASD Files 2 Complaints Against Star At First Boston
abstract: NASD, regulatory body for Nasdaq market, files two complaints against former Credit Suisse First Boston banker Frank P Quattrone, saying he breached host of securities regulations during stock market boom; says Quattrone improperly pressured his analysts and passed hot offerings to clients in return for banking business; also suggests that Quattrone had significant knowledge of civil and federal investigations at time he endorsed suggestion by David Brodsky, firm's chief legal counsel at time, to clean out files in December 2000; Quattrone is being investigated by US attorney's office in Manhattan, which is trying to determine whether he obstructed federal probe; New York State Atty Gen Eliot L Spitzer is also investigating his practices (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: 'No Decision' On Zimbabwe
abstract: South African officials deny that Pres Thabo Mbeki and Nigerian Pres Olusegun Obasanjo have decided to call for end to Zimbabwe's suspension from Commonwealth of Nations; photo (S)

headline: EMPLOYEE BENEFIT COMPANY TO BUY FLEETBOSTON UNIT
abstract: Employee Benefit Company To Buy Fle

headline: 2 Airline Executives Say Industry Needs More U.S. Aid
abstract: Northwest Airlines chief executive Richard H Anderson and American Airlines chief executive Donald J Carty tell Congress that they are searching their operations for cost cuts but still need government help to pay for new security measures and labor costs; Congress gave industry $5 billion immediately after terrorist attacks but two executives say industry might need additional $4 billion to help it through its financial crisis; Transportation Department says largest airlines lost about $9 billion last year; hearing is first of several examining problems of industry and whether federal government should extend additional financial aid; some lawmakers, including Sen John McCain, who is new committee chairman, are reluctant to pledge any new money; Duane Woerth, president of Air Line Pilots Association, tells committee that binding arbitration is unnecessary because there have been few strikes in industry; photo (M)

headline: Bankers and lawyers see flaws in new pact : Crackdown on tax cheats could backfire on the EU
abstract: BRUSSELS:—  An agreement by European Union countries to crack down on tax cheats will probably encourage some wealthy Europeans to park their money in tax havens in Asia and elsewhere outside the Union, tax lawyers and bankers said Wednesday.

headline: Australia Dispatches First Forces to Persian Gulf
abstract: Australia sends its first forces to Persian Gulf, including naval and military contingent followed by 150-member Special Forces unit, helicopters and fighter squadron; they will join American and British forces assembling there; Australian force has no clear orders from Prime Min John Howard, and he has no mandate from Parliament for any military action that does not have United Nations approval; photo (M)

headline: For America's Big Retailers, Small Is Beautiful, Sometimes
abstract: Many shoppers are finding big retail stores too large, too inconvenient and too tiring to get all way through; Wal-Mart Stores has been aggressively opening scaled-down versions of its Supercenter--less than one-quarter their size--called Neighborhood Markets; Home Depot has opened shrunken version of its usual model in Brooklyn; other retailers, including Toys 'R' Us and Staples, are retrofitting stores to make them smaller, cozier and more intimate, qualities big-box format was supposed to displace; chart; photos (M)

headline: Industry's Pace Slows; Consumer Spending Drops
abstract: Manufacturing expanded in February at the slowest pace in three months after consumer spending on cars and other durable goods fell the most since 1990, reports released today showed.    The Institute for Supply Management, a private industry research group, said its factory index fell to 50.5, from 53.9 in January. A reading above 50 signals expansion. A separate report from the Commerce Department showed that durable goods spending in January dropped 5.7 percent, the biggest decline since the period before the 1990-91 recession.

headline: Consumers in Europe Resist Gene-Altered Foods
abstract: Tinkering with genetic makeup of crops to make them faster-growing and more resilient, something done routinely in United States, is seen in most of Europe as heretical, or at very least unhealthy; few genetically modified foods are found on supermarket shelves across Britain and most of rest of Europe; in some countries, including France and Austria, such foods simply cannot be found at all; public sentiment in much of Europe, stoked by environmental groups, is now so fiercely opposed to genetically altered food that politicians in some countries are winning elections by vowing to keep 'Frankenfood' at bay; decision by European Parliament on stricter labeling of genetically modified foods could be made by this summer, and European officials hope that may make such foods more acceptable, by clarifying exactly how it is made; American companies like Monsanto stand to make enormous profits if Europe allows importing of more genetically modified foods; photos (M)

headline: Britain Calls Its Conference on Palestinian Reform a Success
abstract: Foreign Sec Jack Straw pronounces British-sponsored meeting on Palestinian reform a success despite absence of invitees whom Israel refused to allow to go to London; video link was set up; Straw notes reform proposals (M)

headline: Indonesian Educators Ponder Lessons After U.S. Visit
abstract: Twenty-five educators from traditional Islamic schools in Indonesia spend month in United States as part of program sponsored by State Dept to help Muslims overseas learn about United States; goal is to show skeptical Indonesian Muslims that America is land of tolerance and diversity; Indonesians visited schools and universities, learned about democracy and met with State Dept's senior officials; they also visited Statue of Liberty and Empire State Building and went shopping; one of participants says he found Americans to be friendly, but he is distrustful of policies of American government; in Feb, television studio audience in Jakarta will talk with audience in US, and results will be shown later in both countries; photo; map (M)

headline: Commanders Worry More About Their Troops' E-Mail Than Their Loose Lips
abstract: Concerned that sensitive information might leak out, some units of the United States military are starting to clamp down on e-mail communication from their soldiers and sailors, who have been using it from ships, bases and even desert outposts to stay in touch with family and friends.     The uncertainty underscores the double-edged nature of a technology that is providing a new opportunity for instantaneous interaction from remote locations, a development the Pentagon believes is helping to improve morale in the field and among relatives back home.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Sierra Leone: U.N. Court Indicts 7
abstract: Sierra Leone's United Nations tribunal charges seven men with crimes against humanity during civil war; accused include rebel military leader Foday Sankoh and government Internal Affairs Minister Sam Hinga Norman; both are in custody as are three others; warlord Johnny Paul Koroma and rebel field commander Sam Bockarie are yet to be arrested (S)

headline: London Journal; We Know What He Did for Love, And Now, Word of What She Did
abstract: Secret British files just opened reveal that romance between King Edward VIII and twice-divorced American mistress Wallace Warfield Simpson was closely monitored by detectives from police Special Branch, who reported that she was two-timing Edward with another man; British historian Susan Williams says new files offer wealth of detail that will fill many gaps in knowledge; they may also deepen view among some Britons that marital misbehavior is embedded in monarchal genes; story of Duke and Duchess of Windsor has some similarities to events years later involving Prince Charles, current heir to throne, his longtime love Camilla Parker Bowles and his wife Diana, Princess of Wales who died in 1997 after they were divorced; man identified by Special Branch as having affair with Simpson was Guy Marcus Trundle, said to be 'charming adventurer' who received money and gifts from her; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Advertiser's Profit Falls
abstract: British advertising company WPP Group reports declines in revenue and profit for 2002 and remains cautious on outlook for advertising sector in 2003; says net income fell to 25.5 million pounds ($40.4 million) from 219.6 million pounds year earlier; chief executive Sir Martin Sorrell comments; graph (S)

headline: Interpublic is making some headway with its financial problems as a deadline approaches.
abstract: Interpublic Group of Companies seems to be making some progress in addressing its financial problems as deadline nears for renegotiating loan agreements with banks; agency company has received bids in sale of large division and is cutting costs through merger of two of its agencies (M)

headline: U.S. backs deal to salvage NATO aid for Turkey
abstract: BRUSSELS:—  Vowing to break a deadlock over Turkey that has split NATO allies into bitterly opposed factions, the United States on Wednesday put its support behind a scaled-back plan by the alliance for preparations in the event of war with Iraq.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Arrests In Downing Of Helicopter
abstract: Russian authorities detain four suspects in downing of military transport helicopter in Chechnya in Aug 2002 that killed 121 people; suggest type of portable surface-to-air missile used in attack had been supplied to military units in southern Russia, raising possibility that Russian soldiers sold it to Chechen rebels (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Auto Exports Gain
abstract: Exports of Japanese vú

headline: Toyota Says Profits Nearly Doubled in Last Quarter of 2002
abstract: Toyota said profits nearly doubled in the last quarter of 2002 as Japan's largest automaker continues to solidify its share of the global car market.

headline: Day of Decision Ahead on Mutual Fund Proxies
abstract: DIARY Day of Decision Ahead On Mutual Fund Proxies  For one closely watched Securities and Exchange Commission proposal, Wednesday is show time. That is when the commission plans to vote on a rule requiring mutual funds to disclose their proxy voting records.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Car Sales Rise
abstract: South Korea's five motor vehicle manufacturers--Hyundai and Kia, in Hyundai Automotive Group, GM Daewoo, Renault Samsung and Ssangyong report total sales of 298,000 vehicles in January, increase of 7 percent from year earlier (S)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: By Ballot Not Blood; BELGIUM: Move To Amend War Crimes Law; FRANCE: Rise In Anti-Semitism; ROMANIA: New Rules For Adoptions; RUSSIA: Putin Supports Chechen Aid;.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Phone Stake Sold
abstract: French construction and communications group Bouygues will buy E.ON's 16 percent ownership of Bouygues Telecom for about 1.1 billion euros ($1.17 billion) (S)

headline: Tax Shelter Is Worrying Sprint's Chief
abstract: Sprint Corp chief executive William T Esrey says he could lose his entire fortune if Internal Revenue Service decides that tax shelter that he and president Ronald T LeMay bought from company's auditor Ernst & Young was improper; shelter was sold to executives at hundreds of companies by Ernst & Young; executives were told that shelter would let them delay paying taxes on exercising of options for 30 years, instead of having to pay them year options were excercised; two Sprint executives could face combined tax bill of as much as $123 million without shelters; such shelters are lucrative for Ernst & Young, which can make millions in fees on shelters sold, as well as for law firms; shelter, called ECS, for Equity Compensation Strategy, was described in June 2002 in New York Times; chart; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Insurance Merger Is Abandoned
abstract: Asahi Mutual Life Insurance, one of Japan's weakest life insurers, will abandon its plan to join Millea Holdings (S)

headline: Ford Motor's Future in Brazil Is Now on the Line
abstract: Ford Motor Co's future in Brazil rests with production of EcoSport sport utility vehicle in Camacari; Ford South America president Richard Canny says EcoSport is sport utility vehicle that has been specifically developed for South America and is unique in market; adds Ford hopes vehicle, which will be introduced Feb 21, will create whole new market segment; photo (M)

headline: Bank Deals May Be Ahead At Citigroup
abstract: Citigroup is expected to acquire banks to maintain profitability of its Citibank consumer banking business as competitors move aggressively into its home turf in New York with attractive promotions; will seek to enhance its position in Hispanic banking in US, including Texas, where bank does not have any branches; hopes to compete on breadth of its product offerings rather than by offering free checking accounts or higher interest on certificates of deposit, as competitors are doing; analysts worry that consumer banking business will not be able to maintain recent level of profitability once stock market recovers and consumers again seek higher returns on their investments; photo (M)

headline: Constant Iraqi Attacks Are Holding Up the Allied Forces Trying to Reach Baghdad
abstract: Marine and other allied units pressing toward Baghdad encounter nearly constant harassment and ambush by small bands of irregular Iraqi fighters and remnants of army units they bypassed; officers fear resistance will only stiffen as they get close to capital; attacks appear to call into question American strategy of sweeping past Iraqi Army positions and towns in order to reach Baghdad swiftly; photo (M)

headline: Venezuelan Who Led Strike Is Given Asylum by Costa Rica
abstract: A labor leader who feared for his life at the hands of groups loyal to President Hugo Chávez was granted political asylum by Costa Rica.

headline: U.N. Official Says Iraqis Still Build Barred Missile
abstract: United Nations spokesman Yasuhiro Ueki, in Baghdad, says Iraq continues to build its Al Samoud 2 missiles even while facing UN order demanding start of their destruction by end of week; says weapons inspectors traced all known missiles and their components, but that Iraq's continued production obscures total number of existing missiles (M)

headline: Contract for Oil Fires Set
abstract: Halliburton Co's engineering and construction unit wins contract from Army Corps of Engineers to extinguish Iraqi oil well fires and repair damaged wells (S)

headline: TEAMS OF EXPERTS TO HUNT IRAQ ARMS
abstract: Bush administration deploys mobile labs and new specialized teams of intelligence officials and disarmament experts to Kuwait to help military search for weapons of mass destruction in Iraq as soon as war begins; defense officials also reach out to former international weapons inspectors as part of ambitious top-secret effort to rapidly find, secure and ultimately destroy caches of chemical, biological and other conventional weapons administration asserts are being hidden by Pres Saddam Hussein (M)

headline: Ad Revenue Up For Broadcast TV
abstract: Advertising: Ad Revenue Up For Broadcast TV*

headline: AES SELLS POWER PLANTS FOR $327 MILLION
abstract: Electricity producer AES sells its share of power plants in Bangladesh, Oman, Qatar, Pakistan and California for $327 million in cash; CDC Group will buy two generators in Bangladesh for $127 million and assume $310 million in debt; Bahrain-based partnership agrees to buy AES's stake in some Middle East plants for $150 million, and joint venture of Royal Dutch/Shell Group and Bechtel Group pay $50 million for two California power plants (S)

headline: As Palestinian Violence Subsides, Israel Must Stop Building Settlements, Powell Says
abstract: Sec of State Colin Powell, speaking to American Israel Public Affairs Committee, says Israel must stop building settlements in West Bank and Gaza as Palestinian violence subsides; signals support for peace plan drafted by US, Russia, United Nations and European Union; expresses confidence in progress of war in Iraq and warns Syria that it should abandon its support of terrorism and regime of Saddam Hussein; photo (M)

headline: Online in Ecuador? It's Taking Awhile
abstract: Only 2.7 percent of Ecuadorians have been online; experts are concerned that rapid pace in technology industry will cause third-world nations like Ecuador to slip further behind Europe and North America; government is trying to create hospitable environment for online businesses although many see it as potential hotbed for bribery and instances of exorbitant fees have already been reported; United Nations will begin program in one of country's poorest provinces to give Internet access to small business owners to help expand markets; photo (M)

headline: Philippines Denies It Is Boycotting UBS
abstract: Philippine Finance Sec Jose Camacho denies his government has banned UBS Warburg from participating in government bond underwriting; reports in Philippine newspapers and Asian business press over last week said that government boycotted UBS after it published analyst's report in January that included questions about accuracy of country's current-account figures (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: JAPAN: Auto Exports Gain; SINGAPORE: Economy Expands;.

headline: Anti-Israel Remark Draws More Protest
abstract: Gretta Duisenberg, wife of European Central Bank president Wim Duisenberg and head of pro-Palestinian Dutch group, stirs more controversy and charges of anti-Semitism by comparing Israeli policies to Nazi occupation of Netherlands (S)

headline: MAKER OF FLIGHT DISPLAYS WANTS REFUND FROM RAYTHEON
abstract: L-3 Communications Holdings wants $100 million refund on its $1.2 billion purchase of Raytheon Co's Aircraft Integration Systems to cover cost overruns at business (S)

headline: Chicago Exchange Starts Campaign
abstract: Chicago Mercantile Exchange begins brand image advertising, one month after its initial public offering; campaing was developed by Draft Worldwide (S)

headline: Singapore Warns of Threat From Radical Islamic Groups
abstract: Radical Islamic groups in Southeast Asia are capable of further terrorist acts, the Singaporean government said today.

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: ITALY: Tire Maker'S Profit Soars; BELGIUM: Unrest Roils Steel Maker;.

headline: For Far Smaller Fuel Cells, a Far Shorter Wait
abstract: Prototypes of long-lasting fuel cells that can replace batteries are being tested in laboratories in US and overseas; every big electronics company in world is working on fuel cells; some, like Intel, are going step further and investing millions of dollars in start-up companies like PolyFuel and Neah Power Systems to accelerate development; many analysts expect fuel cells for some consumer electronic devices to begin appearing next year in Japan; betting is that first to reach market will be Toshiba, which is demonstrating prototype of methanol-powered cell this week at trade show in Hanover, Ger; Toshiba says cell could be sold next year with laptops; chart; photo (M)

headline: Moscow Journal; For Flashier Russians, Euro Outshines the Dollar
abstract: Most expensive items in stores of Russia are not denominated in rubles, Russia's official money, but in 'UE' which is euphemism for wholly mythical money which corresponds exactly with exchange rate of United States dollar; after decade in dollar-driven economy, many merchants who price their goods in conditional units are switching from dollar to euro, especially since euro surpassed dollar in world currency markets for first time last month; photos (M)

headline: F.D.A. Approves Biotechnology Drug for Psoriasis
abstract: FDA approves Biogen's Amevive, first drug from biotechnology industry to treat psoriasis; approval is expected to usher in new era in treating psoriasis, a sometimes debilitating skin ailment, and fuel new growth spurt for 25-year-old company; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Volkswagen's Profit Falls
abstract: Volkswagen AG says net profit for 2002 fell 11 percent, to 2.58 billion euros ($2.76 billion), because of declining sales in Europe and US; pretax profit was 3.99 billion euros, 9.6 percent less than year earlier; revenue and production were slightly lower but in line with market expectations (S)

headline: Supreme Court Rules F.C.C. Took Licenses Away in Error
abstract: Supreme Court, 8-1, rules Federal Communications Commission had no right to cancel valuable wireless communications licenses that bankrupt NextWave Telecom had won at auction and then could not pay for; court says while companies are reorganizing under bankruptcy protection, federal bankruptcy law protects them from dismemberment by regulatory agencies, just as law protects bankrupt companies from ordinary creditors; while ruling returns licenses to NextWave, company is still trying to emerge from bankruptcy, and industry analysts say value of such licenses has been falling since FCC tried to reauction them in early 2001 (M)

headline: Indonesia Opposes Use of Military Power to Topple Iraqi Leader
abstract: Indonesian Foreign Min Hassan Wirajuda says his country opposes military action to topple Saddam Hussein of Iraq; says it supports United Naitons Security Council's efforts to disarm weapons of mass destruction; Western diplomats say they did not expect Indonesia to support intervention against Iraq but they do hope to persuade government to keep its statements on Iraq as moderate as possible (M)

headline: New Economy; The carrot that got customers to make transactions online is now making way for the stick.
abstract: Companies that have offered various inducements to encourage customers to handle routine transactions online rather than through service representative are increasingly adding a stick to the carrot, setting higher charges for 'agent assisted' transactions; trend is well on its way among airlines, technology companies that offer tech support and financial services companies; drawing (M)

headline: For Patients, Unpleasant Surprises in Arbitration
abstract: Michelle Andrews column notes more and more health care providers are pushing for binding arbitration as way to settle any medical malpractice claims; arbitration generally gives patients little choice in way claims are handled; drawing (M)y

headline: Russian Court Frees Reporter In Case About Nuclear Waste
abstract: Grigory Pasko, crusading Russian journalist who documented Russian Navy's mishandling of nuclear waste, is released on parole after serving two-thirds of his four-year prison sentence; his case has drawn protests from international human rights groups, who liken his arrest and conviction to Soviet-era repression; it was widely criticized within Russia as blunder by Russia's military and embarrassment for Kremlin; Pres Vladimir V Putin offered to grant Pasko amnesty, but Pasko refused, saying it would be admission of guilt (M)

headline: Seeking Market Clarity
abstract: Battle among top Web search site intensifies with Yahoo's plan to acquire Inktomi for $235 million; graph shows traffic at top four search sites: MSN Search, Google, Yahoo Search and AOL Properties Search (S)

headline: A Little Help From Friends of Friends
abstract: Home Front column suggests using all available resources for job hunting; says distant connections may produce as good results as close ties in extremely tight labor market; photo (M)

headline: Powell, in Asia, Is Dealt A Setback on North Korea
abstract: China, Australia and South Korea reject Sec of State Colin L Powell's appeal to support 'multilateral forum' at which they, US and other countries could pressure North Korea to dismantle its nuclear weapons program; say US should instead begin direct talks with North Korea, strategy Bush Administration repeatedly has rejected; Roh Moo Hyun is inaugurated as president of South Korea; photo of Powell in Beijing with Pres Jiang Zemin of China (M)

headline: Rich Armenia vs. Poor Armenia in Presidential Election
abstract: Armenians to vote in presidential election that is viewed as battle between two countries, rich and poor, that have emerged since country gained independence; Armenia has highest economic growth rate of any former Soviet republic, but more than fifty percent of population lives below poverty line; eight candidates are challenging Pres Robert Kocharian; photo; map; more than 200 observers from 25 countries monitor vote (M)

headline: Swiss Chemical Maker Dismisses Its Chief
abstract: Swiss Chemical Maker

headline: Chimay Journal; Monks' Brew Showers Blessings on Belgian Town
