abstract: Chimay Journal on Belgian town where Trappist monastery ferments more than 13,000 gallons of Chimay beer a day; photos; map; sharp rise in popularity of dark heavy brew spreads blessings on hilly farmland around town near French border, because abbey's foundations invest profits in charitable works and development of local business (M)

headline: The Joys of Music-Sharing
abstract: Ann Pfund letter on Jan 30 article on shared CD mixes, contends recording industry should recognize that file sharing tends to cultivate new customers for CD's

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Business Confidence Improves
abstract: Germany's Ifo Institute's survey of executives says business confidence rose to seven-month high of 88.9 from 87.4 in January (S)

headline: The Web Diarist as Pitchman
abstract: Marketing companies are targeting Weblogs as prime territory to instal links to promote products or services; companies reward bloggers for plugging products, but some are having second thoughts about new role as pitchmen; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Jobless Rate Rises
abstract: Brazil's jobless rate rose to 11.6 percent in Feb (S)

headline: U.S. REPORTS TALKS URGING SURRENDER
abstract: Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld says allied officials have held secret talks with members of Iraq's elite Republican Guard and Special Republican Guard about defecting or surrendering; says Saddam Hussein's 'days are numbered'; says there are signs that threat of all-out American attack is prompting many Iraqi military units and their commanders to consider cease-fire or giving up; United States intelligence officials say man on videotape that was released after American missile assault on what is believed to be Hussein's bunker was probably Hussein, although no final analytical conclusion has been reached; Rumsfeld stresses that US is reaching out to Iraqi leaders and military officers with 'every conceivable mode and method'; his comments seen as latest example of aggressive psychological campaign aimed at putting pressure on Iraqi officers to give up; photo (M)

headline: Kirkkonummi Journal; Finnish Hockey's Odd Man Out (She's Canadian)
abstract: Hayley Wickenheiser, skating prodigy from Canada, is first woman to play professional men's hockey in Finland, not as goalie but as center; she is routinely hurled into boards and body checked by men far larger; she has turned obscure Finnish team from Kirkkonummi into household name; after some initial skepticism, her teammates--won over by her skill on ice--adore her; photos; map (M)

headline: Rwandan Pastor and His Son Are Convicted of Genocide
abstract: Rev Elizaphan Ntakirutimana and son Dr Gerard Ntakirutimana are convicted of genocide and sentenced to prison by United Nations tribunal dealing with Rwandan killing frenzy of 1994, in which members of Hutu gangs killed about 800,000 minority Tutsi and moderate Hutu over three months; elder Ntakirutimana, former head of Seventh-day Adventist Church in western Rwanda, becomes first clergyman to be convicted of genocide by international tribunal; is sentenced to 10 years in prison for aiding and abetting genocide; his son, who worked at church's hospital, receives total sentence of 25 years for same charges and for shooting two people to death; their lengthy trial draws new attention to role of Christian churches during massacre; three Roman Catholic priests are being held on similar charges and Anglican bishop died while in detention; many Rwandan clergymen and church workers took sides during ethnic violence, encouraging or actively collaborating with killers; 300 clergymen and nuns were themselves slain because they were Tutsi or were helping Tutsi; Ramsey Clark, former United States attorney general who is defense counsel for elder Ntakirutimana, says both men will appeal (M)

headline: Consumer Borrowing Report Shows Steep November Drop
abstract: Federal Reserve reports consumer borrowing in November had biggest decline in 11 years, indication that Americans are becoming more wary of taking on debt; says borrowing through credit cards and other types of loans decreased at annual rate of 1.5 percent, or $2.2 billion, first drop since January 1998 and biggest since October 1991; follows increase of $1.5 billion in October; borrowing by consumers totaled $1.7 trillion in November; credit card and other revolving debt fell at $1.6 billion annual pace after $2.4 billion increase in October; graph (M)

headline: Carmakers Design For Generation Y
abstract: Automakers, led by Honda Motors and Toyota Motors, are designing for Generation Y, under-25 group that marketers associate with extreme sports, blaring techno music and zealous individuality; Toyota's Scion is new nameplate that will eventually house collection of vehicles aimed at trendiest Generation Y drivers; Honda is selling Element model at base price just under $17,000; Mitsubishi, which lacked much identity in 1990's, has built youngest customer base of any auto company, not with new vehicle but with sharp marketing; Hyundai's sales have quadrupled over last four years because of affordable prices and 10-year, 100,000-mile warranty; age of average Hyundai buyers has fallen to 35.8; most sought after car among Generation Y buyers is Honda Civic, which sells for under $20,000; chart; photos (M)

headline: Web's Tin Cups Find Soft Touches Aplenty
abstract: E-panhandlers or cyber-beggars have Web sites detailing their hard times and asking visitors for money; some donors are persuaded by stories that are similar to their own circumstances, while others are swayed by allure of helping someone in need so directly; it is hard to know if people seeking charity are fakes, but many are willing to go to great lengths to prove their sincerity; photos (M)

headline: Destination Baghdad: Pushing North
abstract: Maps of Iraq tracing advance of allied forces as they move closer to Baghdad (M)

headline: Regulatory Malpractice
abstract: Jerry Frankel letter urges more thorough regulation of medical devices (Jan 19 article)

headline: Divide Among Jews Leads to Silence on Iraq War
abstract: US Jewish leaders, while supportive of Pres Bush, are unusually silent on issue of going to war against Iraq; cite fear of backlash if war goes badly and inability among Jews to agree on whether or not to support war; recent polls and interviews show that Jewish leaders regard Saddam Hussein as imminent danger, want him removed and recognize danger that terrorism poses worldwide but are skeptical that US can create stable post-war government in Iraq; photos (M)

headline: ON THE GROUND: In Tokyo; Clean Streets and Subways That Run on a Schedule
abstract: Travel article on Tokyo; city's highlights noted; photo (M)

headline: 4 G.I.'s DIE IN CRASH
abstract: Four Americans die when when United States Army Black Hawk helicopter crashes about six miles east of Bagram air base in Afghanistan (S)

headline: Grey Direct Wins An Account at UAL
abstract: Gray Direct wins direct marketing and Mileage Plus customer loyalty communications account of United Airlines and UAL Loyalty Services (S)

headline: Distrust Reopens the Door for Polio in India
abstract: Polio virus--almost vanquished worldwide thanks to cheap and widely available vaccine--makes defiant comeback in India, borne along by rumor and fear; India had 1,509 newly diagnosed cases last year; vast majority are in Uttar Pradesh, country's most populous state, and one of its poorest; government officials and community leaders attribute this to widely believed rumor that oral vaccine is part of government population control scheme; mothers are refusing doses for their children, even when vaccinators come to their homes, fearing it will make their children sterile; polio outbreak has exposed religious health divide; majority of polio cases last year in Uttar Pradesh were among Muslims, although rumor was repeated in Hindu communities too; health officials note that Muslims in Uttar Pradesh tend to be landless laborers with lower literacy rates and greater mistrust of Hindu-dominated government; resurgence of polio in India alarms international health experts, who had aimed for global eradication by 2002; polio is now found in seven countries and has increased only in two: Nigeria and India; photos; map; chart (L)

headline: Boycott of PepsiCo Is Called Off
abstract: Threatened boycott of PepsiCo is called off after Pepsi agrees to donate millions of dollars to nonprofit groups benefiting young people; organization Hip Hop Summit Action Network, led by rap impresario Russell Simmons, called for boycott because it claimed Pepsi was guilty of hypocrisy for running commercial featuring Ozzy Osbourne after ending endorsement deal with rapper Ludacris because of complaints about obscene song lyrics (S)

headline: Israeli Troops Kill 5 Palestinians in Raid on West Bank Camp
abstract: Israeli forces reportedly kill five Palestinian militants in raid on refugee camp in Jenin, bringing to 10 number of Palestinians killed in northern West Bank in less than 24 hours; some Israeli politicians and analysts criticize army as being too quick to shoot; army investigation continues into accidental killings of two armed Israeli security guards in southern West Bank; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Korean Air Earnings
abstract: Korean Air earned 111.9 billion won ($101 million) last year, reversing loss of 590 billion won in 2001, as sales rose 10 percent, to 6.25 trillion won (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Oil Found
abstract: Brazil's state oil company Petroleo Brasileiro, or Petrobras, makes its biggest offshore discovery since 1996, new 1.9 billion barrel field off coast of northeastern state of Sergipe (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar climbs against euro and yen; dollar settles at 118.57 yen, up from 117.32 yen, and euro trades at $1.0813, down from $1.0998 in New York trading; graph; chart (S)2

headline: Fiat to Sell Insurance Unit to Publishing Group for $2.5 Billion
abstract: Fiat agrees to sell its insurance unit, Toro Assicurazioni, to De Agostini publishing group of Italy for $2.5 billion; Fiat has been seeking ways to cut debt and return its embattled automobile division to profitability (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Deals: Broadwing To Sell Unit For $129 Million
abstract: Broadwing Inc agrees to sell its long-distance unit Broadwing Communication Services to C III Communications, owned by Corvis Corp and Cequel III, for $129 million (S)

headline: Amended Lawsuit Accuses Some Stewart Executives
abstract: Amended class-action lawsuit contends senior executives at Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia knew Martha Stewart was under investigation for her sale of shares in ImClone Systems before inquiry was disclosed to public and discussed how that might affect stock price of their company; amended suit contends investigation into Stewart, which became public on June 6, was known at Stewart's company by March 2002; suit says former Martha Stewart employee attended meeting in Sharon Patrick's office in March when investigation was being discussed, including its adverse impact on Martha Stewart shares; also lists several executives, including Patrick and general counsel Gregory R Blatt, who sold total of $5.5 million worth of shares in company in March and May, contending that they should have disclosed what they knew about probe or refrain from selling stock; Salvatore Graziano, partner at Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach, which originally brought suit in August on behalf of group of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia shareholders, comments (M)

headline: IRISH DRUG MAKER TO SELL UNIT TO KING PHARMACEUTICALS
abstract: Irish drug maker Elan sells its primary care division for $850 million to King Pharmaceuticals (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Cuba: Crackdown On Dissidents Continues
abstract: Cuban economist and former political prisoner Marta Beatriz is arrested in tenth day of human rights fast; she and five others, also apprehended, are protesting for release of dissidents, including pacifist reformer Dr Oscar Elias Biscet; four-day-old crackdown has netted over 60 human rights activists and leaders; rights group head Elizardo Sanchez believes sweep of arrests is purposely timed to coincide with invasion of Iraq in hopes crackdown will go unnoticed in world community (S

headline: PepsiCo's Quarterly Profit Increases 21%
abstract: PepsiCo posts 21 percent increase in its fourth-quarter earnings; net income was $805 million, up from $667 million year earlier; revenue rose 7 percent, to $7.5 billion; Al Bru, president and chief executive of Pepsico's Frito-Lay division, is promoted to chairman; John Compton is named president of new division of Frito-Lay called Salty; Rogelio Rebolledo, president-chief executive of Frito-Lay International, will retire next year (M)

headline: Wall St. Security Plans Need Work, Study Says
abstract: DIARY Wall St. Security Plans Need Work, Study Says.

headline: Chaos, or Democracy, in Iraq Could Be Unsettling to Saudis
abstract: Possible chaos from breakdown of existing order in Iraq has become overarching fear among ruling members of Saudi royal family, who realize success in ousting Pres Saddam Hussein could send uncertain winds of change sweeping through region; has motivated day-to-day ruler Crown Prince Abdullah to press efforts to motivate Pres Bush to acquiesce in 11th-hour strategy in which decision to attack Iraq would be followed by pause for intensive diplomacy, even coup-making, to remove Pres Saddam Hussein; Saudi Arabia's failed efforts of past 40 years to unite disparate tribes of peninsula and create sense of nationhood discussed; country has existed in state of arrested political development, under monarchy anchored in deeply conservative Islamic ideology that represses women's rights and excoriates foreign 'infidels;' suffers from extensive corruption, arising from enormous oil wealth (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen falls against US dollar after Japanese official says goverment might consider 'massive' sales to help stem currency's rise; dollar settles at 120.33 yen, up from 119.89 in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: Key to Baghdad: How Hard Will Republican Guard Fight?
abstract: Central question facing American commanders as their troops close in on Baghdad is how fiercely Iraq's Republican Guard will fight; 100,000 soldiers in six Republican Guard divisions are considered Iraq's most loyal and capable force, better trained and better equipped than rest of Saddam Hussein's 350,000-man army; three divisions are guarding approaches to Baghdad; Medina Division, perhaps toughest unit of all, is dug in with Soviet-made tanks to south of Baghdad; it is focus of new American air assault; chart with drawings and descriptions of Republican Guard's armor and weapons (M)

headline: Outbreak Prompts Travel Warning in Asia
abstract: Hundreds of people in Vietnam, Hong Kong and China have been stricken by a mysterious respiratory illness, worried officials of the World Health Organization said today.

headline: Mutual Funds Report; Been Down So Long, You Call This Up?
abstract: Sharpness of stock market decline in first three quarters of 2002 caused third consecutive year of losses despite strong fourth-quarter performances by stock mutual funds; average domestic equity fund lost more than 20 percent of its value in 2002; drawing (M)

headline: Software; Said Simple Simon To the Spyman
abstract: Spyware, or adware, is software that tracks Web surfing habits and uses Internet connection to report results back to data-collection server; most common way for computer to become infected with adware is downloading shareware program, where offending program may piggyback on main program and install on system like parasite; program called Spy Sweeper by Webroot can unmask, disable and remove adware; photo (M)

headline: ARAMARK SELLS CENTERS TO KNOWLEDGE LEARNING CORP.
abstract: Aramark Corp sells its Educational Resources unit to Knowledge Learning Corp for $225 million in cash and $40 million in subordinated note (S)

headline: French Move Toward Curbs on Smoking by Minors
abstract: French Senate approves bill to ban cigarette sales to children under 16, bans cigarette giveaways to minors and require high schools to educate students on hazards of smoking (S)

headline: Not Enough Supplies or Money, Relief Groups Say
abstract: Relief organizations, anticipating US war with Iraq, say they have neither sufficent supplies nor enough money to cope with millions of injured, displaced and starving people that could result; say if fighting is prolonged, particularly in and around cities, at least half of Iraqi civilian population of 25 million people might be left struggling for food and water; Pres Bush has promised to make relief assistance priority of any campaign in Iraq; photo (M)

headline: Merrill Lynch Cut Pay for O'Neal in 2002
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co cuts pay of its chief executive, E Stanley O'Neal, by third in 2002, to $14.3 million; compensation for chairman, David H Komansky, falls 11 percent, to $14.4 million; pay for other top officers noted (S)

headline: Chirac Keeps Iraq Stance at Meeting With Blair
abstract: France resisted appeals to soften its opposition to war with Iraq after a one-day summit meeting here today between Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain and the French president, Jacques Chirac.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.25   4.25   4.75       Discount rate   0.75   0.75   1.50       Federal funds   1.31   1.24   1.69       3-month T-bills   1.17   1.17   1.56       6-month T-bills   1.21   1.22   1.60       10-yr. T-infl.   2.27   2.30   3.37       10-yr. T-note   4.06   4.08   4.83       30-yr. T-bond   4.97   5.00   5.34       Telephone bd.   6.13   6.15   7.42       Municipal bds.   5.13   5.14   5.27          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Shares of Food Companies Fall on Scandal Fears
abstract: Shares of food makers fall after Royal Ahold, Dutch supermarket company, says it overstated earnings at its US Foodservice unit, prematurely booking profits from vendor promotions and trade allowances; investors fear food companies may have been willing participants in huge cover-up (M)

headline: Central Pause, Northern Action
abstract: Map shows US and Kurdish fighter movements, location of airstrikes and other aspects of war in Iraq

headline: Consolidation and Skirmishes
abstract: Maps of military action throughout Iraq and around Nasiriya; diagram of A-10 Thunderbolt, nicknamed 'Warthog,' first Air Force aircraft intended for close air support

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: TURKEY: Victory For Ruling Party'S Leader; CZECH REPUBLIC: Nigerian Diplomat Shot And Killed In Embassy; IRELAND: Huge Shipment Of Khat Is Seized At Airport; RUSSIA: Soldier Kills 4 Comrades, Then Himself;.

headline: Rising War Fears Bring Economic Turmoil to Kurdish-Ruled Zone
abstract: Worry over possibility of war unsettles tenuous economy in Kurdish-ruled northern Iraq, destabilizing local currency, 'old' dinar, and creating confusion in markets for food and gasoline; area is outside Saddam Hussein's rule; rise of old dinar against dollar in last two weeks is seen as remarkable and mysterious and undermines local purchasing power; current economic confusion would likely turn into chaos if war breaks out; photos; map (M)

headline: Tension Tourism on Korean Border
abstract: South Korean companies that specialize in tours of demilitarized zone between North and South Korea, handling about 150,000 mostly foreign tourists each year, are reaching out to young Koreans in face of rising anti-Americanism in South along with complacency about North's military threat; map; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Jobless Rate Rises to 5.8% As 308,000 Jobs Are Lost  The Labor Department reported that the unemployment rate rose to 5.8 percent in February, from 5.7 percent in January, and that 308,000 jobs disappeared from the nation's payrolls, the worst job loss since the two months after Sept. 11, 2001. Bad weather and war fears combined to prolong the economy's malaise.     The job figures were almost uniformly negative. Payrolls shrank in virtually every goods-producing industry and edged down or remained flat across the service sector. Only government payrolls managed a broad-based increase. [Page A1.]

headline: Can't Get a Tee Time? Try the Corner Bar
abstract: Golden Tee Fore! is realistic, 3-D simulated golf game and most successful coin-operated arcade-style game since Pac-Man based on revenue from player use; it has become fixture in sports bars and pool halls with roughly 100,000 machines installed; game described; photos (M)

headline: A Japanese Theme Park Company Fails
abstract: The Huis Ten Bosch Company, one of Japan's largest theme park operators, has declared bankruptcy, highlighting the mounting troubles in the country's vast government-financed recreation industry.    The collapse of the company, with debt of 220 billion yen ($1.8 billion), is the latest evidence of the breakdown between local governments and Japan's commercial banks, which together helped build many parks in the 1980's and 1990's.

headline: Internet Site, Fearing Suit Over Content, Curbs Activity
abstract: Web site foodservicerumors.com, started five years ago by Steve Hoschler, partly shuts down after being threatened with legal action by US Foodservice, US subsidiary of Dutch supermarket retailer Royal Ahold, which is under investigation by federal authorities for accounting irregularities; Hoschler received letter by fax from US Foodservice's lawyer Robert S Brennen, who asked that defamatory and confidential postings be removed; Foodservice's objections center on postings that it considers defamatory and that also disclose confidential information; Hoschler says Foodservice did not make clear which e-mail messages it wanted removed, so he had no choice but to close main news page (M)

headline: Recognizing the Dance on the Dotted Line
abstract: Biometric handwriting recognition may eventually free shoppers from carrying credit or debit cards with signature, system that would render stolen cards useless and reduce fraud; in biometric systems, appearance of signature is of little significance; rather act of signing is key; such systems exist but are expensive, although some companies are exploring ways to widen use; drawing (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Possible Amnesty For Rebels
abstract: Sergei Yastrzhembsky, aid to Russian President Vladimir V Putin, restates willingness of government to extend amnesty to Chechen rebels if they end conflict; statement, however, is simultaneous with levying formal charges against rebel leader Shamil Basayev for December bomb attack in Grozny that killed 70 people (S)

headline: Adviser to U.S. Aided Maker Of Satellites
abstract: Bush administration says Richard N Perle, while leading influentional Pentagon advisory board, advised Loral Space and Communications as it faced government charges that it improperly transferred rocket technology to China; State Department says Perle contacted Asst Sec Lincoln P Bloomfield Jr once or twice in 2001 while Bloomfield was considering how to resolve issue; Sec Colin L Powell calls contacts appropriate, interview; Perle says he was retained by Loral seven months before he was named to head Defense Policy Board and given one-time retainer then; denies urging any government official to settle case; photo (M)

headline: Nuclear Inspection Chief Reports Finding No New Weapons
abstract: Transcript of remarks by Dr Mohamed ElBaradei, director general of International Atomic Energy Agency, before United Nations Security Council; photo (L)

headline: 4 at Merrill Accused Of an Enron Fraud
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission accuses Merrill Lynch executives Thomas W Davis, Daniel H Bayly, Schuyler M Tilney and Robert S Furst of helping Enron Corp fraudulently inflate its annual profits in 1999 through two bogus transactions; all men except Bayly invoked their Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination when asked to testify before SEC; Davis and Tilney were dismissed from firm; Furst resigned in 2001, before commission sought his testimony; Bayly initially testified before commission later declined to provide additional testimony; SEC contends Enron is able to increase its reported earnings by engaging in what amounted to fictitious sales of assets to Merrill, then booking proceeds of those transactions; transactions--one involving sale of electricity barges being built in Nigeria, and other circular energy trades with little economic substance--have been under investigation for months; photos (M)

headline: BUSH SAYS OUSTING HUSSEIN COULD AID PEACE IN MIDEAST
abstract: President Bush declared tonight that removing Saddam Hussein from power in Iraq would bring stability to the region and could set the stage for peace between Israel and a ''truly democratic'' Palestinian state.    In his first significant remarks about the Israeli-Palestinian conflict in eight months, the president, under pressure from European and Arab nations to re-energize the lapsed Middle East peace negotiations, reaffirmed the United States commitment to a Palestinian state and to a three-year timetable outlining the steps for its creation.

headline: Candidates in Iran Jostle to Make a Difference
abstract: More than 200,000 candidates are running for election to municipal councils in Iran that Pres Mohammad Khatami saw as great step toward democracy when he was voted into office four years ago; in big cities like Tehran, enthusiasm for experiment has waned, as has belief that Khatami could bring change in face of obstruction from conservative clergy; but in towns and villages, there is great hope that candidates can make a difference, not so much in politics but in ability to deliver roads, hospitals and education; photos (M)

headline: Once Banned, a Turkish Leader Is Elected and Revives U.S. Hopes for Access
abstract: Recep Tayyip Erdogan, leader of Turkey's governing party, wins seat in Parliament, setting stage for his ascension to prime minister's post and reconsideration of failed bill to let American troops use Turkey as base in war against Iraq; victory follows Constitutional change that allowed him to run for office despite past conviction for inciting religious hatred; he meets with United States Amb W Robert Pearson, who says they discussed Iraq; Erdogan, who backs bill, says there are still significant areas of disagreement between Turkey and US, television interview; notes polls show Turks overwhelmingly oppose involvement in war; photo (M)

headline: Investing; Yields So Low That a Mattress Might Do Instead
abstract: Money market mutual funds generate lowest yields since their 1971 introduction; many fund sponsors cut their management fees to keep $1 share price and prevent investor losses; average money market interest rates fell to 0.82 percent for latest week; photo; graph of monthly returns since 1978 (M)

headline: Microsoft Settles an Antitrust Complaint Filed by Taiwan
abstract: Microsoft Corp settles antitrust complaint filed by Taiwan Fair Trade Commission, but sides differ on how much company actually conceded; commission vice chairman Chen Chi Yuan says part of deal involves commitment by company to reduce prices for its computer software in Taiwan by 26.7 percent; Microsoft says that while it decided to lower its average prices for academic and consumer users in Taiwan by 26.7 percent, it has done so in connection with new marketing campaign and not part of settlement itself; regulators and Microsoft agree that settlement does not find any wrongdoing by Microsoft, which commission had accused of monopolistic behavior and artificially inflating price of Windows software (M)

headline: W.H.O. Adopts Tobacco Pact But Many Countries Object
abstract: World Health Organization, despite objections from US and many other countries, adopts final draft of Framework Convention on Tobacco Control; treaty, if adopted in current form, would ban advertising and promotion of tobacco products in countries where that would be constitutional, impose high taxes on tobacco products and require tobacco industry to divulge all ingredients in cigarettes, print warnings on labels and ban companies from using terms like 'ultra light' or 'light' (M)

headline: Bringing Private Order to a Chaotic Sky
abstract: Bringing Private Order to a

headline: LVMH to Sell Phillips Stake To Auction House Executives
abstract: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton plans to sell its remaining 27.5 percent sake in auction house Phillips de Pury & Luxembourg to Simon de Pury and Daniella Luxembourg, co-chief executives of Phillips; terms of deal undisclosed; 50 of auction house's 135 employees are laid off (M)

headline: Doctor Explains Why He Blew the Whistle
abstract: Dr David P Franklin decided within weeks of accepting job with drug maker Warner-Lambert that he became crucial component in apparent corporate plan to illegally market epilepsy drug called Neurontin; says he thought he had little choice but to blow whistle on what he says was scheme to ignore federal regulations and market drug for more than dozen uses it was not approved to treat, first interview since filing federal lawsuit against Pfizer, which acquired Warner-Lambert, in 1996; Pfizer is negotiating settlement with government prosecutors; issue involves hundreds of millions of dollars that Medicaid and other government programs paid for Neurontin because of what Franklin contends was fraudulent marketing scheme; Pfizer has said actions Franklin claims to have seen would have occurred well before it acquired Warner-Lambert and that it is not aware of any credible evidence that Warner-Lambert employees made false claims about Neurontin; Neurontin accounted for $2.3 billion of Pfizer's sales last year and was one of company's top-selling drugs; Pfizer spokeswoman Mariann Caprino says company policy does not allow sales representatives to make inappropriate claims or encourage use of Pfizer products in treating medical conditions they are not approved for; photo (M)

headline: Bush's Speech Puts New Focus On State of Intelligence Data
abstract: In pressing his case for forceful action against Iraq, President Bush tonight cited intercepted communications, interrogations of prisoners, information from defectors and other unspecified intelligence as evidence that Saddam Hussein continues to build prohibited weapons and bankroll terrorist groups including Al Qaeda.    As he spoke, American intelligence officials were still sorting out how much sensitive information on Iraq to declassify in order to help the White House make its case at a meeting of the United Nations Security Council next week.

headline: U.S. to Resume Food Aid to North Korea, at a Reduced Level
abstract: State Dept announces it would resume shipments of food aid to North Korea, ending two-month hiatus, but that it will cut donations this year by 35 to 75 percent from last year's totals; despite cut, announcement is seen as conciliatory gesture toward newly inaugurated South Korean Pres Roh Moo Hyun; Roh has advocated engagement with Pyongyang and sharply criticized Bush administration's efforts to isolate North; Secretary of State Colin L Powell attends Roh's inauguration in Seoul; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Utility's Profit Falls
abstract: Italy's largest electr

headline: European Leaders Divide Between Hawks and Doves
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair will fly to United States to meet with Pres Bush, bearing unusual pledge of support from 9 European leaders but leaving Continent ever more divided over need for war against Iraq; letter published in several newspapers offers support of leaders of Spain, Italy, Portugal, Denmark and three Central Eureopan nations, in addition to Blair; in letter, leaders urge other Europeans to join them in backing Bush; 10 of 15 existing European Union members do not sign letter; photo (M)

headline: A Publisher's Firing and Hiring Set Up a Battle Over Authors
abstract: Penguin Group division of Pearson confirms naming Ann Godoff as president and publisher of new book imprint; Godoff was ousted by Random House division of Bertelsmann on Jan 16; questions arise about which company will publish future books by authors with whom she has had longstanding relationships (M)

headline: Pentagon Mobilizes Commercial Planes To Fly Troops to Gulf Area This Week
abstract: Pentagon mobilizes fleet of commercial airplanes to move troops and equipment in advance of possible war with Iraq; first flights will involve 47 planes; decision is only second time in its 51-year history that Civilian Reserve Air Fleet has been mobilized; earlier mobilization in 1991 Persian Gulf war, when Pentagon spent $1.5 billion using fleet, noted (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Alert On Mysterious Virus
abstract: World Health Organization issues warning of undetermined flu-like virus which has surfaced in China and Hanoi, Vietnam, affecting 39 health care workers and their families; virus is not associated with avian influenza, which recently killed a man in Hong Kong, but is similar to severe respiratory infection which affected 305 people in Guangdong Province, China, in January and February (S)

headline: Private Sector; Hedge Funds' Big Payout -- for Children
abstract: Hedge Funds Care, which supports efforts to protect children from abuse and neglect, will honor four men for their fund-raising feats: Daniel S Shapiro, Harris Rothstein, Robert J Sherry and Kevin F Shannon; Nicholas J Scoppetta, New York City's fire commissioner, will receive organization's lifetime award (S)

headline: Sabbath-Closing Issue Cracks Unity of Sharon's New Coalition
abstract: Prime Min Ariel Sharon's new coalition faces its first mini-crisis over sensitive question of working on Jewish Sabbath, issue that splits many secular and religious Israelis; Ehud Olmert, minister of industry and trade, orders indefinite suspension of government inspections that enforce laws banning work on Sabbath; decision provokes strong protests from religious groups, including National Religious Party, key member of Sharon's right-wing coalition (M)

headline: Unsolved Problems In Corporate Oversight
abstract: Eleanor Bloxham letter holds Jan 26 article The Revolution That Wasn't shows that despite corporate governance revolution 10 years ago, much remains to be done if boards are to always guard shareholder interests

headline: Company News
abstract: FORMER CHIEF OF HEALTHSOUTH IS RETURNING The HealthSouth Corporation, a leading operator of rehabilitation hospitals, said Richard Scrushy, who stepped down as chief executive in August to head a spinoff company, will return to that post. Mr. Scrushy, founder of HealthSouth, quit as chief executive to head a surgery center spinoff after HealthSouth announced that lower Medicare payments would trim $175 million a year from profit. The company ended the spinoff after investors objected; some called for Mr. Scrushy to leave the company. HealthSouth, which is based in Birmingham, Ala., said William Owens, who had been chief executive, would return to being chief financial officer.   (Bloomberg News).

headline: White House Adds a Crisis
abstract: Analysis of North Korea's abrupt decision to withdraw from Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, forcing Bush administration to face crisis in region; at issue is whether and how North Korea can be dissuaded from building new nuclear bombs; nation's pursuit of nuclear arms serves two ends: assuring that United States will not launch pre-emptive attack and gaining stronger negotiating hand in bid for aid and diplomatic respect; photo (M)

headline: Schmemann to head IHT editorial page
abstract: NEW YORK:—  Serge Schmemann, a veteran foreign correspondent, will become the editorial page editor for the International Herald Tribune in Paris in May, The New York Times announced. Schmemann will succeed Robert J. Donahue, who is retiring after having served as editor of the editorial pages for 22 years.

headline: Peronist Party Losing Its Grip on Argentine Politics
abstract: Argentina's Peronist Party will offer voters three choices in April presidential election, signaling split within movement resulting from longstanding feud between caretaker Pres Eduardo Duhalde and former Pres Carlos Menem; candidates facing Menem are Gov Nestor Kirchner, who has Duhalde's support, and Adolfo Rodriguez Saa, who was president for one week in Dec 2001; Radical Civil Union, Argentina's other party, is in equally confusing situaton and some fear that two-party system is in crisis; photo (M)

headline: KLM Seeks to Join Rivals' Alliances
abstract: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines says it does not plan to merge with British Airways, but is in talks with British Airways and Air France to join one of their alliances (S)

headline: New Executives at Hill, Holliday
abstract: New Executives At Hill, Holliday Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston has hired four executives for its offices in New York and Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil prices rise as resistance by Iraqi troops raises concerns that nation's oil will be kept off market longer than expected; crude oil for May delivery rises $1.75, or 6.5 percent, to $28.66 per barrel in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Avenue A Inc is renamed aQuantive Inc to differentiate agency company from agency it operates, Avenue A; Lane Marketing Communications opens office in New York, led by senior account executive Ryan Leverenz (S)

headline: Computerless in Quito
abstract: Tom Schneck letter conveys frustration at trying to donate used computer to Ecuador where tariffs make it almost cheaper to buy new (Jan 2 article)

headline: Mixed Feelings Next Door to Venezuela's Strife
abstract: Venezuelan drivers, feeling impact of eight-week strike crippling oil industry, cross border to go into Colombia, where gasoline dealers are doing steady business; Cucuta, Colombia, town of 800,000, was created for cross-border commerce, and has come to depend on increasingly affluent Venezuelans taking advantage of their stronger currency to cross into Cucuta to spend day shopping; Cucuta has busy downtown with Miami-style boutiques and elegant shoe stores catering to Venezuelans; photo; map (M)

headline: Safe Opens With a Touch, But Only if It's the Right One
abstract: Inprint safe from 9G Products uses fingerprint recognition technology to allow access to authorized owners; photo (M)

headline: No Bomber, but Israelis Gave Her a Scary Time
abstract: Palestinian Christian woman, Fida Misleh, 23, describes being arrested and detained for time, along with her father, by Israeli authorities, on suspicion of planning suicide bombing attack; photo; two were later released, as was second woman; third woman is reported still held in custody (S)

headline: Advertising; Threat of War Already Curbs The Budgets Of Marketers
abstract: Prospect of war in Middle East prompts advertisers to postpone media-buying decisions, threatening to derail advertising industry's nascent recovery after exceedingly difficult period; 2001 advertising spending fell 6.5 percent, largest decline since 1938; 2002 spending increased modest 2.6 percent (M)

headline: Security Council's Ambassadors Scramble to Find a Compromise
abstract: Fifteen ambassadors on Security Council try to keep up with the action as their leaders draw and redraw plays to pull out--or block--last-second Security Council approval of American-British-Spanish proposal to declare that Saddam Hussein has lost his last chance to disarm (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Pot In Every Chicken
abstract: Police surrounding East London apartment where Eli Hall has been holding a hostage for more than week foil attempt by a friend of his to smuggle marijuana to him in Kentucky Fried Chicken order (S)

headline: Robert E. Hudec, 68, Expert on Global Trade Law, Dies
abstract: Robert E Hudec, expert on global trade law, dies at 68 (S)

headline: Are Shares Of Builders Poised for A Retreat?
abstract: Homebuilding industry analyst Stephen S Kim discusses outlook for stock prices of publicly traded homebuilders; interview; photo (S)

headline: Investing; Barbie & Co. Reviving Mattel
abstract: Mattel shares rise on strength of Barbie doll and other important brands, combined with two years of cost cutting; analysts differ over whether Mattel's stock price fully reflects restructuring it has undergone; photo; graph (M)

headline: Complying, Anxiously, With an I.N.S. Roundup
abstract: Many immigrants comply with Immigration and Naturalization Service program to register men over age 16 from certain Middle Eastern countries, who entered United States as students, tourists or on business, before Oct 1, 2002; many admit having expired visas and say they fear being arrested or even deported; program's goal is to root out terrorists or potential terrorists (M)

headline: A Radio Chip in Every Consumer Product
abstract: Companies as diverse as Gillette, Procter & Gamble, International Paper and Canon USA are teaming up with retailers and customers to apply technology known as radio-frequency identification to tracking products from time they leave assembly line to time they leave store; companies are tagging products with computer chips laden with information about content, origin and destination; are also equipping shelves, doors and walls with sensors that can record that data when products are near; Philips Semiconductor, unit of Royal Philips Electronics, is leading maker of chips; diagram; photo (M)

headline: AMERICAN FARM EQUIPMENT MAKER OPENS OFFICE IN RUSSIA
abstract: Deere & Co opens representative's office in Moscow and may build farm equipment factory in Russia (S)

headline: Like Online Dating, With a Political Spin
abstract: Meetup.com is Web site that organizes groups with similar interests and arranges meetings for them; supporters of political candidates, for example, can find like-minded people online in same area and vote where and when to meet; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Leader Agrees To Inquiry
abstract: South Korean President Roh Moo Hyun says he will not veto law passed by National Assembly authorizing investigation into circumstances of meeting between former President Kim Dae Jung and North Korea's Kim Jong II in spite of pressure from his Millennium Democratic Party; Grand National Party, which holds National Assembly majority, alleges North Korea was paid several hundred million dollars to participate in 2000 meeting; photo (S)

headline: Blair Outlines Plans to Slash Emissions Over 50 Years
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair lays out ambitious plans to fight global warming by cutting carbon dioxide emissions in Britain by 60 percent in next five decades, far exceeding goals of Kyoto Protocol; gently criticizes Pres Bush for failing to do more to combat damaging effects of greenhouse gases; says there can be no genuine security if planet is ravaged by climate change; says economic growth and environmental awareness can coexist (M)

headline: Rare Health Alert Is Issued by W.H.O. For Mystery Illness
abstract: World Health Organization, in rare alert, declares Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome 'worldwide health threat and urges all nations to help in seeking its cause and control; has gotten reports of over 150 new suspected cases in last week in Canada, Hong Kong, elsewhere in China, Indonesia, Philippines, Singapore, Thailand and Vietnam; does not recommend restricting travel to any destination; ill passenger, doctor from Singapore who treated one of earliest cases, and two of his companions are removed from flight from New York City, where he attended medical meeting, on arrival in Frankfurt and put in isolation in German hospital; Dr Julie eL Gerberding, head of Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, says illness apparently is spread from affected individual to others only after direct and sustained contact, not through brief contact or in large crowds, news conference; suggests postponing nonessential travel to affected areas; photo (M)

headline: Let It Snow, But Hold The Slush
abstract: Responsible Party article on Glen Burnett, Trecan Combustion official responsible for selling its snow melters; he convinced New York City that it was cheaper to buy machines than to collect, transport and discard snow clogging busy intersections at out-of-the-way sites; photo (M)

headline: Citigroup Embraces Full Disclosure
abstract: Citigroup chief executive Sanford I Weill comments on difficult year and own weight loss; photo (S)

headline: CONGOLEUM, MAKER OF FLOORING, TO FILE FOR BANKRUPTCY
abstract: Congoleum Corp, maker of sheet and tile flooring, files for bankruptcy protection to erase its current and future asbestos liability; company hopes to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection within six months (S)

headline: Clouds Slowly Lift in South Korea
abstract: Strategy of engagement with North Korea has transformed South Korea in important and often unexpected ways; for decades, it was illegal in South Korea to say anything positive about Kim Il Sung, founder of North Korea; now high school textbooks in South credit Kim for first time for his role in combating Japanese colonialism; this has fed roiling debate in South about changing relations with North and United States and about politicization of history during cold war; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Officials Say Iraqis May Have Killed Some American Prisoners
abstract: American officials say some of Army mechanics captured on March 23 after they took wrong turn in Iraqi town of Nasiriya were apparently executed by their captors, probably in front of townspeople; administration finds itself somewhat on defensive about its strategy despite optimism at Pentagon and White House; photo (M)

headline: Pentagon Draws Up a 20-to-30-Year Antiterror Plan
abstract: Top US military officers draw up comprehensive plan to combat terror that includes confronting countries that sponsor terrorism, even if that would not necessarily mean direct attack; experts say applying pressure on Syria and Iran, Hezbollah's patrons, would likely be more effective than trying to attack Hezbollah itself; document, approved by Gen Richard B Myers, chairman of Joint Chiefs of Staff, represents shift to pre-emptive action against hostile states and terrorist groups; also addresses military's heightened role in homeland security (M)

headline: Overstated Earnings at Ahold Lead to Executive Resignations
abstract: Ahold, the Dutch grocery giant, ousted its top two executives after discovering earnings were inflated by at least $500 million. Company shares fell by two-thirds.

headline: Editors' Note; Variable Annuities
abstract: The variable annuity tables for the fourth quarter of 2002, which were not available at press time for the Mutual Funds Report last Sunday, appear today. They start on Page 28, in Part 2 of this section.

headline: PROVIDER OF STEEL FOR CARS CUTS PROFIT FORECAST
abstract: Steel Dynamics cuts its first

headline: E-Music Sites Settle on Prices. It's a Start.
abstract: Most of big record labels coalesce around set of prices at which they will make almost all of their music available to ever-expanding array of legal online file-sharing services, and America Online's new online music service roughly matches those terms and prices; they all now charge $9 or $10 a month for customers to listen to pool of about 250,000 songs online, using technology called streaming, and they charge about 99 cents to download song and copy it only a CD, where it can be played in car or on home stereo, or converted to computer file format like MP3 to be shared with others, legally or not; some services, like AOL's, include unlimited number of 'tethered' downloads, where songs can be copied onto computer and played offline, for example, by traveling laptop user; these options and expanding pool of songs may help create online services that might appeal to consumers and lure at least some from free-file-sharing services like KaZaA; table (M)

headline: Watching Intently as a War Is Born 6,000 Miles Away
abstract: After months of diplomacy and ominous words from Washington, there was some shrugging acceptance now that the moment for action had come.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: U.S. Experts Help At Bomb Site
abstract: Seven US explosives experts help investigate bombing of social club in Bogota; government blames rebel group Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia

headline: French's Has an Unmentioned British Flavor
abstract: Floyd Norris comment on simmering economic disputes between France and US over France's opposition to war in Iraq and efforts of British Prime Min Tony Blair, who has tried to occupy middle ground between Europe and US, with hopes of bridging differences; says continuing disputes after war could hurt economies of Western Europe and US, neither of which is looking especially strong; cites news release of French's mustard's new ad campaign that says only thing French about mustard is the name; holds nowhere in news release is it mentioned that New Jersey-based Reckitt Benckiser Inc, which produces mustard, is subsidiary of Reckitt Benckiser PLC, which is based in Slough, England; says Britain is chief ally of US in current war, but perhaps people at Reckitt fear some Americans do not appreciate difference between France and Britain; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Bosnia: Postwar High In Refugee Returns
abstract: Over 100,000 Bosnian refugees returned home in 2002 in largest migration home since 1995; 1.2 million of estimated 2.2 million people that left Bosnia are still living outside of region (S)

headline: British Cargo Vessel Carrying Relief Supplies Docks in a Southern Iraqi Port
abstract: British ship loaded with relief supplies docks at Umm Qasr, Iraq, where aid is condidered as much psychological tool as material necessity; it is first vessel to arrive since port and city were captured last week, but skirmishes over rations may bring effort to distribute supplies to halt, as happened in Safwan when Kuwaiti Red Crescent tried bring in supplies recently; photo (M)

headline: Caring for Those Who've Cared
abstract: Vivian Fenster Ehrlich writes My Job column, describing her work as executive director of Dorot, nonprofit group in Manhattan that serves older adults; photo (M)

headline: Shake a Phone Tree. Shake Again.
abstract: Sarah Milstein essay on her experience navigating Earthlink customer service as she tried to install new modem and get back online; drawings (M)

headline: Anger and Warning After Suicide Attack
abstract: A day after four U.S. soldiers were killed by a suicide bomber in a taxi near Najaf, all roads were closed around the town 100 miles south of Baghdad.

headline: U.S. AND ALLIES ASK THE U.N. TO AFFIRM IRAQ WON'T DISARM
abstract: US, Britain and Spain ask Security Council to declare that Iraq has missed its last chance to disarm to avoid war; showdown on new resolution will determine if war to remove Hussein from power will receive final approval from UN; Condoleezza Rice, national security adviser, says that Bush is willing to wait until Hans Blix, UN weapons inspector, reports on Iraq compliance on March 7 and that Security Council vote will come a week later; other officials hint that military action could come immediately thereafter; photos of Security Council members, showing division on whether are for new resolution (US, Britain, Spain and Bulgaria), against it (France, Germany, Russia, China and Syria) and on the fence (Angola, Cameroon, Chile, Guinea, Mexico and Pakistan)

headline: Bar Code Company May Face S.E.C. Suit
abstract: Shares of Symbol Technologies Inc, world's largest maker of bar code scanners, fall 13 percent after company says it might face civil actions in connection with its accounting practices (S)

headline: Prince Charles's Top Aide Quits After Inquiry
abstract: Michael Fawcett, Prince Charles's closest aide, resigns after publication of official report into charges of royal intervention in trial of Princess Diana's former butler and charges that members of prince's staff peddled gifts and covered up accusations of sexual activity within royal household; report finds Fawcett bent palace rules and accepted undisclosed perks and hospitality; it uncovers no serious wrongdoing by Fawcett or any of his colleagues, but it expresses misgivings about many staff practices; report is prepared by Sir Michael Peat, Prince Charles's private secretary; Fawcett is setting up his own event management business and has been guaranteed work by prince, who also gave him cash severance payment; photo (M)

headline: Private Sector; No One's Courting Her? 'Don't Know Why'
abstract: Norah Jones's project manager says Jones has received many offers since winning five Grammy awards, but none from advertiser asking her to become its spokeswoman (S)

headline: 2 Hotel Companies Form Joint Venture
abstract: Hilton Hotels Corp forms $400 million venture with CNL Hospitality Corp to buy and refurbish hotel properties, as it seeks to increase income from management fees (S)

headline: COSTCO REPORTS DROP IN EARNINGS RELATED TO BENEFITS
abstract: Costco Wholesale Corp says earnings in fiscal second quarter ended Feb 16 declined 5.4 percent; net income fell to $182.1 million from $192.6 million year earlier; revenue rose 7.8 percent, to $10.1 billion (S)

headline: Good News on Profits? Not for Those With Good Memories
abstract: Most of the companies that have reported earnings have hit their mark or done better, so why is the Dow in the red?

headline: Which Would Have Done Better Without the Merger?
abstract: Time Warner shareholders would be better off now if AOL merger with Time Warner had never happened; AOL holders have benefited from Time Warner assets; merger could be seen as indication that Stephen M Case, who resigned as AOL Time Warner chairman, unlike vast majority of Internet executives, got joke when Internet share prices were ridiculously high; it was not his job to warn Gerald M Levin, chief executive of old Time Warner, and his colleagues at Time Warner of risks of taking on stock based on such flimsy valuations; photo (M)

headline: Panel Links Faulty Wiring To '98 Crash Of Swiss Jet
abstract: Canadian investigators conclude that 1998 crash of Swissair Flight 111, in which all 229 people on board were killed, was caused by sparks from faulty wiring that ignited flammable insulation above cockpit, crippling aircraft's electrical system; their report strongly sugests that hastily installed entertainment system that provided games for passengers in first class and business class was at least partly to blame for starting fire, perhaps by overloading aircraft's inadequate electrical wiring; jet crashed nose first into chilled waters off Nova Scotia (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Deals: Earthlink Said To Be Near Pact With Vonage
abstract: Earthlink is expected to announce soon deal with Vonage to provide nationwide telephone service to its users; Earthlink is planning to sell Vonage's service, which allows broadband users to place unlimited number of local and long-distance calls for $39.99 per month, under its own name (S)

headline: Stocks Fall, Ending Quarter on Sour Note
abstract: Wall Street's first quarter was poised to end on a sour note today, with declines in the three main stock market indexes.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Slovakia: Peugeot Plans Plant
abstract: World Bus4

headline: Capital One Officer, Facing U.S. Inquiry, Quits
abstract: The Capital One Financial Corporation, the big credit card issuer, said yesterday that its chief financial officer had resigned after securities regulators notified him that they planned to accuse him of insider trading.    The executive, David M. Willey, received what is known as a Wells notice from the Securities and Exchange Commission, which indicated that the agency was close to filing a civil lawsuit against him.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Ministers Arrested
abstract: Zimbabwean authorities arrest about 20 cross-carrying ministers marching to police headquarters in Harare to protest laws approved in 2002 restricting freedom of assembly (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil falls after Bush administration iÄ

headline: Ivory Coast Haven Turns Hostile for Liberians
abstract: Thousands of Liberians who fled to Ivory Coast eight years ago to escape civil war are being repatriated as conflict between government of Ivory Coast and rebels intensifies since failed coup in September 2002; maps; photos (M)

headline: Dividend Tax Cut: An Alternative
abstract: Jesse H Oppenheimer letter responds to Dec 8 article about Bush administration's efforts to reduce tax on stock dividends

headline: In One Hand, U.S. Offers Turkey $4 Billion for War Aid; in Other, a Demand for Reform
abstract: United States offers at least $4 billion to Turkey to compensate for economic damage it might suffer as result of playing active role in American-led coalition in war against Iraq; Recep Tayyip Erdogan, leader of Turkey's governing Justice and Development Party, says $4 billion figure is inadequate to solve Turkey's problems; offer of aid is part of carrot-and-stick approach by Washington to guarantee Turkish participation; Washington wants use of military bases and other facilities that would allow US to use Turkey as staging point for possible attack into northern Iraq; Turkish leadership is worried about domestic political fallout that could result from being seen as too pro-American by largely antiwar Muslim population; Washington has told Prime Min Abdullah Gul that Turkey must within next few days push through critical economic reforms, including radical cuts in public spending, to persuade International Monetary Fund to disburse $1.7 billion installment of fund's package for Turkey; photo (M)

headline: South Korea To Broaden Inquiry Into Conglomerate
abstract: South Korean government will expand its investigation into SK Group; Pres-elect Roh Moo Hyun vows to crack down on traditional techniques by which country's wealthiest families perpetuate their power over economy; Chey Tae Won, hereditary leader of SK Group and chairman of SK Corp, has been arrested on charges of buying, selling and exchanging shares in one SK company for shares in another in order to give himself 6 percent stake in SK Corp, which in turn would assure him power over conglomerate's 58 companies (M)

headline: '60 Minutes' Creator to Step Down in 2004
abstract: CBS News announced today that Don Hewitt would leave his post as executive producer of "60 Minutes."

headline: F. William Free, 74, Ad Man Behind 'Fly Me'
abstract: F William Free, advertising executive who attracted passengers to National Airlines and protesters to his agency with one of his best-known campaigns, 'I'm Cheryl--Fly Me,' dies at age 74; photo (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Feb 16 article on military contractors' use of offsets; Boeing acquired McDonnell Douglas

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: A Move To Scrub The Reichstag
abstract: German conservative politicians would like graffiti, left by Soviet soldiers when they entered Berlin in May 1945, removed from historic Reichstag building; vulgar writing was unearthed seven years ago and has been left in rememberance of 100,000 Soviet lives lost in battle for Berlin; politicians hold it impedes German-Russian relations (S)

headline: Technology Briefing: Hardware
abstract: CORNING TO SHUT PHOTONICS PLANT IN CALIFORNIA; ELECTRONIC DATA'S DEBT RATING IS CUT 2 LEVELS;.

headline: Guess Announces Loss
abstract: Guess said Wednesday that its loss was wider than forecast last year after the company increased promotions and discounts to lure shoppers during the holidays.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Rebels Accused Of Killing Civilians
abstract: Vladimir Kravchenko, Chief Prosecutor of Chechen administration, accuses guerrillas of kidnapping and then blowing up 10 civilians; dismembered bodies have reportedly been found across several acres near Grozny; victims have not been publicly identified and officials offer no proof as of yet to support their assertions (S)

headline: DataBank; What a Difference a One-Day Rally Makes
abstract: Stock market performance in week ended Mar 14 reviewed; tables; graphs (S)

headline: Explosions Rip Diplomatic Offices in Caracas
abstract: Powerful bombs explode outside Columbian Consulate and Spanish Embassy in Caracas, Venezuela, causing extensive damage and injuries from flying glass; come two days after Pres Hugo Chavez berated both countries for interfering in Venezuela's internal affairs; he had been criticized for arrest of opposition leader and for not assisting Colombia for fight against rebels; government denies involvement in blasts; orders tighter security for foreign missions; photo (M)

headline: A Wedding Registry Short on Romance
abstract: Jeffrey Selingo Online Shopper column describes problems that arose when he and his fiancee tried to find online wedding registry that offered features they both wanted; drawing (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Builder Cuts Jobs
abstract: Major Japanese construction company Hazama Corp will lay off 40 percent of its workers, or 1,140 people, and close money-losing subsidiaries as it tries to get more debt relief from banks; graph of share price (S)

headline: Making a Statement, in Absentia
abstract: Messages that many students post when they step away from their computers--called away messages--are becoming creative outlet for instant-messagers; photos (L)

headline: OIL AND GAS PRODUCER TO ABANDON UNSUCCESSFUL WELL
abstract: The McMoRan Exploration Company, an American oil and natural gas producer, said it would abandon an unsuccessful well drilled in shallow waters of the Gulf of Mexico. The Lighthouse Point-Deep prospect was drilled to almost 18,000 feet in about 10 feet of water off Louisiana, the company said. Results of the effort were being reviewed to determine whether further drilling in the area was warranted, the company said. McMoRan Exploration is participating in four exploration wells being drilled in shallow gulf waters, the company said. Production from one of the wells is expected to begin in the second quarter, and plans for another well in the area are being developed.

headline: In Kuwait, a Dentist From Queens Misses the Subway and the Met
abstract: Capt Cynthia V Brito of New York, part of front-line V Corps medical unit now in Kuwait, talks about what she misses at home; is reluctant to go into too many details about being woman in military; photo (M)

headline: Thousands Protest in Cairo Against a U.S.-Led War on Iraq
abstract: Egyptians gathered today in Cairo's main stadium for one of the largest tolerated protests in the country in years.

headline: Random House Venture To Print Books in Japan
abstract: Random House Venture To P

headline: Bush Eases Ban on AIDS Money to Pro-Abortion Groups Abroad
abstract: Pres Bush decides to allow organizations that promote or perform abortions in poor countries to qualify under some circumstances for part of $15 billion he has proposed to fight AIDS in Africa and Caribbean (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL PAPER TAKES $278 MILLION CHARGE
abstract: International Paper takes after-tax charge of $278 million in fourth quarter to increase reserves used to settle claims that it made defective siding and roofing; company has raised reserve at least three times to pay customers who say company's former Masonite unit made building products that swelled and fell apart when wet; has $507 million to pay claims from three-class action lawsuits, which were settled in 1998 and 1999 (S)

headline: Envoys Abandon Scripts on Iraq And Bring Emotion to U.N. Floor
abstract: UN Security Council debate on conflict over Iraq gets surprisingly personal; most of diplomats transcend their scripts, bringing emotion and exasperation to an arena steeped in rote routines, and audience responds in kind; in breach of decorum seldom witnessed in protocol-conscious chamber, applause breaks out as French foreign minister, Dominique de Villepin, concludes his presentation against war by evoking ideas and conscience of 'La France'; US State Sec Colin Powell is equally personal and impassioned in opposing any delay in disarmament of Saddam Hussein; photos (L)

headline: Vatican Urges Catholic Politicians to Oppose Abortion
abstract: The Vatican issued guidelines for Roman Catholic politicians today that underlined the church's unyielding opposition to abortion.

headline: Gharo Journal; A Province Is Dying of Thirst, and Cries Robbery
abstract: Dispute over water between Sindh and Punjab provinces in southeastern Pakistan has caused rising tensions during drought of past three years, and is prime example of ethnic and regional fissures that weaken Pakistan beyond better-known international issues; farmers and politicians in Sindh accuse Punjab of water robbery for allegedly violating internal agreements and taking more than legal share of water from Indus River and its tributaries; article notes residents of Punjab tend to dominate country's military and government bureaucracies; map; photo (M)

headline: For Now, New Rules Don't Snarl Hong Kong Port Traffic
abstract: Maritime officials in Hong Kong report no serious disruptions as United States Customs Service begins enforcing new antiterrorism rules on cargo bound for American ports; note that problems could still crop up when business returns to normal, following Chinese New Year celebrations; rules are aimed at thwarting any terrorist attempts to send nuclear weapons or other bulky weapons of mass destruction to US in 40-foot steel shipping containers used to carry much of world's trade; Customs officials have said new rules could pose serious problems for Hong Kong's port, world's businest; photo (M)

headline: Hong Kong Moves to Raise Birth Rate and Draw Richer Immigrants
abstract: Local leaders announced today that they would begin accepting immigrants based partly on their wealth and talents and would adjust tax policies to encourage families to have more babies.    ''We want to upgrade the quality of the population,'' said Donald Tsang, the administration's chief secretary.

headline: Producer of Comdex Shows Is About to Seek Bankruptcy
abstract: Technology trade show producer Key3Media Group, crippled by plunge in technology industries and cutbacks in corporate travel, plans to file for bankruptcy protection; will propose reorganization plan, backed by Thomas Weisel Partners, that would keep it functioning; photo (M)

headline: Documents Suggest Iraq May Use Chemical Weapons
abstract: Documents smuggled out of Iraq suggest that Saddam Hussein may use chemical weapons against troops invading Baghdad, the BBC reported today.

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BELGIUM: Agfa Sells A Unit To G.E.; IRELAND: Bid For Software Maker; BRUSSELS: France To Be Warned On Deficit;.

headline: Why We Kindle the Dreams of the Young
abstract: MY son is planning to be Steven Spielberg when he grows up. To this end, he has read every Spielberg biography he can find, has added his own English essays to the existing literature and has a framed poster from ''Saving Private Ryan'' hanging on his bedroom wall. (Yes, we let an 11-year-old see an R-rated movie; please don't send angry e-mail messages. It's tough to argue with a child who wants to increase his knowledge of camera angles and special effects, and who has already read the screenplay.)    Because technology moves as fast as it does, Evan even has a head start on The Man himself. When Mr. Spielberg was 11, all he had to work with was a Super 8 camera; his editing method was to film in sequence. Evan is equipped with a borrowed Canon ZR50MC digital camcorder and the iMovie 2 film-editing software that came with our iMac computer.

headline: So, Let the Rat Races Begin!
abstract: Abby Ellin Preludes column about benefits and detriments of solitary work versus work within organizations; drawing (M)

headline: A Recharge En Route
abstract: New power adapter from Mobility Products can charge laptops, hand-held devices and cellphones and works in automobiles, airplanes and indoors with standard electrical outlets; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: THE NETHERLANDS: Bank'S Profit Slips; RUSSIA: Gazprom Sells Bonds; GERMANY: Thyssenkrupp Downgraded; FRANCE: Economy Stalls;.

headline: S.E.C. Upgrades Its Inquiry Into Interpublic's Finances
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission upgrades inquiry into advertising conglomerate Interpublic Group of Companies's finances to formal investigation; can now issue subpoenas; company's statements and restatements concerning $181.3 million in accounting irregularities touched off initial probe (M)

headline: Strike's Effects Tear at Social Fabric in Venezuela
abstract: Seven-week-old strike aimed at shutting down Venezuela's economy and toppling Pres Hugo Chavez has become fault line that divides Venezuelan society into rival camps, wreaking havoc on neighborhoods and families alike; economy is ruins and country has been pushed to brink of civil conflict, but Chavez shows no signs of leaving; strike holds firm in some places, particularly state-owned oil company, but middle class and owners of small and medium-sized business who are base of opposition to Chavez do not know how much longer they can hold out; photos (M)

headline: Heir Apparent to Goldman's Chief Decides to Retire Instead
abstract: John L. Thornton surprised Wall Street today by announcing that he would retire on July 1 to become a professor in China.

headline: Exchange Sues Internet Energy Marketer
abstract: Intercontinental Exchange Inc., said on Monday that the New York Mercantile Exchange was trying to squelch competition by restricting use of its prices in online trades.

headline: The Stars Are Aligned For Makers of Sports Shoes
abstract: Interview with retailing analyst Robert S Drbul (Lehman Brothers) on outlook for athletic footwear business and stock performance of sneaker makers; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Middle East
abstract: LEBANON: Fear Of Offending Saudi Arabia; EGYPT: Members Of Muslim Group Arrested;.

headline: Big Protests Planned in Europe
abstract: From London to Moscow, thousands are set to take part this weekend in what could be one of Europe's biggest antiwar rallies.

headline: World Court For Crimes Of War Opens In The Hague
abstract: New and permanent international criminal court, fiercely opposed by Bush administration and long awaited by other countries, opens in the Hague with swearing in of its 18 judges; will play crucial role in averting as well as prosecuting human rights abuses (M)

headline: Powell on Iraq: 'We Reserve Our Sovereign Right to Take Military Action'
abstract: Excerpts from Secretary of State Colin L Powell's speech on Iraq at World Economic Forum; photo (M)

headline: Julian Bigelow, 89, Mathematician and Computer Pioneer
abstract: Cybernetics and computing pioneer Julian Bigelow dies at age 89; photo (M)

headline: Editors' Note; EDITORS' NOTE
abstract: Editors' Note: Feb 2 article on growing willingness of companies to fill board seats with younger executives failed to mention that Nicole W Piasecki, 40-year-old vice president of Boeing Commercial Airlines and member of Weyerhaeuser board, is descendant of Weyerhaeuser's founder and daughter of founder of helicopter company sold to Boeing

headline: Franks Describes a War 'Unlike Any' in History
abstract: Gen Tommy R Franks, leader of American troops in Iraq, meets reporters from around world nearly 72 hours after beginning of war at press briefing in Qatar; takes pains to emphasize precision of American weapons and target selection to minimize civilian casualties; makes point of calling on two Arab reporters; says military operation is aimed at 'liberating' Iraqi people and not occupying their country; says this war is unlike any other in history; photo (M)

headline: Ontario Decides Not to Sell Part of Big Hydroelectric Utility
abstract: Ontario goverment says it will retain full ownership of Hydro One; governemnt said less than year ago it intended to sell Hydro One through public offering that would have been largest in Canadian history, raising estimated 5 billion Canadian dollars or $3.26 billion (M)

headline: Intel Earnings And Revenue Slightly Beat Expectations
abstract: Intel Corp reports better-than-expected sales and profits, giving investors at least slight reason to hope that worst of technology industry's long downturn is over; posts sales of $7.16 billion and profits of $1.05 billion in fourth quarter of 2002; earned $3.12 billion for 2002; chief executive Craig R Barrett comments; photo (M)

headline: Iraqi Leaders Are Losing Control, Rumsfeld Says
abstract: Pentagon officials said this afternoon that American and British troops had pushed 100 miles into Iraq and that the regime of Saddam Hussein was already losing its power.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Japan Economy Grows For a 4th Straight Quarter  Japan's economy expanded 2 percent in the quarter ended Dec. 31, compared with the previous quarter, defying expectations that growth had stalled and that the fourth recession in a decade had begun.    As in other quarters, growth was driven by exports and steady gains in consumer spending and capital investment, which offset declines in new-home starts and government spending. But the string of four consecutive quarterly expansions may come to a halt this year if the global economy slows. [Page C2.]

headline: WEYERHAEUSER TO SELL LAND FOR $185 MILLION TO CUT DEBT
abstract: Weyerhaeuser To Sell Land For $185 Million To Cut Debt**

headline: Blair and Bush to Meet on War, Europe and Mideast
abstract: Prime Minister Tony Blair said today that he would fly to the U.S. on Wednesday to confer with President Bush on three issues.

headline: Arab Nations Unconvinced by Bush's Reasons for War
abstract: President Bush's recapping of the need to remove Saddam Hussein sounded to Middle Eastern ears today like a domestic pep rally.

headline: U.S. INVESTIGATES PRACTICES OF ELAN, A DRUG MAKER
abstract: FTC opens investigation into whether Elan Corp used unfair practices like listing false patents to prevent development of generic version of Skelaxin, muscle relaxant that Elan agreed to sell with other assets in January to King Pharmaceuticals (S)

headline: U.S.-British Draft Resolution Stating Position on Iraq
abstract: Turkish cabinet endorses proposal to allow 40,000 American troops into country for possible attack on Iraq even before two countries work out final details of agreement; debate reveals deep divisions over wisdom of signing on to plan, under which Turkey will receive up to $15 billion in grants and loans; photo of Turkish women protesting American-led war on Iraq (M)

headline: U.S. Is Behind European Nations on Crowd Safety, Experts Say
abstract: Experts say that the U.S. has done less than many other countries to prevent incidents like the two recent nightclub disasters.

headline: MEMO PAD
abstract: US government may have to relax antitrust restrictions on airline schedules that would allow carriers to combine services if event of war with Iraq; Congress is planning to have closer look at recently announced plan to screen airline passengers by checking their records in credit, criminal and other commercially available databases; so-called assisted passenger prescreening system, called Capps, has come under heavy criticism from privacy groups and airline travelers' organizations since federal said this month that it would begin testing with Delta Air Lines in thre undisclosed airports (Memo Pad column) (M)

headline: U.S. Asks Pakistan to Lift U.N. Envoy's Immunity After a Violent Quarrel
abstract: State Department asks Pakistan to withdraw diplomatic immunity of UN envoy Munir Akram after New York City prosecutors seek to bring misdemeanor assault charges against him for quarrel with girlfriend in his Manhattan home; Pakistani Mission says two have reconciled (S)

headline: Nine Palestinians And Two Israelis Die in Day of Fury
abstract: Nine Palestinians and two Israelis are killed in fighting across Israel and occupied territories; conflict becomes engaged in Israeli electoral politics; new violence breaks out in Nitzana, area that is ordinarily quiet, and comes day after Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat asks Palestinians to refrain from attacking Israeli civilians; Israeli Defense Min Shaul Mofaz promises 'vast operations' against Palestinian militants in occupied territories; Israeli military operations in Gaza Strip and Palestinian town of Jenin prompt Palestinian leaders to accuse Prime Min Ariel Sharon of deliberately trying to torpedo their peace offerings to rally Israelis to his side in runup to parliamentary elections later this month; photos; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: ING Discloses Charge
abstract: World Busin

headline: Archbishop of Canterbury Enthroned
abstract: Most Rev Rowan Williams is enthroned as Archbishop at Canterbury Cathedral in England; he is 104th in line that stretches back to 596; Prince Charles and Prime Min Tony Blair attend ceremony, along with more than 2,000 church and government figures dressed in traditional robes and wigs and miters; outside, there is demonstration by churchgoers and ministers upset with views expressed by new archbishop that they find overly progressive; they parade before cathedral gates wearing black armbands; new church-commissioned report warns of steep declines in church attendance, baptisms, marriages and paid clergy; photo (M)

headline: Defenders of Close Ties With Europe Are Now on the Defensive in the U.S.
abstract: Iraq crisis appears to have prompted growing view in United States of feckless Europe unready to make tough choices that many Americans now see as necessary for West's security; American impatience with France and Germany reaches fever pitch; members of Congress are denouncing two countries and there are calls for boycotts of French products; but anti-Europeanism is not as prevalent in US as anti-Americanism is in Europe, because while America looms large in minds of Europeans, Americans do not think much about European military or economic activity at all (M)

headline: FORD EXECUTIVE TO HEAD MAZDA'S NORTH AMERICAN UNIT
abstract: Mazda Motor Corp, Ford Motor Co affiliate, says James O'Sullivan is named president and chief exeutive of Japanese company's North American unit; succeeds Charles Hughes, who resigned (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Japanese Computer Shipments Decline
abstract: Gartner Japan Dataquest

headline: Blair Repeats Call for Iraq to Be Disarmed
abstract: British Prime Minister Tony Blair said today that he was eager to avoid war in Iraq, but that his belief in the need for Iraq to be disarmed was firm.

headline: AOL Chairman Quits His Post Amid Criticism
