abstract: Sir Hardy Amies, 93, for 50 years couturier to Queen Elizabeth II, died Wednesday "peacefully at his country home," according to a communiqué from his house based in London's Savile Row.

headline: For Blair, a Gamble to Avoid Political Disaster
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair's new checklist for Iraq's disarmament is seen by some as last and possibly desperate attempt to avert his worst nightmare--war in Iraq without authorization of United Nations that could jeopardize his political future; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Paramilitary Leader Jailed
abstract: Johnny Adair, Northern Ireland's most notorious Protestant paramilitary leader, is arrested for breaching terms of release from prison; photo (S)

headline: Hartmarx Delays 2002 Earnings Report
abstract: Hartmarx Corp will delay release of its results for fiscal year ended Nov 30 until its auditors complete review of books for its women's wholesale unit (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Rate Change Unlikely
abstract: Bank of England governor Sir Edward George expects no 'sharp change' in British interest rates, which have held at 39-year low of 4 percent for last 13 months; expects consumer spending and inflation in housing prices to ease without crash in booming real estate market (S)i

headline: U.S. Plan to Monitor Muslims Meets With Widespread Protest
abstract: American plans under Patriot Act to fingerprint and register visitors from numerous predominantly Muslim countries meet with widespread protest and indignation from many of such nations' officials and citizens (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Airline Grounded
abstract: Air Lib, France's second-largest airline, loses its operating license and is forced to ground all its planes after Dutch investment company IMCA declines to invest in airline; Transport Min Gilles de Robien says French government will try to find jobs for carrier's 3,200 employees, but leaves company's fate in hands of commercial court, which could place airline in liquidation or receivership; Air Lib owner Jean-Charles Corbet says bankruptcy is not automatic; also says IMCA might yet invest in company; photo (M)

headline: Citigroup Chief Withdraws His Name From N.Y.S.E. Consideration
abstract: Sanford I. Weill withdrew his name from consideration to be a director of the New York Stock Exchange after the attorney general of New York said he would fight the nomination.

headline: Orbitz Moves Work To Young & Rubicam
abstract: Orbitz awards creative part of its advertising account, with billings estimated at $20 million, to Chicago office of Young & Rubicam Advertising; incumbent agency Fusion Idea Lab decided not to take part in review (S)

headline: SpongeBob and Pals Provide Licensing Gold for Nickelodeon
abstract: Nickelodeon Enterprises, which licenses products like SpongeBob SquarePants doll, is fastest-growing segment of business in Viacom's MTV Networks family; division generated about $2.5 billion in retail sales in 2002, up about 19 percent over previous year while sales of its bigger competitors Disney and Warner Brothers were relatively flat; SpongeBob products recorded retail sales of about $700 million, far exceeding Nickelodeon's initial expectations of $500 million; success of other licensed products discussed; Nickelodeon Enterprises president Jeffrey D Dunn comments; chart; photos (M)

headline: A Safer Sky or Welcome to Flight 1984?
abstract: Article on controversy surrounding new computer-based system that will evaluate precise personal information about passenger booking airline ticket, then assign that passenger one of three color-based security ratings; Lockheed Martin is developing system and Delta Air Lines has volunteered to help test in pilot program that starts at end of March; drawing (M)

headline: U.S. and Turkey Reach Accord to Let G.I.'s Establish a Base
abstract: United States reaches agreement with Turkey on package of $15 billion in immediate economic and military aid, in step that is expected to pave way for American troops to use Turkish territory as base in case of war with Iraq; Turkish Parliament is expected to approve arrangement; photo of Prime Min Abdullah Gul (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Fund Official Is Detained
abstract: Jorge Baca Campodonico, member of International Monetary Fund mission sent to scrutinize Argentina's economic policies, and former minister of finance in Peru, is detained on his arrival in Buenos Aires on corruption charges at request of Peruvian government (S)

headline: Jurors Were Divided Over Morgan's Lawsuit
abstract: Jurors who were about to weigh J P Morgan Chase's $965 million claim against 11 insurers over Enron oil and gas trades say they were split before opponents in lawsuit reached settlement on Jan 2 (M)

headline: Liquid Audio Gets a Buyer For Its Assets
abstract: Anderson Merchandisers, music distributor for Wal-Mart, agrees to buy some of assets of Liquid Audio, troubled digital music pioneer, move that could make it easier for record companies to sell and promote songs online; financial terms undisclosed; Anderson hopes to distribute music downloads through Web sites of retailers, including Wal-Mart, though no deal has been worked out; new company, which has not yet been named, will be run by Liquid Audio founder Gerry Kearby, who says company has licenses to distribute over 350,000 songs (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Slower Growth Expected
abstract: South Korea's Finance Min Jeon Yun Churl says economic growth will slow and trade surplus will decline in 2003; predicts economy will grow by about 5 percent after climbing 6.2 percent in 2002; says trade surplus will probably fall short of last year's $10 billion because exports will increase at slower pace (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Serbia And Montenegro: Parliament Formed
abstract: Serbia and Montenegro, Europe's newest country, sets up Parliament to replace old federal assembly that was dissolved when Yugoslavia was renamed and reconstituted (S)

headline: Allies Say They Took Iraqi Posts Early to Prevent Use of Chemical and Biological Arms
abstract: Officials of coalition forces report that in opening hours of war against Iraq, American and Australian special forces flew deep into country and seized or blew up specific command posts far from Baghdad to prevent officers there from ordering use of chemical and biological weapons; officials stress that no chemical or biological weapons were stored at command centers that were attacked thus far; Iraqis deny having such weapons (M)

headline: Merrill Campaign on Banking to Open
abstract: Merrill Campaign On Banking to Open.

headline: Chinese Legislature Meets to Appoint Leaders
abstract: China's annual legislative session opens, Beijing, with personalities eclipsing policies as country moves to formalize first sweeping leadership transition in decade; outgoing Prime Min Zhu Rongji opens People's National Congress with report praising economic progress and future plans; Congress will elect Hu Jintao to succeed Pres Jiang Zemin; expected behind-the-scenes power that will determine country's future discussed; Jiang's broad power base assures he will remain potent unofficial policy maker for many years, despite relinquishing presidential duties; he is expected to retain post as chairman of powerful Central Military Commission; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Brewer's Profit Rises
abstract: Cia de Bebidas das Americas, Latin America's largest brewer, says fourth-quarter net income rose to 431.4 million reais ($127 million) from 178.7 million reais year earlier; revenue increased 13 percent, to 2.44 billion reais (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Military Says It Downed Indian Plane
abstract: Pakistan claims to have shot down Indian spy plane over Pakistan-controlled part of Kashmir; India denies incident took place (S)

headline: UNION LEADERS SAY THEY'LL REVIEW AMR'S PROPOSED CUTS
abstract: Transport Workers Union leaders, who represent mechanics and ground workers at American Airlines, say they will review AMR's proposal seeking $625 million in cost reductions to ensure cuts are needed to keep carrier from seeking bankruptcy protection (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: New Valley Cancels Bid For Globalstar
abstract: New Valley Corp abandons plans to take control of Globalstar, bankrupt satellite telephone company, after failing to reach agreement with creditors; graph (S)

headline: Some Reshuffling of Agency Posts
abstract: Some Reshuffling Of Agency Posts Leading executives are taking new jobs.

headline: New Economy; Even as it gazes toward the stars, the space program has broad benefits for those rooted to Earth.
abstract: Calls for reducing NASA's budget in wake of Columbia disaster prompt review of technologies now flourishing in commercial world that owe their existence to space program, among them global positioning system, virtual reality and satellite television; perhaps biggest technological legacy of program is reliable electronics; photo (M)

headline: Senate Report Says Rubin Acted Legally in Enron Matter
abstract: Senate Governmental Affairs Committee report concludes former Treasury Sec Robert E Rubin 'did not act contrary to law' in weeks before Enron collapsed by suggesting to then Treasury Under Sec Peter R Fisher that he urge major credit-rating agencies to delay issuing downgrade of Enron; Rubin, who resigned as Treasury secretary in July 1999 and several months later became chairman of Citigroup's executive committee, called Fisher on Nov 8, 2001, after learning that Enron was close to losing its investment-grade rating; Citigroup stood to lose more than $1 billion that it had lent to Enron if its credit rating was downgraded and company subsequently collapsed; Rubin had been asked to make call by Michael A Carpenter, head of Citigroup's investment banking unit at time (M)

headline: Paul Klingenstein, 88, Seller Of Photographic Equipment
abstract: Paul Klingenstein, founder of Kling Photo Corp, dies at age 88 (M)

headline: A Projector to Match Your Magnetism
abstract: Basics column discusses new generation of digital projectors for use with computer to show business presentations or hook up to other video output such as VCR or DVD; technology explained; prices noted; photos (M)

headline: Troops Told To Carry Freedom, Not the Flag
abstract: United States troops rolling toward Iraq border are given orders on two matters of decorum: not to throw candy to Iraqi children and not to display flags of any kind, even American flag; military officials say candy would draw swarms of children to convoys, creating dangerous situation among many trucks, Humvees and trailers barreling toward Baghdad; say flag could give citizens of Iraq wrong idea about convoys, which are not an army of conquest that is intent on claiming Iraqi land or treasure (M)

headline: Y.&R. Executive Quits for Competitor
abstract: Jim Ferguson, top creative executive at Young & Rubicam, is leaving to join competitor DDB Worldwide, in new post of executive vice president and creative consultant (S)

headline: South Korea's President-Elect Rejects Use of Force Against North Korea
abstract: Pres-elect Roh Moo Hyun of South Korea insists on peaceful approach toward North Korea, which he says wants to escape its status as rogue state, interview; will not contemplate military strike from South Korean territory against North Korean nuclear complex on Yongbyon, even if North Korea were found to be reprocessing nuclear fuel for bomb production there; tries to play down recent wave of anti-Americanism in South Korea and denies his candidacy rode such a wave; vows to keep his country's relationship with US strong while trying to usher North Korea out of international isolation; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Abbey Has First Annual Loss
abstract: After a disastrous foray into corporate banking, the mortgage lender Abbey National reported the first annual loss in its history, writing down losses equivalent to $3.6 billion on acquisitions and investments. The net loss for 2002 was £1.2 billion ($1.91 billion) in contrast to a net profit in 2001 of £947 million. The company also halved its dividend to 25 percent. Analysts had expected the dividend cut and the loss, but were divided on the extent of the damage. Abbey's shares seesawed, rising by as much as 8 percent before falling to 378 pence.   Alan Cowell (NYT)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Trial Set For Terror Suspects
abstract: Greek judicial officials set March trial for 19 suspected members of November 17 terrorist group (S)

headline: Glimmers of an Investor-Friendly Russia
abstract: Signs of foreign investment are again showing up around Russia; BP has agreed to make single largest foreign direct investment in Russia's post-Soviet history, $6.75 billion commitment to create giant new oil company; businesspeople are now asking whether after decade of zigzagging economic policies, Russia has finally become safe, fertile ground for foreign investors; photos; chart (M)

headline: Blair Tells Parliament the War Is on Track
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair tells House of Commons that campaign against Saddam Hussein is encountering difficulties, but says strategy is still going according to plan; Britian has suffered its 17th war death; since British troops entered combat, opinion polls record large majorities against war have swung around to small majorities in its favor; but large parts of population, including Blair's Labor Party, still oppose it; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Software
abstract: COMPUWARE LOWERS EARNINGS ESTIMATE; SAP POSTS BETTER-THAN-EXPECTED REVENUE;.

headline: Briefly Noted
abstract: U.S. PLANE ATTACKED Five war protesters overpowered a policeman guarding a hangar at Shannon Airport in southwest Ireland and attacked a United States Navy plane with hammers, as well as vandalizing the site with human blood and spray-paint, the police said. The protesters were arrested at the scene and later appeared in court. The airport is a refueling stop for American military planes en route to the Persian Gulf.    Brian Lavery (NYT).

headline: Credit Suisse Reports Loss Of $2 Billion
abstract: Credit Suisse Group reports 2002 loss of 3.3 billion Swiss francs ($2.4 billion), and co-chief executive Oswald Grubel calls results 'unacceptable'; says assets under management fell by 16.4 percent, including net outflow of 2.6 billion Swiss francs ($1.9 billion); assets under management at Credit Suisse First Boston fell by 21.3 billion francs ($15.7 billion); Credit Suisse says it will eliminate 1,250 more jobs to try to get back to profitability; photo (M)

headline: Offering Delayed By South Africa
abstract: South African government announces that first public offering of shares in its national telecommunications company Telkom will take place March 4; is selling 139 million shares, or about 25 percent of company's stock; share price is expected to range from $3.92 to $4.79 (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Rate Change Unlikely; SWITZERLAND: Wider Use For Novartis Drug; ITALY: A Plan For Fiat;.

headline: New Leaders Named by China, Capping Wide Transition
abstract: An extensive but evolutionary leadership transition has placed technocratic, career bureaucrats in command of the country.

headline: Sun, Again, Bets Against the Odds
abstract: Article on challenges facing Sun Microsystems and its chief executive Scott McNealy; quandary for company that rode high on Internet wave is that its business appears to be highly dependent on high-cost, proprietary hardware at time when technology trends and customers seem headed in other direction, toward inexpensive PC-based hardware that is more like industrial commodity; photos; graphs; Sun relies on own microprocessor design and Solaris software, while rivals run Microsoft's Windows or Linux, which is distributed free and constantly improved by network of programmers (M)

headline: Today's Lesson, Class, Is This: Ethics Really Matter in Business
abstract: Today's Lesson, Class, Is This: Ethics Really Matter in Business.

headline: Allies Adapt To Setbacks
abstract: Analysis: American military is moving to adapt, as war in Iraq fails to produce swift victory Bush administration clearly hoped for; air campaign that was supposed to 'shock and awe' Saddam Hussein's government did neither; Iraqi military's command and control system is still intact, and Hussein has not lost his grip on power; Iraqis surprise allies by deploying thousands of fedayeen and paramilitary forces in southern Iraq for guerrilla-style hit-and-run attacks; allies are countering by putting off battle of Baghdad and focusing efforts on attacking paramilitary groups in and around Najaf, Nasiriya, Samawa, Basra and other southern and central Iraqi cities; United States military can hardly do anything else, considering limited ground forces Bush administration has allocated for initial phase of campaign and need to take care of threats in their rear; planning and preparations for drive to Baghdad are very advanced, and American commanders are certain battle will take place relatively soon; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Internet
abstract: U.S. CHARGES AUSTRALIAN WITH COPYRIGHT INFRINGEMENT; HOUSE TO HOLD HEARINGS ON CHILD PORNOGRAPHY; BLACK BOX STOCK FALLS TO 4-YEAR LOW;.

headline: Large H.M.O. to Make Treatment Guidelines Public
abstract: Kaiser Permanente, nation's largest nonprofit health maintenance organization, will publish on its Web site guidelines developed and used by Kaiser's doctors for treatment of hundreds of diseases; also agrees to share with public information about way it pays doctors, including financial incentives; new guidelines, which are being published as part of settlement of two lawsuits brought by consumer groups over patient care, are not compulsory, so doctors will still be free to deviate from them without penalty; Kaiser patients will have access to information they can use to assess treatment they receive and discuss it with their doctors; patients will have to look up information themselves on Kaiser's Web site; consumer advocates say Kaiser's moves will push other managed care companies and medical groups to make similar disclosures regarding treatments and doctors' compensation (M)

headline: Goddard, Claussen Open an Agency
abstract: Ben Goddard and Rick Claussen leave Goddard Claussen Porter Novelli to open agency GC Strategic Advocacy (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Peace Effort Slogs On
abstract: Irish Prime Min Bertie Ahern and British Prime Min Tony Blair meet to plan strategy for upcoming talks in Belfast; talks to focus on ending Northern Ireland assembly stalemate, which led to home-rule suspension last October (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Merger Talks
abstract: Norway's Den Norske Bank and

headline: Brighton Journal; There's Life Yet in the Seaside's Tottering Old Lady
abstract: Brighton Journal on Brighton, once-grand English resort where ornate West Pier, dating to 1866, is crumbling into ocean while disputes hold up $23-million restoration; photos; map; some townspeople, while fond of old pier, question spending so much money on promenade built for Victorians; visitors today are mostly day-trippers who do not stay for evening entertainment (M)

headline: Keeping Business in the Family
abstract: Public companies controlled by families are common in Canada; Edward S Rogers, founder and chief executive of Rogers Communications, is expected to be succeed by his son Edward S Rogers Jr; David Thomson last May extended his family's control of Thomson Corp; his father Kenneth Thomson is son of company's founder Lord Thomson of Fleet; Power Corp founder-chairman Paul Desmarais has installed his sons Andre and Paul Jr as joint chief executives; photos (M)

headline: As an American Armada Leaves San Diego, Tears Are the Rule of the Day
abstract: Description of scene and personal vignettes as 10,000 sailors and marines leave San Diego aboard seven ships headed toward Persian Gulf; photo (M)

headline: Britain Charges Venezuelan Who Had Grenade in Airport
abstract: Hasil Muhammad Rahaham-Alan of Venezuela, who was arrested at Gatwick Airport last week with live grenade in his luggage, is formally charged with terrorist crimes, and government says army patrols at Britain's airports would be kept in place for foreseeable future; no application for bail is made and Rahaham-Alan is ordered held over for appearance next week at court; grenade was discovered during baggage inspection (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction: two ratings provided by Morningstar Inc have appeared in reverse order in weekly mutual fund tables since July 7

headline: China's New Prime Minister Seen as Careful Conciliator
abstract: Article profiles Wen Jiabao, China's new prime minister; he says his priority will be reviving country's stagnating rural economy; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Ending Diplomatic Crisis With Morocco
abstract: Spain and Morocco agree to exchange ambasr

headline: Carter Proposes Plan to Solve Impasse in Venezuela
abstract: Former President Jimmy Carter offered two plans today for leading Venezuela toward elections and ending a 51-day-old strike.

headline: Concerns About Economy And War Send Stocks Down
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average and Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fall more than 2 percent to their lowest level since October as concerns about war with Iraq, slowing economic growth and plunge in financial stocks drag market lower; forces push bond prices higher and interest rates even lower as investors seek shelter in Treasury market; yield on 10-year note falls to 3.57 percent from 3.65 percent; price rises 19/32, to 102 16/32; 1.33 percent yield on two-year note is lowest since early 1950's; decline in financial stocks start when Federal Reserve Bank of St Louis president William Poole raises questions about financial viability of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac if there was sudden financial crisis; shares of Fannie Mae plunge $4.35, or 6.9 percent, to $58.95, while Freddie Mac's stock drops $3.20, or 5.9 percent, to $50.80; US dollar falls to $1.1045 against euro from $1.101 and 116.94 yen from 116.99; dollar is down 5 percent against euro and 1.6 percent against yen in 2003; Dow Jones industrial index drops 171.85 points, or 2.2 percent, at 7,568.18; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closes off 21.41 points, or 2.6 percent, at 807.48; Nasdaq composite index drops 26.92 points, or 2.1 percent, to 1,278.37; graphs; charts; photo (M)

headline: A New Managing Editor at Real Simple
abstract: Time Inc is expected to announce that Carrie Tuhy, managing editor of Real Simple magazine, is being replaced by Kristin van Ogtrop, executive editor of Glamour; Tuhy wil become editorial director of Real Simple (S)

headline: COURT REINSTATES SUIT AGAINST ALLSTATE IN 1994 QUAKE
abstract: An appeals court has reinstated a lawsuit against the Allstate Corporation related to the 1994 earthquake in Northridge, Calif. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled that a California law, enacted in 2001, that extended the amount of time people had to sue insurers did not violate the company's rights. The court reinstated a lawsuit brought by policyholders who say Allstate misled them about the amount of damage their homes suffered in the earthquake. Allstate received more than 46,000 claims and paid out $2 billion. Peter Klee, a lawyer for Allstate, said the decision was not a surprise because it followed the reasoning of three previous rulings by state appeals courts.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Chemical Acquisition
abstract: South Korea's largest chemical manufacturer, LG Chem, and Honam Petrochemical plan to take over Hyundai Petrochemical for $1.5 billion if company's creditors agree to write off as much as $500 million in debts (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Utility Bid Rejected
abstract: Iberdrola, one of Spain's largest utilities, rejects unsolicited 15 billion euro ($16.59) takeover bid by smaller rival Natural Gas (S)

headline: Nothing Like Big Deficits To Hearten Bond Traders
abstract: US bond market is more comfortable now that nation is running huge budget deficit; only two years ago, Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan voiced fears that government was in danger of building up such big budget surpluses that Treasury market could dry up; Greenspan had warned that government would have no choice but to put its extra money into buying up corporate stocks and bonds; there is no need to invent life-support system for $3 trillion Treasury market with Bush administration forecasting deficits into foreseeable future; graphs (M)

headline: Avalanche Kills 8 U.S. Skiers Touring Canada
abstract: Eight backpacking American sky mountaineers on helicopters tours of Selkirk Mountains of western Canada are buried and killed by avalanche (S)

headline: U.S. Demands Iraq Show Cooperation by the Weekend
abstract: The secretary of state said the president would press for a resolution authorizing use of force if Iraq was still not cooperating at the end of the week.

headline: War's Effect on Retailers Appears to Be Mixed
abstract: Preliminary figures from major United States retailers show that sales slowed during first week of war with Iraq but appear to be rebounding to prewar levels as military conflict continues (M)

headline: In Baghdad, Government Seeks to Portray Normalcy
abstract: Hours after the U.S. opened war against Iraq, the streets in this city of 4.5 million people were deserted.

headline: 7 Die in Mideast Violence; Sharon Gains Coalition Support
abstract: Two Palestinian gunmen attack Israeli Army post in West Bank city of Nablus, killing Israeli officer and soldier before being shot dead; in northern Israel, Arab man stabs police officer in what is being treated as terrorist incident; man is shot and killed by police; Palestinians in Gaza Strip accuse Israeli forces of killing two male nurses at hospital; against this backdrop of violence, Prime Min Ariel Sharon continues his efforts to form new coalition government; says he wants to form broad coalition of right and left, but Labor Party is resisting his appeal (M)

headline: ANTIWAR PROTESTS FAIL TO SWAY BUSH ON PLANS FOR IRAQ
abstract: Pres Bush dismisses antiwar protests as factor in his plans for confronting Iraq, and presses ahead with effort to persuade reluctant allies that UN inspections will not get Saddam Hussein to disarm; says that being swayed by size of protests is like deciding policy based on focus group, that leader has to decide policy based on security; photo; European Union statement explicitly, if reluctantly, supporting use of force raises British and US hopes of ultimately winning over Security Council; Prime Min Blair suggests protesters listen to Iraqi exiles' accounts of 'barbarous and detestable' regime; Bush scorns notion of giving Iraq yet another chance; Sec Colin Powell continues intensive talks continue on drafting new UN resolution (M)

headline: Bush Gives Hussein 48 Hours, and Vows to Act
abstract: The president said the Iraqi leader and his two sons must leave the country and warned diplomats, aid workers and journalists in Iraq to get out of harm's way immediately.

headline: Fair, Isaac Buys a Super Bowl Spot
abstract: Fair, Isaac Buys A Super Bowl Spot Another advertiser is joining the handful of dot-coms that are buying commercials during the Super Bowl.

headline: BANKRUPTCY COURT APPROVES LIQUIDATION OF WIZ STORES
abstract: Bankruptcy

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: SCHERING, Berlin, the pharmaceutical company, said it would share United States promotion rights for Finacea, its new treatment for the skin disorder rosacea, with Allergan, Irvine, Calif., a pharmaceutical company.    DUKE ENERGY, Charlotte, N.C., the utility owner, agreed to sell its 23.6 percent stake in a natural gas pipeline from British Columbia to Chicago to two partners, Enbridge and Fort Chicago Energy Partners, both of Calgary, Alberta, for $245 million.

headline: Ahead of Re-election Run, Indonesia's President Is Chased by Corruption Complaints
abstract: Indonesian Pres Megawati Sukarnoputri celebrates her 56th birthday even as demonstrators parade around Jakarta, protesting price increases for basic commodities like fuel and electricity that are rooted in corruption; Megawati, once champion of underclass, is excoriated by some of her supporters; question on everyone's mind is whether Megawati, in power for 18 months, can rally enough support to win presidential elections next year; photos (M)

headline: Forewarned Is Forearmed? Not Always
abstract: Jeffrey L Seglin interviews Barbara Ley Toffler on her forthcoming book, Final Accounting: Ambition, Greed and the Fall of Arthur Andersen, which describes her experience founding and leading ethics consulting group at Andersen for four years; Toffler says that if she, who had previously taught business ethics at Harvard Business School, became caught up in Andersen culture, with its pressures to make money, there is no telling what might happen to young people joining Andersen with no idea of whether what is happening is normal or not (M)

headline: Loiseau may have succumbed to the pressure of French success : A chef dies:How many stars are enough?
abstract: PARIS:—  Bernard Loiseau, 52, chef-owner of La Cote d'Or restaurant in Burgundy — one of only 16 Michelin three-star restaurants in France — has died of a gunshot wound, apparently self-inflicted.

headline: Market Place; Financial Dominoes and Dividend Taxes
abstract: Elimination of taxes on corporate dividends, as Pres Bush is expected to propose, could provoke sweeping changes in way companies raise money and Americans invest; could make American corporations less likely to go broke in bad times, while making it more expensive for states and cities to borrow money; Wall Street could see boom in fees as companies rush to issue preferred stock, relatively obscure security that could become most popular way for many companies to raise money; could encourage more companies to pay dividends; saving would be more likely to accrue more to those who hold their stocks in taxable accounts, as opposed to 401(k)'s and individual retirement accounts; could make such retirement accounts less popular, or at minimum make investors less likely to use them for their stock investments; Bush's stimulus package is also expected to include aid for hard-pressed state and local governments, many of which face large budget deficits that otherwise must be eliminated by raising taxes or cutting spending; dividend plan could hurt those same states and local governments, by raising their borrowing costs and reducing their tax revenues; graph (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Philippine President Signs Economic Reform Bills
abstract: President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo today signed a set of economic reform bills that she said would improve the Philippine economy in the next 18 months.

headline: Sharon Seals Deal With One More Party To Firm Up Coalition
abstract: Israel's Prime Min Ariel Sharon signs up far-right National Union party to join proposed government, increasing his parliamentary majority and adding hawkish complexion to coalition (S)

headline: Looking for Answers in Aftermath of Korean Subway Fire
abstract: Forensic experts today sifted through the charred remains of flesh and bones in subway cars gutted by an arson attack.

headline: A Meteor of a Magazine
abstract: Andrew Ross Sorkin reviews book Starving to Death on $200 Million a Year: The Short, Absurd Life of The Industry Standard, by James Ledbetter (S)

headline: Pocket PC's For Smaller Pocketbooks
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column reviews Pocket PC's, noting that prices have dropped precipitously in recent months; drawing; photos (L)

headline: Banker Runs Off to Join the (Media) Circus
abstract: Wesley K Clark, retired army general, television commentator and object of political speculation, is leaving as investment banker to work as commentator for CNN in Kuwait (S)

headline: Airstrikes Continue As Allies Consider Timing of a Thrust
abstract: Unexplained blast tears through Baghdad market, killing or wounding 100 civilians, and Iraqi authorities blame allied forces; American officials say they are not responsible; blast comes as skirmishes with irregular forces loyal to Saddam Hussein continue to plague American and British armies in midst of large-scale resupply operations; military officials say timing of any thrust on Baghdad is under intense review; photo; map (M)

headline: Private Funds Lag, Report Says
abstract: Report by Thomson Venture Economics and National Venture Capital Association shows that annualized returns of private equity funds over last 20 years slipped below 15 percent minimum expected by most venture capital investors (S)

headline: Poor Mr. Case? Financially, Think Again
abstract: AOL Time Warner chairman Stephen M Case liquidated some of his personal holdings long before announcing he would step down as chairman; Case sold shares for roughly $155 million after merging AOL with Time Warner in early 2000; sold AOL shares worth about $531 milion from 1992 through 1999; Case and his family own 11.3 million shares of AOL Time Warner and Case has 22.7 million stock options; shares Case owns outright are worth about $171 million; graph (M)

headline: Europeans Warn of Terror Attacks in Event of War in Iraq
abstract: European investigators have evidence that over the past six months, Islamic militants have been recruiting hundreds of fellow Muslims to carry out attacks in the event of a war against Iraq, according to French and other European antiterrorism experts.    A French expert, who requested anonymity, said one threat to Europe came from radical groups who have links with Chechnya and have learned how to make chemical weapons, either at training camps in Afghanistan or while serving in the Soviet Army. He said Chechnya was now a kind of ''neo-Afghanistan,'' a new training ground and staging area for anti-Western terrorists.

headline: Personal Business; Beyond Botox: An Industry's Quest for Smooth Skin
abstract: Cosmetic dermatologists and surgeons expect FDA to approve half-dozen injectable cosmetic fillers for treatment of wrinkles and sagging skin over next few months in response to consumer demand for treatments that work faster on facial flaws and last longer than Botox, which temporarily paralyzes muscles responsible for wrinkling; say field may become very crowded for a while until clinical track records are established; dermatologists' chief concern about permanent fillers is that side effects may also be permanent; products on horizon include Artecoll, Restylane, CosmoDerm and CosmoPlast; photo (M)

headline: A Poor Woman's Work Is Never Fun
abstract: Diana B Henriques Off the Shelf column reviews book Global Woman: Nannies, Maids and Sex Workers in the New Economy, edited by Barbara Ehrenreich and Arlie Russell Hochschild; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Water Concern Acquired
abstract: RWE says its Thames Water subsidiary has completed $4.6 billion acquisition of American Water Works Co (S)

headline: Start-Up Finds Technology Slump Works in Its Favor
abstract: Phil Goldman starts Mailblocks, company that will provide service that he says will permanently end e-mail spam for small annual fee; system will intercept e-mail messages from any correspondent unknown to subscriber and automatically return to sender a digital image of seven-digit number and form to fill out; only after human being views number and types it into form will system let e-mail be delivered; Goldman says new technologies and slumping technology economy are making it relatively easy to enter new markets; photo (M)

headline: Saudis Send Proposals To End War To Both Sides
abstract: Saudi Arabia sends US and Iraq proposals to end war; Prince Saud al-Faisal, kingdom's foreign minister, calls on both sides to stop war and send conflict back to United Nations (M)

headline: ANDREW CORPORATION FORECASTS A QUARTERLY LOSS
abstract: Andrew Corp forecasts second-quarter loss after cutting its estimate by as much as 20 percent (S)

headline: Wyeth Expecting Subpoena In Inquiry Involving Schering
abstract: Wyeth expects to receive subpoena soon from Justice Department related to inquiry into whether it colluded with Schering-Plough in sale of over-the-counter drugs on offshore oil rigs; Wyeth spokesman Francis Sullivan says federal prosecutors plan to have grand jury hear accusations; Federal prosecutors are looking at whether Wyeth, maker of Advil, Robitussin and Centrum vitamins, colluded with Schering to lower commission rates paid to broker that was selling companies' over-the-counter medicines in vending machines on offshore rigs; Sullivan says probe centers on sales of less than $10 million and broker commissions of less than $300,000; identifies broker as Compass Marketing (M)

headline: Microsoft Is Said to Shift Strategies for MSN Service
abstract: IDC, Internet research firm, reports that Microsoft Corp has abandoned its goal of trying to overtake America Online as largest online service and that its new strategy is to make MSN a portal or software company, with customers obtaining their own Internet access from any source; Bob Visse, director of marketing at MSN, says Microsoft does not plan any retreat from provision of slower, telephone dial-up access to Internet, but that its best course is to use leading-edge software as its competitive advantage as market shifts more and more to broadband (M)

headline: Lehman Cuts Pay of Chief
abstract: Lehman Brothers Holdings cuts pay of chairman Richard Fuld by 22 percent, to $12.5 million, as company profit 18 percent (S)

headline: CHRISTIE'S RAISES COMMISSION ON SALES ABOVE $100,000
abstract: Christie's International will raise commissions on auction sales to 12 percent of amounts above $100,000 from 10 percent; buyers' premium on first $100,000 remains at 19.5 percent (S)

headline: Sarendhi Journal; Broken Taboos Doom Lovers in an Indian Village
abstract: Hindu man and Muslim woman he loved from Sarendhi, India, are killed by her three brothers for breaking rigid social codes that have maintained peace and order for centuries in thousands of such Indian villages; intercaste and interreligious marriages are frowned upon, but villagers say greater infraction was that two young people came from same village, making them like brother and sister; say such a union would be viewed as incestuous; woman's three brothers are in jail and could be hanged, although they could also claim that sight of their sister in bed with man constituted 'sudden and grave provocation,' a defense under Indian law; photos; map (M)

headline: If Short Sellers Take Heat, Maybe It's Time to Bail Out
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Market Watch column on Prof Owen A Lamont's study that found that stocks of companies that try to thwart short sellers are generally overpriced and lag general market after companies wage public battles with short sellers; study also found that short sellers are often dead right in their assessments; graph (M)

headline: TEVA SAYS BRITISH COURT INVALIDATES 2 MERCK PATENTS
abstract: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries, leading maker of generic drugs, says British court invalidated two Merck & Co patents for osteoporosis drug Fosamax; Merck will appeal; Teva says it will not introduce generic version of Fosamax in Britain until 2004 because of 'regulatory procedures'; Merck says ruling by High Court of Justice for England and Wales also benefits Arrow Generics and Generics UK Ltd, unit of Merck of Germany; two Mercks are unrelated (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: SOUTH KOREA: Refiner'S Records Seized; JAPAN: Starbucks Profit Falls; JAPAN: Kirin Forecasts Profit;.

headline: Yugoslavia Is Again Reinvented, in Name and Structure
abstract: Parliament in Belgrade formally consigns name Yugoslavia to history books, endorsing Constitution of new, less binding union of Serbia and Montenegro; new state is compromise between independence aspirations of Montenegrins and international edict that there be no more redrawing of Balkan borders; map; chronology; two states are bound together for three years, which may allow time for reforms that might lead to membership in European Union; shifting of power to republics leaves Yugoslav Pres Vojislav Kostunica as big loser in his interminable power struggle with Serb Prime Min Zoran Djindjic (M)

headline: Private Sector; Hello? Can You Hear Me? I'm Moving!
abstract: Stephen Wozniak, wireless industry pioneer, is moving from his 16-year-old dream home in Los Gatos, Calif, because he cannot get decent cellphone signal (S)

headline: A Suicide Attack and Strikes at Basra
abstract: Heavy bombs struck Baghdad again, and a marketplace was destroyed, although American officials denied responsibility. Allied warplanes pounded Republican Guard positions on the outskirts of the Iraqi capital. As allied ground troops regrouped, American officials in Washington tried to defend their handling of the war and to quell internal disagreements among military leaders. A huge explosion shook Kuwait City, ripping apart a waterfront shopping mall and setting nerves on edge.

headline: Profit for the Quarter Off 4% at Topps
abstract: Topps Co says profit fell 4 percent in fiscal third quarter ended Nov 30 on 8 percent decline in sales; net income dropped to $2.91 million from $6.53 million; sales fell to $66.7 million from $72.1 million (S)

headline: Northrop Elevates Its President To Complete Succession Plan
abstract: Northrop Corp says president Ronald D Sugar will become next chief executive, succeeding Kent Kresa, who is retiring on April 1; photo (M)

headline: COMPUTER CONSULTANT NAMES CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER
abstract: BearingPoint Inc names Robert Falcone chief financial officer, succeeding Robert Lamb, who resigned (S)

headline: INSPECTOR ORDERS IRAQ TO DISMANTLE DISPUTED MISSILES
abstract: Hans Blix, chief United Nations weapons inspector, demands that Iraq start destroying--within week--all its Al Samoud 2 missiles and any illegally imported engines designed for use in rockets, which United Nations experts say exceed allowed range of 92 miles; demand appears to set stage for diplomatic showdown over next two weeks that could determine whether Iraq faces war; photos of Pres Bush and Samoud missile (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Software
abstract: COREL AGREES TO BE ACQUIRED BY VECTOR CAPITAL; KEYNOTE OFFERS TO BUY BACK 33% OF ITS SHARES; SYMANTEC WILL BE ADDED TO S.& P. 500;.

headline: Split on Iraq May Harm U.S.-Europe Trade Ties
abstract: Businesspeople in Germany are watching nervously for signs that split on Iraq will harm US-Europe trade ties; only confirmed example of soured business relationship involves Lederett, German leather maker; company's owner and chief executive Grit Kuhnt says it lost important American customer because of German government's lack of support for US; case drew widespread attention in Germany because Kuhnt wrote angry letter to Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, urging him reverse hs antiwar stance; Schroder and French Pres Jacques Chirac reaffirm their opposition to military action; US and Britain have blamed France for much of diplomatic impasse (M)

headline: Argentina Will End Freeze On Bank Savings Accounts
abstract: Argentina, buoyed by signs of economic recovery, says it will end unpopular freeze on bank savings accounts imposed in late 2001 over next 120 days; move will free estimated $5.5 billion still trapped in banks; Min Roberto Lavagna says savers, whose dollar accounts were converted into local currency, will get back about 80 percent of their money in cash and government bonds; analysts say Pres Eduardo Duhalde acts to boost candidacy of Nestor Kirchner in Apr presidential elections (M)

headline: For Kurds, Big Menace Is an Incursion by Turks
abstract: Turkish military officials push Parliament to reconsider whether to let American soldiers enter for possible attack on Iraq, while Kurdish protests intensify against deploying Turkish forces in limited area of northern Iraq; American and Turkish officials say Kurdish threats and fears are exaggerated, but Kurds are now declaring Turkish soldiers as much of a threat as Saddam Hussein; this raises nightmarish prospect for United States that Kurds could block or even attack Turkish forces if they enter Iraq alongside American units; photo (M)

headline: Fear Said to Be Keeping Iraqi Dissidents From Rebelling
abstract: Uprisings of Iraqis against Saddam Hussein are not as large as American forces expected; several members of Iraqi opposition groups say people in Basra live in fear and under something close to martial law and will not rise up until moment security apparatus of country crumbles (M)

headline: Split at C.I.A. and F.B.I. On Iraqi Ties to Al Qaeda
abstract: Some analysts at CIA complain that senior Bush administration officials have exaggerated significance of some intelligence reports about Iraq, particularly about its possible links to terrorism, and some FBI investigators are baffled by administration's insistence on solid link between Iraq and Qaeda, which they do not think exists; Deputy Defense Sec Paul D Wolfowitz and Stephen J Hadley, deputy national security adviser, are cited as being most eager to interpret evidence deemed murky by intelligence officials to show clearer picture of Iraq's involvement in illicit weapons programs and terrorism; Sec of State Colin L Powell, in addressing United Nations Security Council, is expected to cite intelligence of possible connections between Saddam Hussein, Ansar al-Islam, Islamic militant group that may have produced poisons in remote region of northern Iraq, and Abu Mussab al-Zarqawi, Qaeda leader (M)

headline: Business; In Japan, Foreigners Inspire Wave of Spinoffs
abstract: Management buyouts begin to take hold in Japan as large companies laden with debt come under pressure to unload underperforming subsidiaries, and foreign private equity firms are called on to help manager buy their own company; trend should help Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi make good on pledge to double amount of foreign investment in Japan by 2008; graph; photo (M)

headline: HUSSEIN RALLIES IRAQI DEFENDERS TO HOLD CAPITAL
abstract: Iraq's leaders resurface in contemptuous, even cocksure mood, challenging American forces to push on across last 50 or 60 miles of desert toward decisive showdown in Baghdad; appear emboldened by five days of fighting that has shown Iraqi troops offering stiffer resistance than expected; Pres Saddam Hussein appears on television in 25-minute speech aimed at further stiffening Iraqi defenses; says Iraq's aim is to drag out war, denying US and Britain quick victory they planned and dragging them into 'this quagmire'; Hussein has been silent since shortly after first American bombing raid last week, and some American officials had suggested he might be seriously injured or killed; his appearance on TV has effect of steadying government, at least for now; Deputy Prime Min Tariq Aziz, Hussein's principal voice to world for decade, holds news conference; he, too, was rumored to have been killed or hurt in bombing; strolls into hotel fingering Havana cigar and mocking American officials who suggested that air raid had 'decapitated' Iraqi leadership; claims all members of Iraqi leadership are alive and well, with exception of one man killed in battle for Najaf; photos (L)

headline: THREATS AND RESPONSES: Briefly Noted; PROTESTS AT ISSUE
abstract: American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee files suit against city of Dearborn, Mich, alleging its rules for public protest are unconstitutional; under city law, groups must file request for protest 30 days before action; committee lawyer says that it is unreasonable for people to wait that long if Iraq is bombed (S)

headline: In a New Setback for Blair, A Cabinet Minister Resigns
abstract: Robin Cook quits as British cabinet minister to protest Prime Min Tony Blair's support for use of force in Iraq; this complicates Blair's position on eve of divisive parliamentary debate about looming war; Blair's staunch support of Pres Bush's position on Iraq has alienated him from several European nations, many members of his own Labor Party, and wide swaths of British public; Cook is first high-ranking political casualty; Cook, in letter to Blair, praises him for 'heroic efforts' to obtain United Nations approval of military action, but says he opposes Britain taking unilateral military action; polls show sizable majority of British public and significant minority of members of Parliament from Blair's Labor Party agree with Cook's opposition to use of force without United Nations sanction; photo (M)

headline: Iraqi Leadership Shows Defiance After Airstrikes
abstract: The third day of the war appeared to find Saddam Hussein in Baghdad in the tightest spot since he took power in 1979.

headline: E.U. Takes Over for U.N. in Supervising Police in Bosnia
abstract: The European Union's supervision of the police in Bosnia is viewed as a test run of an evolving common-defense policy.

headline: GALEN HOLDINGS AGREES TO BUY 3 PFIZER DRUGS
abstract: Galen Holdings agrees to buy oral contraceptives Estrostep and Loestrin and hormone replacement therapy femhrt from Pfizer Inc for $359 million, with additional $125 million payble if drugs maintain market dominance until patents expire (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BOEING CO., Chicago, the world's largest airplane maker, said it would dismiss 115 workers at an airplane parts plant in Oak Ridge, Tenn., on April 10 as part of the 5,000 jobs the company plans to eliminate this year because of declining aircraft deliveries.    TETRA TECH INC., Pasadena, Calif., a consultant and provider of engineering and technical services, agreed to buy a nuclear waste management unit from Foster Wheeler Ltd., Clinton, N.J., an engineering and construction firm, for about $80 million in cash.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bank Chairman Resigns
abstract: World Business Briefing: Germany: Bank Chairman Resigns*

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Journalist's Sentence Upheld
abstract: Iranian court upholds 13-month sentence of reform journalist Ahmad Zeidabadi for spreading lies; court also sentences Nargess Mohammadi, wife of reformist Taqi Rahmani, to 12 months in prison; she is found guilty of jeopardizing national security during interviews she gave while her husband was in jail (S)

headline: Ubiquitous Yet Little Used, the Diskette Hangs On
abstract: Most computers are made with disk drives even though they are little used; diskettes storage is limited, there are other competing formats that hold more data and it is easy to e-mail files; Imation, world's largest manufacturer of disks sees its market growing overseas, while US market is slowly fading; photo (M)

headline: Weapons Inspectors Agree on New Visit to Baghdad
abstract: U.N. inspectors agreed on a new visit, amid signs that Iraq might permit overflights by U-2 surveillance planes.

headline: Creating a lifestyle:Hermes draws on 80 years of experience
abstract: PARIS—  Leave it to Hermes to have one of the most exclusive and sumptuous lifestyle collections around. Hermes is far from a newcomer to the sector. In fact, its first products date to 1922 when the house introduced accessory-filled travel trunks to meet the needs of new automobile drivers.

headline: Saudis Have Been Raking In Oil Money
abstract: Elevated oil prices and expanded production as result of Iraqi conflict are pouring as much as billion extra dollars a week into Saudi Arabia, and could double government's oil revenues this year; since last year, members of Orgn of Petroleum Exporting Countries have been ratcheting up output as anxiety over war with Iraq, heightened United States demand during unusually cold winter and interrupted Venezuelan production pushed oil prices steadily higher; Saudi Arabia, whose OPEC quota is usually 7 million barrels a day, is now pumping 9 million barrels daily, and output could surge to 10.5 million barrels--its full capacity--if country makes up for lost Iraqi production during war; fear in Saudi Arabia is that any new government in Iraq would invest heavily to upgrade and expand Iraqi oilfields, providing global oil market with huge new source of supply, diluting demand and depressing prices (M)

headline: 3 MEMBERS OF NATO AND RUSSIA RESIST U.S. ON IRAQ PLANS
abstract: France and Germany close ranks against United States, teaming with Belgium to block attempts by NATO to begin military planning for defense of Turkey in event of war with Iraq and teaming with Russia to issue joint declaration calling for intensified weapons inspections as alternative to war; in response to blocking of NATO, Turkey takes highly unusual step of invoking Article IV of NATO treaty, which requires entire alliance to consult if any member feels its security is threatened; further NATO meeting is called for Feb 11; move by three NATO members most reluctant to use military force against Iraq marks one of most serious cleavages in history of alliance and is sharply criticized by some members as blow to strength and credibility of organization at core of trans-Atlantic cooperation; at United Nations, Iraq delivers letter to chief UN weapons inspectors agreeing to allow flights over country by photographic surveillance aircraft; photos; diagram (L)

headline: North Korea Urged to Comply as 3-Way Talks Open in Washington
abstract: The U.N. nuclear agency strongly urged Pyongyang today to comply with its own safeguards as talks aimed at pressing North Korea to end its nuclear efforts began.

headline: Forces Continue March Toward Baghdad; Troops May Be Missing
abstract: United States troops suffered their first significant casualties today as American forces advanced to within 95 miles of Baghdad, with Iraq Television showing what it said were the bodies of at least four American soldiers and images of several American prisoners of war, including one woman.

headline: BIOGEN TO PAY $55 MILLION TO SETTLE PATENT DISPUTE
abstract: Biogen will pay $55 million to Berlex Laboratories, affiliate of Schering, as part of settlement that ends patent infringement claims related to two companies' drugs for treatment of multiple sclerosis (S)

headline: Fierce, Stinging Winds Destroy 17 Army Tents in Kuwait
abstract: Fierce, stinging wind, with gusts of over 70 miles an hour, destroys 17 tents, including mess tent, in US military camp outside Kuwait City; hundreds of troops rush outdoors to hold down tents during worst of storm; senior military officials, noting that sandstorms are common from mid-February to mid-April, says crucial element in invasion of Iraq would be air assaults led by helicopters; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: E-Mail Suggests Analyst Coached WorldCom Chief  As shares of WorldCom were falling a year ago, the company's founder, Bernard J. Ebbers, spoke out in a call with analysts and swatted down rumors of financial problems. According to an e-mail message uncovered by federal regulators, Mr. Ebbers received a good deal of help with his rousing script from Jack B. Grubman, the telecommunications analyst at Salomon Smith Barney.    While there is nothing illegal about an analyst advising a chief executive on how to approach a conference call, providing such detailed coaching, as the e-mail message does, is highly unusual and seems to indicate that Mr. Grubman considered himself a close adviser to Mr. Ebbers, playing a role that would normally be the task of a corporate insider or public relations specialist. [Page A1.]

headline: Indonesians Unite in Protest of Wave of Price Increases
abstract: Economic adversaries under most circumstances, Indonesia's business community, consumers and labor groups have found themselves united in protest this week.

headline: Ruby Tuesday Chain Selects Kaplan
abstract: Ruby Tuesday Chain Selects Kaplan Ruby Tuesday in Maryville, Tenn., which operates 600 casual restaurants, has named the Kaplan Thaler Group in New York as agency of record on its creative account, and MediaVest U.S.A. in New York as agency of record on the media duties. Both assignments had previously been handled internally.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Shares Of Sonic Solutions Soar On AOL Pact
abstract: Shares of Sonic Solutions rose as much as 24 percent yesterday after America Online agreed to license Sonic's technology for creating compact discs and DVD's. AOL is the world's biggest Internet service, with 27 million customers in the United States. MusicNet on AOL, a music-subscription service that AOL introduced yesterday, will include Sonic's AuthorScript program, which burns CD's. MusicNet subscribers will be asked to pay as much as $17.95 a month for access to 250,000 songs by performers from all five of the world's biggest music companies. People who buy tracks will be able to burn them directly to a CD. Shares of Sonic rose 53 cents, or 13 percent, to $4.63. The stock had dropped 31 percent in the last year.

headline: Explosions Strike Baghdad Again; 50 Are Reported Dead
abstract: Baghdad was hit early today by explosions after some of the most powerful bombardments of the Iraqi capital since the start of the war 10 days ago.

headline: Talk of Arab 'Democracy' Is a Double-Edged Scimitar
abstract: Egyptian politicians and analysts say Arabs are unconvinced that war against Iraq would bring stability, let alone democracy, to their country; those interviewed say forced overthrow of Iraq's dictatorship would unleash fury of anti-American sentiment, especially among fundamentalist Islamic forces, resulting in new crackdowns that would stifle democratic changes; that view is shared even by those who might benefit most from democracy in Egypt, including Rifaat al-Said, who spent 14 years in prison for uttering word 'democracy,' and Essam el-Erian, whose political organization Muslim Brotherhood is officially banned; they argue that imposition of democracy by force in Iraq would be viewed as American repression, not liberation (M)

headline: STRASBOURG SUSPECTS
abstract: German prosecutors narrow their case against four Algerian men suspected of planning bomb attack in Strasbourg, France, dropping charge that suspects belong to terrorist group (S)

headline: After Gaza City Raid, Israel Considers Occupation
abstract: Two days before Israeli elections, Israel's defense minister said that the army was weighing a re-occupation of the Gaza Strip.

headline: Kenya's New Millionaires Find Wives and Woe
abstract: Tiny town of Dol Dol, Kenya, has been transformed by $7.4 million legal settlement of suit filed on behalf of hundreds of poor, nomadic herdsmen who have lost fingers, eyes and limbs from explosives left by British troops that used grazing land as training ground; so-called 'boom-boom money' averages about $18,000 per person, in country where average person makes less than $1 a day; payouts vary according to injuries suffered; newfound wealth is causing squabbling between husbands and wives about how money should be spent; photos; map (M)

headline: JUDGE APPROVES SETTLEMENT BETWEEN KMART AND FLEMING
abstract: Federal Bankruptcy Judge Susan Pierson Sonderby approves settlement between Kmart Corp and Fleming Companies, reducing Fleming's $1.5 billion claim in Kmart's bnakruptcy case to $385 million (S)

headline: Burning Trenches, Smoking Ruins and Strikes by Ground, Air and Sea
abstract: A day after the intense aerial bombardment of Iraq, American-led forces advanced on the ground, pummeled targets from the air and launched new strikes from the sea. Under a waning moon, the waxing American and British invasion accelerated as armored units continued their run toward strategic targets in the north, east and west.

headline: Activision Account Is in Review
abstract: Activision is conducting informal review of its advertising account, which has been handled by D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Los Angeles office since 2000; billings estimated at $20 million (S)

headline: Vivendi Move Doesn't Mean Asset Sales Are Imminent
abstract: Vivendi Universal paves way for partial or complete sale of its American entertainment assets at board meeting in Paris, when directors vote to give chief executive Jean-Rene Fourtou right to shed those businesses; company cautions move does not mean sale is imminent (M)o

headline: WorldCom Decides to Take $79 Billion Write-Down
abstract: WorldCom is writing down $79.8 billion of its good will and other assets; says all existing good will, valued at $45 billion, will be written down; also says it will reduce value of $44.8 billion of equipment and other intangible assets to about $10 billion; write-downs are important step in WorldCom's efforts to emerge from bankruptcy because they allow company to reduce its depreciation and amortization expenses to $143 million, from about $480 million in December (M)

headline: Conseco to Stick to Insurance In Plan to Leave Bankruptcy
abstract: Conseco Inc, insurance and finance company, files reorganization plan that details its plans to emerge from bankruptcy and maintain its insurance business while selling its consumer finance operations (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Cuba: Crackdown On Drug Production
abstract: Cuban government announces tougher policy on drug abuse and vice including, for first time, acknowledgement of domestically grown drugs, mainly marijuana; prostitution and drug use have seen proportional increase with rise in tourism (S)

headline: A Guide to Navigate Managed Care Fights
abstract: Kaiser Family Foundation and Consumers Union publish state-specific guidelines on their Web sites to help people resolve disputes with their health plans (S)

headline: African Food Shortages Ending Everywhere Except Zimbabwe
abstract: United Nations says number of hungry people is rising in Zimbabwe even as food shortages ease in other parts of southern Africa; says number of people in need of emergency food aid in Zimbabwe has jumped to 7.2 million in Dec; country's government has evicted almost all white commercial farmers; production of corn plunges nearly 70 percent (M)

headline: Bush Gives Hussein 48 Hours, and Vows to Act
abstract: Pres Bush gives Saddam Hussein of Iraq 48 hours to go into exile or face attack from United States and handful of allies; addresses nation hours after he abandons attempts to forge united diplomatic front against Iraq; makes clear that hostilities could begin as soon as two-day ultimatum expires, or sooner if Hussein openly spurns demand from US that he go and take his two sons with him; warns diplomats, aid workers and journalists in Iraq to get out of harm's way immediately; tone and language in 15-minute address suggests he expects nothing but continued defiance from Hussein; speech marks failed end to six months of diplomacy intended to convince skeptical allies like France and Germany, and United Nations Security Council, that weapons inspections have proven ineffective and that only through immediate application of force could Hussein be disarmed; Bush now faces war with only Britain providing substantial military support and many other nations--as well as portion of domestic public opinion--condemning him for what they see as rush to war; president puts US on heightened alert for terrorist reprisals; gives notice to Iraqi people that he will soon begin invasion to liberate them from murderous regime, and issues stark warning to Iraqi military against using chemical and biological weapons or destroying their nation's oil wells; says war criminals will be punished, and that 'the tyrant will soon be gone'; photos (L)

headline: For PC Buying, a New Picture
abstract: Personal computer makers are counting on expanding needs of consumers to stem two years of declining sales; for two decades, sales of PC's were driven by succession of innovations and new operating systems; now, high-peformance applications are transforming computer use and requiring more bells and whistles as well as increased capacity; photos; graphs show ups and downs in market (L)

headline: Partnership Aims At Minorities
abstract: HeadQuarters Advertising, Saeshe Advertising and Walker Marchant Group, ad agencies owned by members of minorities, join Los Angeles office of Hill & Knowlton USA to form partnership called DiversAlliance to collaborate on client services and business development (S)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: ARMENIA: Fraud Charged After Election; RUSSIA: Trying To Win Hearts And Minds; RUSSIA: Putin Says Politics Needs More Women; NORTHERN IRELAND: Seeking A Voice In Ireland; MALTA: European Union Vote Tomorrow;.

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Gas Deposit Found
abstract: Exxon Mobil says it might have discovered Australia's largest offshore gas deposit about 124 miles off country's northwest coast; Jansz field could hold as much as 20 trillion cubic feet of gas (S)

headline: French Diplomat Offers Some Conciliatory Remarks
abstract: Foreign Minister Dominique de Villepin declined to say explicitly who he hoped would win the war for Baghdad.

headline: Guinea's Key U.N. Role Gives It Bargaining Power
abstract: West African country of Guinea holds pivotal presidency of United Nations Security Council, giving it key role in debate over war with Iraq; officially, Guinea has not said which side it will take; Guinean diplomats strenuously deny any material quid pro quo for their votes, although Guinea could use American intervention in speeding debt relief; photo (M)

headline: McDonald's, stung by a loss, summons a high-level meeting to rework its marketing.
abstract: Top executives of McDonald's Corp are anxiously hoping that meeting focused on advertising and marketing, scheduled to begin Feb 4, will generate some sorely needed ideas to help company reverse crippling decline in revenue growth and profit; graph; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
abstract: MOTOROLA SELLS 25 MILLION SHARES OF NEXTEL; 3COM SELLS COMMWORKS UNIT FOR $100 MILLION; ECHOSTAR REPORTS WIDER FOURTH-QUARTER LOSS;.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: A Move To Drop 'London'
abstract: Londonderry (Northern Ireland) City Council passes motion to change city name back to original Derry; London was added by Royal Charter more than 350 years ago and will require Parliament act to be repealed; local authority changed its name to Derry in 1984; unionists oppose change; map (S)

headline: Executive Returning to Chicago
abstract: Executive Returning To Chicago.

headline: Ivory Coast Leader Appoints A Premier After a Peace Deal
abstract: Ivory Coast Pres Laurent Gbagbo formally accepts peace plan to end country's four-month-old civil civil war and appoints new prime minister, Seydou Diarra, to lead reconciliation government (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Judge From 1993 Standoff Returns To Post
abstract: Valery Zorkin, judge whose ruling against Pres Boris N Yeltsin in 1993 helped spark deadly crackdown on rebellious pro-Communist Parliament, gets his old job back, becoming chairman of Russian Constitutional Court for second time (S)

headline: For Sprint Chief, a Hard Fall From Grace
abstract: Critics say Sprint Corp's financial performance in recent years provides justification for board's decision to force ouster of chief executive William T Esrey and president Ronald LeMay, even if their tax shelters had not become targets of Internal Revenue Service inquiry; Sprint spokesman Bill White says Esrey will continue in his position until company succeeds in hiring Gary Forsee, vice chairman of BellSouth and chairman of its Cingular Wireless joint venture with SBC Communications; Esrey's career at Sprint discussed; chart; photos (M)

headline: Kohl's Taps Reality TV In Latest Commercial
abstract: Kohl's will run 'reality' television commercial in which two men propose marriage to their girlfriends on camera (S)

headline: Russia Orders a New Trial In Chechnya Murder Case
abstract: Russian Supreme Court, in victory for family of slain woman Elza Kungayeva, rejects verdict in murder trial of prominent army Col Yuri Budanov and rules that military court ignored procedure; Budanov, decorated army commander, had admitted strangling 18-year-old Chechen woman after abducting her in March 2000 but claims he killed her in fit of rage; military court had declared that Budanov was temporarily insane at time of killing; he will stand trial again before new judge (M)

headline: HOME DEPOT WILL COMBINE 2 REGIONAL DIVISIONS
abstract: Home Depot said yesterday that it would combine its New England and Eastern divisions to reduce costs. The expanded Eastern division, based in Atlanta, will oversee more than 600 stores with 110,000 employees, the company said. Merchandising and support operations will move to South Plainfield, N.J., from Canton, Mass. Home Depot decided on the consolidation after successfully combining its Southeast and Mid-Atlantic divisions last year. The combination will not hurt earnings, cause store closings or cut jobs, Home Depot said. The company also said it would open 10 stores in New England, creating 2,000 jobs.

headline: Weather Grounds Copters
abstract: Punishing sandstorm grounds attack helicopters of 101st Airborne Division; forecasters expect it will take 12 hours for visibility to return to normal after winds abate; waiting has given leaders of division time to rethink battle plan, now that helicopters prove to be vulnerable to Iraqi fire power (M)

headline: Wal-Mart Says Sales to Meet Forecast
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores says demand for spring merchandise and food is helping March sales to rise within its forecast, while J C Penney Co says sales at its department stores are falling more than planned (S)

headline: Chicago Exchange Starts Campaign
abstract: Chicago Exchange Starts Campaign The Chicago Mercantile Exchange has started brand image advertising, a month after its initial public offering.

headline: At Least Those 401(k)'s Beat the Stock Market
abstract: Vanguard Group study finds 401(k) investors had smaller losses than overall stock market in 2002; credits diversification, noting gains most 401(k) investors had on their fixed-income investments partially offset stock market losses; average 401(k) lost 13.3 percent in 2002, compared with 22.1 percent drop in Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, including reinvested dividends (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Five Illegal Migrants Drown
abstract: Five North Africans drown when small rubber boat carrying at least 40 people sinks off southern Spanish coast; several reach shore and evade capture, while 27 are arrested (S)

headline: Sibling Cities Issue a Plea For Decency Toward Frites
abstract: Campaign to promote French-American friendliness amid disagreements over looming war with Iraq is being promoted by cities of Aix-en-Provence and sister city in Coral Gables, Fla; described; both cities issue proclamation urging both nations to recognize 'inherent decency of mankind' (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Bank's Profit Slips
abstract: Dutch financial services and banking concern ING says fourth-quarter profit fell 2.7 percent from period year earlier, to 922 million euros ($998 million); photo (S)

headline: A Dead End for Afghan Children Adrift in Pakistan
abstract: Tens of thousands, possibly hundreds of thousands, of child laborers, often refugees from Afghanistan, toil in garbage dumps, textile factories and food markets across Pakistan; for many of them there is only one way out: Islamic religious schools; so-called madrasas take in many children with promises of free food, clothing, education and, most of all, escape; squalid workplaces are prime recruiting areas for schools that United States has described as potential breeding grounds for Islamic militancy; estimated 10,000 madrasas with 1 million to 1.7 million students are believed to exist across Pakistan; majority are operated by hard-line Deobandi sect whose madrasas was birthplace of Taliban; Pakistani officials say they are doing their best to regulate madrasas and curb poverty that makes them so attractive; say they need more economic aid from US and other Western countries to do so; photo; map (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: TURKEY: Change Opens Door For Popular Politician; BOSNIA: U.N. Cedes Police Role To Europe; BRITAIN: Deal On London Tube Overhaul; ITALY: Volcano Aftermath On Isle; FRANCE: Effects Of Spanish Spill;.

headline: West Coast Law Firm Closing After Dot-Com Collapse
abstract: Partners at San Francisco law firm Brobeck, Phleger & Harrison wind down firm, bringing to end 77-year-old Bay Area institution that rose flamboyantly and rapidly on Internet boom; decision comes after efforts to merge with law firm Morgan Lewis & Bockius fail; firm may not technically dissolve even though it may cease operating as single unit as its lawyers leave (M)

headline: Asian Medics Stay Home, Imperiling Respiratory Patients
abstract: World Health Orgn officials say care of many patients with mysterious respiratory illness called severe acute respiratory syndrome is being seriously jeopardized because nurses and other health care workers are staying away from their jobs out of fear of getting sick themselves; say some hospitals in Vietnam and Hong Kong are working with half usual staff, raising fears that inadequate care will contribute to further spread of disease; federal health officials report 13 suspected cases in US, including two in New York City; patients had recently traveled to Hong Kong or to Guangdong Province in China, where outbreak appears to have begun last Nov; photo (M)

headline: Stop Rewarding Litigious Behavior
abstract: Richard J Yoder letter responds to Dec 15 The Right Thing article by suggesting punitive damages awards go to part of society whose laws have been broken rather than to plaintiffs

headline: Your Taxes; College Savings Plans: You'll Need a Scorecard
abstract: Parents looking to reduce their tax bills and save for college face bewildering array of investment options and tax credits, each with different set of regulations ad income restrictions, and options will change again if Congress approves Bush administration's proposed Lifetime Savings Accounts; photo (M)

headline: There's More to Trading Oil Than Handicapping a War
abstract: Lagging prices of oil company stocks despite rising prices and profits discussed; graph (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Phone Outlook Lowered
abstract: World Bu

headline: Credit Suisse Deal Is Seen
abstract: Credit Suisse First Boston is close

headline: Webdenda
abstract: Nick Bilton was named senior creative at Powell , New York, the top creative post at the agency. He had been creative director at Lowe & Partners Worldwide, New York, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Leo Burnett USA , Chicago, promoted four employees to vice presidents. They are: Eduardo Alvarez , associate director for data base marketing; David Brot , account director; Sara Fitzgibbons Norgle , account supervisor; and Birgit Wendt , group account director. Burnett is part of the Leo Burnett Worldwide unit of the Publicis Groupe. California Pizza Kitchen , Los Angeles, which operates 149 restaurants, named Grant, Scott & Hurley , San Francisco, to handle some creative duties on its account along with media planning and buying. Media duties had been handled by Brand Forbes, Dallas, part of Havas, while creative duties had been handled by various agencies on a project basis. Billings have not been determined. CFM Direct, King of Prussia , Pa., promoted two employees. Lisa Freeman , senior account director, was named vice president for client relations. And Andrew Surden , senior account executive, was named account supervisor. Carrie Cook was named to the new post of vice president and director for event marketing at Hill, Holliday, Connors , Cosmopulos, Boston. She had been senior producer at ABC News, New York, part of the ABC network owned by the Walt Disney Company. Hill, Holliday is part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Dentsu , Tokyo, is closing Dentsu Fuse , an Internet consulting division, effective on March 31, citing large financial losses. Elwanda Edwards , group account director at the Tracy Locke Partnership , Dallas, was named partner. Tracy Locke is part of the Omnicom Group. EPI USA , Fremont, Calif., a maker of computer monitors, named Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners West , San Francisco, as agency of record for the company's AOC and Envision brands, which had been handled internally. Billings were estimated at less than $1 million. Kirshenbaum Bond West is part of Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners, a division of the Kirshenbaum Bond Creative Network.

headline: Ridge Says Warning Levels Might Be Lowered in Days
abstract: Homeland Security Dept Sec Tom Ridge says heightened alert level warning of possible terrorist attacks might be lowered in coming days, depending on assessments of threats received by government; threat level, which was raised on Feb 7, is currently at orange, second highest category; officials remain concerned about possible threats to New York and Washington; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Bank Profit Falls
abstract: Commonwealth Bank of Australia says first-half profit fell 48 percent; net income fell to 622 million Australian dollars ($368 million) in six months through Dec 31, from 1.2 billion Australian dollars year earlier (S)

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: ARGENTINA: President Seeks Election Monitors; HAITI: Report On Rights Violations;.

headline: Warner Video Names Chief
abstract: Warner Brothers names James Cardwell president of home video unit, succeeding Warren Lieberfarb, who resigned in December (S)

headline: Comcast's Second-Generation No. 2
abstract: Profile of Stephen B Burke, president of cable unit of Comcast, who is content to be No. 2 to chief executive Brian L Roberts; Burke cannot hope to ever run company since Roberts family still controls third of company's voting interest; Burke's role is much like one his father, Daniel B Burke, had as right-hand man to Thomas S Murphy at Capital Cities/ABC; photos (M)

headline: Toyota Says Profits Nearly Doubled in Last Quarter of 2002
abstract: Toyota said profits nearly doubled in the last quarter of 2002 as Japan's largest automaker continues to solidify its share of the global car market.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: US Airways Chief Weighs Post-Bankruptcy Strategy  Although US Airways plans to emerge from bankruptcy today, it still needs to cut costs and consider retooling how it makes money, given the bleak market for air travel and the war with Iraq, the company's chief executive said.    American Airlines, which is struggling to stay out of bankruptcy court, said yesterday that it had reached tentative agreements on labor concessions with six small work groups in its largest union, the Transport Workers Union. [Page C2.]
