headline: World Briefing | Europe: Cyprus: Demonstrators Want Peace Deal
abstract: Turkish Cypriots demonstrate in Nicosia in hopes of influencing leader Rauf Denktash to accept agreement for unified Cyprus; country has been divided since 1974 and Turkish north's entrance into European Union is at risk if island is not reunited (S)

headline: BLACKBIRD CHIEF TO OVERSEE FANNIE MAE AND FREDDIE MAC
abstract: Pres Bush intends to nominate Mark C Brickell to succeed Armando Falcon Jr as chief regulator of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac (S)

headline: Genzyme Outlook Clouded
abstract: Genzyme Corp says profit for 2003 will probably be below analysts' expectations; company's shares fall $2.55, to $30.65 (S)

headline: Urgent Mystery at Outset: Was Hussein Hit?
abstract: U.S. officials said that they were not sure which, if any, top Iraqi officials where killed in the first airstrike on Baghdad.

headline: Newspaper Selects Shop for Campaigns
abstract: San Francisco Chronicle names San Francisco office of Foote, Cone & Belding to handle campaign to promote help-wanted ads in newspaper's classified section and on its Web site and campaign to attract readers by promoting content of Chronicle; spending estimated at $2 million (S)

headline: Pentagon Tries to Dampen Expectations of Quick Win
abstract: The Pentagon said today that the war in Iraq was going well, with American and British troops moving deep into the country and closing fast on Baghdad.

headline: A Haitian Survivor Mourns, and Keeps Fighting
abstract: Profile of Michele Montas, longtime critic of government corruption in Haiti, who is now living in exile in New York City; she is still fighting to establish who was behind assassination of her husband, Jean Dominique, in April 2000; he was country's most famous journalist and fiercest critic of corruption, who operated Radio Haiti-Inter; she was forced to silence radio station after someone tried to kill her; photo (M)

headline: Unarmed American Intruder Roils Britain
abstract: The American ruddy duck has been flying around Britain for 50 years but only now is showing its capacity to hit the British where they live.

headline: Some Tax Breaks For Military Service
abstract: Tax breaks for people in military and their families include deferral of taxes owed if new enlistees and reservists called to active duty can show ability to pay is impaired as result of military service; military personnel may also be entitled to exclude combat pay from gross income (M)

headline: Defiance From Baghdad, Troops on the Move, and Security Warnings
abstract: Overview of events around world regarding Iraq on Mar 18 (M)

headline: White House Suggests Budget Deficit May Set a Record and Exceed $300 Billion
abstract: White House officials suggested today that the federal budget deficit could surpass $300 billion this year, setting a record as President Bush pushes plans for big tax cuts and new spending for the military and homeland security.    Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, told the Reuters news service that the deficit could hit 3 percent of gross domestic product, which would put the deficit above $300 billion.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Bids For Oil Company
abstract: Formal expressions of interest in bidding for one-third stake in Hindustan Petroleum were filed by 12 companies by deadline March 17; ChevronTexaco, BP, Exxon Mobil, Royal Dutch/Shell, Petronas and Saudi Aramco were among foreign oil companies making initial bids; Indian conglomerate Essar also made bid (S)

headline: As Darkness Falls, Marines Pour Across Border Into Iraq
abstract: The ground war against Iraq kicked off tonight as United States marines, backed by heavy air strikes and artillery, surged across the border in darkness.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Americans Closing Guest Ranch
abstract: American owners of popular guest ranch in southern Mexican state of Chiapas say they are closing it to tourists because of violent intimidation by Zapatista members of neighboring community; owners, Ellen Jones and Glen Wersch, are former Peace Corps workers who have operated their Rancho Esmeralda for eight years; they say staff members have been focus of death threats by Zapatistas, who contend that ranch rightfully belongs to them (S)

headline: Gene tools root out truffle fraud
abstract: PARIS:—  A French research laboratory has unraveled the genetic code of the famed black truffles from the Perigord region, finally giving anti-fraud inspectors a tool to distinguish between the pricey French fungus and a Chinese competitor that looks identical but tastes insipid.

headline: United Seeks More Time To File Plan
abstract: United Airlines asks bankruptcy judge for six more months to file its restructuring plan, saying it needs additional time to sort out complexities of strategy that will include new low-fare carrier and significant cuts in wages and benefits for its employees; UAL Corp, parent of United, now faces April 8 deadline for submitting its proposal; company will have until Oct 6 to make its filing if judge approves; extra time would give United chance to gauge consequences of any war with Iraq on airline industry; Air Transportation Association, which represents major carriers, says long conflict in Iraq could prompt industry to cut 70,000 more jobs, on top of 100,000 lost since Sept 11 terrorist attacks in 2001; says several carriers could be forced into bankruptcy; predicts travel will fall by 15 percent if war lasts for three months, resulting in job losses and reduction of 2,200 flights; association president James C May comments; photo (M)

headline: Germany's Military Sinking to 'Basket Case' Status
abstract: Germany, once America's strongest military ally, is now one of worst military laggards in North Atlantic Treaty Orgn; its aging war apparatus was designed to fight Soviet Union in tank war that never came; successive German administrations have failed to modernize, citing cost of absorbing former Communist East Germany and other economic constraints; United States has urged Germany and other NATO allies to transform their traditionally static armed forces into high-tech, mobile services that can better share task of policing world; United States spends 3.3 percent of its gross domestic product on its armed forces, while Germany's military spending last year totaled just 1.5 percent of GDP; with no obvious enemy threatening Germany security, German population has no desire for more military spending; that could change if US, as some Americans are suggesting, sharply reduces its presence in Germany, redeploying troops farther east in Europe; graph (M)

headline: After Weeks of Avoiding a Stand, Japan Says It Will Back the U.S. Resolution on Iraq
abstract: Japan's decision to back new United Nations resolution on Iraq sought by United State follows weeks of fence-sitting, marked by almost no public debate; coincides with first large antiwar protest, Tokyo; ex-Min Makiko Tanaka's criticism of government's failure to discuss stand publicly and her call for Japan to urge US patience gets no press coverage and stirs no reaction (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft To Invest $2 Billion In Programs
abstract: Microsoft Corp will invest $2 billion in next fiscal year to sell programs to companies with fewer than 500 workers; names top sales executive Orlando Ayala to lead new group selling software (S)

headline: Kabul Journal; The Afghan Elvis 'Lives' 24 Years After His Death
abstract: Efforts are under way to restore grave of Ahmad Zahir, Afghanistan's most beloved pop musician; he has been dead 24 years but his legend has magnified over years, even as Taliban destroyed monument to him; his songs recall freer prewar Afghanistan, far less ethnically polarized than it is today; he won fans in all ethnic groups; his sister Zahira Zahir says he was killed by Afghan Communists, who objected to song he sang that suggested Afghanistan was living in slavery; photos (M)

headline: Company Man to the End, After All
abstract: Review of former Enron chairman and chief executive Kenneth L Lay's personal records and interviews with his financial advisers and other witnesses show Lay, pilloried in media for allegedly secretly unloading much of his own stake while urging employees in summer of 2001 to buy Enron stock, retained his faith in company virtually until its collapse; data seem to transform case of what appeared to be criminal insider trading into more complex mosaic of hubris and financial recklessness; Lay, forced by margin calls, sold almost $100 million worth of Enron shares in 2001, but went to great lengths to hang onto Enron shares, even as debacle unfolded; graphs; chronology of events; photos (M)

headline: Alcoa and Iceland Agree on Smelter Project
abstract: Alco

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  Existing-Home Sales: Dec.    TUESDAY  Durable Goods Orders: Dec.  Consumer Confidence: Jan.  New-Home Sales: Dec.  Prices of New Homes: Dec.

headline: With Militant Group Routed, American and Kurdish Forces Hunt for Clues About Al Qaeda
abstract: Ansar al-Islam, militant group that Sec of State Colin Powell has described as link between Baghdad and Al Qaeda, is destroyed as military force in coordinated ground attack by Kurdish fighters and American Special Forces soldiers; more than 250 fighters are thought to have been killed; officials say Ansar compound yields large haul of raw intelligence and evidence of manufacture of ricin, poison made from castor beans; photos (M)

headline: Tyco, After the Glitter and the Agile Math
abstract: Analysis of outlook for Tyco International without the accounting gimmickry; Edward D Breen, chief executive, acknowledges that company is not fast-growth, high-margin collection of assets that fomer chief executive L Dennis Kozlowski touted; new Tyco, though still viable, is what skeptics always thought it was: hodgepodge of consistently profitable but unconnected, slow-growth businesses that produce things as diverse as surgical gear and home-security systems (M)

headline: Trying to Sweeten a Bitter Pill By Getting More Severance Pay
abstract: Some employers will extend benefits or give better severance deal to employees being laid off if they can demonstrate need; photo (M)

headline: Parsons Seen Topping List To Be New AOL Chairman
abstract: AOL Time Warner chief executive Richard D Parsons is emerging as most likely successor to chairman Stephen M Case, who is stepping down in May (M)

headline: Shifting the Burden of Funding Pensions
abstract: Bush administration's proposals for retirement savings accounts are consistent with its philosophy that capital should not be taxed; Council of Economic Advisers chairman Glenn Hubbard similarly favors scrapping estate tax and doing away with taxes on dividends if corporations have already paid taxes on money; administration's beliefs about taxes and saving for retirement could have far-reaching implications for such cherished features of middle-class life as company pension and Social Security system; proposals would shift pension burden to individual workers; White House theorists suggest that if Americans have chance to discover pleasures of tax-free investment withdrawals, they will buy into its broader ideology of individual self-reliance; critics say new savings accounts would favor rich and hamper government's ability to collect taxes in future; Dallas Salisbury, president of Employee Benefit Research Institute, and Lawrence B Lindsey, former White House economic policy adviser, comment; chart; photos (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.25   4.25   4.75       Discount rate   0.75   0.75   1.50       Federal funds   1.25   1.31   1.81       3-month T-bills   1.14   1.16   1.66       6-month T-bills   1.16   1.19   1.73       10-yr. headline: Micron Shares Jump on Sales Report
abstract: Shares of Micron Technology rise 11 per

headline: PRESIDENT READIES U.S. FOR PROSPECT OF IMMINENT WAR
abstract: Pres Bush, in rare prime-time news conference, prepares country for possibly imminent military action against Iraq; says Saddam Hussein poses direct threat to security of United States and insists 'we really don't need anybody's permission' to defend US; says only days remain for diplomatic solution and vows that he will press for vote on new resolution at United Nations in next few days, even if it appears he could not muster majority 9 of 15 votes on Security Council, and despite French and Russian threat of veto; says these problems will not deter him from disarming Hussein; hints that he might agree to some kind of deadline for Hussein, as British have proposed; portrays himself as protector of country and repeatedly invokes Sept 11 terrorist attacks, saying Hussein poses comparable danger; tries again to link Iraq to terrorists; repeatedly states that Iraq has failed to disarm; appears determined to pre-empt March 7 report by Hans Blix, chief arms inspector, who is expected to say Hussein is finally destroying some of his weapons and that inspectors need more time to complete their job; Bush portrays Iraq as most urgent threat, while referring to North Korea's drive to produce nuclear weapons in coming months as 'regional issue'; urges China, Russia, Japan and South Korea to join in pressuring North; despite mounting criticism of his refusal to hold direct talks with North, he says he will not change course; photos (L)

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: PERU: President Seeks New Antiterror Powers; CUBA: No Letup On Opposition; CHILE: Ex-Aide To President Faces Bribe Charge;.

headline: Troubles in U.S. for Irish Drug Maker
abstract: Irish drug company Elan's sale of $850 million worth of drugs and other assets to King Pharmaceuticals may be in jeopardy; King says it has 'serious concerns' about consummating deal because Federal Trade Commission investigation concerning Elan's muscle relaxant drug Skelaxin and insomnia drug Sonata; Elan's shareholders approve sale in special meeting, Dublin; Elan chairman Dr Garo H Armen comments; photo (M)

headline: U.S. question:with us, or against us?: Issue in sharp focus
abstract: PARIS:—  The United States' effort at documenting Iraq as a seething threat to humanity went so far in its presentation of damning evidence and intention that, whatever the world's reaction, it leaves American leadership in a place from which it is difficult to return.

headline: W.T.O. Rules Against U.S. On Steel Tariff
abstract: World Trade Organization rules steel tariffs imposed by Pres Bush last year are illegal; administration will appeal decision; European and other nations could impose trade sanctions of comparable value against US if US loses when final report is released in April; case against tariffs was brought by European Union, which accused US of illegally protecting steel industry; European Union's trade commissioner Pascal Lamy calls traiffs 'unjustified, highly protectionist US measures'; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; WorldCom Report Adds to the Size Of Its Sales Drop
abstract: Internal WorldCom spreadsheet shows that sales at five of its important divisions dropped far faster in second half of 2002 than company reported publicly, plummeting after company disclosed major accounting scandal in June and filed for bankruptcy protection in July; does not track overall revenue for divisions, but rather monthly value of their new business, thus indicating that new business in WorldCom's revenue pipeline has dwindled considerably--with negative implications for revenue; graph (M)

headline: Keep the Cameras On
abstract: The Boss column by Louis Rukeyser, host of Louis Rukeyser's Wall Street on CNBC, on his career; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Wider Use For Novartis Drug
abstract: World Business Briefing: Switzerland: Wider Use For Novar

headline: 1.5 Million Demonstrators In Cities Across Europe Oppose a War Against Iraq
abstract: More than 1.5 million Europeans, from parks of London to piazzas of Rome and avenues of Paris and Berlin, march in huge protest against war in Iraq; it is Continent's biggest coordinated peace demonstration in memory and leaves many protesters jubilant at show of antiwar sentiment; photo (M)

headline: Marines Meet Potent Enemy In Deadly Fight
abstract: Allied forces meet stiff resistance from regular Iraqi soldiers and guerrillas near Nasiriya on March 23 in deadliest fighting of war; at least 10 marines die and dozens are wounded in clash with pockets of Iraqi infantry and bands of guerrillas known as Martyrs of Saddam while trying to secure bridges and retrieve wounded Army soldiers, left stranded after about dozen members of unit were killed or captured after making wrong turn while trying to skirt city before dawn; photos (M)

headline: UNILEVER REDUCES FORECAST OF GAIN FOR QUARTER
abstract: Unilever expects 5 percent gain in first-quarter profit, less than analysts expected (S)

headline: In an F-18, Five Seconds From a Deck Veiled by a Sandstorm
abstract: Pilots describe hair-raising landings during storm as they return to USS Abraham Lincoln, aircraft carrier stationed in Persian Gulf, from afternoon mission supporting ground troops around Baghdad; photos (M)

headline: Turkey Declares Intention to Back U.S. War Plans
abstract: Turkey's prime minister said today that his government would ask parliament later this month to allow U.S. troops to use the country in event of a war with Iraq.

headline: Champion Mortgage Seeks New Agency
abstract: Champion Mortgage Co is placing its $20 million ad account in review after parting ways with Martin Agency (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Shell's Profit Rises
abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell Group says fourth-quarter earnings rose 46 percent, to $2.78 billion; annual earnings were down 23 percent, to $9.2 billion; plans to sell some onshore oil pipelines and storage tanks in US (S)

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS for DAVID H. DIESSLIN; No Need to Stand Still In Uncertain Times
abstract: Interview with financial adviser David H Diesslin on personal financial strategies consumers should consider in light of war in Iraq to minimize any difficulties ahead; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.25   4.25   4.75       Discount rate   0.75   0.75   1.50       Federal funds   1.25   1.29   1.71       3-month T-bills   1.17   1.18   1.54       6-month T-bills   1.21   1.23   1.57       10-yr. T-infl.   2.37   2.38   3.36       10-yr. T-note   4.14   4.17   4.86       30-yr. T-bond   5.05   5.07   5.37       Telephone bd.   6.21   6.21   7.43       Municipal bds.   5.14   5.15   5.32          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Tries To Strengthen Position
abstract: Microsoft Corp, in bid to secure central place in new gadgets that are increasingly preferred platform for digital media, says it will license its Windows Media technology to consumer electronics makers at lower prices and for better terms than its main competitors do (S)

headline: TOP IRAQI ADVISER SAYS HE BELIEVES WAR IS INEVITABLE
abstract: Gen Amir al-Saadi, top science adviser to Saddam Hussein, says he fears United States attack might now be inevitable regardless of what United Nations weapons inspectors conclude about last two months of renewed searches for weapons of mass destruction in Iraq; Secretary of State Colin L Powell warns reluctant allies not to shrink from strike on Iraq; says burden is on Iraq to comply, or it will be made to comply with military force; says no decision on using force would be made before Pres Bush meets Prime Min Tony Blair of Britain on Jan 31; in Iraq, at least three more Iraqi weapons specialists refuse to be interviewd in private by UN inspectors; earlier in week six other scientists refused to speak to inspectors outside presence of Iraqi government officials; Bush administration has pointed to this as further evidence that Hussein is trying to undermine inspection process; Deputy Defense Sec Paul D Wolfowitz says Washington has evidence that Iraq has threatened to kill scientists and their families if they cooperate with UN inspectors; Iraq claims it cannot force scientists to speak; photos (M)

headline: G.I. Hunt For Qaeda Intensifies
abstract: About 1,000 American troops, backed by attack helicopters, mount dawn assault on string of mountain villages and caves in southeastern Afghanistan, sending forceful message that search for Al Qaeda members will not slacken as war in Iraq gets under way; Osama bin Laden and Taliban leader Mullah Muhammad Omar and many of his senior commanders remain at large, and are rumored to be staying in tribal areas of Pakistan along Afghan border (M)

headline: Honeywell Posts a $1.4 Billion 4th-Quarter Loss
abstract: Honeywell International says it had $1.47 billion fourth-quarter loss as it settled asbestos claims and profit from airplane parts and automated controls declined; sales rose less than 1 percent, to $5.86 billion (S)

headline: Take 2 for Delta and Its Low-Cost Carrier
abstract: Delta Air Lines said yesterday that its new low-cost carrier, Song, would start service on April 15 by flying between New York and West Palm Beach, Fla.    Service will gradually expand until November, Delta said, when Song will be operating 144 daily flights with a fleet of 36 Boeing 757's that connect three Northeast cities and Washington with five Florida cities. Executives said the airline's fares would compete with those of other low-cost carriers and that passengers would be asked to pay extra for optional food and entertainment, like limited access to the Internet.

headline: THREATS AND RESPONSES: THE SCENE -- Berlin; New German Unity At Old Dividing Line
abstract: Estimated 500,000 antiwar protesters gather at Brandenburg Gate, Berlin, to protest likelihood of American-led war in Iraq; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Protestant Group Upset
abstract: Northern Ireland Protestant paramilitary group Ulster Volunteer Force withdraws from international peace accord facilitator because its members are angered by Britain's snubbing them and devoting attention to Irish Republican Army's Sinn Fein party (S)

headline: Gunmen Kill 7 Shiite Worshipers in Pakistan
abstract: Gunmen open fire on Shiite mosque in Karachi, Pakistan, killing at least seven worshipers; Shiite leader says shooting may have been linked to approach of Islamic month of Muharram, which Shiites observe as month of mourning; suspicions fall on Laskhar-e-Jahngvi, militant Sunni group; photo (M)

headline: Today's Lesson, Class, Is This: Ethics Really Matter in Business
abstract: Today's Lesson, Class, Is This: Ethics Really Matter in Business.

headline: Ex-Aide to Mao Urges China to Move Toward Democracy
abstract: A onetime secretary to Mao Zedong has published a sweeping call for political change in a Beijing magazine.

headline: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Vical Shares Soar On Vaccine News
abstract: TeØ

headline: AT&T's Gloom Shows the Sector Is Still Flagging
abstract: Shares of AT&T Corp plunge 19.1 percent after company says it does not expect dismal telecommunications market to improve significantly in 2003; reports revenue in its consumer unit fell to $2.7 billion in fourth quarter, down 20 percent from year ago; consumer revenue fell by 22.3 percent, to $11.5 billion, for all of 2002; reports loss from continuing operations of $611 million compared with loss of $216 million year ago; overall revenue dropped to $9.3 billion, down 8.6 percent from about $10.2 billion in comparable quarter last year; David W Dorman makes his first financial report as chairman-chief executive; photo (M)

headline: Strong Reservations, Most Aimed at Bush
abstract: President Bush's ultimatum to Saddam Hussein and the approach of war prompted strong reaction abroad.

headline: Automated Avatars Take the Strain Out of Animation
abstract: Software developers are working on tools to make animation cheaper, more automated and less of drain on processing power; Moving Picture Experts Group has published specification for facial and body animation that developers can adhere to; drawing (M)

headline: Robben Island Journal; With Vivid Palette, Mandela Depicts the Jailhouse Years
abstract: Robben Island Journal on drawings Nelson Mandela has made depicting his memories of 18-year imprisonment on bleak South African prison island; photos; works are auctioned on Robben Island, now tourist attraction, to raise money for charity; 84-year-old Mandela, who worked with art tutor, talks about life on island and reminisces about growing up as shepherd boy in rural Eastern Cape province (M)

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Chelsea; Sailors, Runaways and Now, Bicoastal Hoteliers
abstract: Portholed Chelsea building, designed in 1960's for National Maritime Union and later teenagers' shelter operated by Covenant House, is to be redeveloped as Maritime Hotel; building was bought in 2001 by Sean K MacPherson and Eric Goode for $19 million; hotel developers are Richard Born and Ira Drukier; photo (M)

headline: CNN Cancels Her Program, And Chung Quits Network
abstract: CNN tells Connie Chung, one of its most prominent anchors, that it has dropped her prime-time program, effective immediately; Chung declines offer to stay with network in some other capacity; Chung joined CNN last summer; Chung's program Connie Chung Tonight has been suspended for coverage of war with Iraq; Chung has contract, worth about $2 billion per year, that has more than year left; Chung associate says Chung is shocked and extremely disappointed; photo (M)

headline: Novartis's Stake in Roche Fuels Merger Speculation
abstract: Novartis says it has accumulated enough stock in rival Roche Group to control 32.7 percent of voting rights in company; announcement touches off speculation that Novartis is pressing Roche's founding family to agree to merge companies and create world's second-largest pharmaceutical maker; Roche spokesman Daniel Piller says Oeri and Hoffmann families, who hold slight majority of voting rights in Roche, have no intention of selling; Novartis's chairman-chief executive Daniel Vasella says company has no plans to pursue hostile takeover; says $2.1 billion that Novartis spent last year buying Roche stock is long-term investment; photo (M)

headline: NATO Secretary General to Leave His Post in December After 4 Years
abstract: Lord Robertson says he will step down as NATO secretary general in December, resisting requests by many members to stay on for another year (M)

headline: China Cracks Down on Protests After Sending Dissident to U.S.
abstract: Chinese authorities intensify efforts to suppress protesters in country's restive northeast, just week after releasing Xu Wenli, country's most prominent political prisoner, and sending him to United States; police charge two leaders of worker demonstrations in city of Liaoyang with subversion, crime that carries death penalty, after they organize protests to focus attention on workers' interests; China's decision to release Xu, who has pushed for greter democracy in China since late 1970's and has spent 16 of past 21 years in prison, was greeted as significant concession to US and Western critics of its human rights record; but Western rights groups warned that releases of prominent dissidents are mixed blessing, often leading to fresh crackdowns on less-well-known protesters (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Chávez Rejects Early Election
abstract: Pres Hugo Chavez rejects proposal by opposition movement for constitutional amendment that would shorten president's term and lead to new elections in Venezuela (S)

headline: E-Commerce Report; In the world of Internet sites that cost money, fantasy sports games have found eager players.
abstract: Sports fantasy sites find that fans are quite willing to pay to play; online players typically create teams from among roster of major sports leagues, principally football, hoping to win prizes from Web site if their choices perform better than those of opponents; photo (M)

headline: Harmless or Not, You Can't Be Sure
abstract: Makeshift barbed wire enclosures ring Nasiriya, holding more than 100 prisoners after four days of fighting that have left American forces with tenuous hold on city; many are low-priority detainees, probabaly refugees or farmers, possibly soldiers who have deserted; they are probably harmless, but they must first be questioned; marines note fighters have dressed as civilians trying to surrender, and have hidden weapons all over town; as result, all civilians around Nasiriya are suspect; some of those held were captured in heat of battle, but most simply walked up to Marine units carrying white flags; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Terror Trial To Proceed
abstract: Dublin court denys request by Real IRA leader Michael McKevitt currently awaiting trial on terrorism charges; request, refused on legal technicality, was for defense access to documents outlining involvement and background of FBI informer David Rupert, whose information led to McKevitt's arrest and now posssible conviction; Republican guerrilla group Real IRA was responsible for 1998 car bombing in Omagh, Northern Ireland, which killed 29 people and injured dozens more (S)

headline: Business; Auto Sales Are Down. Punish the Parts Makers.
abstract: Dim outlook for auto parts makers and their stocks discussed in light of plans by Ford Motor and General Motors to cut output; Delphi, by far industry leader, is trying to expand its customer base beyond GM, its former owner and still source of 60 percent of its sales; Delphi, Lear Corp and others are also moving to build more elaborate and more expensive components rather than parts; income graphs of industry leaders; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Insurer To Cut Jobs
abstract: Assicurazioni Generali, Italy's largest insurance company, plans to cut 2,800 jobs, about 5 percent of its work force, after suffering undisclosed losses in 2002; graph (S)

headline: Cap Gemini in Account Review
abstract: Cap Gemini In Account Review.

headline: Microsoft Loosens Apple's Hold on Schools
abstract: Apple Computer, formerly undisputed leader in sales of personal computers to schools, has steadily lost ground over years to lower-priced PC's that run Microsoft Windows software; Apple faces another threat in education market: proposed class-action legal settlement by Microsoft could result in donation of hundreds of millions of dollars of Microsoft software to needy schools throughout Calif; Apple's position is that deal to resolve Calif consumers' lawsuit would let Microsoft off easily by giving some of money back to company, and would turn what should have been punishment for anticompetitive behavior into means for Microsoft to build bigger share of state's school software market; Microsoft, which is determined to secure deal and avoid another prolonged legal battle, is negotiating to try to make arrangement more palatable to Apple; research analyst says despite snags in this case, tying legal settlements to donations of products and services is becomingincreasingly common in computer industry; photo; graphs (M)

headline: With Its Nuances, Iraq Report Can't Resolve U.N. Stalemate
abstract: European analysts and political figures say that if United Nations inspectors have a little bit for everybody in their reports, they do not have enough of anything to resolve stalemate in Security Council (M)

headline: Van Wagner Buys Viacom Outdoor Unit
abstract: Van Wagner Communications acquires New York City telephone kiosk ad business of Viacom Outdoor; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: BARR LABORATORIES SEES HIGHER-THAN-EXPECTED PROFIT
abstract: Barr Laboratories Inc says it will have profit of $3.85 to $3.95 per share for fiscal year ending in June, higher than company's previous forecast (S)

headline: Got a Minute? See Six Films Or Make One of Your Own
abstract: Ten-second videos are brainchild of David Wild; genre has inspired contest and winning entries will be posted online; photo (M)

headline: A Friendship Sundered by Muslim Code of Honor
abstract: Profile of Norma Khouri, activist seeking to bring international pressure on Jordan to remove laws that effectively let men kill wives, sisters and daughters for perceived breaches of chastity; thousands of women in Muslim nations are believed to die at hands of relatives each year in honor killings; Khouri, who fled Jordan and lives in hiding in Australia, comments, interview; photo (M)

headline: Troops Endure Blowing Sands And Mud Rain
abstract: Troops in Iraqi desert are hit with sandstorm and winds of more than 50 miles per hour, and then by pelting mud, all in temperatures near 100 degrees that hinder troops garbed in protective suits, body armor and helmets; photos; sandstorm of 'biblical' proportions grounds helicopters and causes long delays for convoys headed toward Baghdad; photos (M)

headline: Two Blasts Jolt Beijing Campuses, Leaving 9 People Hurt
abstract: The closely spaced explosions, which appeared to be caused by homemade bombs, ripped through canteens at two of China's most prominent universities around lunchtime today.

headline: Comments by Donald Rumsfeld on 'This Week'
abstract: Following is a transcript of an interview with Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld on ABC'S "This Week" on Sunday, as provided by the Federal News Service

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Adobe Imposes Limit On Insiders' Share Sales
abstract: Adobe Systems Inc is forcing directors and officers to hold for two years at least 25 percent of shares they get from exercising options; also urges shareholders to reject investor proposal to force executives to hold 75 percent of such shares; AFSCME Pension Plan, which owns 2,747 shares, has said its proposal would prevent executives from cashing out 'before the effects of their mismanagement' become apparent (S)

headline: Fight Looms Over Who Bears the Biggest Tax Burden
abstract: Battling looming over Pres Bush's $674 billion plan to reduce taxes centers on who actually bears tax burden in America and who should; White House and Republican lawmakers say tax system places hugely disproportionate burden on rich; note Internal Revenue data show top one percent of taxpayers pay staggering 37 percent of all federal income taxes; contend bottom 50 percent of taxpayers pay little or nothing; many working poor people get money back, thanks to expansion of recent years of tax breaks like child tax credit; Democratic lawmakers and other critics say argument is wrong because it fails to take into account impact of payroll taxes for Social Security and Medicare; those taxes account for almost as much as federal income tax revenue, but they hit middle-income and lower-income workers much more heavily than rich; Citizens for Tax Justice estimates wealthiest 1 percent of taxpayers earned about 18 percent of all income in 2001 and paid about 25 percent of all federal taxes; graphs (M)

headline: Trying to Walk the Line Between Fear and Ridicule
abstract: News analysis of Bush administration's effort to strike right balance in communicating to public what it believes is appropriate level of concern about terrorist threats, and what response to take; Homeland Security Sec Tom Ridge's color-coding of terror threats and his recent advice to buy duct tape and plastic sheeting quickly became fodder for parody and ridicule (M)

headline: Threat of Iraq War Draws World Leaders, With Different Views, to the Pope's Door
abstract: World leaders seek audience with Pope John Paul II as prospect of American-led military strike against Iraq looms ever larger, appealing to his power to sway international opinion and power of visit to reflect well on their own positions; Joschka Fischer, German foreign minister, and Tarik Aziz, deputy prime minister of Iraq, have already come, and Prime Min Tony Blair of Britain is scheduled to; pope has repeatedly stated his opposition to a war in Iraq under current circumstances (M)

headline: International Briefs | Asia: Japan: Stock Loss At Bank
abstract: Japan's Sumitomo Trust and Banking Co says losses on its stockholdings grew by 64 percent in fourth quarter of 2002, to create paper loss of 193.6 billion yen ($1.6 billion) (S)

headline: Baghdad Bombing, A Northern Victory and Differing Accounts of the War
abstract: Daily summary of events in Iraq war, Mar 28 (M)

headline: Europe Scrutinizing Deals Studios Make With Pay TV
abstract: European Commission antitrust officials are investigating broadcast-rights deals between Hollywood film studios and some European subscription TV companies; commission spokeswoman Amelia Torres says officials are focusing on duration of exclusive contracts that seven largest movie companies has with one European pay TV company; does not identify company, but analysts believe it is Canal Plus of France; officials also suspect that prices for pay TV rights may have been inflated by collusion; companies like Canal Plus, British Sky Broadcasting and Sogecable of Spain have signed identical contracts with seven largest studios agreeing to pay high prices to all of them in return for exclusive rights in their territories; Walt Disney and BSkyB, controlled by News Corp, confirm they have been approached by commission as part of investigation (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: New American Embassy To Open
abstract: New and heavily fortified American Embassy will soon be inaugurated in Nairobi, Kenya, nearly five years after terrorists leveled previous one with bomb (S)

headline: U.S. Citizen Held in China
abstract: The Chinese police have detained a United States citizen in connection with efforts by the banned Falun Gong spiritual movement to hijack Chinese television and radio stations earlier this year.

headline: Remarks by Germany's Foreign Minister to Security Council
abstract: Following is the transcript of the statement by the foreign minister of Germany, Joschka Fischer, to the Security Council today as recorded by the Federal News Service.

headline: Pakistan's Islamic Parties Rally to Oppose a U.S. War on Iraq
abstract: Tens of thousands of Pakistanis shout condemnations of Pres Bush as country's hard-line Islamic parties rally in Rawalpindi against possible United States-led attack on Iraq; it is latest reminder of severe domestic pressures on Pres Pervez Musharraf as he decides whether to support his American allies (M)

headline: G.I.'s in South Korea Encounter Increased Hostility
abstract: American soldiers stationed in South Korea tell of verbal abuse and assaults by hostile South Koreans; photos; rising anti-Americanism stems in part from friction of having 37,000 US troops living in close quarters with people of one of world's most densely populated countries, but resentment verges on hatred, and extends to Canadians, Britons, Australians and New Zealanders; many young South Koreans believe North Korean tale that US troops divided nation, but reality is that Communist North attacked first and almost wiped out South Korea; leaders try to ease situation, well aware that there would be no South Korea without US (M)

headline: Vodafone Is Wanting to Shed Part of Its Japanese Venture
abstract: Britain's Vodafone Group wants to sell its fixed-line division of Japan Telecom Holdings; Ripplewood Holdings appears to be front-runner to acquire division; analysts estimate business is worth about 300 billion yen ($2.5 billion); photo (M)

headline: Seoul Again Delays Vote on Military Backing for U.S. in Iraq
abstract: The Parliament bowedto spreading protests and delayed for a second time a vote on sending 700 army engineers and doctors to Iraq.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: CBS and Don Hewitt Agree On a Change at '60 Minutes'  CBS and Don Hewitt, 80, the founder and executive producer of ''60 Minutes,'' have agreed to a succession plan in which Mr. Hewitt will step aside to make way for the ''60 Minutes II'' producer Jeffrey Fager, 48. In return for cooperating, Mr. Hewitt will retain control of ''60 Minutes'' through next season and will then become a paid, emeritus news division executive with tenure through age 90.    By ensuring Mr. Hewitt a long-term position, CBS can freshen the leadership of ''60 Minutes,'' which is fading in the ratings, while avoiding a confrontation with a man considered to be the most accomplished news producer ever. [Page A1.]

headline: Hewlett-Packard Combines Duties
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co consolidates worldwide interactive assignments, which has been handled by as many as 80 advertising agencies; billings undisclosed (S)

headline: Israel Won't Let Palestinian Leaders Attend London Talks
abstract: Israel's leaders forbid Palestinian leaders to leave country for talks in London, as much of rest of Israel takes day to mourn its dead following pair of deadly suicide attacks; talks in London, being sponsored by Prime Min Tony Blair, are intended to encourage Palestinian leadership to become more democratic and less corrupt; Israeli officials also order closing of three Palestinian universities; Israeli tanks and helicopters continue military operations in Gaza Strip, where they say they killed one Palestinian gunman; photos; map (M)

headline: Saudi Arabian Foreign Minister Urges U.S. to Pause From Invasion
abstract: Prince Saud al Faisal, Saudi foreign minister, urges United States to 'have a breather' in its invasion of Iraq and give United Nations another chance to disarm country peacefully; also calls on Saddam Hussein to think of 'sacrifices' he can make, implying that Hussein should seek exile rather than see his country destroyed; says Saudi Arabia would allow safe passage for Hussein and his family to reach Bahrain, which has offered sanctuary to Hussein (M)

headline: An Attack Drill Proves to Be a Real Test for Kuwaitis
abstract: Chaos and confusion mar Kuwaiti drill of mock Iraqi poison gas or Scud missile attack, such as country might face if US troops cross border into Iraq to overthrow Pres Saddam Hussein; government is buying two million gas masks to distribute through neighborhood supermarkets in coming weeks; there are also drills at schools, amusement parks and oil facilities to prepare people for biological or chemical attacks; photo (M)

headline: Havas Combines Marketing Units
abstract: Advertisi4

headline: Think You Can Beat the Market? A Study Says 1 in 5 Can
abstract: Mark Hulbert column on new study that found up to 20 percent of investors may be able to regularly pick stocks that beat market; study is based on complete trading histories of over 110,000 individual accounts at national discount brokerage firm; graph of average annualized returns of accounts studied (M)

headline: Eclipsed by Events, U.N. Officials Wonder About the Past and Ponder the Future
abstract: Diplomats and United Nations officials alternate between moments of blame and sadness over Security Council's inability to resolve conflict over Iraq without war; many show dour determination to demonstrate institution's enduring relevance and importance; there is already talk of next issue: UN's role in providing assistance and endorsing 'post-conflict administration' for Iraq; chronology of events since Pres Bush addressed United Nations on Sept 12, 2002, challenging it to force Saddam Hussein to disarm and implying that if it did not succeed, United States might take military action; photos (M)

headline: Music Label Sees Video Games As Way to Promote New Songs
abstract: Island Def Jam joins forces with Electronic Arts, world's largest game maker, to introduce songs on video game rather than radio; first game, Vendetta, will contain 12 Def Jam artists; idea is to lure young, male consumers into buying entire CD's when they are released to stores up to four months later; photo (M)

headline: U.N. Chief Says It Is Too Early to Consider War With Iraq
abstract: Secretary General Kofi Annan said today that it was too early for the Security Council to consider whether to authorize military action against Iraq.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Aid Worker Freed In Chechnya
abstract: Nina Davidovich, director of Russian aid organization who was kidnapped in July 2002 in Chechnya, is freed in raid; kidnapping prompted United Nations to suspend relief operations there for several weeks (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: More Food Is Needed
abstract: Another 325,000 tons of food is needed this year to reach World Food Program's minimum goal of 512,000 tons for North Korea (S)

headline: U.S. Supports Anticrime Group In the Caucasus and Central Asia
abstract: United States, with concern growing about dangers worldwide of organized crime and terrorism, will provide financial support for law enforcement to regional group of countries in Caucasus and Central Asia; five countries--Georgia, Ukraine, Uzbekistan, Azerbaijan and Moldova--formed their regional group four years ago and are planning law enforcement center linking their police forces, border guards and custom authorities (S)

headline: Uneasy Accord By Investigators In Banker Case
abstract: Rival prosecutors vie to lead criminal investigation of Frank P Quattrone, Credit Suisse First Boston's embattled technology trader; Eliot L Spitzer, New York attorney general, and his counterpart, James B Comey, US attorney for Southern District of New York, issue statement saying that they agreed to cooperate fully, but neither cedes control of investigation (M)

headline: Afghanistan's Police Force Needs Overhaul, Rights Group Says
abstract: Amnesty International said that Afghanistan and the international community needed to make the overhaul of the country's police force an urgent priority, to restore the rule of law.

headline: Greek Terror Defendants Don't Look the Part
abstract: ''You're the beekeeper?'' a judge asked Dimitris Koufodinas, trying to distinguish him from the other defendants in a maximum-security courtroom here.    Mr. Koufodinas, 45, nodded. Until last summer, he had been living in this city's suburbs, tending hives on a grant from the European Union. Then the police began looking for him, and he hid for weeks in a tent at a nudist beach before turning himself in.

headline: North Koreans Celebrate Birthday of 'Dear Leader'
abstract: North Koreans celebrate birthday of Kim Jong Il with day off from work and school, tasty treats for children and fireworks; photo (M)

headline: The Week's Economic Events
abstract: TUESDAYNone.

headline: Swiss Bank Says Profits Declined 19% Last Year
abstract: Switzerland's Julius Baer Holding reports assets under management fell 16 percent in 2002; net profit was 183 million Swiss francs ($137 million), 19 percent decline from 2001 and below expectations of analysts; bank will cut 300 more jobs in 2003 (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Mobile Phone Rate Dispute; ITALY: Insurer To Cut Jobs; NORWAY: Interest Rate Cut; SWITZERLAND: Net Income Falls;.

headline: Technology Briefing: Software
abstract: PARAMETRIC SHARES DROP AFTER REVENUE CHANGES; SOFTWARE BUDGETS WILL DECLINE, REPORT SAYS;.

headline: Concerns About Commerce as Borders Tighten
abstract: United States and Canada raise their guards against possible terrorist infiltrators at border crossings between two countries; huge traffic jams occur in first few days; to allow faster clearance at several of busiest points along border, officials on both sides set up registration systems for individuals and companies that regularly cross border; photo (M)

headline: Iraqis Were Leaving Basra After Dusk
abstract: The battle for Basra, Iraq's second-largest city, escalated today as American warplanes attacked a huge column of tanks and armored vehicles.

headline: Israeli Coalition Takes Shape, Shunning Ultra-Orthodox
abstract: Ariel Sharon's new government was taking shape today as a coalition that is expected to take a tough line on the Palestinian uprising.

headline: Stealth Fighters, and U.S. Marines, on Way to South Korea
abstract: United States Stealth fighter planes were flying here today to take part for the first time in seven years in war games with American and South Korean forces.

headline: STANDARD & POOR'S SAYS IT MIGHT LOWER ALTRIA'S RATING
abstract: Standard & Poor's weighs lowering credit rating of Altria Group to below investment grade because Altria's Philip Morris unit must raise $12 billiion for bond to appeal $10.1 billion tobacco judgment against it in Illinois (S)

headline: With No Opposition, U.S. Forces Seize Airstrip
abstract: The Army's Third Infantry Division advanced as far today as a much larger ground force did in four days during the Persian Gulf War.

headline: Wall Street Star May Face Suit By Regulators
abstract: NASD reportedly advises Henry Blodget, former Internet stock analyst at Merrill Lynch, that he will probably be sued for fraud and other violations of securities regulations; cites Blodget's public support of companies that he was deriding in e-mail messages to associates at Merrill Lynch; will also argue that Blodget's research reports were inappropriately influenced by Merrill Lynch's investment bankers; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: NORTH KOREA: New Risks Seen For Children;.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Echostar Reports Wider Fourth-Quarter Loss
abstract: Technology Briefing: Echostar

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen strengthens as nomination of central banker leads to speculation that Japan will not adopt any policies to weaken currency; dollar settles at 117.92, from 118.80, in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: How Big Could the Next Wave Be? Check the Risk Level
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column says mutual fund investors who are concerned about risk should consult RiskMetric Group's assessment of value at risk among domestic stock and bond funds; table (M)

headline: Britain Joins U.S. to Draft New Measure Aimed at Iraq
abstract: Diplomats from United States and Britain work on new resolution intended to present short-term ultimatum to Iraq and to enlist maximum possible support on Security Council for military action; spokesman for United Nations weapons inspectors reports that for first time since inspections were resumed in Iraq, U-2 reconnaissance aircraft flew over country to provide intelligence for inspectors; Iraqi government opposed such flights as recently as week ago; new British-US resolution is not likely to be introduced until after 15-member Security Council's scheduled debate on Iraq issue on Feb 18; timing is aimed at blunting criticism that Anglo-American coalition is so determined on its course that it does not adequately take other views into account (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Delays Bond Sale
abstract: South Korea's Kookmin Bank delays sale of $850 million worth of bonds in foreign markets; puts off offer for at least another two weeks (S)

headline: British Businessman Considers a Bid for the Safeway Stores
abstract: British businessman Philip Green is expected to make bid for Safeway supermarket chain; Safeway already has firm agreement to be acquired by rival William Morrison Supermarkets for $4.7 billion in stock (M)

headline: Oxford Journal; America the Monster? Not Altogether, Oxford Says
abstract: Britain prepares for possible war alongside United States in Iraq, and Oxford Union, one of Britain's oldest and best-known student bodies, holds debate about whether United States itself is biggest threat to world peace; every speaker, those for and those against war in Iraq, express awe at America's unbridled power now aimed at Iraq; after two hours of debate, there is narrow 195-to-151 vote in America's favor; photo (M)

headline: Lord Wilberforce, 95, Keeper Of an Antislavery Tradition
abstract: Richard Orme Wilberforce, retired member of Britain's highest court and human rights advocate, dies at age 95; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Austria: Far-Right Party In Coalition Talks
abstract: Chancellor Wolfgang Schussel's conservative Austrian People's Party begins talks with far-right Freedom Party on forming goverment (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Register.com Gets Bid From 2nd Investor Group
abstract: IWB Acquisitions, unit of Zackfoot Investments, wants to acquire Internet address provider Register.com, offering about $227 million, or 12 percent more than rival RCM Acquisition Co bid of $202.4 million (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Palm Lowers Price To Lift Sales
abstract: Palm Inc lowers price of its most expensive hand-held computer devices as much as 20 percent, seeking to reverse slump in sales (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: United Mechanics Argue Against Push for Pay Cuts  The machinists' union at United said that it opposed the airline's demand for short-term wage concessions because executives had not provided sufficient financial information to make an informed decision. The union said United needed to return to profitability by developing a comprehensive business plan rather than asking its unions for piecemeal cuts.    United is seeking concessions that would save it $70 million a month while it negotiates for longer-term cuts that would equal $2.4 billion a year from 2003 to 2008. [Page C4.]

headline: Rumsfeld Defends War Planning
abstract: The defense secretary said that he and his commanders had not underestimated the number of ground troops needed.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: KLM Narrows Loss
abstract: Dutch airline KLM lost 66 million euros ($71 million) in fiscal third quarter ended Dec 31, improvement from 94 million euros lost year earlier; sales increased 7 percent, to 1.6 billion euros; imposes hiring freeze and will reduce size of fleet to cut costs; graph (S)

headline: This Chat Is Music to Your Ears
abstract: Sony introduces series of cellphone headsets that incorporate same technology used in headphones for its portable music players, enhancing sound and blocking unwanted noise better than most sets; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: EXPORTS GROW IN SEVERAL NATIONS; SOUTH KOREA: Steel Maker'S Profit Rises;.

headline: A Lifelong Dissident Defies Iran's Rulers on Torture
abstract: Ezatollah Sahabi, Iranian dissident who has spent much of his life as political prisoner, dares Islamic Republic to execute him; he declares that death is preferable to torment he suffers at hands of justice system that has broken him and continues to pursue him; Sahabi's challenge, in form of letter to three branches of government, is latest and perhaps most dramatic manifestation of battle between political dissidents and justice system run by clerics that use various forms of repression, including torture; photos (M)

headline: A Mystical Part of Israel to Visit (for Keeps)
abstract: Safed, in Israel's far north, regards itself as Judaism's second-most holy city after Jerusalem; town fathers are appealing to Jews overseas to make their final resting place among holy men in hillside cemetery; Safed is selling safety, exclusivity, price and possibility of swifter resurrection; and, at time when tourism has all but collapsed, hope is that families of those buried in Safed will become frequent visitors there; photo (M)

headline: Slower Pace, Not a Pause
abstract: Military Analysis: unanticipated resistance from guerrilla forces in south and limited size of American force in region slows tempo of war plan, despite Gen Tommy R Franks's insistence that US military is pressing ahead; military is loathe to admit to any 'operational pause'; faced with threats in rear, need to guard supply lines, imperative to consolidate logistics and prospect of urban warfare in Baghdad, allied forces are confronting multitude of tasks; most military experts agree that allies would be in stronger position to advance on Baghdad had Bush administration sent more troops; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Office Depot expands its advertising relationship with Omnicom Group (S)

headline: 2 More Executives Defect from D'Arcy
abstract: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles executive vice presidents John Russo and Bob Nelson are joining DDB Worldwide, rather than shifting to other agencies owned by Publicis as D'Arcy is closed; Russo becomes co-executive creative director and Nelson is named director of broadcast production (M)

headline: Your Taxes; Pound for Pound, a Tax-Law Guide Can Save Money
abstract: Roundup of books offering advice on tax law and tax planning; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: GERMANY: Another Blow To SchrÖDer'S Party; KOSOVO: Serbian Premier Invited To Talk; ESTONIA: Leftists Reeling After Election; BRITAIN: Spear That Felled Captain Cook Up For Sale;.

headline: Half a Million Are Left Homeless In Afghan Cities as Winter Bites
abstract: Half million people face freezing winter with completely inadequate shelter in Afghanistan's cities; they are returning refugees with no house to rebuild, those displaced by years of war and still unable to go home, and urban poor made homeless by war and rising costs; not one house has been rebuilt with international assistance in last year in Kabul, where staggering 78,000 houses were destroyed over years of fighting; even so, disproportionate number of returning refugees are arriving in capital and its environs; United Nations aid officials say they concentrated on assistance to rural areas in 2002, focusing on more vulnerable people in remote villages, hoping to prevent cities from being inundated by flow of people from countryside; say more than two million refugees and internally displaced people have returned to their homes in last year; say efforts to position food stocks and supplies in mountainous regions have avoided hunger in provinces; but officials are becoming acutely aware of dire conditions in cities themselves; photos (L)

headline: Anger on Iraq Seen as New Qaeda Recruiting Tool
abstract: Al Qaeda and other terrorist organizations reportedly have intensified efforts to recruit young Muslim men in United States, Europe and Africa, tapping into rising anger about American campaign for war in Iraq; intelligence and law enforcement officials warn invasion of Iraq will produce groundswell of recruitment for groups committed to attacks in United States, Europe and Israel; surge in Qaeda recruitment efforts has been most visible in Germany, Britain, Spain, Italy and Netherlands; investigators have increased their use of informants and bugging devices to monitor mosques and other gathering places (M)

headline: New Signs of Weakness Show Risk of Resuming Recession
abstract: Consumer confidence has fallen to its lowest level in more than 10 years, a reflection of the head winds created by the Iraqi crisis and soaring energy bills.

headline: A Mixed Victory for Amgen in Patent Case
abstract: Federal appeals court upholds ruling that stops Transkaryotic Therapies and Aventis from selling rival to Amgen's anemia medication Epogen; upholds ruling that Transkaryotic's Dynepo drug infringed on two Amgen patents; court also says Transkaryotic can argue again that three Amgen patents are invalid (S)

headline: Be Patient With North, Seoul's Kim Urges the U.S.
abstract: Pres Kim Dae Jung, retiring lion of South Korean politics, advises United States to try patience and respect in dealing with North, amid flurry of diplomatic maneuvers over North Koera's nuclear weapons program; asserts that while he thinks that North Korea should give up its nuclear development, there is 'no other way but dialogue' to settle issue; Roh Moo Hyun, who is to be inaugurated as Pres Kim's successor on Feb 25, proposes summit meeting with North Korean leader Kim Jong Il to resolve peninsular nuclear crisis (M)

headline: S.E.C. May Add Some Rules
abstract: SEC weighs establishing of self-regulating organization for mutual funds and requiring mutual funds and financial advisers to designate chief compliance officer, expand internal audits and review their internal controls annually; also plans to vote on rule requiring stock analysts to certify that their reports actually represent their views and state in writing that they have received no compensation from companies covered in their reports (S)

headline: United Airlines Reports Loss of $1.5 Billion
abstract: The UAL Corporation reported today a net loss of $1.5 billion in the fourth quarter, capping off the most horrendous year in the airline's storied history.

headline: United Arab Emirates Urge Hussein to Give Up Power
abstract: Sheik Zayed bin Sultan al-Nahayan, president of United Arab Emirates, calls on Saddam Hussein to step down as president of Iraq, telling Arab League summit meeting in Egypt that this is only way to avoid American-led war and devastation it could cause Iraqi people; proposal, first by Arab leader, offers Hussein and his senior lieutenants immunity from prosecution in exchange for stepping aside within next two weeks; Iraqi representatives reject idea and promise to resist US; meeting, which was supposed to forge unified Arab response to Iraqi crisis, exposes deep divisions and ends without formally considering emirates' proposal; photo (M)

headline: Exxon Chief Says Oil Industry Is Already Jarred by Fears of War
abstract: Exxon Mobil chairman-chief executive Lee Raymond says oil industry is already feeling powerful repercussions from current economic and political volatility spawned by fears of war in Persian Gulf; says oil prices near $40 per barrel create number of problems for oil companies; adds oil prices in high 30's have long-range impacts that are not all that attractive; graph; chart (M)

headline: PRODUCTION OF LOCKHEED FIGHTER PLANE IS CUT BY 15%
abstract: Production of Lockheed Martin Corp's F/A-22 fighter plane has been cut by about 15 percent to help pay for potential overruns of as much as $1 billion in development costs; production now calls for 276 jets (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: New Oil Board
abstract: Venezuelan Pres Hugo Chavez appoints new board at state-owned oil company, Petroleos de Venezuela, solidifying control over company after strike aimed at ousting him failed; photo of company pres Ali Rodriguez (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Brocade Loss Caused By Job-Cut Costs
abstract: Brocade Communications Systems Inc says net loss in first quarter ended Jan 25 was $6.89 million compared with net income of $11.7 million year earlier; sales were unchanged (S)

headline: A Senior Aide To Blair Says She May Quit
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair faces widening dissent among his Labor Party followers as Clare Short says she will resign as international development secretary if Britain joins in war against Iraq without United Nations authorization, Andre Reed resigns as ministerial aide to protest government's readiness to go to war and Labor insider Doug Henderson warns revolt among Labor legislators could broaden; Blair's unswerving support for Pres Bush's invasion plans has become by far his riskiest political gamble since taking office; only 15 percent of Britons favor war without second UN resolution; Blair loyalists seek to convince nation that new resolution is still possible (M)

headline: 1,000 U.S. Paratroopers Open Northern Front
abstract: More than 1,000 members of 173d Airborne Brigade land in Kurdish-held northern Iraq, in one of largest paratroop drops since World War II; goal is to secure airfield so cargo planes can deliver American tanks and Bradley fighting vehicles, opening long-delayed northern front in war against Saddam Hussein; plans for northern front have been complicated by Turkey's refusal to accept allied ground troops on its soil, enabling Hussein to concentrate his forces in south, where irregular fedayeen groups are putting up stiff resistance; Iraqi Republican Guard makes maneuver south of Baghdad in preparation for confrontation with allied forces approaching city; guard is believed to be moving in light vehicles; earlier reports of column of 1,000 armored vehicles are described by Central Command in Qatar as error; bombing of Baghdad resumes, with several big explosions rocking center of city; Iraqi authorities say errant bomb or missile crashed into Baghdad market, killing 17 civilians and wounding many more; Pentagon officials acknowledge that allied bomb or missile could have gone astray; Maj Gen Stanley A McChrystal says cause might have been Iraqi missile that missed its target and fell back to earth; international criticism of war intensifies, but Pres Bush appears unconcerned by rising chorus of protest; leaders in Middle East and Europe call for cease-fire, and Sec Gen Kofi Annan denounces civilian losses in war zone and shortage of food and water in southern city of Basra; map (L)

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Global Hand-Held Computer Sales Fell In 2002
abstract: Dataquest Inc says global sales of hand-held computers fell 9.1 percent in 2002; adds worldwide shipments declined to 12.1 million units; Palm's market share worldwide declined to 36.8 percent in 2002 from 38.1 percent in 2001; Hewlett-Packard declined to 13.5 percent, compared with share of 16.9 percent in 2001 (S)

headline: U.S. Treasury Schedules Bond Auctions
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week comprises today's auction of three- and six-month bills and an auction tomorrow of four-week bills. There was no trading Monday in in Treasury futures on the Chicago Board of Trade and of United States Treasury securities.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 1.15 percent, the six-month issue was at 1.16 percent and the four-week issue was at 1.15 percent.

headline: 2 Protestant Guerrillas Are Killed in Northern Ireland
abstract: A Protestant guerrilla boss and one of his gang members were shot to death in Belfast on Saturday night in an internal feud.

headline: Thrills and Frustration on Bay Area Screens
abstract: San Francisco Bay Area has highest concentration in nation of television stations that broadcast digital video signals, half of which emit some high-definition signals; satisfaction of HDTV owners depends on effectiveness of rooftop UHF antennas they install and what (if any) HDTV programming is available when they choose to watch television; graph (M)

headline: Pedestrians vs. Scooter
abstract: Theodore Rodriguez-Bell letter contends Segway scooters have no place on sidewalks where they will be competing with pedestrians for space (Jan 23 article)

headline: U.S. Businessman Linked To Iraqi Arms Purchases
abstract: Law enforcement officials say Sahib Abd Amir Haddad, Iraqi-American businessman arrested in Hungary in November, was once key middleman for Saddam Hussein in illegal weapons purchases and tried last year to organize last-minute arms-buying spree for Iraq in response to growing threat of American invasion; Haddad, who was previously identified as major supplier of Iraq's chemical weapons program before 1991 Persian Gulf war, is awaiting extradition to Germany, where he faces charges of conspiring in late 1990's with two German men to purchase equipment for Iraq for manufacture of giant cannon, a 'supergun' that could have been used to lob chemical, biological or nuclear weapons up to 35 miles; Haddad left US in mid-1990's after collapse of his international trading company in Nashville (M)

headline: Pharmacy Benefit Companies Won't Disclose Fees
abstract: Companies that provide discounts on prescription drugs for about 200 million Americans refuse to tell Congressional investigators how much they are paid by drug makers to promote sales of their favorite drugs; General Accounting Office says companies, which are called pharmacy benefit managers, obtain reduced prices for eight million members of Federal Employees Health Benefits Program; says keys to profit for Medco Health Solutions and AdvancePCS are rebates and fees from drug makers; Medco and Advance do not dispute importance of rebates and fees from manufacturers, but insist that amounts are proprietary information and that they will not disclose them; pharmacy benefit companies are expected to manage drug benefits for 30 million elderly and disabled Americans under most proposals for Medicare drug benefit that Congress is expected to debate this year; critics say system results in higher overall costs (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Lower Growth Estimate
abstract: World Busi

headline: Talks Begin On Trade Pact With Morocco
abstract: Bush administration begins negotiating for free trade agreement with Morocco, emphasizing importance of expanding economic relations with Muslim world and pledging to try to complete accord within one year; America exports only $475 million worth of goods to Morocco each year, but both sides cast hoped-for agreement as one that might enhance Morocco's role as business hub connecting North Afirca to Europe, Midddle Eastern and US; US trade representative Robert B Zoellick hopes other Muslim nations will see benefits derived by pact (M)

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: LIBERIA: 3 Aid Workers Missing; SOMALIA: Warning On Peace Talks; SOUTH AFRICA: I Was Duped, Winnie Mandela Says;.

headline: Bounced From Executive Suite, but Not for Long
abstract: Article traces current occupations of former chief executives unseated during ostensible revolution in corporate governance of early 1990's; many are still managers; photo (M)

headline: Turkey Bans One Kurdish Party and Moves on Second
abstract: Turkey's senior prosecutor files petition with Constitutional Court to close country's leading pro-Kurdish political party, latest example of government's tense relationship with its Kurdish minority; there is profound wariness and suspicion among Turkish officials toward Kurds as war in Iraq draws near; fear is that war would whip up demands for independence and even set off violence among Kurds in southeastern Turkey, near Iraqi border (M)

headline: Edith Hirsch, 103, Commodities Economist
abstract: Edith Hirsch, former commodities economist and consultant, dies at age 103 (M)

headline: Army Chief Raises Estimate of G.I.'s Needed in Postwar Iraq
abstract: The Army's chief of staff said today that several hundred thousand American troops could be required in Iraq after a war.

headline: North Korea Opens Unofficial Channel for U.S. Talks
abstract: Two North Korean diplomats meet at their own initiative with Gov Bill Richardson of New Mexico, former Democratic congressman and ambassador to United Nations, who has traveled to North Korea and appears to be trusted by its leaders; trip to Santa Fe by Han Song Ryol and Mun Jong Chol is intended to open communications with Washington about North Korea's nuclear confrontation with US: spokesman for Richardson reiterates that he is not working in any official capacity and that he would report to Secretary of State Colin Powell; White House says Richardson is empowered only to deliver same message that it has said in public: no negotiations until North Korea halts its two nuclear projects; photo (M)

headline: NEC's Losses Narrow on Rise In Chip Prices
abstract: NEC Corp says rebound in chip prices in fourth quarter of 2002 narrowed its losses for period; reports loss of just 4.5 billion yen ($38 million) in quarter compared with 155 billion yen loss year earlier; total sales fell by 5 percent (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Explosives Found
abstract: Explosives, hidden by suspected members of Jemaah Islamiyah and believed to be intended for foiled 2001 attack on American and Israeli embassies in Singapore, are found by Malaysian police buried on estate near Singapore border (S)

headline: Big TV's Without A Fortune
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column reviews high-definition wide-screen tube TV's; while not as glamorous as plasma screens, they are cheaper than plasma screens and better than rear-projection models; sets offer plenty of component hookups to allow user to create home theater; models cited are by Sony, Panasonic, Phillips and Toshiba; drawing; photos (M)

headline: South Korea Leader Visits U.S. Military Base
abstract: President-elect Roh Moo Hyun moved strongly today to ease concerns about anti-Americanism in South Korea.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Fed Chief Rebuts Bush Plan For New Round of Tax Cuts  Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, rebutted many of President Bush's arguments in favor of new tax cuts, saying the economy probably does not need a short-term stimulus and warning that deficits could spiral out of control. Mr. Greenspan also disagreed with Mr. Bush's argument that rising budget deficits have little link to higher interest rates.    In a cautious assessment of the economy, he said the biggest obstacle to faster growth was uncertainty about a likely war with Iraq. Though expressing optimism that the economy would strengthen once those uncertainties disappeared, he suggested that the Fed would not raise interest rates soon. [Page A1.]

headline: Getting Onto the Internet at 30,000 Feet or So
abstract: Lufthansa Airlines begins flying Boeing aircraft between Frankfurt and Washington outfitted with Internet connectivity developed by Boeing Co; British Airways plans to start trial flight with same technology between London and New York in February; Japan Airlines and SAS have signed contracts with Boeing to outfit plans to offer Internet service in 2004; Hong Kong's Cathay Pacific will offer e-mail service using technology developed by Tenzing Communications, owned by Airbus; another system, jointly developed by Tenzing and ARINC, is being used by Virgin Atlantic Airways; technology has been tested by Air Canada and Singapore Airlines (M)

headline: Russia Halts Tourist Trips Into Space In Emergency
abstract: Russia suspends indefinitely its lucrative space tourism program, thrust by Columbia space shuttle disaster into new role as sole supplier of International Space Station; decision deprives badly underfinanced Russian Aviation and Space Agency of sideline that added as much as $20 million per tourist to program whose entire budget totals only $266 million (M)

headline: TAUBMAN REJECTS LATEST BID FROM SIMON
abstract: Taubman Centers, shopping mall empire founded by A Alfred Taubman, rejects $1.7 billion takeover bid from rival Simon Property Group as inadequate; Simon Property joined last week with Westfield America, which is controlled by Australian mall owner Westfield Holdings, to make its latest bid of $20 per share, up from its previously rejected offer of $18 per share; Taubman Centers chief executive Robert S Taubman reiterates that company is not for sale (S)

headline: Most Fund Brokers in Study Failed to Give Full Discounts
abstract: Inquiry by Securities and Exchange Commission, NASD and New York Stock Exchange shows that all but 2 bokerage firms out of 43 overcharged at least some customers who were eligible for discounts on purchases of mutual funds; finds over all, almost third of customers who were eligible were overcharged; regulators say that some disciplinary actions are possible but add that in many cases problems appeared to have stemmed from inadequate procedures at brokerage firms rather than intent to overcharge customers; inquiry was conducted from November to January (M)

headline: Ears Cocked to the U.N., G.I.'s Watch and Wait
abstract: American 101st Airborne Division, in Kuwait, has many tasks to finish to make war possible, even as debate continues at United Nations Security Council over need for war with Iraq (M)

headline: Dennis Franz Leaves Nextel Commercials
abstract: Actor Dennis Franz is disappearing from advertising for Nextel Communications, which is assessing effectiveness of campaign from its longtime agency, Mullen (S)

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: VENEZUELA: Strike Leader Exits; MEXICO: Gold Diggers Beware;.

headline: KRISPY KREME ACQUIRES MARKETING RIGHTS IN 4 AREAS
abstract: Krispy Kreme Doughnuts acquires marketing rights to four Kansas and Missouri areas from partnership, whose operating partner is former company employee; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Rights Groups Accuse Egypt Of Detentions
abstract: Human rights groups accuse Egyptian authorities of detaining hundreds of people, including opposition member of Parliament Muhammad Farid Hassanein, in brutal crackdown on people protesting war in Iraq; witnesses say detainees were beaten and tortured; officials deny charges, saying they tolerate public gatherings as long as demonstrators do not attack police or damage property (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
abstract: LUCENT REACHES SETTLEMENT WITH FORMER EXECUTIVE; CHINA UNICOM REPLACES EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR;.

headline: Russia Reiterates Doubts on War Against Iraq
abstract: MOSCOW, Feb. 7 — Foreign Minister Igor S. Ivanov briefed Russian legislators behind closed doors today on the United States' argument that Iraq was hiding weapons of mass destruction, and he said after a meeting with Finland's foreign minister that the crisis had entered

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: National Semiconductor Will Lay Off 500
abstract: National Semiconductor Corp plans to lay off 500 workers, or 5 percent of its staff, and sell some slower-growing businesses; hires Goldman Sachs Group to sell units; graph (S)

headline: Protests Turn Violent in Australia and Spain
abstract: Protests against the war in Iraq continued around much of the world today, with demonstrators defacing in France a replica of the Statue of Liberty.

headline: Grey Global Buys Darwin Medical
abstract: Grey Global Group acquires Darwin Medical Communications in attempt to expand its healthcare advertising capacities; terms are not disclosed (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: INDONESIA: Exports Lag Forecasts; SOUTH KOREA: Trade Surplus Rises; CHINA: Citigroup Investment; CHINA: Trade Volume Grows;.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Discounts Hurt Retailer
abstract: British retailer Marks & Spencer reports 7 percent rise in third-quarter sales in stores open at least one year, but says disappointing clothing sales in November required it to take greater markdowns during its post-Christmas clearance sale; graph (S)

headline: A Few Months in Washington and He's a Changed Man
abstract: A Few Months in Washington And He's a Changed Man.

headline: Andersen Seeks Graceful Exit to Leases
abstract: Arthur Andersen's lease on office space in Sarasota, Fla, has been terminated; space is back with building's owner Wells Real Estate Funds of Atlanta; Andersen is seeking graceful exit to leases in about 90 cities; photo (M)

headline: ADVANTA TOLD TO PAY $29 MILLION TO FLEETBOSTON
