abstract: Judge Jack B Jacobs tells Advanta Corp, provider of credit cards to small businesses, to pay $29.4 million for duping FleetBoston Financial Corp into overpaying for consumer credit card unit; FleetBoston sued Advanta in 1999 for understating liabilities in sale and failing to disclose problems in coding correct interest on accounts; coding problem later forced FleetBoston to refund $41.8 million; Jacobs awards Advanta $854,907 on counterclaim, reducing FleetBoston's verdict to $29.4 million (S)

headline: U.S. Envoy in Beijing to Press for Help With North Korea
abstract: China said it would be glad to host negotiations between the U.S. and North Korea as an American diplomat arrived in Beijing.

headline: U.S. Rejects Criticism on Awarding of Iraq Contracts
abstract: The overriding United States objective is to provide the quickest possible relief to the Iraqi people, an American official said.

headline: Times Appoints 2 Editors to New Positions
abstract: Richard J Meislin, technology editor at New York Times, is appointed editor of news surveys and election analysis; will be succeeded as technology editor by Tom Redburn, assistant business editor (S)

headline: Margins Add Silver to a Cloudy Retailing Season
abstract: December's comparable-store sales, compiled from stores open at least one year, rise about 1.6 percent from last year, most disappointing increase in at least decade; some companies say that profit on items sold was higher than last year; chart (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Airline Expanding To Sweden
abstract: The discount Irish airline Ryanair said it would set up a new hub at Skavsta Airport, 60 miles southwest of Stockholm, in April and add six routes to the two it has now linking Skavsta with Frankfurt and London. Ryanair's chief executive, Michael O'Leary, said his airline's fares were 84 percent less than those of the dominant Scandinavian airline, S.A.S..   Brian Lavery (NYT)

headline: G.E. to Spend $100 Million Promoting Itself As Innovative
abstract: General Electric Co is replacing its familiar corporate slogan 'We bring good things to life' with 'Imagination at work,' which is meant to laud its innovations in areas far afield from prosaic products like refrigerators and night lights; new $100 million advertising campaign was developed by BBDO Worldwide; change is also intended to reflect re-emphasis on research and big long-term ideas under new chief executive Jeffrey R Immelt; photos (M)

headline: War's Uncertainties Raise Anxieties of Arab Investors
abstract: Arab bankers, investors and deal makers throughout Europe watch from sidelines, unwilling to bet their fortunes on future of Iraq and worried about more regional instability, even as Americans and Europeans eye postwar opportunities; Arab banks are said to be experiencing huge liquidity, with new money pouring in every day, as investment comes to virtual standstill (M)

headline: World Briefing: Middle East
abstract: IRAN: Rushdie Death Sentence Is Renewed; IRAN: Another Death Sentence Is Lifted;.

headline: Chief Sees More Changes for US Airways
abstract: US Airways, emerging from bankruptcy, explores further cost-cutting strategies and reconsiders its business plans to regain profitability in bleak market for air travel and during war with Iraq; chief executive David N Siegel hopes to lower operating expenses additional $100 million to $200 million annually and decrease number of planes in its fleet; American Airlines continues its struggle to stay out of bankruptcy court (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: African Refugees Are Rescued After 2-Week Ordeal
abstract: Six Africans are recovering in Spanish hospital after being rescued from small wooden boat in which they spend two weeks adrift in Atlantic Ocean, survivors of group trying to reach Europe through Spain's Canary Islands; survivors are from Ghana and Mali (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Brewer's Profit Falls
abstract: Belgium's Inl

headline: Turner Confirms Doubt About CNN-ABC Link
abstract: Ted Turner, founder of Cable News Network, tells CBS News that he opposed merger of CNN and ABC News, interview, CBS program 60 Minutes II; executives on both sides of negotiations say his opposition would make little difference because merger proposal is dormant if not moribund; Turner says he cannot buy CNN back because he cannot afford it, having lost $7 billion to $8 billion in collapse of price of AOL Time Warner stock; Turner has resigned as vice chairman of AOL Time Warner Inc (M)

headline: Bristol-Myers Lowers Revenue By $2.5 Billion in Restatement
abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb Co restates its financial results, largerly reflecting its move away from inventory practices that inflated its earlier figures; reduces revenue by about $2.5 billion and earnings from continuing operations by about $900 million for three years through 2001; also adjusts its financial results upward for 2002; reports earnings from continuing operations of $1.9 billion on sales of $18.1 billion in 2002; company is under formal investigation by Securities and Exchange Commission; graphs (M)

headline: White House Reports a Decline in Colombia's Coca Cultivation
abstract: Bush administration reports that antidrug forces for first time have reduced amount of coca being cultivated in Colombia; cites aggressive aerial spraying in past year by Colombian troops; report comes as administration's efforts in Colombia come under fresh scrutiny with kidnapping of three Americans by leftist rebels on Feb 13 after their plane crash-landed in jungle; Pentagon has sent 49 soldiers and advisers to Colombia to assist with efforts to free Americans, who were apparently conducting aerial surveillance for company under Pentagon contract (M)

headline: Islands in the Mall: Pushcarts as Revenue Streams
abstract: Once-humble pushcart, some now equipped wiht electricity and plumbing, has become darling of mall operators and other landlords as way of getting additional rental income; wheeled carts, now called retail merchandising units, can add 2 percent to 3 percent to mall rental stream; during two-month holiday shopping season, vendor at top mall can pay more than $20,000 for 45-square-foot pushcart, and annual rents can reach $50,000; photo (M)

headline: Wireless Rivalries Fuel Fight Over a BellSouth Executive
abstract: Article on BellSouth Corp's fierce reaction to announcement by its vice chairman Gary D Forsee that he plans to become chief executive of rival Sprint Corp as industry's carriers are in all-out struggle to increase subscribers and sales; says Cingular Wireless, which BellSouth operates with SBC Communications, is struggling as it seeks to compete with other nationwide carriers, including Sprint's wireless operation; graph (M)

headline: Cordiant Seeks To Sell More Assets
abstract: Cordiant Communications Group will seek to sell additional assets to reduce debt as it renegotiates its loan agreements with banks for second time (S)

headline: In Military Towns, Contractors' Windfall Is Not Doing Much Trickling Down
abstract: Experts are already speculating on what war in Iraq might do to United States economy, but effects are already being felt in cities where military bases and weapons plants are economic mainstays, and the news is grim; local businesses remain in doldrums and many fear war and continuing threat of terrorism will only make things worse; efficiency and cost-cutting measures by military contractors is allowing them to produce more without hiring more workers or spending more money locally; scene in Tucson, home to Raytheon plant and Davis-Monthan Air Force Base, described; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Shipbuilding Dispute
abstract: South Korean government is preparing to file trade complaint against European Union over subsidies to shipbuilders; will file formal complaint with World Trade Organization in February (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Border Accord With Russia
abstract: Ukraine President Leonid D Kuchma and Russian President Vladimir V Putin sign treaty ending four-year border negotiation (S)

headline: Menu of the Sky
abstract: Steve Mann letter on Jan 12 article welcomes America West airlines' selling food and snacks on board flights

headline: NORTHWEST BANCORP AGREES TO BUY FIRST BELL BANCORP
abstract: N

headline: Taking a Punch, Then Making a Pitch
abstract: Boxing-equipment maker Everlast Worldwide enlists boxers, including former heavyweight champion Larry Holmes, to sell its goods at Las Vegas show; photo (S)

headline: Lucent Chief Plans a Path Back to Black
abstract: Lucent Technologies chief executive Patricia F Russo plans to return nation's leading maker of communications switching equipment for telephone companies to profitability by end of 2003; has overseen elimination of 22,000 employees and other cost-reducing strategies; reiterates forecast of 20 percent sales growth in current quarter, to $2.5 billion; company adapts to major customers' sluggish spending; photo; graphs (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
abstract: MOTOROLA INCREASES BID FOR NEXT LEVEL BY 13%; BELLSOUTH AND EARTHLINK EXPAND NET ACCESS PACT;.

headline: China Unveils Another Plan to Cut Bureaucratic Red Tape
abstract: China unveils its third plan in past decade to streamline its huge government bureaucracy, aiming to reduce corruption and eliminate overlapping responsibilities that contribute to waste in its economy; plan, if accepted during National People's Congress, would create independent American-style regulatory bodies to oversee banking, state-owned assets, food and drugs (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Kazakhstan: Government Critic Sentenced
abstract: A court sentenced a leading journalist and government critic to three and a half years in prison, saying he raped a 14-year-old girl in his country home last autumn. The journalist, Sergei Duvanov a 49-year-old editor of a human rights journal, is one of a number of journalists who have been arrested, threatened or killed after criticizing the autocratic government of President Nursultan Nazarbayev.   Michael Wines (NYT)

headline: PFIZER ORDERED TO STOP SHIPPING E.P.T. PREGNANCY TEST
abstract: Pfizer Inc is ordered by Federal Judge Katharine Hayden to stop shipping EPT, its best-selling home pregnancy test, while it fights patent-infringement lawsuit by rival Inverness Medical Innovations Inc; order does not affect boxes of EPT already on store shelves (S)

headline: F.C.C. Delivers Some Cheer To Slumping Silicon Valley
abstract: Makers of broadband equipment like Cisco Systems and Juniper Networks and semiconductor giant Intel look forward to new orders as result of exemption made for broadband equipment when FCC decided to retain many of rules that govern local telecommunications markets; FCC's action is not expected to mean much for big equipment suppliers to local telephone companies, and analysts are not especially optimistic about prospects for significant spending increase on broadband technology by the Bells (M)

headline: More Than 120 Die in Arson Attack on South Korean Subway
abstract: Witnesses said that a 56-year-old man with a record of mental illness had set the fire by lighting a flammable liquid.

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Charges In Spice Girl Plot; ITALY: Lionizing Venice; ITALY: Charge Against Berlusconi Is Dismissed; SERBIA: War Crime Indictment ; SPAIN: Plans To Extract Leaking Oil;.

headline: Powell, in Asia, Is Dealt a Setback on North Korea
abstract: China, Australia and South Korea urged the U.S. to begin direct talks with North Korea, a strategy Washington has repeatedly rejected.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Motorola Settles Dispute With Iridium Creditors
abstract: Motorola Inc will make final $12 million payments to group of Iridium creditors led by J P Morgan Chase to settle suits over loan repayments (S)

headline: US Air Cutback Accepted
abstract: US Airways Group, which filed for bankruptcy protection in August, says that employees who train flight crews have ratified agreement that includes benefit cuts and pension concessions (S)

headline: Strategy Split Is Reported In Top Ranks of American
abstract: American Airlines executives reportedly are split over whether to seek bankruptcy protection; are still asking bankers to put together financing as quickly as possible in case American decides to file; Donald J Carty, chief executive of parent AMR, and several colleagues reportedly want desperately to avoid bankruptcy and work out labor and supplier concessions out of court (M)

headline: The Screaming Eagles Fly to the Gulf
abstract: In their desert camouflage uniforms of light beige and brown, the soldiers on the Fort Campbell airfield were clothed for weather in the Persian Gulf, not the cold, damp night air of a Kentucky winter. A thick coat of fog had dropped onto the Army base. For an instant as they filed in a long, single line onto their jet, the soldiers formed silhouettes against the murky glow of fog-shrouded runway lights.    It was near midnight on Thursday, and the 101st Airborne Division -- the Screaming Eagles -- was beginning its flight from Kentucky to the deserts of Kuwait, a distance of some 7,000 miles.

headline: C.I.A. Aides Feel Pressure In Preparing Iraqi Reports
abstract: Some analysts at Central Intelligence Agency say they felt pressured to make their intelligence reports on Iraq conform to Bush administration policies; debate was renewed after disclosure by Dr Mohamed ElBaradei, head of International Atomic Energy Agency, that claim that Iraq sought to buy uranium from Niger, claim cited publicly by Pres Bush, was based partly on forged documents; American intelligence officials say forged documents were not created by CIA or any other US government agency, and that they were always suspicious of them (M)

headline: Tending to a Garden Of Work References
abstract: Advice for job seekers on importance of good references and on how to find best references (S)

headline: U.S. Spy Plane Crashes in South Korean Town, Injuring 5
abstract: United States spy plane crashes in Hwasung, South Korea, injuring pilot and four Koreans on ground; plane is late-model version of U-2 reconnaissance aircraft; such planes are not believed to be flying over North Korea, but these flights are believed to have been source of some of detailed information US acquired on North's nuclear weapons program; United States apologizes to South Korea for accident and pledges to process claims for personal injuries and property damage quickly; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Suit Expected Against Star Of First Boston
abstract: NASD notifies Frank P Quattrone, top investment banker at Credit Suisse First Boston, that it plans to file civil suit against him; will contend that Quattrone, who led firm's technology banking and research group in Palo Alto, Calif, during late 1990's, failed to supervise technology stock analysts and employees responsible for allocating shares of initial public offerings to clients who were also paying firm for investment banking services; will also contend that Quattrone dispensed hot stock offerings to favored customers of firm, practice known as spinning; Quattrone says he expects to be cleared of any wrongdoing; photo (M)

headline: Webdenda
abstract: Lance M. Adeszko was named sales development manager at the Chicago office of USA Weekend , succeeding Brian Deleney , who left, the company said. Mr. Adeszko has been Midwest director at the Chicago office of Meredith Interactive, part of the Meredith Corporation. USA Weekend is owned by the Gannett Company. Peter Armour , senior vice president for consumer marketing at Conde Nast Publications , New York, part of the Advance Magazine Group , was named senior vice president for consumer marketing at the Advance Magazine Group as part of a reorganization. Advance Magazine is part of Advance Publications. Austin Kelley Advertising , Atlanta, promoted three employees to senior vice presidents. They are Patty Kinney , director for traffic services; Lou Ann Russell , account director; and Duncan Stone , associate creative director. Austin Kelley is part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Balance Sheet Manager , Burlingame, Calif., which assists loan transactions between banks, named Welch Nehlen Groome Advertising , Garden City, N.Y., to handle the company's first print and online advertising. Billings were estimated at $1 million. Bruce Brandfon , publisher at Scientific American magazine , New York, was promoted to vice president. Scientific American is part of Holtzbrinck Publishers, part of Verlagsgruppe Georg von Holtzbrinck. John Carter , creative director at T.G. Madison , Atlanta, was named to the new post of executive vice president and executive creative director. He assumes duties that had been handled by Virgil Shutze, president and chief creative officer, who continues as president. Mike Colt , executive vice president and executive creative director at Leo Burnett USA , Chicago, was named vice chairman. Burnett is part of the Leo Burnett Worldwide unit of the Publicis Groupe. Corey L. Cutler was named to the new post of executive vice president at the Ruth Group , New York, a financial public relations and investor relations agency. He had been senior vice president at FD Morgen-Walke, New York, part of the Cordiant Communications Group, heading the technology practice. Drew Fawcett , vice president and associate creative director at Rabasca & Company , Melville, N.Y., was named creative director, succeeding Rick Bodamer, who left, the agency said. Also, Bruce Richards was named to the new post of senior vice president and director for client services; he had been senior vice president and management supervisor at Bates North America, New York, part of the Bates Worldwide unit of the Cordiant Communications Group. Gear magazine , New York, and the Brand Entertainment Group , New York, part of the J. Walter Thompson division of the WPP Group, formed a joint venture to produce television programming. Terms were not disclosed. Gear is published by Guccione Media. Kevin Gelbard was named to help develop corporate partnerships at the Creative Artists Agency , Beverly Hills, Calif. He had been vice president for sales at Envision, Los Angeles, part of the Anschutz Entertainment Group division of the Anschutz Corporation. Michael Gentry was named to the new post of national account director at Roska Direct , Montgomeryville, Pa. He had been senior account manager at IMS Health, Plymouth Meeting, Pa. The Green Bay Packers named Lindsay, Stone & Briggs , Madison, Wis., as the first agency of record on the account of Lambeau Atrium , a convention center and restaurant complex being added to the facilities at Lambeau Field that is scheduled to open in September. Billings have not been determined. Bill Hewson , director for client strategy at Sharpe Partners , New York, was named to head a new department of relationship marketing and media, as director. Patrick Kiss was named to the vacant post of managing director at Butler, Shine, Stern & Partners , Sausalito, Calif. He had been executive vice president at the San Francisco office of Foote, Cone & Belding, part of the FCB Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Larry Kleehammer was named director for account services at Buck & Pulleyn, Rochester , N.Y. He had been vice president and worldwide account director at the Rochester office of Saatchi & Saatchi Rowland, part of the Saatchi & Saatchi unit of the Publicis Groupe. Bill Kolberg , senior vice president at the Los Angeles office of Porter Novelli , part of the Omnicom Group, was named general manager for Los Angeles. He assumes duties that had been handled by Steve Jursa, acting general manager, who continues as senior partner and global convergence practice leader. Liberty Bank , Portland, Ore., named Leopold Ketel & Partners , as agency of record on its account, which had been handled by B/O/C Advertising, Portland. Billings were estimated at $500,000. Linda McCutcheon was named director for publications at AARP , Washington, succeeding Martha Ramsey, who was named senior adviser to the chief executive. Ms. McCutcheon had been chief executive at KOZ Inc., Durham, N.C. Gordon McLeod was named to the new post of president at Sports Illustrated Interactive , New York, part of the Time Inc. division of AOL Time Warner. He had been vice president and general manager at Parenting.com and Parenting TV, New York, units of the Parenting Group at Time Inc. NKH&W , Kansas City, Mo., acquired the McIntosh Group , Fort Smith, Ark., and Image and Strategy , Little Rock, Ark. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Electronic Data's Debt Rating Is Cut 2 Levels
abstract: Electronic Data Systems Corp's debt is cut two levels by Moody's Investors Service on concern about cash flow and customers' ability to pay their bills (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Slower Privatization
abstract: Taiwanese government says that from March 3 to 5 it will sell only one fifth of 500 million shares in Chunghwa, Taiwan's largest telecommunications company, that it had previously promised to sell; government controls 82 percent of Chunghwa but will dispose of slightly more than 1 percent of company in sale (S)

headline: South African Commission Ends Its Work
abstract: South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, marking formal end of its work, warns government against issuing blanket amnesty to perpetrators of crimes of apartheid; urges businesses to join with government in delivering reparations to millions of blacks victimized by former white minority government; Archbishop Demond Tutu, commission chairman, delivers its final findings and recommendations to Pres Thabo Mbeki; photo (M)

headline: Blair Survives a Mutiny Over Joining U.S. in War
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair pledges his political future on Britain's joining United States in forcibly disarming Saddam Hussein following resignations of three government ministers; he survives parliamentary rebellion by members of his own Labor Party; Blair has deployed 45,000 British troops to Persian Gulf even as majority of British public remain unpersuaded of need to go to war now; photo (M)

headline: The Early Interview Gets . . .
abstract: Survey of chief financial officers suggests they are more likely to hire job applicants who have morning interviews than those whose interviews come later in day (S)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Teacher Jailed For Threat To U.S. Diplomat
abstract: Egyptian English-language teacher is sentenced to year in prison for sending e-mail to Federal Bureau of Investigation threatening American Ambassador David Welch before his visit to Assuit, Egypt (S)

headline: ImClone Founder Pleads Guilty to Avoiding Sales Tax on Art
abstract: Samuel Waksal, who last year pleaded guilty to insider trading, said he conspired with a gallery to dodge $1.2 million in taxes.

headline: No Promises From Turkey About Staying Out of Iraq
abstract: American officials implore Turkish leaders to keep their troops out of northern Iraq, but talks end without any such assurance from Turkey; Turkish officials say they will order troops into northern Iraq to prevent refugees--and perhaps Kurdish terrorists--from streaming into Turkey; Pres Bush's supplemental war budget includes $1 billion aid package for Turkey (M)

headline: Movies or Music Files? A Jukebox Does Double Duty
abstract: Archos Multimedia Jukebox 20 can play MP3 tunes and video clips in MPEG-4 format; works with most Windows and Macintosh systems; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Ex-Premier Blames Army
abstract: Former British Prime Minister Edward Heath testifies that 1972 Bloody Sunday shooting of Londonderry marchers was not caused by standing governmental shoot-to-kill policy; says that situational decisions were made by military officers on scene; five-year-old inquiry into deaths of 14 protesters is predicted to run until 2004 (S)

headline: Iraqis Ambivalent on Inspections
abstract: Iraqi citizens express anger mixed with hope towards the new U.N. mission to find weapons of mass destruction.

headline: China Has Held U.S.-Based Dissident Incommunicado Since April
abstract: United States-based dissident Yang Jianli has been held incommunicado in China for more than nine months for traveling on false passport; his relatives have received no formal notice of charges against him; Yang's siblings say no lawyer will take his case without seeing arrest notice; say they are getting runaround from police and other bureaus; Yang took part in pro-democracy demonstrations around Tiananmen Square in 1989, then fled China to United States after bloody crackdown; he has been on Chinese government blacklist ever since, repeatedly denied permission to visit (M)

headline: Internal Rift Dooms Arab League Plan to Help Avert a War by Pressing Iraq
abstract: Efforts by Arab League to press Saddam Hussein to disarm collapse under weight of internal bickering and brush-off from Iraqi government; delegation of league foreign ministers calls off planned trip to Baghdad after Syria dismisses it as American ploy that would only help legitimize attack on Iraq; final blow comes when Iraq sends message telling ministers to stay home; aborted visit underlines disarray in organization, which has found itself relegated to sidelines as UN debates possible war against one if its members; Arab leaders are united in opposing war but not on how to exert influence on Iraq or on US (M)

headline: Priceline Buys 14% Stake In TravelWeb
abstract: Priceline aligns itself with TravelWeb, upstart hotel reservation Web site, in deal that will give Priceline 14 percent stake in TravelWeb; Priceline will promote TravelWeb's inventory of discount hotel rooms on its Web sites along with its $8.5 million investment in TravelWeb, which is owned by group of five major hoteliers and hotel reservations company Pegasus Solutions (M)

headline: Fed Leaves Interest Rates Unchanged
abstract: Federal Reserve leaves benchmark federal funds rate on overnight loans between banks at 1.25 percent, lowest in 41 years, but also departs from its standard practice by saying that uncertainties about Iraq are so great that it cannot assess risks of economic downturn; is first time Federal Reserve has refused to comment on 'balance of risks' between inflation and recession since February 2000; photo (M)

headline: More Advertisers for Super Bowl
abstract: More Advertisers For Super Bowl Additional advertisers are making plans to run commercials during the ABC broadcast of Super Bowl XXXVII on Jan. 26.

headline: A Heads-Up on Terrorism
abstract: Oklahoma state government begins offering e-mail service that alerts subscribers whenever terror threat levels change at state or national level; photo (M)

headline: MEMO PAD
abstract: Wyndham International reintroduces offer that gives new members of its ByRequest guest-loyalty program free local and long-distance phone calls within 48 contiguous US; American Express opens business-travel center in Shanghai and is planning another one in Guangzhou; estimates business travel spending in China is $4 billion to $5 billion per year; Air Transport Association chief economist David Swierenga says average domestic air fares declined 1.6 percent during December; says for all of 2002 fares were down 15 percent and passenger traffic was down 8 percent over 2001; State Department, in wake of possible war in Iraq, issues worldwide alert advising Americans abroad to be prepared for possible emergencies and to keep passports and other important travel papers readily at hand (Memo Pad column) (M)

headline: Joy for Tyco's New Boss, Not for Investors
abstract: Floyd Norris column on recent disclosures by Tyco International of financial problems at its security subsidiary despite investor confidence in company after new management, led by Edward D Breen, assured investors at end of 2002 that no major fraud was found at company; says Tyco's head David Boies lined up investors at end of last year for two convertible bond issues that proved to be overwhelming success, growing to $4.5 billion from initially announced $3.25 billion; holds investors feel betrayed, and share price is now only pennies above price it rose to on day Breen was hired last year; adds bonds, with conversion prices in low $20's, are trading well below what investors paid for them; graph (M)

headline: GLAXO SAYS IT WILL FIGHT NEW YORK LAWSUIT
abstract: GlaxoSmithKline chief executive Jean-Pierre Garnier says it will fight accusations by New York State Atty Gen Eliot L Spitzer that company inflated drug costs for government health programs and consumers; Pharmacia, which is also named in Spitzer's suit, says company is cooperating with Spitzer's office and hopes to avoid litigation (S)

headline: Carnival in Rio Is Dancing To More Commercial Beat
abstract: Many people in Rio de Janeiro fear that Carnival is becoming less a people's festival than tightly controlled industry; stands along Carnival parade, focal point of five-day celebration, will be filled not with knowledgeable samba fans, but with tourists, celebrities and high rollers, many of whom are guests of corporations that have spent huge sums on luxury boxes; samba schools that used to choose parade themes developed by their members and based on folk or mythological subjects are now paid by large companies to choose topics that are thinly disguised commercials; tourists unversed in samba can buy their way into parade; professional companies now create costumes and floats once made by seamstresses and carpenters from neighborhoods around samba schools; criminal gangs that now control hillside slums where samba schools were born have forced several to move performances into middle-class areas that are fine for tourists but not easily within reach of traditional supporters; photos (M)

headline: A Leftist Takes Over in Brazil and Pledges a 'New Path'
abstract: Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva is inaugurated as president of Brazil, promising 'new style of government' and crusade against hunger, injustice and corruption; country's history offers no precedent for rise to power of da Silva, first member of working class to become president and first candidate of left-wing party to win presidential vote; he has credited his resounding triumph to rejection of free market policies of his predecessor Fernando Henrique Cardoso; change of guard delights and reinvigorates Latin Amerian left, but in what is regarded in Brazil as calculated snub, American delegation is led by Robert B Zoellick, US trade representative; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bankruptcies Rise
abstract: Bank of Korea reports number of bankrupt companies increased to 418 in December from 372 in November; also says debt default ratio, measurement of percentage of promissory notes that are overdue in payments, rose to 0.07 percent in December from 0.04 perent in November (S)l

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: E.P.A. Approves the Use Of Monsanto's Altered Corn  The government announced that it had approved a new type of genetically modified corn that it says could lead to a significant reduction in the use of toxic insecticides. The approval was granted by the Environmental Protection Agency to a corn developed by Monsanto that is resistant to the corn rootworm.    The approval is a lift for Monsanto, which has been struggling with falling earnings, and for the crop biotechnology industry, because it is the first truly new product in some years. The company said it expected the corn would eventually generate $150 million to $200 million in revenues. [Page C10.]

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PLAINS ALL AMERICAN PIPELINE, Houston, which transports oil, acquired a pipeline in West Texas from a unit of Holly Corp., Dallas, a petroleum refiner, for about $24 million.    AUTODESK INC., San Raphael, Calif., a maker of software used to design bridges and buildings, said it acquired two software makers, truEInnovations and Linius Technologies Inc., and agreed to purchase some assets of a third, VIA Development. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Mechanics At United Oppose a Cut In Pay Now
abstract: Machinists' union at United Airlines says it opposes airline's demand for short-term wage concessions because executives have not provided enough financial information for union to maker informed decision and because two sides have not engaged in back-and-forth negotiations; union also says United needs to return to profitability by developing comprehensive business plan rather than by asking its employees for piecemeal cuts (M)

headline: Screenwriters, Resist
abstract: Marisa D'Vari letter contends computer assisted screenwriting does not work and brings disrespect to craft (Feb 27 article)

headline: American Protester Killed by Israeli Bulldozer in Gaza
abstract: An American woman in Gaza to protest Israeli operations was killed Sunday when she was run over by an Israeli bulldozer.

headline: U.S. Expands Afghan Aid For Maternal and Child Health
abstract: Bush administration will spend $5 million this year to rebuild and expand largest women's hospital in Kabul, Afghanistan, and to create four satellite teaching clinics for maternal and child health in other parts of country; this is administration's latest effort to address health needs of Afghanistan's 25 million people, particularly its women and children, who have among world's worst health and greatest needs; World Bank and United Nations agencies estimate that it will cost roughly $15 billion over next 10 years to rebuild Afghanistan (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank Official Selected
abstract: British government appoints Rachel Lomax to succeed Mervyn A King as deputy governor of Bank of England when King takes over from Sir Edward George as governor later this year; Richard Lambert will join Monetary Policy Committee, which sets interest rates, in June (S)

headline: In Texas, Texas-Size Injury Expenses
abstract: Workers Compensation Research Institute study

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Electronics Loss
abstract: LG Electronics reports loss of 179.1 billion won ($152.9 million) in fourth quarter compared with loss of 243.5 billion won year earlier; sales rose to 4.61 trillion won from 4.05 trillion won (S)

headline: North Korea Fires Antiship Missile in Test Launch
abstract: North Korea test-fired a medium-range anti-ship missile today in another apparent attempt to bring the United States into direct talks on its nuclear program while Washington focuses on going to war in Iraq.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Grows
abstract: Japan's merchandise trade surplus expanded 20.4 percent in February compared with same month year ago as exports to China offset decline in shipments to US (S)

headline: Japan Legislators Seek Ways to Prop Up Falling Stock Prices
abstract: Jolted by the recent declines in Japanese stock prices, lawmakers from the ruling party proposed several measures to prop up the market and soften the impact on banks.

headline: Longtime Editor of GQ Magazine to Retire
abstract: Art Cooper, the longtime editor in chief of GQ, announced today that he would step down from his post in June.

headline: New Urgency for Bolstering Oversight
abstract: Disclosure by Royal Ahold that it overstated its earnings by at least $500 million over last two years may spur efforts to overhaul financial oversight in Europe; European regulators and corporate executives have for most part resisted any effort to impose wholesale changes in accounting and governance rules despite number of accounting scandals in recent years; Germany introduces proposals that would let investors pursue class-action litigation against executives who investors believe had misled them (M)

headline: Watching a Cold Front Advance Across Your Palmtop Screen
abstract: Web site operated by AccuWeather starts pilot project that allows users of hand-held running Palm OS or Pocket PC operating system to download animated graphics along with forecast information; photo (M)

headline: Muscovites' Love for a Classic Ends at the Park
abstract: Small but growing group of Moscow residents protest plan to build monument to writer Mikhail Bulgakov in much-loved city park; they say monument will ruin quiet park, and they particularly object to plans to construct granite walkway on banks of park's pond; in Russia, struggles between ordinary citizens and 'the power'--as Russians call it--rarely end in victories for the people; this scuffle over park might; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Bank Profit Falls; BRITAIN: Consumer Confidence Dips; FRANCE: Insurer Posts Gain; BRITAIN: Bank Official Selected; SPAIN: Telecom Loss;.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Internet Newspaper Raided
abstract: Popular Malaysian internet newspaper Malaysiakini is shut down after making statements critical of government control of media; editor Steven Gan may be charged with sedition (S)

headline: Next U.N. Vote on Iraq Could Put Schröder on the Spot
abstract: Chancellor Gerhard Schröder faces the prospect of another U.N. vote on an Iraq war, and a "no" vote could damage Germany's ties with its allies.

headline: Plot to Poison Food of British Troops Is Suspected
abstract: American government officials say Islamic militants arrested in Britain this month may have been plotting to lace food supply on at least one British military base with poison ricin; say intelligence reports show that one of suspects worked for food preparation company and had been in contact with individuals who worked on at least one British military base; caution that assessment is working theory among British investigators, and that conclusive evidence has not yet been obtained; revelation raises concern in Britain and United States about security of allied forces as war preparations continue; British Home Office declines to comment on reports, but potential threat clearly heightens concern; Prime Min Tony Blair recently ordered increase in number of troops being deployed to Middle East in preparation to join US if it uses force against Iraq (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Concurrent Computer Shares Plunge
abstract: Shares of Concurrent Computer Corp falls as much as 31 percent after company lowers forecasts; graph (S)

headline: G.E. TO BUY BRITISH INSTRUMENT UNIT FOR $4.74 MILLION
abstract: The General Electric Company, which began selling electronic sensors last year, plans to buy the pressure-measurement and calibration unit of Hill & Smith Holdings of England for £3 million ($4.74 million). Hill & Smith's SI Pressure Instruments unit makes sensors for companies like automakers and utilities, G.E. said. The acquisition will be folded into Druck Holdings, a sensor maker bought last year by GE Industrial Systems. The purchase is expected to close by the end of June.

headline: New Seoul Leader to Press U.S. and North to Yield a Bit
abstract: Pres-elect Roh Moo Hyun of South Korea is preparing compromise proposal that would require both North Korea and US to accept concessions to resolve standoff over North's nuclear program; North Korea renews its call for US to reopen talks with it, but US State Department says North Korea must first stop its two programs to build nuclear bombs; photo (M)

headline: In Blix's Words: 'Iraq Could Have Made Greater Efforts' to Find Illegal Items
abstract: Excerpts from UN weapons inspector Hans Blix's report to Security Council on Iraqi weapons programs; photo (M)

headline: HealthSouth and Chief Charged With Fraud
abstract: The S.E.C. charged the nation's biggest operator of rehabilitation hospitals and clinics with overstating its earnings by at least $1.4 billion since 1999.

headline: Cases of New Bird Flu in Hong Kong Prompt Worldwide Alerts
abstract: World Health Organization alerts health officials around world to increase somewhat their preparedness in response to two human cases of apparently new strain of bird flu that surfaces in Hong Kong this week (M)

headline: Bank of England Cuts Rates to Lowest Point Since 1955
abstract: The bank's monetary policy committee trimmed 0.25 percent off its base lending rate to a 48-year low of 3.75 percent today, making its first change in rate for 14 months.

headline: Data-Storage Company Senses Mild Pickup
abstract: EMC announced fourth-quarter earnings that confirmed a rebound in spending on information technology, and especially data-storage products, as 2002 wound down.

headline: Sandstorms come early to Kuwaiti desert this year
abstract: KUWAIT:—  An unusually harsh sandstorm has swept through Kuwait, disrupting air traffic and exposing thousands of American, British and Kuwaiti troops to blinding desert winds for several hours.

headline: Illinois Joins Suits To Collect Taxes On Internet Sales
abstract: Illinois joins lawsuits against Wal-Mart Stores, Target, Office Depot and three smaller retailers, accusing them of failing to collect taxes on Internet and catalog sales; move comes as several states, facing severe budget shortfalls, are exploring way to collect tax revenue from online retailers (M)

headline: Where Banks Pay Borrowers to Borrow Money
abstract: Some Japanese banks are paying borrowers to borrow from them, practice analysts say will continue until faith in banking system improves; once-rare phenomenon of loans at negative interest, first seen in Japan in late 1990's, is back (M)

headline: Bush Offers a Break if Companies Pay Taxes
abstract: Floyd Norris column suggests that since Pres Bush's plan to end taxation of dividends applies only to dividends that come from profits on which corporate taxes are actually paid, it might one day lead to revival of corporate income tax; graph shows decline of corporate income taxes as percentage of gross domestic product since 1965 (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Sony Is Venturing Into Online Games for Multitudes
abstract: Grid computing, a concept that originated in supercomputing centers, is taking a step toward the mainstream: Sony will announce today that it will use the technology to accelerate its push into the emerging market for online games with thousands of players at a time.    Sony is teaming up with I.B.M. and Butterfly.net Inc., a software start-up that will build the grid for players who use Sony's PlayStation 2 video game consoles. The companies plan to demonstrate the technology next week at the annual Game Developers Conference in San Jose, Calif.

headline: Microsoft to Give Governments Access to Code
abstract: Microsoft Corp, in effort to slow acceptance of Linux operating system by governments abroad, announces that it will allow most governments to study programming code of its Windows systems; governments will be allowed to plug their security features instead of Microsoft's technology into Windows; more than two dozen countries are encouraging agencies to use 'open source' software--developed by programmers who distribute code without charge and donate their labor to debug and modify software cooperatively; best-known of open source projects is GNU Linux, operating system that Microsoft regards as leading competitive threat to Windows (M)

headline: PAY FOR ADELPHIA EXECUTIVES IS DEBATED IN COURT
abstract: Adelphia Communications asks Federal Bankruptcy Judge Robert Gerber to approve pay package for two newly hired executives William Schleyer and Ronald Cooper, while investor committee led by former board member Leonard Tow asks Gerber to reject or alter contracts; $41 million in compensation includes salary, bonuses, stock and options (S)

headline: Rule Your Own Realm: The Ultimate E-Mail Address
abstract: Article offers suggestion that e-mail users purchase their own domain name, eliminating having to change address with change of service provider; notes companies that offer service and prices; drawing (M)

headline: 2 U.S. Officers Expect More North Korean 'Provocations'
abstract: Two most senior officers overseeing American military operations in South Korea say it is likely that North Korea will step up its provocations in bid to gain financial aid and diplomatic attention from United States; Adm Thomas B Fargo and Gen Leon J LaPorte say North Korea would perhaps start up its nuclear reprocessor, provoke incident along demilitarized zone or at sea, or even conduct underground nuclear test; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Auto Sales Fall
abstract: Japan's auto sales fell to 16-year low in 2002; car and truck makers sold 5.8 million vehicles, 2.3 percent decline from pervious year; sales by Toyota Motor Corp fell 2.2 percent, while Honda Motor Co rose 7.9 percent (S)

headline: INVESTING WITH: Anton V. Schutz; Burnham Financial Services Fund
abstract: Carole Gould profile of Burnahm Financial Services fund and Anton V Schutz, president of Mendon Capital Advisors, which runs fund for Burnahm Asset Management; photo; chart (M)

headline: As Vaccination Rates Decline in Ireland, Cases of Measles Soar
abstract: Irish public health officials blame latent fears aout safety of vaccine for measles, mumps and rubella for measles outbreak; vaccination rate has fallen to 63 percent in parts of Dublin and 72 percent nationally, despite subsequent studies debunking study suggesting link between vaccine and autism; some Irish doctors say low immunization levels are chronic problem in Ireland; National Disease Surveillance Center official Dr Darina O'Flanagan presses for new immunization strategy (M)

headline: Trade Deficit Is Narrower As Economy Slows Buying
abstract: Commerce Department reports trade deficit narrowed in January from record as Americans bought fewer foreign-made goods in slowing economy and exports rose; trade gap in goods and services was $41.1 billion; deficit reached record $435.7 billion in 2002; imports fell 2 percent in January, to $123 billion; graph (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Aid Workers Questioned
abstract: Authorities in Zimbabwe question five foreign aid workers, including one American, and accuse them of working as journalists without accreditation; workers are from Lutheran World Federation and write for in-house publication; country's strict media laws require all foreign journalists to be invited before working there (S)

headline: Officials in Iraq Voice Defiance After Airstrikes
abstract: Senior Iraqi officials strike posture of defiance in face of advancing coalition troops and punishing air attacks on Baghdad that reduce many of Saddam Hussein's most prized palaces and other crucial government buildings to ruins; make public statements seeking to downplay damage; allied attacks underscore how defenseless Iraq is against satellite- and laser-guided weapons; Pentagon disputes claim of senior Iraqi official that two American pilots have been captured; that claim is part of wider pattern of statements that conflict starkly with American and British accounts of how war is going; Iraq contends that coalition ground forces scored none of breakthroughs claimed at port of Umm Qasr, or in drive north from Kuwait to Nasiriya; photos (M)

headline: The Week's Economic Events
abstract: MONDAYConstruction SpendingDec.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Sumitomo Mitsui Share Sale
abstract: Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group will raise 300 billion yen, or $2.5 billion, by selling preferred shares (S)

headline: North Korea Tests a Missile as South Korea Prepares for a New President
abstract: North Korea conducts its first missile launching test in three years, apparently seeking attention as Roh Moo Hyun is inaugurated as president of South Korea; US officials say test was of short range tactical missile and express no alarm; Kim Dae Jung, South Korea's departing president, rebuffs US call for multilateral talks with North Korea and urges direct dialogue between US and North Korea (M)

headline: Opposition to Britain's Iraq Plan Brings New Diplomatic Flurry
abstract: Britain and the United States said diplomatic talks — intended to round up more support among the Council's 15 members — would continue, perhaps into next week.

headline: U.N. Inspector Says Iraq Falls Short on Cooperation
abstract: Hans Blix, one of chief United Nations weapons inspectors, gives broadly negative report on Iraq's cooperation with two months of inspections, providing support to Bush administration's campaign to disarm Iraq by force if necessary; says Iraq appears not to genuinely accept--'not even today'--disarmament which is demanded of it; offers grim 15-page catalog of Iraq's chemical and biological arms programs that provide exhaustive account of ways in which Saddam Hussein has failed to prove he has eliminated illegal weapons; after Blix speaks, Secretary of State Colin L Powell says 'time is running out'; Pres Bush is expected to press his case for disarming Hussein in his State of Union address, and he is scheduled to meet later this week with allies, including Prime Min Tony Blair of Britain; administration officials say White House is likely to declassify some intelligence information about Iraq's effort to obtain and conceal weapons of mass destruction; Dr Mohamed ElBaradi, chief UN inspector for atomic weapons, says his team has found no evidence so far that Iraq has tried to revive its nuclear arms program; appeals to Security Council for 'few months' more to complete his work; clash in 15-member Security Council over duration of inspections sharpens, with US saying they have already gone on long enough and other veto-bearing Council nations, including France, Russia and China, contending that they should be allowed to continue; Britain supports German proposal that inspectors report back to Council again on Feb 14; photos (L)

headline: Powell Reaffirms U.S. Desire for North Korea to Face Council
abstract: The statement put the U.S. on opposite sides from China in a growing tug-of-war over Pyonyang's nuclear arms program.

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: RUSSIA: An Aluminum Tax Proposal; FRANCE: Engineer Revises Plan; GERMANY: Media Bidder Withdraws;.

headline: Wall Street has voiced confidence in Interpublic's new chief but questions whether he will succeed.
abstract: Shares of Interpublic Group of Companies gain 5 percent on news of that David Bell has replaced John J Dooner Jr as chairman and chief executive, but doubts are multiplying about whether restructured management team can pull off turnaround at company whose problems range from federal investigation of its accounting procedures to mounting losses at a sports-marketing division (M)

headline: Tribune Names Broadcast Chief
abstract: Tribune Co names Patrick Mullen president of company's broadcasting unit to oversee Tribune's 24 television stations, its entertainment division and Chicago radio station; succeeds Dennis FitzSimons (S)

headline: Jobless Claims Remain High
abstract: Labor Department reports initial jobless claims totaled 421,000 in week ended March 14 and 425,000 previous week; says less-volatile four-week average of claims rose to 424,750 from 421,000; Conference Board says index of leading economic indicators fell 0.4 percent in February; Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia's general economic index dropped to minus 8.0 in March from 2.3 in February (M)

headline: With Bombing, Iraqis Escalate Guerrilla Tactics and Show New Danger on Front Lines
abstract: Suicide attack that kills four Army solders at checkpoint north of Najaf leaves commanders stunned and angry; will almost certainly result in tightening of security around units spread across hundreds of square miles of Iraq; attack is significant escalation of guerrilla tactics used by Iraqi fighters to harass American-led troops; photo; map (M)

headline: Marines See Iraqi Army Bound by Fear, Not Loyalty
abstract: Members of First Marine Division, who will lead charge toward Baghdad, believe Iraqi Army will crumble before them, but worry that Saddam Hussein will barricade himself in city to force siege and humanitarian crisis to play to world public opinion; they say they have learned from intelligence reports that Iraqi Army is poorly equipped and disciplined, and held together by fear of retribution rather than any sense of loyalty (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft To Buy Some Assets Of Connectix
abstract: Microsoft Corp will purchase some of assets of Connectix Corp, small maker of so-called virtual machine software; deal includes company's flagship product, Virtual PC, which permits Macintosh users to run applications written for Microsoft Windows and Intel-based personal computers; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: REGULATOR SEEKS DETAILS OF EL PASO'S BORROWING PLAN
abstract: El Paso Corp asks Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to provide details of plan to sell assets and borrow against two units as company raises cash for debt reduction; commission is concerned that company's Southern Natural Gas and ANR Pipeline units might become saddled with debt of their parent; El Paso agrees to sell natural gas reserves to Chesapeake Energy (S)

headline: Japan Airlines Moves Its Account
abstract: Japan Airlines names Colby & Partners to ha

headline: Chinese Computer Maker Plans a Push Overseas
abstract: Legend Group, China's largest manufacturer of personal computers, plans big push into foreign markets soon, probably including forays into United States and Europe (M)

headline: Chile Feels the Weight of Its Security Council Seat
abstract: From the moment it joined the United Nations Security Council on Jan. 1, Chile has followed a strategy of trying to stay out of the line of fire on the Iraq crisis, hoping that the five permanent members can reach a compromise that would spare smaller nations from having to take sides.    But with that outcome now unlikely, President Ricardo Lagos finds himself pressed by the United States on one side and by deepening domestic opposition to any war on the other.

headline: Yahoo's Paid Video to Supply Sports, Finance and 'Survivor'
abstract: Yahoo is set to introduce its first subscription video service, with programming that includes college basketball, investment news and CBS's Survivor (M)

headline: Market Place; Group Increases Its Hostile Offer For Mall Empire
abstract: Simon Property Group increases its hostile offer for A Alfred Taubman's shopping mall empire and enlists new partner Westfield America in takeover battle; Simon Property and Westfield, which is controlled by Australian mall developer Westfield Holdings, offers $20 per share in cash, or about $1.7 billion, for Taubman Centers and its upscale malls; offer is 11 percent increase from previous bid; chart; photos (Market Place column) (M)

headline: U.S. Missile Hits British Jet; Crew Is Missing
abstract: A search is under way for the crew of a British Tornado aircraft appeared to have been shot down early today by a United States patriot missile.

headline: INTERNATIONAL EDUCATION/ A SPECIAL REPORT: Setting up a business school in Asia
abstract: Insead, one of Europe's largest and most prestigious business schools, recently opened a new campus in Singapore. Rather than an offshoot of the main campus aimed at an Asian market, Helmut Schutte, dean of the Asia campus, told Thomas Crampton of the International Herald Tribune that the project is part of a fully integrated global campus.

headline: NATO Decides by Consensus
abstract: Last week's Dispatches column, about the debate within NATO over protecting Turkey, prompted a letter from a spokesman for Lord Robertson, the NATO secretary general. Here is the letter and a brief reply from Michael R. Gordon.

headline: Webdenda
abstract: Advertising revenue for print and electronic versions of Yellow Pages directories rose 1.4 percent in 2002, to $14.1 billion, compared with $13.9 billion in 2001, according to the Yellow Pages Integrated Media Association, Berkeley Heights, N.J. The 2001 figure was revised upward from a previous estimate of $13.6 billion. The association predicted a 2.9 percent increase in ad revenue in 2003 from 2002, to $14.5 billion. Stella Barrett was named to the new post of Chicago sales representative at Parade , the Sunday newspaper supplement owned by Advance Publications. She had been media manager at Ace Hardware, Oak Brook, Ill. Kerry Bianchi , vice president for marketing at Time4 Outdoors , New York, was named to the new post of associate publisher and director for marketing services. Time4 Outdoors, which publishes magazines like Field and Stream and Outdoor Life, is a division of Time4 Media, part of the Time Inc. unit of AOL Time Warner. Cathy Brown , group account director at the Tracy Locke Partnership , Dallas, was named a partner. Tracy Locke is part of the Omnicom Group. Deborah R. Cohen , senior vice president at the Chamberlain Communications Group , New York, and Ovidio L. Torres , executive vice president, were named partners. Gayle Champagne was named manager at the new Detroit office of the James G. Elliott Company . She had been Detroit sales director at InStyle magazine, published by the Time Inc. unit of AOL Time Warner. The Direct Marketing Association , New York, acquired the DM Days New York Conference and Expo , a direct marketing trade show. Terms were not disclosed. Lori Golay was named senior vice president and account director at Colby & Partners , Santa Monica, Calif. She had been senior partner and director for client services at the Los Angeles office of J. Walter Thompson, part of the WPP Group. Colby is owned by Dentsu. Jim Heininger was named partner and general manager of a new Chicago office of Carmichael Lynch Spong , the public relations unit of Carmichael Lynch, which is based in Minneapolis. Mr. Heininger had most recently been partner and general manager at the Chicago office of Porter Novelli, part of the Omnicom Group. Carmichael Lynch is part of Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Carole Kessie , East Coast advertising manager at Spa Magazine , New York, part of Islands Media, was named East Coast sales director, succeeding JoAnn Martin, who left, the company said. Andy Law , founder and chairman of St. Luke's , London, and Kate Stanners , deputy chairwoman, resigned, the agency said. Their departures came after weeks of debate by board members over the future course of the agency, which was formed in 1995. The resignations mean that the agency will be led by its joint managing directors, Neil Henderson and Phil Teer. Lloyd Lawrence , art director at Media Logic , Albany, was promoted to the new post of senior art director. Gary McBride was named president and chief executive of the Latin American Multichannel Advertising Council , Miami, a new organization formed by divisions of 23 cable television networks including CNN International, the Discovery Channel, Fox Kids and Turner Broadcasting System Latin America. Mr. McBride had been a consultant and before that was president at the Latin American division of Bates Worldwide, part of the Cordiant Communications Group. The organization works to persuade marketers that advertise on Latin American television to spend more of their budgets on cable TV. The Promotion Marketing Association , New York, formed the Event Marketing Council and named two co-chairmen: Charlie Horsey , chief executive at CMI, New York, part of Clear Channel Worldwide, and Kerry Smith , publisher at Event Marketer magazine, Norwalk, Conn., published by Event Media Associates. Rich Rasor , Eastern advertising director for the Marine Group at Time4 Media , New York, was named to the new post of general advertising director for the group. Time4 Media is part of the Time Inc. unit of AOL Time Warner. Jordan H. Rednor and Steve Gundersen opened a consulting company in New York, the Rednor Gundersen Group . Until August, Mr. Rednor was president and chief operating officer at the New York office of Draft Worldwide, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. At that time, he was shifted to a post at Interpublic with unspecified duties, and he left Interpublic in recent weeks. Mr. Gundersen continues as chief executive at Gundersen Partners, New York, which specializes in executive searches. Toby Simpkins was named to the vacant post of vice president and director for promotions at Cramer-Krasselt , Milwaukee. She had been senior marketing manager for the customer marketing and business innovation group at the Coca-Cola Company, Atlanta. Annette Suarez , senior producer at Margeotes Fertitta & Partners , New York, was named to the vacant post of director for broadcast production. Margeotes is majority-owned by the Maxxcom unit of the MDC Corporation. The Texas Rangers Baseball Club , Arlington, Tex., named Ornelas & Associates , Dallas, the first agency of record for advertising aimed at Hispanic consumers. Billings were not disclosed. The Rangers are part of the Southwest Sports Group.

headline: Not Going Green Is Called a Matter of Economics
abstract: Tools for constructing environmentally conscious, energy-efficient office buildings have existed for decades, but commercial developers have not adopted principles of what is commonly called green or sustainable building because compelling case demonstrating economic rewards has not been made; movement is underway to promote green development as economically compelling, complete with trade organization that sets aside and rewards certifications to buildings under Energy and Environmental Design program administered by private US Green Building Council; innovations in Tower Building in Rockville, Md, discussed; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Broadcom Shares Drop After Unit Head Is Replaced
abstract: Shar

headline: Old British Newsreels Find New Life Online
abstract: British Pathe puts more than 3,500 hours of its old newsreels online, where they can be viewed at no charge; photo (M)

headline: North Korean Talks? U.S. Weighs the Possible Price
abstract: Analysis: now that North Korea has sent signal via Gov Bill Richardson that it might be willing to discuss ways to pull back from crisis with United States, Bush administration officials must decide whether to open direct negotiations with North or dismiss efforts of Richardson, who recently talked with North Koreans; photo (M)

headline: Iraq Pins Hopes on Antiwar Mood at U.N. and in Streets Around the World
abstract: Iraqi leadership appears convinced that its best chance to forestall war lies in cultivating antiwar sentiment both at United Nations Security Council and on streets of world capitals; range of interlocutors from Dr Mohamed ElBaradei, director general of International Atomic Energy Agency, to Baghdad-based diplomats to writers in other Arabic newspapers warn Iraqis not to delude themselves, emphasizing that patience in Security Council is limited and that demonstrators are hardly marching in support of Iraqi government or of any weapons of mass destruction it might have; photos (M)

headline: Message to Saddam:Exile is his last chance : Diplomacy ends; Bush issuing an ultimatum
abstract: WASHINGTON:—  President George W. Bush planned to issue an ultimatum Monday to President Saddam Hussein, saying in a formal address from the White House that the Iraqi leader must leave the country or face war.

headline: Slump Aside, Trade Deficit Hits a Record
abstract: Commerce Department reports record $44.2 billion trade deficit in December, up 10 percent from November, sign that economic growth around world remains even weaker than it does in US; imports rose, with those from China leading increase, sending trade deficit to $435.2 billion in 2002, up from $358 billion in 2001; US had its biggest trade deficit with China, followed by European Union, Japan and Canada; computer exports fell 12.6 percent, to $9.2 billion, and imports rose 27.6 percent, to $16.2 billion (M)

headline: P.&G. to Acquire German Hair-Care Concern for $5.8 Billion
abstract: The deal — the largest in Procter & Gamble's history — will give the Cincinnati-based company an entree into the global hair-care market.

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Change At Six Continents; GERMANY: Trouble For Mobilcom Founder; SWITZERLAND: Abb Unit Seeks Protection; BRITAIN: Ruling Favors Czech Brewer; CZECH REPUBLIC: Dispute Over Tv Station;.

headline: Pakistanis Protest Possible Iraq War
abstract: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, March 2 — Tens of thousands of Pakistanis marched in Karachi today to oppose a military attack on Iraq, shouting

headline: Labor Government Unveils Finance Plans for Higher Education
abstract: The Labor government proposed that universities should be allowed to charge students higher tuition fees, and that students, in turn, should be able to delay paying until after graduation.

headline: Freddie Mac's Profit Rises
abstract: Freddie Mac says fourth-quarter profit increased to $1.7 billion from $1.36 billion year earlier; operating earnings fell 1 percent, to $846 million (S)

headline: Powell's Address, Presenting 'Deeply Troubling' Evidence on Iraq
abstract: Transcript of Sec Colin Powell's address to UN Security Council presenting US evidence of Iraqi weapons programs; photos; maps; diagrams (L)

headline: New Wariness in Russia Toward Help From West
abstract: Russia appears to withdraw its welcome to Americans and other foreigners trying to help country's people and institutions, such as by denying visa to 30 Peace Corps volunteers and barring re-entry of Irene Stevenson, American labor activist; American officials and experts say trend could undermine not only Russia's image as emerging democracy but also its relations with US; some officials attribute actions to wounded pride, feeling that Russia does not need outside help; Stevenson photo (M)

headline: U.N. Planning To Feed Iraqis In a War, Annan Says
abstract: Secretary Gen Kofi Annan tells Security Council that United Nations is planning to feed up to 10 million hungry Iraqi civilians and care for at least 2.6 million refugees in wake of possible American-led war in Iraq; appeals to 15 Council ambassadors for $120 million to pay for urgent contingency planning (M)

headline: International Briefs | Europe: Ireland: Home Prices Rise
abstract: Data reveal that average price of house in Ireland rose 13.3 percent in 2002, up from 4.4 percent in 2001 ; average house price in Dublin, most expensive area, ranges around 280,000 euros ($303,000) (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Airline's Loss Narrows
abstract: Privatized Spanish airline Iberia says its loss narrowed to 15.6 million euros ($17 million) in fourth quarter from 88.7 million euros year earlier (S)

headline: Path to Universal Insurance
abstract: Steve Abramson letter comments on Jan 5 article about political backing for universal health care

headline: U.S. Confident Much of Europe Will 'Heed the Call' on Iraq
abstract: The White House expressed firm resolve on Iraq today, saying that several European countries would join in a "strong coalition."

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: LIBERIA: Inquiry Into Aid Workers' Killings; CENTRAL AFRICAN REPUBLIC: President Deposed;.

headline: Mideastern Investment in U.S. Properties Soars
abstract: Influx of investment capital from both Arab and Israeli investors, in roughly equal proportion, makes Middle East second-largest source of foreign investment in United States commercial real estate this year after Europe, where changes in German pension fund laws contributed to surge in investment in American properties; within last year, seven apartment complexes in San Antonio and six more throughout Texas were purchased by Alon USA, based in Dallas, subsidiary of Alon Israel Oil Company; oil companies are major sources of investment in American commercial real estate; photo of San Antonio apartment complex; table shows leading sources of foreign investment in US commercial real estate (M)

headline: Kurdish Forces Prepare To Attack in Northern Iraq
abstract: Kurdish officials say Kurdish guerrillas have been acting as guides and scouts inside Iraqi-controlled territory, helping small teams of American soldiers to enter Iraq for missions behind Iraqi lines; larger groups of Kurdish soldiers are moving into at least four front-line villages around Kirkuk and Mosul, feeding speculation that Kurdish forces will be asked to play significant role in any American effort to open northern front against Iraqi Army; Kurdish officials say American Special Operations forces and Kurdish fighters are within days of launching ground offensive against Ansar al-Islam, militant Islamic movement with alleged ties to Al Qaeda, which controls small pocket of territory between Kurdish-controlled northeastern Iraq and Iran; photo; map (M)

headline: France to Veto Resolution On Iraq War, Chirac Says
abstract: In a dramatic break with the United States, President Jacques Chirac said tonight that France would veto a United Nations resolution threatening war against Iraq.    ''My position is that whatever the circumstances, France will vote no,'' Mr. Chirac said. He added that he had ''the feeling'' that Russia and China, which also have veto power in the Security Council, are prepared to follow France's lead.

headline: Private Sector; Not Exactly the Family Silver, but Still . . .
abstract: Exor, company through which Angelli family controls their assets in France, sells 75 percent it owned of venerable Chateau Margaux estate and its 245 acres of vineyards; buyer is Corinne Mentzelopoulos, daughter of Andre Mentzelopoulos, who had originally sold stake to Angellis; photo (M)

headline: 2 Wall St. Firings Said to Be Linked To Harassment
abstract: J P Morgan Chase dismisses investment bankers Palden Gyuimed Namagyal, managing director and son of onetime king of Sikkim, and Norman Gretzinger after fellow banker complained that they sexually accosted in bar woman who worked for them; some Wall Street people say swift and severe action against high-ranking and highly paid employees shows how seriously some big investment banks treat complaints of sexual harassment; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Turning Out A Red Light
abstract: The Minister of Women's Affairs, Mu Sochua, said the police had shut down one of the seediest landmarks of Phnom Penh, a brothel district in Svay Pak village commonly known, by its distance from the capital, as Kilometer 11. A warren of dirt alleys patrolled by thugs and touts, it emerged in the 1990's to serve the desires of United Nations peacekeepers. Many women who work there were trafficked from Vietnam, and many are under age.   Seth Mydans (NYT)

headline: Market Place; Corporate Gain, Treasury's Loss In Bush Plan
abstract: Latest changes in Bush administration's tax proposal on dividends would probably provide tax exemption for companies whose dividends would have been taxable under Bush's original proposal, under which dividends would be tax-exempt only to extent they came from profits on which company actually paid taxes; one change would benefit companies that in past have been forced to pay corporate alternative minimum tax; other principle change would make it easier for companies to obtain refunds of taxes paid in previous years and would make it easier for cyclical companies to make all their dividends tax-exempt (M)

headline: New Element In Iraq's Mix
abstract: Analysis of efforts by Bush administration to persuade UN Security Council to soften its opposition to war in Iraq; contends Pres George Bush may have set new standard for avoiding war impossibly high by declaring that he would be satisfied only with Iraq's complete disarmament and Saddam Hussein's departure; notes chief UN weapons inspectors Hans Blix and Mohamed ElBaradei have no mandate to change Baghdad government; photos (M)

headline: Bush and Blair Express Determination to Remove Hussein
abstract: Uncompromising resolve was also voiced by Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, who appeared before the Senate Approprations Committee as the two leaders were speaking at Camp David.

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: INDONESIA: Price Plan Falters; JAPAN: December Sales Fall; JAPAN: Decline In Auto Sales Forecast; JAPAN: The Cost Of Wireless; SOUTH KOREA: Broadband Purchase Scrapped;.

headline: COCA-COLA TO LAY OFF 1,000 EMPLOYEES IN NORTH AMERICA
abstract: Coca-Cola Co will lay off 1,000 employees in North America; five hundreds cuts will be made at company's headquarters in Atlanta; chairman-chief executive Douglas N Daft comments (S)

headline: Turkey Sends Army Troops Into Iraq, Report Says
abstract: Turkish troops cross Iraqi border hours after government opens airspace to American military planes bound for Iraq; move will likely anger Bush administration officials and Kurds of northern Iraq; there is deep concern in Turkey that Kurds may use war to set up independent Kurdistan, which Turkish officials fear would inflame their own large Kurdish minority; Turkish Foreign Min Abdullah Gul says troops are there to prevent flight of refugees into Turkey; photo (M)

headline: Italy Considers a Proposal to Cut the Time to Complete a Divorce
abstract: Italian Parliament is considering proposal that would drastically reduce time it takes to get divorce; country has one of world's highest concentrations of Roman Catholics and one of European Union's lowest divorce rates; messy divorces can take up to 10 years in Italy before final papers are signed; politicians say obligatory three-year separation period often ends in more years of limbo and legal bills; proposal would reduce period to one year; Vatican has attacked proposal on ground that it would further erode family values (M)

headline: History in a Greenhouse
abstract: Biotechnology company Antigenics chief executive Garo H Armen The Boss column on his life and career; photo (M)

headline: Gateway Switches To Leo Burnett
abstract: Gateway changes creative ad agencies for thi

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Technology Loss Narrows
abstract: World Business Briefing: Ireland: Technology Lo

headline: A-Arms Treaty: Goals and Signers
abstract: Treaty on Nonproliferation of Nuclear Weapons took effect in Mar 1970; seeks to prevent spread of nuclear arms and arms technology and to promote disarmament and cooperation on peaceful uses of nuclear energy (S)

headline: CINTAS, MAKER OF UNIFORMS, LOWERS ITS OUTLOOK
abstract: Cintas Corp, country's largest maker of uniforms, lowers its fiscal 2003 expectations even further, as sales during holidays fell significantly below expectations (S)

headline: Hyundai Sorry for Paying North Korea
abstract: Hyundai group chairman Chung Mong Hun apologizes for secretly sending $500 million to North Korea; payments brought about North-South summit in June 2000 and helped company win number of contracts (S)

headline: Trading Places; In an $800 Palm-Based Model, The Aroma of Power and Luxury
abstract: Palm and other companies that make organizers expand product lines to include larger color screen, headphone jack, microphone for voice notes and video output for showing photos; sacrifice low price and light weight to include such multi-use functions; photos (M)

headline: Oil Price Falls on Chance of More Output
abstract: Price of crude oil falls for second day on speculation that OPEC will raise production to make up for shortfall from Venezuela and take advantage of 16 percent rally this month; in New York, crude oil for February delivery falls 17 cents, to $31.20 a barrel; graphs (S)

headline: Plan for U.S. Troops in Philippines Hits Snag
abstract: US Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld, following meeting in Washington with Philippine counterpart Angelo Reyes, says plan to send US troops to fight Muslim extremists on island of Jolo in southern Philippines has been put on hold; two sides are unable to agree on rules that would conform with Philippine Constitution, which prohibits foreign troops from carrying out combat missions; photo (M)

headline: Reviews Begin on 2 Big Accounts
abstract: Reviews Begin On 2 Big Accounts Two big advertisers, America Online and Nextel Communications, have started reviews on their accounts, with combined billings estimated at $300 million to $400 million.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bayer Lawsuits Increase
abstract: Bayer AG says number of lawsuits it faced after recall of anticholesterol drug Baycol has risen to 7,400 from 5,700 in November; Baycol was withdrawn in August 2001 after it was linked to more than 50 deaths worldwide (S)

headline: Sharon Says Arafat's Truce Call Aims at Influencing Israeli Voters
abstract: Prime Min Ariel Sharon of Israel speaks dismissively of Yasir Arafat's appeal for pre-election halt to Palestinian attacks on Israeli civilians; implies that Arafat is trying to help his dovish opponent; Palestinian officials, who view Sharon as implacable enemy, have openly voiced their preference for his opponent Haifa Mayor Amram Mitzna, former general who has said he would dismantle Jewish settlements in West Bank and Gaza Strip and reopen direct negotiations with Palestinians (M)

headline: For Laptops, A New Way To Say 'Fast'
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column describes Centrino, new microprocessor designed specifically for laptops; chip increases speed yet extends battery life; chart compares features and prices of various models with new chip; drawing (M)

headline: Korean Says Foreigners' Fears Are Hurting Stock Market
abstract: South Korea's new finance minister, Kim Jin Pyo, asserts that foreigners' misconceptions about tensions with North Korea are to blame for much of South Korean stock market's shaky performance in recent weeks and may be scaring investors away from country (S)

headline: Plan to Offer Free Electronic Tax Filing
abstract: Seventeen tax preparation companies will offer free electronic tax filing under agreement announced that will keep government out of software business; Acting Treas Sec Kenneth Dam says that up to 75 million Americans will be eligible for free tax preparation and filing under program; Internal Revenue Service has begun to provide link on its Web site to 17 companies; companies receive assurances that IRS will not develop its own tax preparation software; H&R Block director Robert Weinberger says it is too early to gauge any financial benefit from participating in program (M)

headline: Defense precedents : Japan breaks ground in naval cooperation
abstract: TOKYO—  The Aegis-class destroyer Kirishima recently left the Japanese port of Yokosuka for the Indian Ocean. The Kirishima will replace one of three other Japanese destroyers escorting support ships that have been refueling other countries' ships involved in the war on terrorism in Afghanistan.

headline: Sharon Close to Forming 3-Party Government in Israel
