abstract: Prime Min Ariel Sharon is putting together coalition government for Israel comprising his hawkish Likud Party, fiercely secular Shinui Party and National Religious Party, leading advocate of Jewish settlers; government would be expected to take tough line on Palestinian uprising and on restarting peace negotiations; Shinui's participation and Sharon's shunning of ultra-Orthodox factions could mean reduction in role of religion in Israeli civil live; other parties might join coalition, which has only 61 seats in 120-seat parliament; photo (M)

headline: The Poor Woman Is Gone And Her Castle's Besieged
abstract: Local authorities in Wales plan to take Cardigan Castle and turn it into museum and tourist attraction now that its owner, Barbara Wood, who has jealously kept them at bay, is moved to retirement home; lawyer who claims to have power of attorney over her affairs refuses to hand property over and has offered it for sale for $1.28 million; photos (M)

headline: G.E. CHIEF RECEIVES A 10% RAISE, TO $6.9 MILLION
abstract: General Electric Co increased salary and bonus of Jeffrey R Immelt by 10 percent, to $6.9 million, in his first full year as chief executive officer (S)

headline: Israeli Troops Kill Three Palestinian Militants
abstract: Israeli troops in the West Bank tore down a three-story apartment building with a tank shell and a bulldozer today.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Where's The Plutonium?
abstract: Anonymous Japanese offical at government's nuclear safety office reports 450 pounds of plutonium missing from Tokaimura complex; does not suspect foul play, only mismanagement and faulty measurements; amount, however,is sizeable enough to manufacture 25 bombs (S)

headline: In Iraq's Kurdish Zone, Anti-Hussein Forces Wait for U.S.
abstract: Kurds in northern Iraq are still waiting to see if United States will open conventional northern front, which remains possibility after Turkish Parliament votes to allow American planes to fly through Turkish airspace into Iraq; vote would allow Pentagon to airlift troops into Kurdish territory, should it choose to do so; in interim, Kurdish fighters are portrait of both confusion and restraint; photo (M)

headline: S.E.C. Adopts New Rules For Lawyers And Funds
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission votes to adopt rules that would require lawyers to take concerns about violations of securities laws to top executives at companies they advise and, if necessary, to corporate boards; rules would not require lawyers to take their concerns directly to SEC if executives and board fail to respond appropriately to lawyer's warning; final version of rule also offers complex definition explaining when lawyer must report evidence of fraud to management; SEC also approves rules requiring mutual funds to disclose how they vote investors' shares on corporate issues, change that was criticized by mutual fund executives but widely praised by shareholder advocates; outgoing SEC chairman Harvey L Pitt comments; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Cyprus: Protest Against Peace Plan
abstract: At least 30,000 Turkish Cypriots stage demonstration supporting leader's rejection of UN peace plan; Greek and Turkish leaders are facing March 10 deadline to decide whether to hold public vote on plan (S)

headline: Los Angeles Magazine Banks on a New Voice
abstract: Los Angeles Magazine, 42-year-old survivor of multiple makeovers and variety of owners, attempts revamping designed to allow it to thrive in city's urban sprawl where more than a dozen competitors have gone out of business in past 20 years; Emmis Communications is current owner hoping to re-invigorate magazine; photos (M)

headline: Suspect Is Arrested in the Killing of a Hong Kong Businessman
abstract: Police in China report arrest of suspect in murder of Henry Lam, prominent Hong Kong businessmen who was shot while dining at one of Hong Kong's most famous restaurants (M)

headline: Turkey's Cabinet Approves Plan, With Details Lacking, for U.S. Troops
abstract: The Turkish government endorsed a proposal today to allow thousands of American troops into the country for a possible attack on Iraq. It did so even before the two countries had worked out the final details of the agreement, a senior Turkish official said.    An endorsement by the Turkish cabinet would ordinarily clear the way for the measure to be taken up by the Parliament. But a Turkish official said the cabinet took up and approved the incomplete agreement under pressure from Washington.

headline: Ahem. Did You Notice My Work?
abstract: Anecdotes on getting recognition in workplace (S)

headline: Defectors Bolster U.S. Case Against Iraq, Officials Say
abstract: Bush administration officials have concluded that international inspectors are unlikely to find tangible and irrefutable evidence that Iraq is hiding weapons of mass destruction, so administration is preparing its own assessment that will rely heavily on evidence from Iraqi defectors; former Iraqi scientists, military officers and contractors have provided American intelligence agencies with portrait of Saddam Hussein's secret programs to develop and conceal chemical, biological and nuclear weapons that is starkly at odds with findings so far of UN weapons inspectors; but there are deep divisions in Washington over value of information from defectors; administration says three or four thought to have most valuable firsthand information have been placed in witness protection program and offered asylum (M)

headline: Economy Saddled by Worry Over Security, Fed Chief Says
abstract: The economy is laboring under a cloud of geopolitical tensions and uncertainties, but it generally remains as it was six months ago, Alan Greenspan told Congress today.

headline: Tanker Ships Face Inquiry In Europe Over Pricing
abstract: European antitrust officials have raided the offices of four companies that operate oceangoing chemical tanker ships this week, looking for evidence that they colluded to fix rates. But one of the companies said that what might look like collusion was actually normal business in a small, struggling market.    ''If we are fixing prices, then we are doing a pretty poor job of it,'' said Geoffrey Thompson, managing director of European operations for the Tokyo Marine Company, whose offices in London were searched Wednesday morning by seven European Commission officials. Most companies in the business are losing money, Mr. Thompson said, and Tokyo Marine is barely turning a profit.

headline: Officer's Death in Antiterror Raid Stirs Debate in Britain
abstract: The police interrogated three North African men in the wake of an antiterror raid on Tuesday that led to the killing of an officer in Manchester.

headline: Taiwan Ends a Half-Century Freeze on Flights to China With a Trip to Shanghai
abstract: Taiwan's China Airlines breaks half-century freeze on commercial aviation across Taiwan Strait, picking up passengers at international airport in Shanghai and returning to Taiwan; flight is first of 16 charter flights to help Taiwanese living in mainland China to return home for Lunar New Year holiday; it is billed as important step toward restoring transportation links between political rivals; China has pushed for direct transport links for several years, but Taiwan has moved slowly to allow people and goods to flow freely to and from mainland, citing security concerns (M)

headline: States Pan for Gold By Luring the Gray
abstract: States, especially southern states, are aggressively marketing themselves to Americans approaching retirement, hoping they will relocate with their pensions and life savings; studies find that healthy retirees give more to a community than they get back; photo (M)

headline: Computers Seized by F.B.I. Are Returned
abstract: The Medi-Hut Company, a medical supplies company whose headquarters were raided by federal agents in November, said that the F.B.I. had returned all of its computers.

headline: 3 Terror Suspects Agree to Extradition to U.S.
abstract: Three men sought accused of plotting to trade drugs for antiaircraft missiles agreed today to their extradition.

headline: Turkey Calls a Regional Meeting To Try to Head Off an Iraq War
abstract: Turkish Prime Minister Abdullah Gul calls for regional foreign ministers to meet in attempt to avert American-led war with Iraq; says he gave Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein blunt personal warning of war if he does not comply with United Nations resolutions; Middle Eastern leaders grow increasingly desperate to prevent war but remain eager to be on winning side should one start; Western diplomat reports that Turkish leaders agree in principle to allow American air and ground forces to use country as base to stage military strikes against Iraq; commentators speculate that latest flurry of diplomacy by Middle Eastern officials is intended to provide political cover for countries to join military venture that is overwhelmingly opposed by their own people; photo (M)

headline: Vatican Book Is Offering Reflections On 'New Age'
abstract: Vatican issues 90-page booklet reflecting on New Age movement; is worried that people might turn away from church in favor of holistic spiritualism that promises 'cosmic correspondences' and vague connection to nature and universe at risk of diminishing God (S)

headline: 'IN PRINCIPLE,' IRAQ AGREES TO DESTROY FORBIDDEN MISSILES
abstract: Government of Saddam Hussein says it agrees 'in principle' to begin destroying ballistic missiles judged illegal because their range exceeds limits imposed after Persian Gulf war; decision is in letter to Hans Blix, chief United Nations weapons inspector, after he distributes report concluding that Iraq made 'very limited' response to disarmament requirements set forth by Security Council last Nov; report, to be delivered to Security Council on Feb 28, appears to offer some support for Bush administration's claim that Hussein is not serious about disarming; Iraq's pledge to destroy more than 120 missiles indicates Hussein is trying to head off military assault by US and its allies; Pres Bush dismisses Iraq's plan to destroy missiles, saying 'total, complete disarmament' is what has been demanded; senior administration officials claim their intense lobbying campaign is making progress toward securing 9 of 15 Security Council votes for American, British and Spanish resolution that would provide United Nations backing for military action (M)

headline: Loss Narrowed in 4th Quarter at Liberty Media
abstract: Liberty Media reports fourth-quarter loss of $692 million compared with net loss of $3.71 billion year earlier; revenue rose 2.9 percent, to $536 million; Liberty and Comcast signal they may restructure their joint venture to operate home-shopping channel QVC (M)

headline: Market Place; Oil Companies Are Said to Balk On Production
abstract: Study by Cambridge Energy Research Associates shows many of largest oil and gas companies are hesitant to greatly increase their investments in oil production because they fear volatile prices in future; says hesitancy comes as oil industry begins to grapple with many challenges over next seven years in nearly every realm, from drilling for oil to shipping and refining it; warns world markets could face possible shortages and companies could face lower returns on future projects if such caution continues; general strike in Venezuela and growing possibility of war in Iraq have lifted oil prices from $25 to $26 per barrel in November; crude oil for March delivery falls 64 cents, or 1.8 percent, to $34.48 per barrel in New York; graphs; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Exchange Restrictions Lifted
abstract: Argentine government lifts currency exchange restrictions imposed year ago when economy collapsed and default on nearly $141 billion in public debt was announced; move is intended to help break months-long logjam in talks with International Monetary Fund, which has complained about currency controls (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Insurer Takes A Charge
abstract: Belgian-Dutch banking and insurance concern Fortis says it lost 1. 7 billion euros ($1.8 billion) in stock market in 2002, causing its annual earnings to decline more than 80 percent (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Germany Restricts Game It Says Glorifies War
abstract: German government places Electronic Arts computer game depicting animated US siege of Baghdad on index of games it considers violent, barring their promotion and display but allowing stores to keep them under the counters and sell them to adults; drawing (S)

headline: Warlord Is Said to Be Ready to End Standoff With Kabul
abstract: Padsha Khan Zadran, powerful Afghan warlord who is pro-American and anti-Taliban but who opposes American-backed government of Pres Hamid Karzai, may be softening his opposition after months of deadlock and bloodshed; negotiations between Zadran and Karzai, through mediator, may be close to ending standoff; United Nations officials are seeking to negotiate face-saving way for Zadran to change in his position; he has railed against Karzai's 'illegitimate government,' but he is losing support as backing for Karzai grows; photo; map (M)

headline: Greek Monks Guard Faith and Sacred Ground
abstract: Some 110 ultra-orthodox monks led by Father Methodius resist eviction from Esfigmenou monastery, Mount Athos, Greece; local police have restricted movement of supplies and visitors into and out of fortress-like monastery; representatives of some of 19 other Orthodox monasteries on peninsula vow to oust monks; isolated peninsula has long been revered by Orthodox Christians and remains semi-autonomous state; Patriarch Bartholomew has branded Esfigmenous monks schismatics after 30-year dispute over their rejection of ecumenism and ordered their eviction; dispute is before Greece's highest administrative court; map; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Australia/New Zealand
abstract: AUSTRALIA: Jobless Rate Falls; NEW ZEALAND: Flat Retail Sales;.

headline: Patents; Some new incarnations of snow, for the industry and the wintry-blanket effect.
abstract: Two Swedish inventors patent method of using artificial snow to kill bugs and other vermin; three Japanese inventors patent method of testing snow tires on turntable covered with artificial snow; Florida man patents device that sprinkles artificial snow over branches of trees to give them winter wonderland look (M)

headline: New Prime Minister Takes Charge in Turkey
abstract: Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the leader of the Islamic-based political party that rules Turkey, assumed the post of prime minister and assembled a new Turkish government today.

headline: War a Boon For Outfitters And Trainers
abstract: War in Iraq has been boon for British companies that provide equipment and training for hundreds of people sent by news media to cover American and British forces in Iraq; London-based Expedition Kit Ltd has expanded its line to include combat gear like protective vests and bullet-proof plates; founder Tim Simpson says sales have quadrupled since expanding its line; SatCom Distribution in Salisbury, Wiltshire, says sales of satellite phones have increased considerably; AKE Group and Pilgrims Group are offering courses to teach journalists, humanitarian aid workers and others how to cope with dangerous situation like combat and kidnapping; Centurion Risk Assessment Services founder Paul Rees says business has doubled in last year; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Democracy Advocate On Trial Again
abstract: Nine-judge panel in Egypt opens third trial of Saad Eddin Ibrahim, Egyptian-American social scientist and democracy advocate charged with defaming Egypt and taking money from overseas without authorization (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Deal Lets Wachovia Control Prudential Brokerage Unit  The acquisition of Prudential Financial's brokerage division by Wachovia will give the bank a 62 percent stake in the new brokerage company. Prudential will retain 38 percent. The two companies have been negotiating the combination, originally conceived as a joint venture, since the fall.    The combination of the two units will create the nation's third-largest brokerage firm, with client assets of $537 million. Wachovia and Prudential will take combined charges and accounting adjustments of $681 million in connection with the deal, and expect savings of $220 million. [Page C3.]

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: PAKISTAN: Religious Coalition Seeks Islamic Law; CHINA: Amusement At U.S. Charges; JAPAN: Premier Vows To Press Reforms;.

headline: Factories Wrest Land From China's Farmers
abstract: Huge swaths of farmland in China are being seized by officials and sold for commercial use, often with little or no compensation for farmers, who lease land collectively held by their villages and have only vague property rights; many of country's one billion farmers are struggling to survive as they watch their farmland being turned into economic development parks; farmers' plight was major focus of recent session of National People's Congress, with surprisingly frank talk generally overshadowing official penchant for rosy statistics; farmers face hardships that reflect both China's changing economy and their own diminishing influence; photos; map (M)

headline: Senior Executive at Merrill Leaves to Join Law Firm
abstract: George A

headline: Hitachi Has New Plans And New Unit For Drives
abstract: Hitachi develops new strategy for competing in digital disk drive industry, hoping to improve upon record of IBM, whose disk drive business Hitachi agreed to acquire in April 2002; new unit, Hitachi Global Storage Technologies, will expand storage capacity of IBM's smallest disk drives and sell it to makers of relatively inexpensive small consumer electronics devices, to give digital cameras, portable music players and personal organizers the capacity to play movies, animation and other multimedia applications; photo (M)

headline: A NATION AT WAR: 75th EXPLOITATION FORCE; Special Team Seeks Clues To Establish War Crimes
abstract: Military assigns special Army unit to gather evidence to substantiate reports that Iraq is committing war crimes; mobile team from 75th Exploitation Task Force is trying to investigate allegations of torture of American prisoners at Nasariya hospital, but has been unable to complete search because of fighting; task force is only mobile US team not specifically charged with searching for weapons of mass destruction; it includes members of Criminal Investigation Division trained in preservation of evidence in combat situations; Iraqi theater is rife with rumors of abuse, but American officials want to be certain before charges of war crimes are made (M)

headline: North Korea Issues Warning, And Seoul Seeks Compromise
abstract: South Korea's National Security Council prepares compromise proposal to ease standoff between United States and North Korea, spurred by North Korean warning that situation is 'very serious and unpredictable'; will propose that Pres Bush make promise not to attack North Korea and that North Korean leader Kim Jong Il, in exchange, agree to put North Korea's nuclear program back under international controls (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Suspected Plot Foiled
abstract: German federal prosecutors announce they have detained five people suspected of founding Berlin terrorist organization supported by international Islamic extremists; group planned to recruit Arab students for their attacks (S)

headline: Avant Wins Contract for Oral Vaccine for Anthrax and Plague
abstract: Avant Immunotherapeutics receives contract from DynPort Vaccine Co, Defense's department's contractor for development of vaccines against possible biowarfare agents, to develop oral vaccine for military that would work against anthrax and plague; oral vaccine will probably take 5 to 10 years to develop; contract is for $2.8 million initially and could grow to $8 million over two years (M)

headline: 2 Palestinian Policemen Slain in Israeli Raid in Gaza Strip
abstract: A helicopter fired a pair of missiles that killed two Palestinian policemen today during an Israeli raid for suspected militants.

headline: At Least Those 401(k)'s Beat the Stock Market
abstract: DIARY At Least Those 401(k)'s Beat the Stock Market.

headline: Wall St. Firms Are Faulted In Report on Enron's Taxes
abstract: Senate Finance Committee is told Wall Street banks, acting on advice of leading lawyers and accounting firms, helped Enron devise tax shelters that let company operate tax-free for years while exaggerating its reported profits by billions; senators say findings, in three-volume report by staff of Joint Committee on Taxation, raises disturbing questions about reliability of corporate financial reporting; Sens Charles E Grassley and Max Baucus pledge to campaign for legislation closing abusive tax shelters and to push for further reform of acccounting rules and enforcement of ethical standards governing accountants and lawyers; Lindy L Paull, chief of joint committee staff, says Enron's tax department 'was converted into an Enron business unit, complete with annual revenue targets'; report says tax shelters were intended to allow Enron to book $2 billion of profits almost immediately, even as company was saving $2 billion on federal income taxes over period of years; chart; photos (M)

headline: In Leaderless Gaza, Israeli Forces and Hamas Fight It Out
abstract: Gaza Strip remains leaderless as tight Israeli restrictions on Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat have prevented him from visiting area for well over year; power vacuum has taken on added urgency because of fierce crackdown by Israeli forces in area against Hamas, militant Islamic group (M)

headline: Markets & Investing; Pressure Points for Oil Market: Venezuela, Iraq, Nigeria . . .
abstract: Analysts say 2003 might turn out to be rockiest year in decade for oil prices; pressure points include possible war in Iraq, political unrest in Venezuela, price war between OPEC and non-OPEC producers and labor unrest in Nigeria; light sweet crude ended 2002 at $31.20 per barrel on New York Mercantile Exchange; price of oil averaged about $26 per barrel in 2002, result in large part because of series of production cuts made by OPEC; photos (M)

headline: A Car Man Who's Stuck in Drive
abstract: Toyota Motor president and chief executive Fujio Cho comments on his plans for company's continuing growth, interview; wants to make Toyota world's premier automaker; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: NIGERIA: Stoning Appeal Delayed; MOZAMBIQUE: Officers Charged In Suspect'S Escape; UGANDA: Rebels Kill Peace Envoy; SOUTH AFRICA: Protest For Aids Drugs;.

headline: Many Iraqis, Like Their Government, Complain About Arms Inspections
abstract: Iraqis complain of disruption and damage caused by international arms inspectors, even while they hope that war may be averted if inspectors complete their work without turning up chemical, biological or atomic weapons; inspectors are accepted in Iraq as wedge against any American attack, and they are also used to attack Bush administration; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: E-COMMERCE SYNOPSYS TO BUY NUMERICAL TECHNOLOGIES Synopsys Inc. has agreed to buy Numerical Technologies Inc. for $250 million, or $7 a share, the companies announced yesterday. The acquisition price represents an 89.2 percent premium, based on Numerical's closing price of $3.70 a share on Friday. Shares of Numerical, which is based in San Jose, Calif., closed yesterday at $6.91, up $3.21, or about 87 percent. Chip-making companies use Numerical's software and other applications to produce integrated circuits with patterns that are smaller than the wavelength of light. Numerical's applications are based on phase-shifting and optical correction technologies that compensate for distortions caused by working in such reduced dimensions. Synopsys, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., makes electronic design automation software. The company expects the deal to speed production of sub-wavelength chips as well as reduce costs and manufacturing risk for customers developing power-efficient integrated circuits. The acquisition requires regulatory approval and other closing conditions. The deal is expected to close in the first quarter.   (Dow Jones/AP) COPYRIGHT ACCORD ON DIGITAL SHARING The recording industry and a coalition of technology companies have reached an agreement in principle to oppose any government-required technologies that would prevent consumers from sharing songs and other digital material. The Recording Industry Association of America and two technology groups, the Business Software Alliance and the Computer Systems Policy Project, plan to offer details of the agreement at a news conference today. The groups are expected to back voluntary means to stop piracy. The accord does not include the Motion Picture Association of America, which has supported government action to prevent digital piracy.   (NYT).

headline: HBO Offers 4 Networks Comedy Hit 'Sex and City'
abstract: HBO offers all four major broadcast networks 90 episodes of Sex and the City that have already run on HBO for use in their prime-time schedule; has been editing some explicit sex and sex talk from shows to make them acceptable to broadcasters (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Wins Legal Case
abstract: Microsoft Corp wins legal fight to bar Software & Information Industry Association and Computer & Communications Industry Association from appealing Federal Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly's approval of its antitrust settlement with US goverment and nine states (S)

headline: In Net Attacks, Defining the Right to Know
abstract: Article discusses whether companies that have been hit with computer attack should disclose it; many companies believe it is prudent not to let public know, while consumer advoctes think full disclosure is only option; Consumer Action official Linda Sherry says people have right to know whether electronic network is safe; often, consumers find out only if problem is widespread; number of computer crimes reported to CERT Coordination Center, federally financed information clearinghouse for computer security, has risen sharply; CERT believes only about 5 percent of crime is reported; last year, 82,000 incidents were reported, but Symantec's DeepSight Threat Management System monitors detected 52 million security events in seven-day period; some instances of hacking noted; some security experts are calling for government regulations that would require institutions to disclose security breaches, particularly those that directly affect consumers; photos (L)

headline: Pro-Qaeda Oil Workers A Sabotage Risk for Saudis
abstract: Saudi Arabian government increased security around Saudi oil fields and processing centers after discovery that employees of state-owned oil company sympathetic to Al Qaeda were discussing sabotage plans late last summer; American intelligence officials who discovered conversations alerted Saudi authorities, who quickly arrested and interrogated suspects; sabotage case and response to it underscore deep anxieties about security of Saudi oil when war with Iraq could make it more valuable, but also more vulnerable, than ever; map (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Parametric Shares Drop After Revenue Changes
abstract: Shares of Parametric Technology Corp fall as much as 23 percent after company says it booked $20 million to $25 million in sales earlier than it should have and will restate results (S)

headline: Investing; Seed From Which Hedges May Grow
abstract: Growing number of investment firms are financing promising hedge fund managers, much as venture capitalists underwrite risky startups in hopes that some will strike it rich; in return for financing, incubated funds will provide investors with more information about their operations than typical hedge fund; many are required to meet performance benchmarks; graphs (M)

abstract: Thai economy grew at annual rate of 6.1 percent in fourth quarter of 2002, fastest pace since before 1997-98 Asian financial crisis (S)

headline: KEMPER ENDS UNDERWRITING AND SELLS MAIN BUSINESSES

headline: A British Defense Employee Is Shot Dead in Saudi Capital
abstract: British employee of BAE Systems, defense contractor, is shot and killed in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, in latest of series of attacks on Britons, Americans and other Westerners in Saudi Arabia and other Arab countries; is identified as Robert Dent; police chase gunman and arrest man identified as Saud bin Ali bin Nasser, car salesman; BAE Systems employs more than 5,000 people in Saudi Arabia; its workers have been attacked before; British travel advisory for Saudi Arabia notes that seven bombings have killed or injured Westerners since Nov 2000 (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: U.S. Charges Australian With Copyright Infringement

abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 28.43 points, or 0.4 percent, to 8,201.45; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closes down 1.43 points, or 0.2 percent, to 868.52; Nasdaq composite index declines 3.20 points, or 0.2 percent, to 1,384.25; US Treasury bond prices and yields are little changed; price of 10-year note rises 3/32, to 99 20/32, while yield slips to 3.92 percent from 3.93 percent; 30-year bond falls 1/32, to 106 24/32, while yield rises to 4.93 percent from 4.92 percent; graphs; charts (M)

headline: Your Taxes; Too Many Pennies From Heaven?
abstract: Size and multitude of Pres Bush's tax-cut proposals leaves even supply-siders dizzy and wondering how much of them he can actually achieve; proposals, taken together, would radically transform way people invest in stocks, think about taxes and save; critics and supporters alike say this is simply first installment in plan to overhaul tax system from one that taxes incomes to one that taxes consumption; drawing; table (M)

headline: Regional Squabbling Scuttles an Iraqi Opposition Meeting
abstract: Effort to showcase cooperation between Turkey and Kurdish parties in northern Iraq ends when lone Turkish soldier blocks road taking 150 foreign journalists to northern Iraq and orders their buses to return to Silopi, nearby border town; reasons are unclear and recriminations among reputed allies against Saddam Hussein are bitter (M)

headline: Leased-Car Crash Liability Under Review in 3 States
abstract: Car companies, auto dealers and banks are putting pressure on New York State legislators to amend 1929 law that if unchanged could make it difficult for New Yorkers to lease cars; law allows plaintiffs in car accidents to use leasing companies for damages, under legal principle called vicarious liability, because companies technically own cars; New York, Rhode Island and Connecticut are only states that allow leasing company to be held accountable for unlimited damages if care is involved in crash; amendments are pending in all three states; leasing companies, including those owned by Ford and General Motors, say rewards are escalating into hundreds of millions of dollars; have threatened to stop doing business in New York (M)

headline: SYNTHES OF SWITZERLAND AGREES TO BUY SPINE SOLUTIONS
abstract: Synthes-Stratec, world's biggest maker of devices to treat broken bones, agrees to acquire closely held rival Spine Solutions for $350 million (S)

headline: Private Sector; A Flair for Making Things 'Out of Thin Air'
abstract: Stephan Paternot, who made and lost fortune in dot-com mania, comments on playing lead character in film Wholey Moses, which he helped produce; photo (S)

headline: Steinway Workers Strike
abstract: Steinway Musical Instruments, maker of Steinway pianos, said today that workers were on strike at a plant in Eastlake, Ohio. The workers' contract expired Feb. 15. The strike by Local 2359 of the United Auto Workers, which represents about 230 employees at the Conn-Selmer plant, will cut production by 150 instruments a day, the company said. Existing inventory is expected to meet customer needs for several months, Steinway said.

headline: Texas Instruments Directors Come Under Fire
abstract: Institutional Shareholder Services, influential adviser to institutional investors, is urging clients to oppose re-election of Texas Instruments directors, including chairman and chief executive Thomas J Engibous; cites disclosure that board adopted costly stock option plan for nonmanagement employees in January without shareholder approval; also opposes as too costly proposed stock option plan for directors (M)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Too Many Security Patches.

headline: Report From UBS Leaves Some Puzzled
abstract: UBS's president Peter A Wuffli says company will no longer offer any guidance about its future results; makes unexpected announcing concerning five small Swiss private banks that UBS owns leaving some analysts wondering whether UBS is preparing to abandon that business; says five small banks, with combined assets of 70 million Swiss francs ($51 billion) and headquarters scattered across Switzerland, would be placed under single holding company along with Global Asset Management; Wuffli denies that small banks have been put up for sale; adds holding company plan is meant to revamp banks and make them more profitable; some analysts are surprised that holding company would preserve small banks' independent names; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: $25 Billion In Extra Spending
abstract: Lower house of Japanese Parliament approves extra $25 billion in new spending on public works projects and job creation (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: An Aluminum Tax Proposal
abstract: Russian government commission recommends that country stop extending tax breaks to its aluminum industry; system of tax breaks, known as tolling, began in Russia in early 1990's as way to help domestic producers; dropping breaks will cost biggest aluminum producer, Russian Aluminum, $70 million to $80 million per year (S)

headline: U.S. AIDES DISMISS MOVES BY BAGHDAD BUT FEEL PRESSURE
abstract: The White House declared today that Iraq's efforts to destroy missiles and convince the United Nations that it was cooperating with weapons inspectors was ''the mother of all distractions.'' But inside the administration, officials feared efforts to put additional military and diplomatic pressure on Saddam Hussein were becoming more complicated.     Iraq destroyed six more missiles today and the United Nations team in Baghdad issued mild praise for its sudden interest in disarmament, however fragmentary. But the Bush administration declared that Mr. Hussein was, by his action, admitting that he lied in a declaration to the United Nations in December.

headline: If, and When: War's Timing
abstract: Patrick E Tyler analysis of timing of US military strike against Iraq in light of French suggestion that United Nations Security Council give arms inspectors month more before convening again on March 14; notes that while some American military officials favor moonless nights of early March as time to begin bombing campaign, others believe that beginning of combat operations could slide to middle or latter part of month; says attempt to win support of France and other Security Council members may thus be worth the extra time (M)

headline: In Nasiriya, Marines Find an Urban Fight They Didn't Want
abstract: Heavy small-arms fire kept up as sundown approached on the second day of fighting in Nasiriya, key to U.S. advances to Baghdad.

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Sentence Upheld For Comments On Veils
abstract: Liberal muslim cleric Hojatolislam Hassan Eshkevari's appeal of seven-year sentence is denied; was imprisoned for saying at 2000 Berlin conference that women in Iran should not have to wear veil (S)

headline: Russian TV Network Fires American Executive
abstract: MOSCOW, Jan. 17 — The American financier who runs Russia's often-embattled NTV television network said today that he had been dismissed by the network's state-controlled owner, the latest chapter in a media drama sometimes seen as an indicator of this nation's press freedom.

headline: Sharon Ousts Netanyahu as Foreign Minister
abstract: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon dealt a quick political blow to Benjamin Netanyahu today by ousting him as foreign minister.

headline: INVESTING WITH/Richard C. Pell And Donald Quigley; Julius Baer Global Income Fund
abstract: Carole Gould Investing With column explores investment tactics and results of Julius Baer Global Income fund, managed by Richard C Pell and Donald Quigley; photo; graph and table of fund's finances (M)

headline: Honeymoon In Brazil: Market's Gift To New Chief
abstract: Brazil's new Pres Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva appears to be winning over markets that only months ago demonized him, fearing that his leftist Workers Party could plunge Brazil and surrounding region into economic chaos; Brazil's currency, the real, has rallied 6 percent against dollar since da Silva took office on Jan 1 after dropping 35 percent last year; Sao Paulo's Bovespa stock index, punished last year as da Silva's victory appeared increasingly likely, has also rallied to its highest level since June; Brazil remains vulnerable to international investors' sentiments and one wrong move by da Silva's economic team could wipe out current good will; Henrique Meirelles, new head of central bank, pledges 'no adventures' in monetary policy and promises to focus on curbing inflation, inaugural speech; inflation is expected to rise around 10 percent in 2003; graph (M)

abstract: IBM will announce on Monday 10 new services aimed at bringing "grid" computing to business.

abstract: Travel article on Greenwich, Conn; town's highlights noted; photo (M)

headline: Iranian Calls U.S. Presence Worse Than Rival's Weapons
abstract: Former Iranian Pres Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani says that while Iraq should be disarmed, presence of American forces in region is worse than Iraq's access to weapons of mass destruction, speech, Tehran University; seeks to portray United States as dangerous warmonger; hints Iran might be singled out after Iraq; urges United Nations to take lead in disarming Iraq; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Troops Called Out For Carnival
abstract: Recent violence in Rio de Janeiro prompts Brazil to allocate 3,000 troops in addition to 30,000 police to maintain peace during Carnival; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Chohung Bidder Selected
abstract: South Korean government names Shinhan Financial Group, which is dominated by Shinhan Bank, as leading candidate to take over Chohung Bank, Korea's third largest; Shinhan has offered about $3 billion for government's 80 percent stake in Chohung (S)

abstract: The Super Bowl indicator was once a staple of Wall Street. Until recently, it had worked surprisingly well.

abstract: Werenfried van Straaten, Dutch priest who founded Catholic charity after World War II, dies at age 90 (M)

abstract: American Embassy in Kuala Lumpur will issue hundreds of visas to Malaysian students wishing to study in US; visas have been held back for months because of increased security fears in US (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Airline Cuts Flights
abstract: Japan Airlines temporarily cuts number of flights to Hawaii and Europe, citing drop in demand because of war in Iraq (S)

abstract: British court rejects assertions that British Army unlawfully denied equal pay and conditions to Gurkha soldiers recruited in Nepal (S)

headline: Automakers Agree To Work Together For S.U.V. Safety
abstract: Auto industry acknowledges that sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks pose serious dangers to cars; agrees for first time to work together to increase safety; industry's main lobbying group sends letter to National Highway Traffic Safety Adm head Dr Jeffrey W Runge, saying automakers will take steps toward voluntary standards to make cars safer when hit by larger vehicles and to make SUV's and pickups less dangerous; standards would probably lead to greater deployment of air bags, and possibly reinforcements in car doors; also, it might lead to lowering large SUV's and pickups so that their front ends are less likely to skip over hoods of cars or hit passengers' upper bodies in collisions from side; industry will develop tests to measure role stiff frames of larger vehicles play in collisions; until now companies have refused to work together to produce significant changes; industry's pledge of cooperation comes after Runge's warning that Bush admininstration was considering imposing regulations in absence of voluntary standards; photos (L)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Food Concern Cuts Outlook
abstract: Royal Wessanen, world's largest marketer of specialty foods, cuts is 2002 and 2003 profit forecasts and agrees to departure of chief executive Mac Zondervan; graph (S)

headline: Its Bankruptcy Process Incomplete, Kmart Changes Chiefs
abstract: James B Adamson resigns as Kmart chief executive; will remain chairman; Julian C Day, president and chief operating officer, succeeds him in post; shift comes as company's bankruptcy reorganization remains incomplete; photos (M)

headline: Webdenda
abstract: January 28 -- Gil Bashe was named executive vice president and head of the health practice at Makovsky & Company , New York. He assumes duties that had been handled by Jack Domeischel, senior vice president and managing director for the health practice, who left, the agency said. Mr. Bashe had been president at Catalyst Communications, South Plainfield, N.J. The Beanstalk Group , New York, reorganized its licensing division after the departure of four senior managers who left to start their own agency, Brandgenuity . Under the reorganization, Beanstalk is combining its licensee management and client service units into a client management department. Gail Stern , senior vice president for licensee management, was named senior vice president and head for client management. David Milch , vice president for client services, was named vice president for client management. Scott Rosenzweig , vice president for licensee management, was named vice president for sales. Caren Calabrese , director for client services, was named sales director. Liz Ramaswarmy , manager for licensee management, was named manager for client management. Debra Restler , director for marketing, was named director for marketing and business development. Robert J. Bellafiore was named to the new post of director for public affairs at Eric Mower & Associates , Syracuse. He had been deputy secretary for policy and planning for Gov. George E. Pataki of New York. Eric Correll was named account supervisor at 5W Public Relations , New York. He had been account executive at the public affairs division of the MWW Group, East Rutherford, N.J., part of the Golin/Harris International subsidiary of Advanced Marketing Services, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Deutsch , New York, part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies, was named agency of the year for 2002 by Advertising Age , owned by Crain Communications, and by Adweek , owned by VNU. Those publications also agreed on global agency network of the year, selecting Saatchi & Saatchi , part of the Publicis Groupe. Advertising Age also honored a multicultural agency of the year, the Vidal Partnership, New York. Diane Crook , Eastern regional advertising director at Men's Journal , New York, published by Wenner Media, was promoted to advertising director, a new post. Electronic Media , Los Angeles, a television industry trade magazine published by Crain Communications, is being renamed Television Week , effective with the March 3 issue. Hospitality Sales and Marketing Association International , McLean, Va., named Vicki Freed , senior vice president at Carnival Cruise Lines , Miami, the winner of the HSMAI Award for Top Sales Achievement for helping restore cruise-line bookings after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. Indigo , Chicago, a corporate jet service, named Blue Elephant , New York, as agency of record on its account, with billings estimated at $6 million. The account had been handled internally. Indigo is part of New World Air Holdings. The Maine Office of Tourism , Augusta, named Warren Kremer Paino , New York, part of Winning Strategies, as agency of record, with billings estimated at $3 million. The account had been handled by Swardlick Marketing Group, Portland, Me. Mike Moran was named to the new post of chairman for the Olympic practice and consultant for the sports and entertainment group at Edelman Public Relations Worldwide , New York, part of Daniel J. Edelman Inc. Mr. Moran had been chief communications officer at the United States Olympic Committee, Colorado Springs, Colo. He will be based in Colorado Springs for Edelman and travel among the agency's offices. Paul Murray was named to the new post of vice president for client relations at CFM Direct , Oakbrook Terrace, Ill. He had most recently been vice president for product marketing at the Lombard, Ill., office of Equifax. Erin Pierce was named senior account executive at Media Logic , Albany. She had been an account executive at Smith & Jones, Troy, N.Y. Robin William Robert was named group account director at the Los Angeles office of Ornelas & Associates . He had most recently been group account director at Casanova Pendrill, Irvine, Calif., part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Kate Robertson was named executive vice president at Euro RSCG Europe , Paris, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide division of Havas. She succeeds Christian de la Villehuchet , who was named chief executive at Euro RSCG Belgium , Brussels. Ms. Robertson, who will be based in London and Paris, had been chief marketing officer for the Africa, Middle East and Europe division of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, which is being closed by its new parent, the Publicis Groupe. Sesame Workshop , New York, signed a marketing agreement to sell merchandise tied to ``Sagwa, the Chinese Siamese Cat,'' an animated series produced by Sesame Workshop and CinéGroupe, in the Mervyn's chain of stores owned by the Target Corporation. Terms were not disclosed. Kumar Shahani was named executive principal and group management director at a new health-care marketing practice at the Seattle office of Publicis Dialog . He had been vice president for client services at Lena Chow Euro RSCG, Palo Alto, Calif., part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas. Publicis Dialog is a division of Publicis in the U.S., part of the Publicis Worldwide unit of the Publicis Groupe. Spontaneous Combustion , New York, hired two employees for new posts. Juan Delcan was named creative director; he had been director and creative director at V12, Los Angeles, part of Virgin Digital Studios. Marybeth Phillips was named executive producer; she had been executive director for production at the media and entertainment brand identity group of Razorfish, New York. Jason Stinsmuehlen was named to the new post of senior vice president and group creative director at Mullen , Wenham, Mass. He had been associate creative director at the Playa del Rey, Calif., office of TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group. Mullen is part of the Partnership division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

headline: Psst: A Spot Where Gamers Get Their Own Inside Skinny
abstract: Ain't It Cool Games site offers news to users about what's hot and what's not in world of video games (M)

headline: CHIQUITA IS CONSIDERING CLOSING PANAMANIAN UNIT
abstract: Chiquita Brands International Inc, banana grower, says it might close money-losing Panamanian unit unless union reconsiders company's proposal to sell business (S)

headline: Bankruptcy Judge Approves Overhaul Plan for US Airways
abstract: US Bankruptcy Judge Stephen Mitchell approves US Airways' restructuring plan, clearing way for airline to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection by March 31; approves plan after receiving strong endorsement from airline's creditors' committee; action comes despite objections from US Airways' pilots, who are upset by airline's bid to set aside their pension plan and replace it with program that will pay up to 75 percent less in benefits; US Airways chief David N Siegel comments; photo (M)

headline: Allied Advances, Tougher Iraqi Resistance, and a Hunt in the Tigris
abstract: Chronology of events in war on Iraq on Mar 23, 2003 (M)

headline: Explosion in a Gaza House Kills 2 Teenagers; Cause Is Disputed
abstract: Two teenagers are killed and 11 other people are injured when explosion tears through house near Gaza City that belongs to member of militant Islamic group Hamas; Hamas leader Abdel Aziz Rantisi blames explosion on missiles fired from Israeli helicopter (S)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: RUSSIA: Trying To Mend Ties With Georgia; CYPRUS: Protest Against Peace Plan; SERBIA AND MONTENEGRO: The First President; GERMANY: Broke Berlin Finds Money For Frogs;.

headline: Where Officer Died, Britons Blame Policy on Asylum Seekers
abstract: People in Crumpsall neighborhood of Manchester, England, blame government and its liberal policy on asylum seekers for death of local detective in botched antiterrorism operation; three men described as Algerians were arrested during raid, one a failed asylum seeker, whose rent of about $112 a month was reportedly being paid by local council; fourth Algerian is arrested in Manchester on suspicion of terrorism (M)

headline: Bush Asserts U.S. Is Making Progress in Iraqi War
abstract: The president said today that the war is going according to plan, at least as much as possible, and that victory is certain.

headline: 4 Killed in Suicide Bombing at Checkpoint in Northern Iraq
abstract: A man detonated a bomb he was wearing near a Kurdish military headquarters in northern Iraq today, killing himself and three others in what the authorities described as the first Kurdish suicide bombing.     The authorities said the attack, at a military checkpoint in Zamaqi, was probably the work of Ansar al-Islam, a militant Islamic group that the United States contends has connections to both Al Qaeda and President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. It occurred late in the morning, when a sport utility vehicle used as a taxi was stopped at a checkpoint by Kurdish guards. A Kurdish security official said the guards were suspicious of the taxi's passenger and asked him to leave the vehicle for an inspection. ''When he was about to be checked, he pressed the button,'' the official said.

headline: Bold Step for Bush
abstract: Analysis of draft 'road map' to peace and Palestinian state drawn up by UN, European Union, Russia and US Pres George Bush; notes that while three other parties regard proposal as fixed, Bush sees it as open to amendment and Israel has criticized it as threatening its security; chart outlines plan (M)

headline: African Town's Pride and Joy Vanished When Ferry Sank
abstract: Death toll from sinking of Senegal ferry Joola last Sept is put at 1,863, making it second-worst nonmilitary maritime disaster ever; ferry had on board estimated 400 students from town of Ziguinchor, en route to Dakar to attend school and university classes there; they were pride and joy of town, and when ferry sank, so did future of Ziguinchor; ferry, run by Senegalese military, was holding three times as many passengers as allowed when it capsized; Pres Abdoulaye Wade has accepted responsibility and pledged assistance; official investigation blamed wreck on 'blatant and repeated failures'; photo; map (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Honduras: Remains May Be American Priest's
abstract: Honduran officials find skeletal remains that may be those of American Jesuit Rev James Carney; missionary has been missing since 1983 when rebel group he ministered to was killed by Honduran military; tests will be done to identify remains (S)

headline: Jeanne de Rothschild, 94, Who Came From Stage
abstract: Baroness Jeanne de Rothschild, actress who married scion of Vienese branch of Rothschilds, dies at age 94 (M)

headline: Low Profiles and No-Shows at Golf's Showcase
abstract: Controversy over refusal of Augusta National Golf Club to invite a woman to join club prompts corporations to forgo or or scale back their presence at this year's Masters Tournament; some have been sponsors in past, and others have used Masters to entertain clients and reward executives and employees even if they have no official link to tournament; some cite economic weakness for withdrawals, but others give more credit -- or blame -- to Martha Burk, chairwoman of National Council of Women's Organizations, who plans to lead protest outside club's main gate; photos (M)

headline: U.S. to Allow Wine Labels That List Health Claims
abstract: Treasury Department rules that winemakers may put health claims on labels but only if they are highly detailed, including qualifications that industry may not wish publicized, or if they simply tell consumers where to find health-related information; aim is balance between opponents of alcohol and winemakers' rights to make accurate claims; photo (M)

headline: One Dies in Attack at U.S. Camp; Soldier Is Held
abstract: Apparent fratricide attack at American military base in Kuwait takes life of one soldier and wounds 13 others; American soldier is in custody for attack; allegedly threw grenades and fired shots into tent used by leaders of brigade from 101st Airborne Div; military sources describe alleged attacker as sergeant attached to engineering unit, an American citizen who is Muslim convert; concern over intentional attack by one American soldier on others has been muted, although once ammunition arrived in large quantities, morale officers urged vigilance among soldiers who might have personal problems and could do harm to themselves; photo (M)

headline: Bush Officials Debate Release Of Iraq Secrets
abstract: Pres Bush's top national security aides debate whether to declassify satellite photographs of suspected Iraqi weapons sites and truck convoys, as well as telephone intercepts and interviews with defectors and detainees, to demonstrate that Iraq is defying weapons inspections; officials search for way for Secretary of State Colin L Powell to make credible argument at United Nations, without harming sources of intelligence; evidence being considered is never entirely reliable, which adds another layer of uncertainty; Powell reportedly wants to be armed with brief containing few select, vivid items of solid evidence, not mosaic of murky material that could be discounted by skeptical allies and critics of Bush administration; officials say crucial part of Powell's case will center on continuing Iraqi obstruction, including fact that Iraq has so far made it impossible for UN inspectors to fly U-2 surveillance aircraft over country (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Hardware
abstract: GATEWAY REPORTS LOSS AS REVENUE DROPS; COURT DISMISSES FRAUD CASE AGAINST RAMBUS;.

headline: Tech Data Reports a Loss
abstract: Tech Data reports fourth-quarter loss of $303 million compared with prof2

headline: France and Germany are left to wonder:Did they go too far?
abstract: PARIS:—  In the end, beyond the maneuvering, the rhetoric, the professed convictions, there were questions in Paris and Berlin about whether France and Germany's opposition to an American-led war on Iraq got a bit out of hand.

headline: Powell Urges Venezuelans To Embrace Carter's Ideas
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell strongly urged the Venezuelan government and its opposition today to accept one of the two proposals offered by former President Jimmy Carter to end the 54-day-old strike that has filled Venezuela's streets with protesters, shut down businesses and paralyzed its oil industry.     As diplomats in Washington and officials in Caracas reported progress toward ending the impasse, several leaders of the opposition movement said they were prepared to begin negotiating on one of Mr. Carter's proposals -- a referendum on President Hugo Chávez's rule.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Loss At Bank
abstract: South Korea's Kookmin Bank reports worse-than-expected net loss of 202.6 billion won ($173 million) in fourth quarter compared with loss of $140.7 billion won year earlier; says it had profit in 2002 of 1.31 trillion won compared with 1.49 trillion won in 2001 (S)

headline: Remarks by Russia's Foreign Minister to Security Council
abstract: Following is the transcript of the statement by Igor Ivanov, the foreign minister of Russia, to the Security Council today as recorded by the Federal News Service.

headline: With 6 Degrees of Separation, Computers Stay in Sync
abstract: Scientists have conquered problem of keeping computers that are networked in parallel configuration to form giant supercomputer synchronized; Gyorgy Korniss, University of Florida, and Zoltan Toroczkai, working at Los Alamos National Laboratory, spearheaded development of mathematical model using small-world theory to arrive at idea that random contacts ensure that computers stay in step; theory is also behind 'six degrees of separation' concept in human interactions; drawing (M)

headline: E.U. Ban on Genetically Modified Food Criticized
abstract: The Bush administration's top trade official announced today that he wanted to file a case against the European Union for its ban on genetically modified food.

headline: Text: President Bush's Remarks at the Pentagon
abstract: Following is a transcript of President Bush’s remarks at the Pentagon today as recorded by The New York Times:

headline: HASBRO EXTENDS DEAL ON STAR WARS TOYS BY 10 YEARS
abstract: Hasbro wins 10-year extension of agreement with Lucas Licensing to make Star Wars toys and games; company has made items for last 27 years (S)

headline: Israel Rejects Belgian Court Ruling on Sharon
abstract: Israeli officials react with outrage to decision by Belgium's highest court that Belgium could try Prime Min Ariel Sharon for war crimes once he leaves office; Israel recalls its ambassador to Brussels, and Foreign Min Benjamin Netanyahu summons Belgium's ambassador to Israel to receive protest; human rights groups hail Belgian court's decision; Sharon and former senior official Amos Yaron are being sued by survivors of 1982 massacre of Palestinian refugees in Lebanon by Lebanese Christian militias, who were backed by Israeli forces; Israeli commission held Sharon, who was Israel's defense minister at the time, indirectly responsible and he resigned his post (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: RUSSIA: Tracking Foreigners; SLOVAKIA: European Union Vote Is Set;.

headline: Ex-Merrill Executive Named To Lead Irish Drug Maker
abstract: Ex-Merrill Executive

headline: Fears of War and Illness Hurt Tourism in Asia
abstract: War in Iraq and outbreak of mysterious respiratory ailment that began in China are combining to wreck havoc on tourism in Asia, and are threatening to weaken economies throughout region; leading airlines are scaling back operations; major hotel chains are reporting unusual number of cancellations; photo (M)

headline: U.N. SPLIT WIDENS AS ALLIES DISMISS DEADLINE ON IRAQ
abstract: US and Great Britain plan to urge UN Security Council to vote on new resolution giving Iraq until March 17 to disarm; France, Russia and China, which hold veto power, dismiss new proposal; actions come after chief UN weapons inspectors Mohamed ElBaradei and Hans Blix contradict some US and British assertions about Iraqi violations; ElBaradei says report, believed to be from British intelligence, that Iraq tried to purchase uranium from Niger is based on fake documents; both say Iraq, under threat of force, is increasingly but belatedly cooperating; photos; charts (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Hardware
abstract: TERADYNE SHARES DROP ON WIDER LOSS; FUJITSU'S DEBT IS DOWNGRADED;.

headline: G.E. Said to Explore Sale of Motor Unit
abstract: General Electric reportedly seeks to sell its motor manufacturing unit, part of GE Industrial Systems, for as much as $900 million (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Trouble For Mobilcom Founder
abstract: Gerhard Schmid, founder and former chief executive of MobilCom, files for protection from his creditors because of slumping share price; photo (S)

headline: Washington's Disunity Complicates Dialogue
abstract: Serious divisions within Bush administration over whether to enter serious talks with North Korea before it dismantles its two nuclear programs complicate efforts of Gov Bill Richardson, Democrat, to serve as go-between in defusing nuclear crisis; Richardson is known and trusted by North Koreans because of past contacts with him while he was member of Congress; United States has been encouraging Japan, South Korea and other countries to reach out to North Korea to probe its aims; photo (M

headline: A 'Belt and Suspenders' Politician Says Quebec's Electorate Is Tired of Excitement
abstract: Interview with Mario Dumont, leader of Action Democratique du Quebec, protest party whose sole seat in Canadian Parliament is one he holds; he is suddenly contender to be Quebec's next premier after years of insults and neglect from colleagues in powerful Liberal Party and Parti Quebecois; photo (M)

headline: New Premier Takes Office in Turkey as War Worries Loom
abstract: Recep Tayyip Erdogan, founder of Islamic-based Justice and Development Party, assumes post of prime minister of Turkey and forms new government; Erdogan, who has advocated deployment of US troops in Turkey for invasion of northern Iraq, makes no mention of timetable for new vote on issue, already once rejected by Turkish Parliament; Pentagon, perhaps reflecting uncertainty of situation, has begun moving ships from Mediterranean near Turkey to Red Sea (M)

headline: White House Says Inaction Would Echo '90's Mistakes
abstract: The White House said that the U.N.'s failure to act would compound past mistakes and encourage North Korea and Iran.

headline: Broker Convicted of Fraud Is Set Free
abstract: Dana C Giacchetto, former stockbroker who was once known as 'broker to the stars' and was later convicted of swindling his clients, has won early release from federal prison; served 3 years of 5-year prison sentence (S)

headline: British Police Review 'Poison' Raid That Left Officer Dead
abstract: British police interrogate three North African men over Jan 14 antiterror raid in Manchester that led to killing of police officer; politicians and law enforcement authorities debate what went wrong in operation and what can be learned from it; slain officer Detective Constable Stephen Oake was not wearing body armor that other officers were wearing and died of single knife wound to chest; Prime Min Tony Blair says attack proves his government was right in passing emergency laws permitting police to detain people on suspicion of being threats to national security; photo (M)

headline: Biological and Chemical Weapons Would Be Likely to Slow but Not Stop the Invaders
abstract: American and British soldiers ready to invade Iraq know they may face chemical and biological agents that Iraq is suspected of having in its arsenal; experts say prepared troops can be well protected against such threats; American troops are equipped with elaborate set of protective garments; these include boots, gloves and helmets, used in various combinations, ranked in levels from zero through 4 according to severity of threat; diagrams of various protective gear (M)

headline: American Airlines Has Loss; Southwest Posts a Profit
abstract: AMR Corp, parent of American Airlines, reports net loss of $529 million in fourth quarter compared with loss of $798 million year earlier; revenue was $4.19 billion, 10.1 percent increase over year earlier; net loss was $3.51 billion for 2002, 10.1 percent increase over year earlier; chief executive Donald J Carty comments; Southwest Airlines reports profit of $42.4 million in fourth quarter, 33.2 percent drop from $63.5 million year ago; revenue rose 13.2 percent from year earlier, to $1.4 billion; chief executive James F Parker comments (M)

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: ZAMBIA: Rains Destroy Homes And Crops; LIBERIA: Rebels Close In On Capital;.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: 350,000 Subscribers For Virgin Mobile
abstract: Virgin Mobile USA, wireless carrier venture between Sprint PCS and Virgin Group, is expected to announce that it signed up 350,000 subscribers in its first six months of operation in US; Virgin Mobile chief executive Daniel H Schulman says he expects company to be profitable within two and half years; photo (M)

headline: Gypsies' Suit Against I.B.M. Is Given Green Light by Swiss Court
abstract: Swiss court clears way for $12-billion lawsuit against IBM by group of Gypsy organizations that charge company helped Nazis automate records to organize Holocaust; previous suit by Jewish survivors was dropped for fear of blocking settlement with Germany and Switzerland on other Holocaust compensation (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Another Safeway Bidder; SWITZERLAND: Loss At Chemical Concern; SWITZERLAND: Insurer Reverses Loss; THE NETHERLANDS: Pharmaceutical Profit Warning; ITALY: Higher Bid For Toll Company;.

headline: Y.& R. Hires Executive From BBDO for 2 Posts
abstract: Young & Rubicam Advertising hires Michael Patti, vice chairman and senior executive creative director at New York office of BBDO, to be chairman and chief executive of its flagship New York office as well as worldwide creative director (S)

headline: Bush Promises To Adopt Plan For the Mideast
abstract: Pres George Bush, following several days of negotiations with British Prime Min Tony Blair, promises to adopt long-deferred peace plan for Palestinian state as soon as Palestinians choose new prime minister; says, during statement in White House Rose Garden, 'there can be no peace for either side in the Middle East unless there is freedom for both;' Blair, moments later, hails Bush's announcement as showing 'obligation of even-handedness' on eve of possible war against Iraq; photo (M)

headline: Path to Universal Insurance
abstract: Ross A Beaujon letter on Jan 5 article backs Sen John B Breaux's proposal to have all Americans buy private health insurance

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: More Federal Aid For Health Care
abstract: Canada's Prime Minister Jean Chretien and nation's 10 regional directors approve $8 billion dollar increase in federal aid to local health care over next three years; three Arctic directors refuse to sign accord, holding it does not give equitable treatment to rural Native areas (S)

headline: Butler, Shine & Stern Buys SF Interactive
abstract: Butler, Shine & Stern in Sausalito, Calif., has acquired SF Interactive in San Francisco, which will become a division of the newly renamed Butler, Shine, Stern & Partners. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Falls
abstract: Japan's current account surplus contracted in December as export growth slowed; surplus grew 34 percent in 2002, first expansion in four years (S)

headline: Market Place; Low Consumer Confidence May Be Bullish
abstract: Conference Board reports consumer confidence plunged to reading of 62.5 in March, lowest level in almost 10 years; graph (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Turkey May Reconsider Vote On Its Role in Iraq Invasion
abstract: Turkish leaders signal that they are giving fresh, urgent consideration to United States officials' requests for Turkey's cooperation in invasion of northern Iraq; Turkish Parliament narrowly rejected resolution to authorize moving American ground troops into southeastern Turkey on Mar 1; until today, Prime Min Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who publicly supports resolution, has said he would not resubmit it to Parliament until next week, if then; latest developments suggest he has dramatically accelerated timetable for new vote, resurrecting American hopes that had been fading fast (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Microsoft Said to Abandon Goal of Overtaking AOL  IDC, the big technology research firm, said in a report that Microsoft had abandoned its goal of trying to overtake America Online as the largest online service.    ''MSN,'' the report states, ''has adopted a new strategy -- to ultimately become a portal or software company, with customers obtaining their own Internet access from any source.'' [Page C5.]

headline: Schedule for Stock Sales
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:      AtheroGenics, Alpharetta, Ga., six million class A shares. Morgan Stanley and Lehman Brothers.

headline: France Offering Plan to Expand Iraq Arms Hunt
abstract: France gives Security Council members detailed plan for extending and strengthening UN weapons inspections in Iraq as alternative to military action; proposes to triple number of inspectors and increase aerial surveillance, although there is no mention of reported French-German plan to send in UN peacekeepers; diplomats note Iraq has placed conditions on U-2 flights; European Union official Javier Solana says union leaders will meet on rift among NATO members over US position; reportedly terms dispute is one of timing, not substance; US national security adviser Condoleezza Rice meets UN weapons chief Hans Blix in New York and urges him to come down hard on Iraq in his crucial report to Security Council; stops short of setting deadline for inspectors to leave Iraq; photo; Sec Colin Powell talks with British, French, Russian and German counterparts and Sec Gen Kofi Annan to try to break impasse in NATO; France, Germany and Belgium are resisting US and Turkish requests to provide equipment to protect Turkey in event of war with Iraq, Europeans saying approval would be tantamount to voting in favor of war (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar gains against euro after index of American manufacturing increased in December by most since June 1991; euro settles at $1.03600, down from $1.05030 on Dec 31; graph; chart (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: GERMANY: Siemens Profit Slips; FRANCE: Sales Rise At Lvmh; THE NETHERLANDS: Klm Narrows Loss;.
