headline: A NATION AT WAR
abstract: Some Targets Off Limits  American commanders have avoided bombing some high-priority Iraqi targets, mainly in Baghdad, for fear of civilian casualties, making it harder to achieve some of the air campaign's goals.   PAGE B12    Moving Out of the South  The U.S. military's focus on Baghdad came into sharp focus, as troops and materiél moved out of southern Iraq, leaving behind a kind of benign military occupation.   PAGE B1

headline: S.E.C. Chief Says Fixing the Agency Will Take Time
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission chairman William H Donaldson testifies before House appropriations subcommittee that agency will take longer than previously thought to shore itself up with hiring of 800 lawyers, accountants, investigators and other employees despite huge budget increase after years of financial neglect; aides to Donaldson say his two biggest priorities are finding chairman of new accounting oversight board and shoring up management and morale of agency; photo (M)

headline: Europeans Told to Avoid U.S. Accords On Airlines
abstract: European Union warns governments of its 15 member nations that it will take legal action against any of them that make individual 'open skies' airline agreements with US, which give permission for airlines to fly between countries (M)

headline: Four A's President Pressed to Stay On
abstract: Advertising: Four A's President Pressed to Stay On*ï

headline: For Stay-at-Home Film Buffs With a Taste for the Opulent
abstract: Bang & Olufsen introduces high-end home theater set-up combining finest components; photo (M)

headline: Powell Seeks China's Help, And, at U.N., Its Abstention
abstract: Sec Colin Powell will meet with Chinese leaders in Beijing to try to narrow sharp differences on dismantling North Korea's nuclear weapons program and disarming Iraq; will urge China to use its 'considerable influence' as principal supplier of aid to North Korea; will also ask China not to veto new UN resolution on use of military force in Iraq; photo; Powell pressed case on Iraq during stop in Japan (M)

headline: Exiled American Outlives Stalin's Shadow
abstract: Profile of and interview with David Natanovich Bell, native of Houston, Tex, who has lived in Soviet Union since he was barely 10; Bell, now 81, is among last of small band of Americans and their kin who quit United States in depths of Great Depression and headed for Josef Stalin's socialist paradise; for acting on their convictions, many suffered grievously; some died, marooned in prison camps or worker to death building dams for greater Soviet glory; many others, including Bell's brother, sister and children, fled to America and Europe after Soviet Union's borders began to crack open; Bell chose to stay and live with his wife in Dubna, 80 miles north of Moscow; photo (L)

headline: A Pair's Persistence Pays Off
abstract: Rosemary Coffin and Maryanna Hatch are enjoying retirement at RiverWoods, $45 million nonprofit life-care retirement community in Exeter, NH, which they conceived of 20 years ago and helped bring into reality; photos (M)

headline: Do-It-All Palmtops: New Tricks
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column describes new palmtops by Palm and BlackBerry that can handle e-mail, Internet access and function as cellphones; drawing; photos (M)

headline: Private Sector; Yes, She's a Household Word, But the House Isn't Pretty
abstract: Internet poll conducted by I Want Media Inc finds 112 of about 500 readers surveyed named Martha Stewart Media Person of the Year for 2002; her alleged insider stock trading attracted unflattering media coverage; photo (S)

headline: Pair of Bombers Kill 23 in Israel; Reprisals Begin
abstract: Two suicide bombers commit deadliest attack against Israel in 10 months, blowing themselves up just seconds apart in downtown area of Tel Aviv; 23 are killed and 100 more injured; area is crowded with foreign laborers and Sunday evening shoppers; spokesman for Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades, Palestinian militant organization, claims responsibility; Israeli reprisals begin, with gunships entering skies over Gaza and rocketing Palestinian positions there; Prime Min Ariel Sharon's cabinet meets in emergency session; rescue teams encounter scene of horrific carnage; say two bombs appear to be unusually large and were packed with nails and ball bearings and hunks of metal to sharpen their effect; photos; map (M)

headline: Sale by Softbank Will End Its Control of Yahoo Japan
abstract: Softbank plans to sell part of its majority stake in Yahoo Japan, one of its most valuable assets, to help meet debt payments and to expand its high-speed Internet services here.    Softbank, whose share price has fallen 98 percent from its peak, is under pressure to introduce new broadband Internet services to compete with Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, the market leader.

headline: Iraq Gave No New Evidence in Arms Report, Inspector Says
abstract: Hans Blix said today that Iraq's report was "devoid of any new evidence" that the country had no banned weapons.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Belden Lowers First-Quarter Outlook
abstract: Belden, maker of cable and wire products, cuts its first-quarter outlook to well below Wall Street estimates, citing lower-than-expected revenue; graph (S)

headline: Because It's There: Putting Everest Online
abstract: Sherpa Tsering Gyaltsen plans to build world's highest Internet cafe at base camp of Mount Everest in time for 50th anniversary of Sir Edmund Hillary's famous ascent; positioning wireless radios on moving glaciers and insulating gear against cold pose significant challenges; installation will benefit residents of Namche Bazar, who will also get Internet access; photos; maps (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bankruptcy For Internet Concern
abstract: Korea Thrunet, a South Korean Internet access provider, spurned an offer from the Dacom Corporation, preferring to file a court petition for bankruptcy after admitting it could not pay bills that are due this month. Thrunet earlier rejected an offer from Hanaro Telecom, an Internet provider. Dacom, a telephone company that is part of the LG Group, was thought to have decided to wait until Thrunet had no choice but to lower its price. Thrunet will remain in business under court protection, selling off assets and looking for what it regards as a reasonable bid.   Don Kirk (NYT)

headline: IN THE BATTLEFIELD
abstract: U.S. RAID IN AFGHANISTAN -- About 1,000 American troops launched a raid on villages in the mountains of southeastern Afghanistan today, hunting for members of Al Qaeda.   PAGE A23

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None

headline: Compressed Data; Looking After Life Without Leaving Office
abstract: Survey conducted by Center for e-Service at University of Maryland finds that workers spend average of 5.9 hours each week using Internet at home for job-related purposes, compared with 3.7 hours weekly devoted to personal Web business at office (M)

headline: Serb Leader Is Assassinated
abstract: Prime Minister Zoran Djindjic helped overthrow and send Slobodan Milosevic to face a war crimes tribunal.

headline: Seeking Customers in a Blighted Area
abstract: Seeking Customers in a Blig

headline: Israel Takes Back Land in Gaza; Raids Kill 3 and Wound 15
abstract: After weeks of intensified raids into Gaza, Israel for the first time has begun doing here what it has done since last summer in the West Bank.

headline: 18 Ex-Guantánamo Captives Suddenly Out on Kabul Street
abstract: Eighteen Afghans who were returned from American detention center at Guantanamo Bay are freed by Afghan authorities onto streets of Kabul, shaken and tired and showing flashes of anger and resentment at whole ordeal; are given no money or assistance by either Afghan authorities or Americans; four senior Taliban officials are captured after weeklong hunt led by Afghan police; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Premier Agrees To Talks
abstract: Prime Minister Hun Sen says Cambodia will send delegation to United Nations at invitation of Secretary General Kofi Annan to prepare for resumption of talks about setting up international tribunal to try surviving leaders of Khmer Rouge; UN suspended talks last year, saying Cambodians were not negotiating seriously; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Less Red Tape
abstract: Center for Economic and Financial Research study of hundreds of small businesses finds legislation enacted in 2001 and 2002 in Russia has begun to reduce red tape (S)

headline: New Creative Heads at Two Agencies
abstract: New Creative Heads At Two Agencies Two agencies have hired creative chiefs.

headline: A System to Please the Eye (Not to Mention the Ears)
abstract: Philips introduces Emotive Micro line of bookshelf-size systems with vertical design that can play several types of CD's; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Volkswagen Investment
abstract: Volkswagen picks its Puebla, Mex, plant to make new Bora model for European market; plans to invest $2 billion in plant in next five years and add 1,500 jobs; car's production will begin in 2005 with 100,00 units per year (S)

headline: Bush Warns Hussein Again But Sidesteps Any 'Deadline'
abstract: Pres Bush says time is running out on Saddam Hussein to disarm voluntarily but issues no specific deadlines; comments during meeting with Polish Pres Aleksander Kwasniewski; photo; European leaders reiterate insistence on second Security Council resolution to authorize any military action, and even Britain suggests upcoming deadline for arms inspection report should not be considered war trigger without new resolution (M)

headline: White House Sticks to Decision to Avoid Talks With North Korea
abstract: The Bush administration believes that North Korea should be dealt with multilaterally, either by its neighbors or by the United Nations Security Council.

headline: Your Taxes; The Quest for Tax Breaks
abstract: Step-by-step guide to IRS Form 1040, prepard by Jan M Rosen of New York Times and Marc Luscombe and Ernest Zoumot of CCH Inc, provider of tax and business law information and software

headline: That Other Problem With 'Old Europe'
abstract: Floyd Norris column on weak European economies, especially in France and Germany, says Pres Bush may be more dependent than he realizes on successful European economic policies; says in 2002, American economy showed growth rate of 2.4 percent, Germany's rate was 0.2 percent and France is doing only slightly better; graph (M)

headline: Trial Begins for French Candidate for Central Bank Post
abstract: Jean-Claude Trichet went on trial today for a decade-old banking scandal that could jeopardize his chances to become the next president of the European Central Bank.

headline: Florence Journal; The Warts on Michelangelo: The Man Was a Miser
abstract: Interview with Rab Hatfield, professor of art history at Syracuse University program in Florence, Italy, whose book, The Wealth of Michelangelo, concludes that Michelangelo was miser who died with modern equivalent of tens of millions of dollars, even though he complained constantly about deprivation and has often been cast as somewhat poor; photos (M)

headline: THREATS AND RESPONSES: The Intellectuals; Artists Feel Chirac's Slap, But Hesitate to Take Sides
abstract: Questions of United States versus Europe, or even of 'old Europe' versus 'new Europe,' mean little to Imre Kertesz, Hungarian novelist and Nobel Prize winner, who says that as an artist, he is European, but he cannot shake his emotional attachment to United States; like Kertesz--and unlike many of their counterparts in Western Europe--several writers and other cultural figures from Eastern and Central Europe seem reluctant to take sides in increasingly fraught dispute that is fracturing old political alliances; photos of Kertesz and of Czech writer Ivan Klima, who also speaks warmly of America (M)

headline: Mutual Funds Report; Pursuing Growth, Fund Is a 10-Year Leader
abstract: Profile of Calamos Growth fund, Calamos Investments mutual fund managed by John P Calamos Sr that is one of top-performing diversified domestic stock funds for last ten years; photo (M)

headline: Business; R.V.'s and Tourism Help Areas Buck the Economic Tide
abstract: Employment rolls fell 0.2 percent across United States in 2002, but some areas did well, with 140 of 316 metropolitan areas adding jobs; among big gainers were centers for tourism or military; map (M)

headline: Car Bomb at Checkpoint Kills Australian Journalist and Several Kurds
abstract: Car laden with explosives detonates at Kurdish military checkpoint at Girdi Go, Iraq, killing Australian television cameraman and wounding television correspondent he worked with; at least 3 Kurds are killed and 24 others injured in same blast; suicide bombing occurs at chaotic checkpoint near border with Iran; photos (M)

headline: Personal Business; As Job Seekers Multiply, So Can Empty Promises
abstract: Advice for job seekers on avoiding being swindled by disreputable employment search firms; Ian Leicht, who set up Web site to help protect job seekers, comments; photo (M)

headline: Land Reforms in Scotland Give Big Estates the Jitters
abstract: Rich estate owners in Scotland are in uproar over law passed by Scottish Parliament that would give 'crofters,' small-scale tenant farmers who have lived in Highlands for generations, right to collectively purchase sections of estates they live on, whether landowner wants to sell to them or not, and that would establish 'right to roam' limiting landowners' right to eject people from their property; supporters of bill, which is due to be signed into law this year, note that half of private land in Scotland is in hands of 343 landowners and that only half of Scotland's land has gone on market in past century; photo; map (M)

headline: Suspect in Bali Bomb Attack Says Americans Were Target
abstract: Ali Imron, key suspect in bomb attack in Bali last Oct, says American were primary target; nearly 200 people were killed, most of them Australians; Imron explains how attack was carried out and makes clear that suicide bomber was involved; says special bomb vest was designed by Malaysian university professor, who has not been caught (S)

headline: Explosion, Said to Be From Missile, Rocks Empty Mall in Kuwait
abstract: Explosion rocks empty shopping mall in Kuwait City, sending huge plume of white smoke toward sky; Kuwaiti officials blame errant American cruise missile that landed in water nearby; emergency workers gather fragments to be used for analysis; map (M)

headline: Neighbors of Brazilian Citadel of Chic Are Angered by Its Growth
abstract: Daslu, trendy shop in Sao Paulo, Brazil, has become very public litmus test of whether left-leaning city government is serious in reining in unchecked urban growth; Daslu's problems began when City Hall inspectors discovered that its owner bought up neighboring houses and gradually expanded her store without extending her premises' commercial license, thus violating zoning regulations; neighborhood association's protest led to order for Daslu to close, but store's owner filed for series of court injunctions and store is still open; sales staff includes daughter of Sao Paulo Gov Geraldo Alckmin; map (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Prison Terms For Homosexuality Convictions
abstract: Cairo (Egypt) misdemeanor court sentences 21 men to three years in prison for homosexuality; 29 men are acquitted; convictions are on appeal (S)

headline: BIG GROCERY DISTRIBUTOR WILL CUT 1,800 JOBS
abstract: Fleming Companies, grocery distributor, will cut 1,800 jobs and says Securities and Exchange Commission has formalized accounting investigation (S)

headline: Missiles hit Baghdad; seaport is said to fall : U.S. and British troops push into Iraq
abstract: KUWAIT:—  As cruise missiles struck government buildings in Baghdad on Thursday, American and British troops launched their ground war, surging across the Iraqi border after nightfall here and reportedly capturing the key seaport of Umm Qasr.

headline: Britain Arrests Russian Expatriate Billionaire and a Colleague
abstract: British police arrest self-exiled Russian billionaire Boris Berezovsky to begin legal proceedings that could lead to his extradition to face fraud charges in Russia; Yuli Dubov, former auto company executive, also arrested; Berezovsky has charged that allegations are part of plot by Pres Vladimir Putin to silence him (S)

headline: Germans Arrest 2 Yemenis at U.S. Request
abstract: German authorities arrest two Yemeni men in Frankfurt at US request; main suspect is identified as Sheik Muhammad Ali Hassan al-Mouyad, imam at mosque in Sana, whom American officials describe as significant Qaeda figure and fund-raiser for Osama bin Laden; Yemeni officials react with surprise; photos; map (M)

headline: Scientist Gives Inspectors First Private Talk
abstract: Iraq bends to central demand of United Nations weapons inspectors, saying one of its scientists has agreed to be interviewed in private, without government witness at his side; interview itself seems less significant on its own than as possible sign that Iraq is feeling deep pressure and might make concessions to stave off attack by United States; photo (M)

headline: Retrieving Precious Data
abstract: Frances W Rodgers letter describes how he stores and occasionally reboots old hard drives (Feb 13 article)

headline: Camp Bonifas Journal; It's Korea, and G.I.'s Sleep With Their Boots On
abstract: Camp Bonifas in South Korea, near demilitarized zone between North and South Korea, is only place where American and North Korean soldiers come eyeball to eyeball; Americans are on highest alert, sleeping in some posts with their boots on, ready to roll out at moment's notice; while world awaits next move by North Korean leader Kim Jong Il, soldiers say their high alert has not changed in recent weeks, during which there have been two missile launchings by North and two incidents involving its MIG warplanes; photos (M)

headline: France's Remarks to the U.N.
abstract: The following is the text of an address by French Foreign Minister Dominique De Villepin at the United Nations:

headline: Women Redefine Their Roles in New Russia
abstract: Russian women are pursuing liberation even if they do not espouse feminism or, more generally, activism; feel that they have lost rights and power with collapse of Soviet system, which set aside certain number of government jobs for women, ensured them places in universities alongside men and opened cafeterias, laundries and day care centers in cities to ease their burden at home; have shown themselves to be more adept then men at adapting to new capitalist system; photos (M)

headline: At Least 16 Killed in Afghan Bus Explosion
abstract: At least 16 people, including women and children, were killed when their bus exploded on a bridge just outside the southern city of Kandahar.

headline: A Vote of Confidence in Real Estate Shares
abstract: DIARY A Vote of Confidence In Real Estate Shares.

headline: Serbia Arrests Suspect in Assassination of Prime Minister
abstract: Serbia's new leader said today that the police had arrested the sniper who killed his predecessor, Zoran Djindjic, a reformer who was assassinated last month by what the authorities say is an underworld gang.

headline: People-Rating on the Web?
abstract: At a dinner party last weekend, my wife and I were chatting with two recently divorced moms. They were tragicomically bemoaning the awkwardness of re-entering the dating world in middle age.

headline: Technology Briefing: Deals
abstract: PIXELWORKS AND GENESIS AGREE TO STOCK SWAP; GTECH TO ACQUIRE INTERLOTT FOR $64 MILLION;.

headline: Australia to Send Senior Diplomats to North Korea
abstract: Australia, one of the few allies of the United States with direct diplomatic contacts with North Korea, is sending an official delegation to Pyongyang.

headline: Army and Marines Begin Wartime Ads
abstract: Army follows Marine Corps in introducing special television commercial with wartime theme and tone (S)

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: SOUTH AFRICA: 'No Decision' On Zimbabwe; LIBERIA: Ex-Ally Challenges President; CONGO REPUBLIC: 10 Die In Attack On Town;.

headline: CONCORD EFS, OWNER OF A.T.M. NETWORK, NAMES CO-CHIEF
abstract: C

headline: Japan Launches Spy Satellite Despite North Korean Threats
abstract: Japan launches rocket carrying two military spy satellites into low-level orbits, ignoring North Kroea's threats of 'disastrous consequences'; satellites carry radar equipment and cameras and will allow Japan to monitor North Korea; North Korea test-fired two short-range missiles in last month; it has warned that launching of satellites could prompt it to drop five-year-old, self-imposed moratorium on long-range missile firings; American officials have put North Korea's missile program under new scrutiny, saying North Korea is maintaining two nuclear programs to produce raw materials for nuclear weapons; photo (M)

headline: Dating of Australian Remains Backs Theory of Early Migration of Humans
abstract: New research suggests that gravesite at Lake Mungo, Australia, is evidence of long migration from Africa more than 40,000 years ago, probably by boats that hugged Asian coast; map; survey revises estimated date of burial to 42,000 years ago, not 62,000 as dated in 1998, supporting theory that change occurring some 50,000 years ago endowed human societies with capabilities for travel and exploiting new environments; Dr James M Bowler and Australian colleagues report findings in journal Nature; Dr Richard Klein says change is so sudden as to suggest genetic change (M)

headline: Bush to Give Hussein an Ultimatum: Choose Exile or War
abstract: President Bush planned to declare tonight that the only way to avoid war was for Saddam Hussein to leave Iraq.

headline: Militants Fire Rockets at 2 U.S. Bases in Afghanistan
abstract: Anti-American militants fired more than a dozen rockets at two United States bases overnight, the second such heavy attack since the war in Iraq began.

headline: Fugitive in EBay Fraud Case Is Arrested
abstract: Kenneth Fetterman, fugitive accused of taking part in fraudulent bidding ring on eBay online auction service, is arrested in Wichita, Kan, and will be brought to trial in Sacramento; Fetterman was indicted in March 2001 on federal charges of wire fraud, mail fraud and money laundering in connection with attempts to auction fake artworks on eBay; three other people have pleaded guilty (S)

headline: Banks Doubled Profit Increase in 2002
abstract: Net income for banks supervised by Office of the Comptroller of the Currency rose 28 percent in 2002, up from 14 percent increase in 2001 (S)

headline: Court in India Orders Archaeological Study of Disputed Holy Site
abstract: Court in northern India orders archaeologists to begin excavating holy site in Ayodhya to determine whether Hindu temple once existed there; site is one of most violently disputed between Hindus and Muslims anywhere in country; right-wing Hindu groups that support governing Bharatiya Janata Party believe site to be birthplace of Hindu god Ram thousands of years ago; they claim Muslim marauders destroyed Hindu temple there and built mosque in its place in 16th century; Muslims say claim is unmproved (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: UAL Has Big Quarterly Loss And Ends Year Deep in Red  UAL, parent of United Airlines, reported a much larger fourth-quarter loss that underscored the problems that forced it to seek bankruptcy protection in December.    The company's fourth-quarter loss was $1.47 billion, nearly five times its loss of $308 million in the fourth quarter of 2001, when the airline was still struggling to recover from the Sept. 11 attacks. For the year, UAL reported a net loss of $3.2 billion, compared with $2.1 billion in 2001. [Page C2.]

headline: Deutsche Telekom Changes Board
abstract: Deutsche Telekom replaces its supervisory board chairman, Hans-Dietrich Winkhaus, with Klaus Zumwinkel in latest management shuffle (S)

headline: How Four Countries Reacted, And What the Iraqis Said, Too
abstract: Representatives of Britain, Germany, China, Russia and Iraq make statements after chief weapons inspectors in Iraq deliver reports to United Nations Security Council; excerpts from remarks of Foreign Sec Jack Straw of Britain, Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer of Germany, Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan of China, Russian Foreign Minister Igor Ivanov and Ambassador Mohammed Aldouri of Iraq; photo

headline: A Misguided View Of Verizon's Value?
abstract: Verizon Communications official Peter W Thonis disputes Jan 19 article on company

headline: New York Seeks Looser Police Surveillance Rules
abstract: New York City asks federal court to ease limits on police surveillance of political groups, move that would enable officers to initiate investigations without evidence of crime and to share their information with other law enforcement agencies (M)

headline: Investing; $30 Million Bet by J. P. Morgan Chase
abstract: J P Morgan Incubator fund, which was set up in December 2002 by J P Morgan Chase, has sole purpose of financing and nurturing new hedge funds, and it is seeking $200 million from outside investors to seed approximately a dozen new funds (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Mine Strike Ends
abstract: About 1,300 copper miners at Cananea, Mexico, mine return to work after reaching agreement over productivity bonuses with Grupo Mexico; agreement ends 16-day strike during which company had threatened to shut down mine; workers will receive bonuses based on output as part of agreement (S)

headline: North Korea Defends Decision to Re-Start Nuclear Program
abstract: North Korea's top diplomat in Beijing blamed the U.S. for his country's decision to re-start its nuclear program.

headline: Iraq Begins Destroying Missiles U.N. Ruled Illegal
abstract: Demetrius Perricos, deputy United Nations weapons inspector, says Iraq has begun destroying its illegal short-range Al Samoud 2 missiles, crushing 4 of stock of about 100; says it will take two weeks for Iraq to destroy the rest, along with their warheads, 380 illegally imported engines, any fuel and all design software; says host of other questions about Iraqi cooperation with his team have yet to be resolved; suggests that inspections can still be effective; photo (M)

headline: Mattel's Profit Is Up by 35%, Led by Sales Of Barbies
abstract: Mattel Inc says fourth-quarter profit rose 35 percent; net income climbed to $186.1 million from $138 million year earlier; sales increased 6.9 percent, to $1.67 billion (M)

headline: Bin Laden Tape May Hint at Attack, C.I.A. Says
abstract: CIA Dir George J Tenet says latest taped message attributed to Osama bin Laden is 'exhortation to his followers,' similar to statements he made last year on Oct 6 and Nov 12 that were quickly followed by deadly terrorist strikes against American and other targets overseas; with fear of attack high, government officials in United States and allies like Britain further tighten security; Pentagon officials order vehicles armed with Stinger antiaircraft missiles to patrol capital and intensify F-16 fighter flights over Washington; for second consecutive day, 450 British troops patrol London's Heathrow Airport as intelligence officials warn that Al Qaeda might be preparing rocket attack against commercial airliner; Tenet, testifying before Senate Armed Services Committee, says American intelligence officials say voice on latest tape appears to be bin Laden's; says message is being examined in search for particular phrases or words that might be coded signals to bin Laden's operatives; experts differ on meaning of message (M)

headline: Bombs Explode in Cities South of Kurdish Region and in Areas Held by Militant Group
abstract: Explosions reverberate in northern Iraq as cities south of autonomous Kurdish region are subjected to intense American aerial bombardment, and similar attack is launched against Ansar al-Islam, Islamic militant group near Iranian border; Kurds, long persecuted by Pres Saddam Hussein, are overjoyed at large-scale assault; other smaller strikes in northern area noted; map (M)

headline: Ernst & Young Financial Details Are Disclosed In Divorce Case
abstract: Every detail that accounting firm Ernst & Young told American partners about its financial performance through late 2000 becomes public as part of divorce case involving chief executive Richard S Bobrow; many aspects of foreign operations are disclosed; documents are released by Hamilton County (Ind) Superior Court Judge Steven R Nation after motions are filed by New York Times to obtain them; disclosure is sure to arouse unhappiness among firm's 1,900 American partners; experts predict information will put competitors at advantage in bidding on contracts, hiring employees and settling lawsuits; financial data will also be of interest to spouses of Ernst & Young partners who are planning divorce; Ernst & Young is not required to disclose anything about its financial to public because it is a privately held firm; documents show firm had revenue of $4.3 billion in year ended Sept 30, 2000, up 12.3 percent from figures in previous year; total earnings were $1.3 billion, down 1 percent from year earlier; margin was 31 percent in 2000, down from 35 percent in 1999; equity stake of nearly 1,900 partners fell to $422 million from $525 million year earlier, down 19.6 percent; average cash earnings per partner were $565,000, up 9.7 percent from $515,000 year before; firm's spokesman Larry Parnell declines comment; chart (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Enron Employees Must Pay Expenses of Pension Plans  The federal judge overseeing the bankruptcy of Enron ruled that the company could not pay fees to an independent overseer of three retirement plans for current and former employees. Instead, the judge said, participants in the plans must pick up the costs themselves.    Enron's creditors, who lose money for every dollar spent on other matters, have strongly opposed such payments. [Page C2.]

headline: Hisashi Shinto, 92, Is Dead; Was Industrialist in Japan
abstract: Hisashi Shinto, one of Japan's most prominent post-war industrialists, who was caught in bribery scandal late in his career, dies at age of 92; photo (M)

headline: Bush Enlarges Case For War by Linking Iraq With Terrorists
abstract: President Bush, enlarging the case for going to war with Iraq soon, said tonight that there was intelligence showing that Iraq was helping and protecting terrorists. He warned that Saddam Hussein could distribute weapons of mass destruction to terrorists who could use them against the United States.    Iraq's alleged terrorist connection is just one reason Mr. Bush cited for preparing for war. He also said Iraq could threaten the Persian Gulf region if it developed weapons of mass destruction, and he assailed its record on human rights.

headline: Sharon Leads Likud to Decisive Victory
abstract: The Israeli prime minister's big win in elections amounted to an endorsement of his tough approach to the conflict with Palestinians.

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Key3Media Allowed To Tap Financing
abstract: Key3Media Group receives approval from Federal Bankruptcy Judge Jerry Venters to tap into $30 million loan from Thomas Weisel Capital Partners (S)

headline: Business; Quiet, but Central, Role For Ammunition Maker
abstract: Profile of Alliant Techsystems Inc, ammunition maker that plays key role in Iraq fighting; company makes all of Army's small-arms ammunition, about half of medium-caliber rounds fired by armored vehicles, anti-tank chain guns in attack helicopters and crucial parts of so-called smart weapons; graphs of financial data and stock price; photos (M)

headline: UNITED AIRLINES TO LAY OFF 704 MORE FLIGHT ATTENDANTS
abstract: United Airlines will lay off 704 more flight attendants, about 3 percent of its total, by Feb 22 because it has reduced flights and amenities (S)

headline: MCKESSON SAYS IT IS PART OF A FEDERAL INVESTIGATION
abstract: Drug wholesaler McKesson says it

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Lucent In Labor Accord
abstract: Communications Workers of America and Lucent Technologies reach tentative agreement on new 20-month contract to take effect when current five-year agreement expires on May 31; pact gives workers 2 percent raise in June and another 2 percent raise year later, but will require them to pay more for most health benefits (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Bush's Budget Includes Tax Cut and Record Deficits  President Bush sent Congress a $2.23 trillion budget with record deficits that would speed up billions of dollars in income tax cuts, provide huge increases for the Pentagon and offer a modest jump in spending for NASA.    The budget proposal forecasts a deficit of $304 billion in the current fiscal year, and projects a deficit of $307 billion for fiscal 2004. Over the next five years the projected deficit would be more than $1 trillion, a potentially problematic number for Mr. Bush. [Page A1.]

headline: Private Sector; Swap Two Grimkés for a Fiorina? Cards Honor Pioneering Women
abstract: Women's Museum, Dallas, offers trading cards that honor significant women throughout history; current year's cards include Hewlett Packard chief executive Carleton S Fiorina, national security adviser Condoleezza Rice and House Democratic leader Nancy Pelosi; photo (S)

headline: IRANIAN CLERIC REBUKES BUSH
abstract: Ayatollah Muhammad Yazdi, member of Iran's conservative Guardian Council, scores Pres Bush's stand in State of the Union address that Iran violates human rights and tries to develop weapons of mass destruction; holds Bush's policies after Sept 11 terror attacks violate rights of Muslim immigrants (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: No Primary For Peronists, Judge Says
abstract: Argentine judge rules ex-Pres Carlos Menem's Peronist party is not required to hold primary to choose single candidate for Apr 27 presidential election; decision paves way for party to offer three candidates, damaging Menem's chances of returning to power (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Eruption!
abstract: Popocatepetl, Mexico's biggest volcano, erupts, throwing rocks and ash more than two miles from crater (S)

headline: Scholastic Posts $500,000 Loss in Quarter
abstract: Scholastic Corp posts loss of $500,000 for fiscal third quarter ended Feb 28 compared with profit of $11.9 million year earlier; sales rose 0.2 percent, to $433.7 million from $432.7 million (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  Personal Income: Jan.  Construction Spending: Jan.    TUESDAY  None

headline: Afghans Report 17 Civilians Killed in Allied Air Raids
abstract: Afghan officials say 17 civilians, including women and children, have been killed in American-led bombing of mountainous region of southern Afghanistan, where US Special Forces have been fighting rebels for several days (S)

headline: Tension at the Checkpoint, Fear Crossing the Bridge
abstract: Iraqi civilians flee fighting in Basra, clutching their possessions and small children in their arms; are afraid of Saddam Hussein's troops inside city who they say are executing people freely; afraid of allied forces outside city whose intentions they do not yet know; and afraid of what would come as their supplies of food and water continue to dwindle; Iraqi soldiers let loose barrage of machine-gun and mortar fire toward civilians walking out of Basra; British soldier is killed in fighting nearer to city, and several others are wounded; Basra, city of 1.5 million people encircled by British troops, remains place of uncertainty; what exactly is happening in city is unclear, but reports from those fleeing are troubling; Basra lies close to Zubayr, town captured by allied forces but still not fully secured; man from there speaks bitterly about Americans who came and took town, then left, leaving town to fedayeen loyal to Saddam Hussein; says fedayeen kill those they saw talking to allied troops; photo (M)

headline: NATO SETTLES RIFT OVER AID TO TURKS IN CASE OF A WAR
abstract: NATO agrees to American request to supply Turkey with equipment to defend itself in event of war in Iraq, resolving bitter dispute that pitted US against France and Germany; agrees to have NATO Defense Planning Council make plans for Turkey's defense by sending Awacs air reconnaissance planes, Patriot missiles and chemical and biological warfare teams to Turkey; France had objected to such planning on grounds that Security Council had not authorized use of force against Iraq, but opposition was circumvented; after announcement, France, Germany and Belgium reiterate their opposition to military action unless authorized by Council; photos (M)

headline: 2 U.S. Computer Workers Are Shot, One Fatally, Near Army Base in Kuwait
abstract: Unidentified gunmen open fire on car carrying two American civilians near US military base, Camp Doha, in Kuwait, killing Michael Rene Pouliot and severely wounding David Caraway; attack, third such incident since US began big deployment last autumn, is described by US and Kuwaiti officials as terrorist ambush; photos; map; victims' employer is San Diego software company Tapestry Solutions (M)

headline: Benyoussef Ben Khedda, 82, Algerian Leader
abstract: Benyoussef Ben Khedda, Algerian nationalist leader who announced his country's negotiated independence from France on July 3, 1962, but was quickly swept from power by revolutionary forces he helped unleash, dies at age 82; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Chief of Goldman Sachs Apologizes For Remarks on Firm's Productivity
abstract: Goldman Sachs Group chairman-chief executive Henry M Paulson Jr apologizes for suggesting last week that most of highly paid employees at investment bank seem expendable; says he gave 'glib and insensitive response' when discussing possibility of more layoffs at Goldman; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: North Korea Says It Is Withdrawing From Arms Treaty
abstract: North Korea set off a flurry of diplomatic activity and condemnation today when it announced it was withdrawing from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty.

headline: Casualties
abstract: The toll of announced casualties in Iraq as of 8 p.m. on Tuesday:    U.S.  KILLED: 20*  CAPTURED OR MISSING: 14*

headline: MIRANT TO FREE UP CASH IN EFFORT TO AVOID BANKRUPTCY
abstract: Electricity producer and natural gas trader Mirant Corp will pay $270 million in penalties to cancel orders for power plant turbines and reduce sales of gas by half in effort to free up cash and avoid bankruptcy (S)

headline: Arab Summit to Be Held in Cairo
abstract: Arab leaders will meet on March 1 in a new effort to forge a united position on President Bush's threats to attack Iraq over its weapons programs.

headline: Dow Jones Drops Goodby, Silverstein
abstract: Dow Jones & Co parts ways with Goodby, Silverstein & Partners, which has handled advertising account of Wall Street Journal since 1999; Dow Jones spent $22.4 million in major media in first 10 months of 2002 to advertise Wall Street Journal (S)

headline: Mutual Funds Report; At the Top of the List, Notable Reversals of Fortune
abstract: Fourth quarter of 2002 brought strong results to many mutual funds; results of three top performers, Kopp Emerging Growth, Legg Mason Focus Trust and Gabelli Blue Chip Value AAA fund, discussed; photos; graphs of funds' results (M)

headline: In China, Quick Rise And Death Of a Tycoon
abstract: Rise of Haixin Steel owner Li Haica

headline: Preaching to Save Shoppers From 'Evil' of Consumerism
abstract: Bill Talen, also known as Reverend Billy, is street preacher who exhorts people to resist temptation--temptation to shop--and to smite demon of consumerism; he declares consumerism is 'dull way of life'; photo of Talen preaching outside Plaza Hotel in Manhattan on Buy Nothing Day (M)

headline: Neighborhood Barricades in Caracas
abstract: Middle-class neighborhoods across Caracas are drawing up neighborhood watch plans in anticipation that left-leaning government of Pres Hugo Chavez is preparing to install communist system in Venezuela that will force people from their homes and businesses to accommodate inhabitants of poorest neighborhoods; critics say plans are dangerous because they are driven more by rumors than reality; photo of Anti-Chavez demonstration (M)

headline: Making Near Beer Acceptable in Near East
abstract: Making Near Beer Acceptable in Ne7

headline: Market Place; Dividend Plan Is of Little Use To Margin Buyers
abstract: Bush admininstration says investors who want to buy stocks with borrowed money will find that dividends received will be taxable even after other dividends are no longer taxed; Treasury Department discloses plan to make dividends taxable if they come from 'debt-financed stock'; says it will extend existing provision, known as Section 246A, that applies to corporations that buy stock with borrowed money; dividends from such shares do not qualify for existing tax break on dividends paid by one corporation to another; 21st Securities tax director Mark Fichtenbaum says investor who uses home-equity loan to buy stock could find that dividends are taxable; stock prices could fall if investors sell stock to pay off margin loans (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank Selects Chief
abstract: HSBC names Stephen Green chief executive succeeding Sir Keith Whitson, retiring (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Pipeline Decision Delayed
abstract: World Business Briefing: Russia: Pipeline Decisi

headline: Computer Associates Sales Come Up Short
abstract: Computer Associates International says sales in third quarter ended Dec 31 rose 4.1 percent, to $778 million; revenue in fourth quarter ending in March will rise to $785 million to $800 million, from $772 million year earlier; Compuware Corp says sales in December quarter fell 27 percent; third-quarter net loss narrowed to $44 million from $231 million year ago; revenue from software subscriptions rose 57 percent to $362 million; third-quarter net income dropped 15 percent, to $25.4 million from $29.8 million; revenue in quarter ended Dec 31 declined to $333.1 million from $453.8 million (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Plan To Toughen Laws On Sex Crimes
abstract: British government announces groundbreaking proposal toughening laws against sex offenders; legislation needs parliamentary approval (S)

headline: Buoyed by Mortgage Bonds, Profit at Bear Stearns Rises 52%
abstract: Bear Stearns Companies says its fiscal first-quarter net income surged 52 percent to record; net income was $274.3 million, up from $180.5 million year earlier; revenue rose to $1.5 billion from $1.24 billion (M)

headline: In Powell's Words: Saddam Hussein Remains Guilty
abstract: Excerpts from Secretary of State Colin L Powell's remarks questioning validity of work by weapons inspectors in Iraq (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Refiner'S Profit Falls; BRITAIN: Wal-Mart Joins Safeway Bidding; THE NETHERLANDS: Food Concern Cuts Outlook; ITALY: Money Promised For Fiat;.

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS -- for ARNOLD H. PEDOWITZ; So Long. Now Don't Compete.
abstract: Arnold H Pedowitz, employment lawyer, answers questions on noncompetition or confidentiality agreement that increasing number of employees -- from executives to hourly workers -- are being asked to sign; photo (M)

headline: Kurds Take Up Positions Along the Turkish Border
abstract: Hundreds of Kurdish soldiers armed with artillery, rocket launchers and heavy machine guns are continuing to take up positions along Iraq's border with Turkey, according to Kurdish officials and local residents. Turkey moved a large military convoy of its own to the border area late last week.    The United States has been trying to broker an agreement to prevent open clashes between the two bitter rivals that could complicate an American-led attack on Iraq. Turkey has said it reserves the right to move its forces into northern Iraq to prevent Kurds from declaring an independent state. Kurds, whose forces would probably be quickly overwhelmed, say Turkey is simply trying to occupy their territory.

headline: Advanced Cell Wins a Cloning Patent Dispute With Infigen
abstract: Patent and Trademark Office rules that Infigen waited too long before asserting its claims to fundamental cloning technology to which Advanced Cell Technology had already been granted patent; those two companies and Geron are battling for priority on assertions that they developed technology for cloning mammals using cell from adult (M)

headline: Iraq Shows One of Its Drones, Recalling Wright Brothers
abstract: Reporters are brought by Iraqi officials to weapons plant outside Baghdad to view Iraq's latest remotely piloted vehicle called drone; Bush adminstration officials claim it has potential to be one of Saddam Hussein's deadliest weapons, able to deliver terrifying payloads of chemical and biological warfare agents; vehicle on view appears more like Rube Goldberg concoction, complete with masking tape; photo (M)

headline: Germans Were Tracking Sept. 11 Conspirators as Early as 1998, Documents Disclose
abstract: Newly obtained documents reveal that Germany's domestic intelligence service was tracking, three years before Sept 11, 2001, terrorist attacks on Washington, DC, and New York City, prominent members of Hamburg terrorist cell that planned and executed aircraft hijackings; question arises about whether German authorities missed chance to disrupt cell during initial stages of planning attacks; photos (M)

headline: SCHERING REPORTS MULTIPLE SCLEROSIS DRUG APPROVAL
abstract: Schering Reports Multiple

headline: Effort to Fix Responsibility for Deadly Korean Subway Fire
abstract: A tragedy of errors was responsible for most of the 130 deaths in the subway fire on Tuesday, investigators said today.

headline: DATA NETWORK OPERATOR FILES PLAN FOR CREDITORS
abstract: Metromedia Fiber Network Inc, bankrupt data network operator under investigation by regulators for its accounting, files plan to give creditors all its new shares and emerge from Chapter 11 (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen falls on word that government may counter 'speculative activity' in currency market; graph (S)

headline: Versatile Masks of Dye Speed the Chip-Making Process
abstract: University of Washington researcher Albert Folch uses food dyes to create new kind of photomask, basic tool of photolithography, which is dominant microfabrication technology in semiconductor industry; dyes aid in testing of chip design prototypes; drawing (M)

headline: Only 26 Days to Valentine's Day. Log On.
abstract: Internet traffic measurer comScore Media reports that nearly 25 million people visited dating Web sites during Nov 2002; graphs (S)

headline: Van Heusen, Shirt Maker, Made a Profit In 4th Quarter
abstract: Phillips-Van Heusen, the largest shirt company in the United States and the new owner of Calvin Klein, reported a fourth-quarter profit yesterday after a loss in the period a year ago. Earnings topped analysts' expectations.     The figures do not reflect the acquisition of Calvin Klein on Feb. 12, but Bruce J. Klatsky, Van Heusen's chief executive, said the Calvin Klein dress shirt business, which it licensed earlier last year, did play a role in the results. ''We launched a range of C.K. dress shirts early in the fourth quarter, and it was the strongest launch ever,'' he said. ''It made us feel very good about the big acquisition.''

headline: Business; On the Trailing Edge of the Arms Industry, by Choice
abstract: Defense Department and handful of private contractors have learned to manage obsolescence of weapon components, some of whose designs and production processes are so outdated and expensive that private sector has long since lost interest in supporting them; many components are so hard to make, or in such little demand, that Defense Departent has had to pay for customized design of repacement parts; some of tactics it has developed for managing obsolescence are finding application in civilian sector; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Federal Pension Agency Said to Disclose Big Deficit  The federal agency that insures the pensions of 44 million Americans has been pounded by a succession of big corporate bankruptcies and has burned through its entire $8 billion surplus in one year.    Though it can continue to make its current payments, the agency is expected to disclose a deficit of $1 billion to $2 billion at the end of this month. Its soundness is likely to deteriorate further in the coming months. [Page A1.]

headline: Venezuela Pumps More Oil, Adding Pressure on Strikers
abstract: Petroleos de Venezuela president Ali Rodriguez says oil industry, though hammered by 61-day strike, is now extracting 1.5 million barrels daily and could reach 2.8 million by end of Mar, level that would let Venezuela meet contractual obligations scrapped when walkout began; assessments, if accurate, are clearest indication yet that Pres Hugo Chavez is on way to reactivating industry opposition leaders had hoped to use as weapon to force his ouster; strike, which shut down much of nation, is fraying as increasing number of businesses reopen; opposition, while still able to muster hundreds of thousands for antigovernment marches, is rapidly losing leverage as talks with government enter new phase; opposition leaders challenge Rodriguez's numbers; photo (M)

headline: Former Minister Assassinated in India
abstract: Haren Pandya, a former minister from the Indian state of Gujarat, was shot and killed today as he took a morning walk near his home.

headline: Stocks Surge as U.S. Signals It May Delay Iraq Action
abstract: The Nasdaq composite index rose nearly 5 percent, while the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose more than 3 percent.

headline: Keeping Soldiers on the Line
abstract: William J Baumann, director of AT&T's military markets, discusses company's contract to provide pay phone service to American troops at camps near front line in war with Iraq; photos (M)

headline: New SK Global Accounting Error Shakes Seoul Market
abstract: The Korean stock market plunged and consumer prices skyrocketed after another accounting error was revealed at Korea's third largest conglomerate.

headline: White House Intensifies Criticism of Iraq Over Warheads
abstract: The White House today called the discovery of 11 empty chemical-weapon warheads "troubling and serious."

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: THE NETHERLANDS: Unilever Sales Improve; IRELAND: Credit Card Bid; SPAIN: Construction Merger;.

headline: Yes, She's a Household Word, but the House Isn't Pretty
abstract: Martha Stewart for public office? Why not? People do seem to enjoy voting for her.

headline: In Iraqi No-Flight Zones, 12 Years of Containment May End in Bombardment
abstract: American pilots who fly tightly controlled no-flight zones over Iraq, where their freedom to engage Saddam Hussein's forces is sharply limited, may soon be called to go on offensive; no-flight zones have proved remarkable, if limited, success, preventing Hussein from sending his air forces into northern and southern Iraq to attack region's Kurdish and Shiite populations; no-flight zones are now seen as training ground for very pilots who may be called upon to attack Iraq; map shows American and coalition air strikes in no-flight zones; chart shows targets struck, by week; photo (M)

headline: China Court Rejects Appeal of Tibetan Monk
abstract: A court has rejected the appeal of a prominent Tibetan monk whose death sentence for bombing and separatist activities had touched off a world outcry.

headline: REBUFFING 2 ALLIES, U.S. PUSHES DEMAND THAT IRAQ DISARM
abstract: Top Bush administration officials are faced with deepest diplomatic rift in decades with some major European allies, but they insist that United States would not have to act alone if war should be needed to force Saddam Hussein to give up all weapons of mass destruction; Secretary of State Colin L Powell brushes aside renewed opposition to war from France and Germany, but another senior administration official acknowledges that US does not now have votes to force second Security Council resolution explicitly authorizing attack on Iraq; all top administration officials--whatever their previous stance--now argue that it is up to Iraq to turn over weapons to United Nations inspectors and not job of inspectors to ferret them out or find 'smoking gun'; Deputy Defense Sec Paul D Wolfowitz, in speech to Council on Foreign Relations, claims Hussein has ordered that any Iraqi scientists who cooperate with inspectors will be killed, as well as their families; military buildup continues in Persian Gulf region; Australia announces it is sending unspecified number of troops, including special forces and air reconnaissance team in advance of possible deployment of fighter planes and transport ship (M)

headline: MERRILL'S GLOBAL HEAD OF STOCK RESEARCH RESIGNS
abstract: Deepak Raj resigns as global head of stock research at Merrill Lynch (S)

headline: APPLE CHIEF TO SWAP OUT OF 22.5 MILLION STOCK OPTIONS
abstract: Apple Computer chief executive Steven P Jobs will give up 22.5 million stock options after company's board approves plan to retire options made worthless by drop in stock's price; Jobs will exchange 27.5 million options for 5 million new ones that will allow him to buy shares in three years (S)

headline: Zimbabwe Opposition Reported to Be Targets of Violence
abstract: Government of Pres Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe strikes back at opponents who staged crippling strike; unleashes wave of violence and intimidation that has brought condemnation from governments and human rights groups around world; Internet reports from Harare describe hospital wards full of people suffering from severe burns and broken fingers and toes; photos show men and women with swollen lash marks on their bodies; opposition leaders say more than 500 people have been arrested; police officials confirm this, claiming those detained had incited violence; deny accusations of brutality; map (M)

headline: Wireless Blogging With a Real-Time Twist
abstract: Communal Weblog called Hiptop Nation offers stream of picture-heavy conversation among T-Mobile Sidekick users; Sidekick allows people to send e-mail and instant messages, browse Web and take pictures, allowing bloggers to offer visual rather than verbal descriptions and responses; photos (M)

headline: Mexico Challenges U.S. on Its Citizens on Death Row
abstract: The government of Mexico asked the International Court of Justice today to block the executions of 51 Mexicans on death row in the U.S.

headline: Argentina Struggles to Meet Debt-Relief Terms
abstract: Doubts grow over how Argentina will be able to satisfy even modest conditions imposed by International Monetary Fund on repayment of its nearly $7 billion in debt; country is stuck in five-year economic slump; lame-duck government of Pres Eduardo Duhalde has said most difficult policy changes required by IMF agreement will have to be deferred until after presidential election scheduled for Apr 27; even if country can honor terms of interim agreement, definitive, long-term accord that would reopen credit lines remains elusive (M)

headline: Israel Kills a Top Hamas Leader; Arafat Promotes Critic of Uprising
abstract: Israel kills Ibrahim al-Makadmah, top leader of Hamas, and his three bodyguards in Gaza City, just before Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat nominates critic of Palestinians' armed uprising to new post of prime minister; Hamas vows to avenge killing, calling Makadmah a purely political leader; Israeli security officials call him central figure in planning, approval and executing of terrorist operations of Hamas; newly named Palestinian prime minister, Mahmoud Abbas, is deputy in Palestine Liberation Orgn; his appointment is step toward meeting demands for change from Palestinian reformers as well as Bush administration and Israel; at issue is how much power Arafat would cede to him; day's events reflect two fronts of conflict--new rush of violence on one hand and halting search for diplomatic avenues on other; Israel takes rare step of permitting some Palestinian leaders to cross army checkpoints to reach Ramallah for Arafat's annoucement of Abbas's appointment; photos; map (M)

headline: When Military Contractors Offer Aid to Countries
abstract: John R Liebman letter on Feb 16 article holds there is nothing secret about offsets: aid contractors give foreign countries in exchange for their purchases of military equipment

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: W. W.GRAINGER INC., Lake Forest, Ill., a supplier of building maintenance products, said it agreed to acquire a direct marketing unit from the closely held Gempler's, Belleville, Wis., a supplier of agriculture and maintenance products. Terms were not disclosed.    DICE INC., New York, an Internet job-search service whose shares sold for more than $54 in March 1999, filed for bankruptcy protection after losing money for 17 consecutive quarters.

headline: China's Sparkle Bedazzles a Visiting Castro
abstract: Pres Fidel Castro of Cuba makes his first state visit in almost decade to China; reunion is warm but bit awkward; unlike Cuba, which has stayed the course as Communist state, China is brimming with entrepreneurs and foreign multinationals and has recently joined World Trade Orgn; Cuba's planned economy was devastated by loss of economic support from former Soviet Union; Castro signs new agreement with Pres Jiang Zemin regarding economic cooperation and aid package; photo (M)

headline: Airstrikes Continue as Allies Consider Timing of a Thrust
abstract: The timing of any assault on Baghdad is under intense review, with generals debating the merits of speed against those of patience.

headline: MEDSOURCE STOCK PLUNGES AFTER IT LOWERS FORECAST
abstract: Shares of medical instruments maker MedSource Technologies Inc lose nearly half their value after company cuts its 2003 profit forecast (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BELDEN, St. Louis, a maker of telecommunications wire and fiber optic cable, said it would close its plant in Kingston, Ontario, by September and eliminate about 200 jobs.    LOCKHEED MARTIN, Bethesda, Md., the military contractor, settled a $30 million fraud suit brought against it by Tactical Communications Group, Billerica, Md., a military technology company. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; When A.I.G.'s longtime chief mentions a successor, Wall Street talks, and keeps talking.
abstract: TALKING with investors in New York yesterday, Maurice R. Greenberg, the venerable leader of the American International Group, touched on the issue of succession. And Wall Street began to buzz.    Mr. Greenberg, who will be 78 years old in May and who has run the company for more than 35 years, did not bring up the subject. But in response to a question, he said: ''My successor is in the company. The board knows who it is, and the individual knows who it is.''

headline: With Stream of Intelligence, Powell Makes Case to U.N.
abstract: The secretary of state presented photographs and intercepts of conversations aimed at proving that Saddam Hussein poses an imminent danger to the world.

headline: Fiat Said to Seek Sale of Some Units to Aid Car Division
abstract: Fiat reportedly plans to sell its insurance and aerospace components businesses in order to raise cash to shore up its money-losing car unit; analysts put likely proceeds of sales at more than 3 billion euros ($3.2 billion) (M)

headline: NORTHWEST ASKS PILOTS FOR 20% PAY CUTS
abstract: The Northwest Airlines Corporation has asked pilots for a 20 percent pay cut and permanent changes in benefits and work rules, the pilots' union said yesterday. The union, the Air Line Pilots Association, told its 5,700 active and 633 laid-off members that it would not respond to the company proposal until after it analyzes the airline's finances. Northwest asked pilots earlier this year to begin talks on labor-cost reductions because revenue had not recovered from a decline that began in 2001. The airline has said it is trying to cut annual expenses as much as $1.5 billion to avoid filing for bankruptcy protection.

headline: Mister Rogers Goes to Russia
abstract: Mr. Rogers and Soviet state broadcasting officials concluded last-minute negotiations that will bring Mr. Rogers to Soviet television.

headline: For Razor-Sharp Reception, Twirl an Old-Fashioned Knob
abstract: Boston Acoustics is touting its new AM-FM Recepter Radio, which incorporates tuner that allows listener to tune out low-level frequencies that can interfere with and distort desired signal; photo (M)

headline: Arab Bloc Calls Meeting in Cairo
abstract: Arab League announces meeting of leaders of member nations on Mar 1 in Cairo in effort to forge united position on Pres Bush's threats to attack Iraq; plan for Mar 1 meeting is compromise between Pres Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, who sought emergency session sooner, and leaders of other Arab states--including Lebanon, Syria and Saudi Arabia--that opposed holding such a session (S)

headline: World Briefing: Middle East
abstract: IRAN: Ban On Torture Rejected; EGYPT: Muslim Brotherhood Loses A Seat;.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Machinery Orders Dip
abstract: Orders for new machinery in Japan, crucial indictor of corporate capital spending, fell 0.2 percent in November from October, suggesting that companies are scaling back investment plans (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | South Africa: South Africa: Trade Surplus
abstract: South Africa posts its biggest trade surplus in 18 months in December, reversing deficit in November; surplus is put at 6.1 billion rand ($707 million) (S)

headline: Defectors Want to Pry Open North Korea
abstract: Three recent defectors from North Korea living in South Korea draw on their experience to give their own proposals for how to deal with unpredictable government of their impoverished homeland; proposals include closing China's five border bridges and imposing economic quarantine; also recommend undermining North Korean leaders by smuggling in radios tuned to South Korean stations and bombing North; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: Bribery Charges
abstract: Three members of Chile's Congress, stripped of parliamentary immunity in Jan in connection with widening corruption scandal that has shaken Pres Ricardo Lagos's government, are arrested on charges of demanding bribes in return for awarding government contracts (S)a

headline: U.S. Troops Meet Iraqis Peacefully
abstract: Marines help young Iraqi farmer Khalid Juwad start his irrigation pump in one of first peaceful encounters between American combat troops and civilians; Juwad and his family live in village called Hamza; he expounds on his view of Iraqi nation, complaining of suffering caused by Saddam Hussein; says he would like Americans to 'get rid of' Hussein but is concerned that they will not complete mission, as in 1991; believes his views are shared by majority of Iraqis living nearby; says resistance coalition forces have encountered comes from militias created by leaders in Baghdad; photos (M)

headline: CREDIT RATING ON SEARS DEBT IS DROPPED ONE LEVEL
abstract: Standard & Poor's lowers Sears Roebuck credit rating to BBB+ because of rising credit card delinquencies (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: 6 Retailers Plan Venture To Sell Music on the Web  Six music retailers plan to announce today that they are joining forces to sell music that can be downloaded from the Web. The effort is motivated in part by the two-year decline in compact disc sales that has forced recording companies to cut costs and lay off employees and has damaged music retailers.    Like the recording companies, music retailers are searching for new sources of revenue. Vinyl albums and cassette tapes have nearly disappeared, leaving retailers with the CD as their main option for selling music. But a proliferation of swapping on the Internet has led to a decline in CD sales. [Page C2.]

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Iraqis In Hostage Case Face Court
abstract: German trial of six Iraqis, seeking political asylum, who invaded Iraqi Embassy in Berlin last August begins; defense claims actions were peaceful protest against Saddam Hussein's regime (S)

headline: Keeping Tabs: A Two-Way Street
abstract: Personal Locator by Wherify Wireless is satellite-based tracking device initially developed to keep track of children; such systems, which are based on global positioning system technology, are not new, but design advances allow components to be small enough to fit into hand-held units or built into jewelry or backpacks; industry veterans see strong demand for tracking technology, from pure navigation systems to finding or keeping tabs on almost anything that is lost; concerns about ability to invade privacy noted; several different systems discussed; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Telecom Loss Declines
abstract: World Business Briefing: Indi

headline: U.S. Finds Different Villain in Search for Ailment's Cause
abstract: Federal health officials say mysterious respiratory illness that has sickened hundreds of people around world might be caused by different virus than first suspected; Centers for Disease Control and Prevention finds strong evidence that previously unrecognized virus from coronavirus family, same virus that causes common cold, is leading hypothesis for cause of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS); Dr Klaus Stohr, virologist who heads investigation of SARS for World Health Orgn, says cause could be paramyxoviridae virus, which WHO suspects, acting alone, or coronavirus alone, or co-infection of both (M)

headline: A Reminder Of a Mission
abstract: Analysis: Pres Bush, in televised news conference, reminds nation that Sept 11 attack that invested his presidency with mission to fight terrorism has brought his administration to brink of war with Iraq and also to brink of estrangement with longstanding allies and, perhaps, with United Nations; indicates that he recognizes how important it is to make every effort to gather more international support; signals that he is consulting closely with allies; there is hint of compromise in his words and in reports earlier in day from diplomats in Washington and at UN they they are talking with Bush aides about giving weapons inspectors few more weeks to test whether peaceful path to disarmament is possible in Iraq; Bush's remarks are mostly aimed at domestic audience; Robert S Strauss, Democratic strategist and fellow Texan, says Bush's frequent references to Sept 11 attacks are aimed at shoring up flagging support for war option in United States (M)

headline: Europeans in America : Freedom fries and raw nerves
abstract: From the haggling within the Western alliance over what to do about Saddam Hussein has emerged a symbol of American irritation: the freedom fry. If behind every joke lies a raw nerve, the freedom-fry protest reflects a ripple of animosity toward the French — and, by extension, other West European governments that have split with U.S. policy on Iraq. Europeans who live in the United States have an obvious, personal stake in how the backlash plays out. Among them are Patrice Higonnet and Peter Gottwald. Higonnet, 65, a professor of French history at Harvard, has dual French and American citizenship. Gottwalomat, is a fellow this year at Harvard's Weatherhead Center for International Affairs. They spoke with Joseph Rosenbloom in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

headline: Equity Offerings Planned
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:      Forest Oil Corporation, Denver, nine million shares. Credit Suisse First Boston and J. P. Morgan.

headline: Kraft Announces Pension Costs
abstract: Kraft Foods Inc will have 5 cents per share in noncash expenses next year because it spread out low returns from pension program (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Aging Chimps Face Deportation
abstract: Berlin Zoo plans to retire five chimpanzees, ages 14 to 24, because they are too sluggish to amuse the public; photo; planned deportation to Chinese zoo prompts outrage (S)

headline: Large Banks in South Korea Report a Big Jump in Profits
abstract: South Korea's Financial Supervisory Service says nation's 19 commercial banks posted 5.88 trillon won ($5 billion) in profit for 2002, 11.4 percent increase from year earlier; agency forecasts 28.3 percent climb in 2003, to 7.54 trillion won ($6.4 billion) (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: RUSSIA: More Cash For Car Venture; BRITAIN: Abbey Has First Annual Loss; POLAND: Delay On Jet Purchase; GERMANY: Growth Stagnates;.

headline: Sandy Tarlow, 59; Worked for Ralph Lauren
abstract: Sandy Carlson Tarlow, advertising executive who was responsible for defining public face of Polo Ralph Lauren for almost quarter century, dies at age 59 (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: QWEST COMMUNICATIONS INTERNATIONAL, Denver, a local telephone company, said it would acquire 49.9 percent of the TW Wireless joint venture from Touch America Holdings, Butte, Mont., for $46 million.

headline: Milan's new deal:Smells like team spirit
abstract: MILAN—  The iconic Roman couturier Robert Capucci, silver-haired, sitting ramrod straight in a formal suit, watched Friday as the first of a trio of stylists interpreted his name. After a parade of soft, slouchy clothes with references to Capucci's boxy sculptures in their folds, out came the Belgian designer Bernhard Willhelm in hooded sweat top. His capsule collection was applauded by the Spanish Sybilla (who is the designer next in line along with the American Tara Subkoff).

headline: Navy Maintains Solid Presence in South Korea
abstract: Commanders aboard the U.S.S. Carl Vinson, which is docked off the coast of Pusan, South Korea, say they're hoping to provide stability to the region.

headline: U.S. May Abandon U.N. Vote on Iraq, Powell Testifies
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell's comment appeared to be evidence that the White House may proceed to war without a second U.N. resolution.

headline: Powell Aide Quits Position Promoting U.S.
abstract: Charlotte Beers, the former advertising executive who has been in charge of the Bush administration's global campaign to enhance the image of the United States among Muslims, resigned today for what she said were health reasons.    Ms. Beers's resignation surprised both her supporters and those in the administration and Congress who found some of her ventures ineffective, including a widely publicized video last year featuring American Muslims speaking favorably about their life in the United States.

headline: PRE-PAID LEGAL ANNOUNCES CHANGES IN TOP RANKS
abstract: Pre-Paid Legal Services Inc's names chief executive Harland Stonecipher president, replacing Wilburn Smith, who resigned (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BOEING CO., Chicago, the aerospace company, said it had won a $132.5 million contract to supply a satellite to Binariang Satellite Systems, Malaysia's only pay-satellite company and a unit of Measat Global Networks Systems, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.    WILLIAMS COS., Tulsa, Okla., an owner of natural gas pipelines, agreed to sell a contract for buying and selling electricity for an Atlanta-area power cooperative to Progress Energy Inc., Raleigh, N.C., an energy company, for $188 million.

headline: Technology Briefing: Hardware
abstract: SHARES OF SONIC SOLUTIONS SOAR ON AOL PACT; NEW PRODUCTS NEEDED, EXECUTIVE SAYS;.

headline: Iraqis Abandon Post And Kurds Advance
abstract: Checkpoint on main highway into Kirkuk is unexpectedly abandoned by Iraqi soldiers, in first crack in Saddam Hussein's once formidable northern defense line; Iraqi soldiers have defended checkpoint since first gulf war in 1991, when Kurds set up independent enclave to north; soldiers slip quickly and quietly away just hours after more than 1,000 American paratroopers jump into friendly Kurdish territory in advance of opening of northern front; Iraqis' departure opens road from Kurdish-controlled zone into Kirkuk, city rich in oil and strained by ethnic tensions; it is one of war's ultimate political and economic prizes; Kurdish civilians and fighters stream in, beginning what appears to be advance on Kirkuk; for Kurds, day is both festive and ominous; by nightfall, there are worrisome signs that jubilation at Iraqis' retreat might give way to mob rule on front where significant numbers of American soldiers have yet to appear and civil order may be difficult to establish and maintain; photo (M)

headline: Resuming Ground Drive, Bombing Baghdad, and Courting Civilians
abstract: Low-flying warplanes attacked Baghdad today arrages of bombs and missiles as American troops fought units of Iraq's Republican Guard outside the capital in what an American officer described as the first "serious" encounter with the outer ring of Iraqi forces protecting the city.

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Citrix Names New Financial Officer
abstract: Cl

headline: Top General Warns of Heavy Strikes to Come
abstract: Gen. Richard B. Myers hinted that the American-led air campaign, which has so far put certain Iraqi government targets off-limits, could become more intense soon.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: UNILEVER PLC., London, a maker of branded consumer goods, said its Unilever Ventures unit had acquired a 40 percent stake in BrainJuicer.com Ltd., an automated market research business. Terms were not disclosed.    WILLIAMS COS., Tulsa, Okla., the U.S.'s second largest pipeline owner, won regulatory approval for the sale of the 972-mile South Texas Pipeline system to Enbridge Inc., Calgary, Canada, an energy transportation and distribution company, for $50 million.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Mitsubishi Electric Profit
abstract: Mitsubishi Electric Corp earned 1.1 billion yen ($9 million) in October-to-December quarter compared with profit of 38.4 billion yen loss year earlier (S)

headline: Handful of Indictments Over Technology
abstract: Natives of China have been accused of obtaining technology from Silicon Valley companies with intent of exporting it to China in three separate cases since October; EHI Group USA Inc/Araj Electronics president Qing Chang Jiang is accused of illegally exporting technology with military applications; is fourth Chinese native to be indicted in last four months; technology appears principally to have commercial, not military uses in two other cases; indictment comes little more than month after US attorney for Northern District of California indicted Fei Ye, US citizen, and Ming Zhong, permanent resident; two men were arrested at San Francisco airport and were in possession of trade secrets stolen from Sun Microsystems, Transmeta Corp, NEC Electronics and Trident Microsystems; US attorney in October indicted Shan Yan Ming, Chinese citizen, who is accused of having obtained unauthorized access to computers of 3DGeo Development Inc (M)

headline: Reversing Trend, Number of Dividend Increases Grows
abstract: Standard & Poor's Corp announces number of American companies announcing dividend increases rose 7.5 percent in 2002; gain provides first solid evidence that corporate America is willing to pay more in dividends to shareholders after bear market that was harder on companies that did not pay dividends than on those that did; 1,425 companies announced dividend increases in 2002, up from 1,326 in 2001; number of companies announcing dividend reductions or omissions declined 34.1 percent, to 135 from 205, after rising in previous year; graphs (M)

headline: Rumsfeld Says Iraq Is Collapsing, Lists 8 Objectives of War
abstract: Defense Sec Donald Rumsfeld says Iraqi government is starting to crumble; lays out eight broad objectives by which Bush administration will define victory; photo (M)

headline: A Spiffy Army of Volunteers Parades in Praise of Hussein
abstract: Thousands of Iraqi men and women who have just completed basic military training march through provincial capital of Baquba to show support for Saddam Hussein; map; parade follows bellicose Hussein speech denouncing UN arms inspectors as spies (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: JAPAN: Retailer Lowers Forecast; JAPAN: Aid For Debt-Laden Companies; MALAYSIA: Telecom Merger;.

headline: Waiting for the President to Pass the Tax-Cut Gravy
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Market Watch column discusses major tax reduction package expected from Pres Bush; sees lobbying efforts bringing substantial benefits to corporate interests; notes that corporate taxes already diminish yearly; cites Tax Notes editor Lee Sheppard's opinion that corporate tax rates will continue to shrink; graph of General Electric's declining effective tax rate (M)

headline: MSNBC Cancels the Phil Donahue Talk Show
abstract: MSNBC cancels Phil Donahue's nightly show, putting end to its high-profile effort to challenge CNN and Fox News Channel in area of prime-time politically oriented talk shows; plans to extend its program Countdown: Iraq with Lester Holt to two hours to fill time slot temporarily; Donahue was brought to MSNBC with much fanfare last July (M)

headline: Judge Delays Sentencing For Former ImClone Chief
abstract: Federal Judge William Pauley Jr postpones sentencing hearing for six crimes that Sameul D Waksal, founder and former chief executive of ImClone Systems, admitted committing in December 2001 when he orchestrated trades ahead of company announcement that sent share price of his company into steep fall; warns that he will order trial on remaining seven charges against Waksal unless prosecutors and defense attorneys work faster to produce documents needed for hearing; both sides are trying to reach settlement on remaining charges; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Tension Before Talks Resume
abstract: Sri Lanka government and Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam begin sixth round of peace talks in Japan; 20-year-old conflict between rebels fighting for autonomous Tamil state and government peaked again last week when Navy sank boat thought to be smuggling rebel weapons (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Opinion On Golden Shares
