abstract: Damaso Ruiz-Jarabo Colomer, advocate general of European Court of Justice, returns split recommendation in lawsuits against Britain and Spain regarding government control of privately held companies; says system used in Spain is acceptable but system used in Britain is not; Colomer's opinion will be considered when court makes final ruling later this year; complaints against so-called golden share provisions in Britain and Spain are made in lawsuit filed by European Commission; commission files new complaints against Italy, Netherlands and Denmark as part of its attempt to create level playing field for investors straddling borders of European Union's member countries (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CONSTELLATION ENERGY GROUP, Baltimore, owner of Baltimore Gas and Electric Co., agreed to buy an electric-supply business in Calgary from Dynegy Inc., Houston, an energy producer, to enter the Canadian market.

headline: Demand for Gold Falls
abstract: World Gold Council says world gold demand fell 3 percent in fourth quarter; demand dropped to 1,083.6 metric tons from 1,116.9 tons year earlier (S)

headline: Baghdad Empties of People, But It Fills With Foreboding
abstract: John F Burns report from Baghdad describes grim day in city shrouded in black clouds from oil trenches set ablaze by Saddam Hussein's forces, hit by huge sandstorm and fearful in knowledge that US military is almost at city gates; photo; Hussein, who has worked for 30 years to make himself unchallengeable in Iraq, now confronts physical force greater than his own, and even loyalists say privately that this time his long years of rule may be over; one middle-class family explains dread of how long fight will take, how long fanatical units will hold out and whether new freedoms will come at too high a price (M)

headline: UAL Says It Lost $1.47 Billion in Quarter
abstract: UAL Corp reports fourth-quarter loss of $1.47 billion, compared with loss of $308 million in quarter year earlier; reports loss of $3.2 billion for full year, compared with $2.1 billion in 2001 (M)

headline: REGIONAL MARKET: 14th Streeet; Building Gets Face-Lift As Area Turns Upscale
abstract: 70,000-square-foot two-story retail building at 25 West 14th Street, empty of tenants since 1990, has been given face lift in last two and half years by new owner Mark Holdings, in partnership with Apollo Real Estate Advisors LP, who hopes to capitalize on neighborhood's continued revival; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: ARGENTINA: Explanation Sought From Iranian; MEXICO: Slight Gain For Pri;.

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Soros Invests Another $1 Million In Bluefly
abstract: George Soros invests another $1 million in money-losing Internet retailer Bluefly Inc (S)

headline: Two Agencies Shut Their Doors
abstract: Ad agency Hampel/Stefanides in New York is shut down by parent Envoy Communications Group in Toronto after ten years in business; HDC in Fort Lauderdale closes (M)

headline: France, Backed by Germany, Calls for Stronger Inspections, but the U.S. Is Unmoved
abstract: France, backed by Germany, proposes to strengthen UN weapons inspections in Iraq to blunt US drive toward war, as Sec Colin Powell's vivid presentation of arms danger sharply increases pressure on Iraq to show radical change in attitude; photo; Sec Gen Kofi Annan appeals to Iraq to listen to chief weapons chiefs Hans Blix and Mohamed ElBaradei (M)

headline: The America's Cup Up Close, Without Binoculars
abstract: Virtual Spectator enhances viewers' experience of yacht racing by creating downloadable real-time, three-dimensional animated rendering that will be used for America's Cup; uses Global Positioning System technology and combines other data to create slick graphic representation of race overlaid with leader information; renderings are also used by television networks broadcasting event; photo (M)

headline: War Roils Arab League, and Highlights Divisions
abstract: Arab foreign ministers today called for an immediate end to the attack on Iraq but agreed on little else to placate the growing numbers of protesters in their streets.

headline: Constellation to Buy Australian Winemaker
abstract: Constellation Brands of the U.S. will buy Australian winemaker BRL Hardy and create the world's largest wine company.

headline: U.S. Says Hussein Threatens Scientists Who Assist U.N.
abstract: Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz accused Saddam Hussein today of hampering the efforts of U.N. inspectors.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: OPEC to Continue Policy Of Supplying Oil as Needed  The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries is expected to announce at its meeting in Vienna today that it will continue to supply as much oil as the markets need, essentially an affirmation of what it has been doing for months now, although with limited success.    Most of the 10 voting OPEC members are now pumping as much oil as they can, but prices have stayed high. In New York, crude oil for April delivery fell 51 cents, to $37.27 a barrel. Market Place. [Page C10.]

headline: U.S. Focuses on Iraqi Links To Group Allied to Al Qaeda
abstract: Bush administration is focusing on possible links between Saddam Hussein and Islamic extremists belonging to Ansar al-Islam who may have produced poison ricin in northern Iraq and a Qaeda terrorist leader who spent time in Baghdad last year; those suspected ties are at heart of administration's latest attempt to demonstrate Iraq-Qaeda connection as it tries to persuade American public and world that Hussein's government must be ousted; Secretary of State Colin L Powell is expected to present evidence of connection to United Nations Security Council on Feb 5 (M)

headline: Antismoking Group Prepares for Review
abstract: The American Legacy Foundation in Washington, which sponsors anti-smoking campaigns aimed at teenagers, yesterday identified the agencies that will take part in a required review for the creative part of its account.

headline: Laptop Sends Network Cruisers Into 802.11a Overdrive
abstract: Toshiba introduces Satellite Pro 6100 series of laptops that offers users high-speed wireless data transfer capability; photo (M)

headline: Phone Giant In South Africa Offers Shares
abstract: Telkom South Africa, national telephone monopoly, goes public with sale by government of quarter of its shares; stock trades at 28.20 South African rand, just 0.7 percent above offering price of 28 rand ($3.50) at close of session; sale raises 3.9 billion rand ($488 million) (M)

headline: Deflation Hurts Retailers
abstract: John Yozzo letter responds to Jan 12 'No Need to Wring Hands Over Retail Sales' article

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Bank'S Results Improve; BRITAIN: Publisher'S Profit Rises; THE NETHERLANDS: Phone Profit Rises;.

headline: One-Two Punch for Investors: AOL and Cable Unit
abstract: AOL Time Warner tells Wall Street to lower its expectations for growth because of problems with cable systems' advertising revenue; says other AOL Time Warner units plan to cut back their advertising on company's cable systems, and one-time advertising deals with new cable services are drying up; analysts say cable unit is still healthy and likely to resume solid growth in several years; others question AOL Time Warner's credibility with regard to its accounting practices; photo (M)

headline: Arab League Is Struggling For Consensus On Iraq Crisis
abstract: Arab leaders quarrel openly over how to respond to growing likelihood of American-led war in Iraq--even over whether they should meet in emergency session to debate how to respond; Pres Hosni Mubarak of Egypt sharply criticizes Arab leaders for failing to respond to his call for Arab League special summit; next regular Arab League summit meeting, scheduled for late Mar, may coincide with war (M)

headline: Retiring Premier Says China Must Pump Money Into Economy
abstract: Prime Min Zhu Rongji says China must continue to pump money into economy to keep it growing at 7 percent or better this year; defends his five-year tenure as he prepares to hand day-to-day control of China's government to new generation of leaders; address to delegates at National People's Congress is valedictory for Zhu, who herded nation through major economic and social changes, often charming foreigners and offending many Chinese officials; Vice Pres Hu Jintao, who replaced Jiang Zemin as Communist Party chief in fall, will succeed Jiang as state president; Zhu will retire in favor of his protege, Wen Jiabao; Li Peng, chairman of legislature, will be replaced by Wu Bangguo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: L-3 COMMUNICATIONS HOLDINGS INC., New York, maker of displays for the U-2 spy plane, said the U.S. government had renewed a contract for the company to repair and maintain combat equipment for Special Operations soldiers. The one-year contract includes options that could extend it to 10 years and up to $1.5 billion.    BANK OF NEW YORK, New York, said its subsidiary, BNY Brokerage Inc., had agreed to acquire certain assets and liabilities of Capital Resource Financial Services, Chicago, a unit of Capital Resource Holdings Inc., pending regulatory approvals. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Acquisition Helps Lift Stanley Works' Profit
abstract: Stanley Works reports fourth-quarter net income rose to $21.9 million from $6.5 million a year earlier; sales rose 3.1 percent (S)

headline: Adventures In Driving, Via Web Map
abstract: Passenger seats across America are strewn with evidence that verbal directions and folding maps are yesterday's tools; increasingly, drivers turn to MapQuest, most popular computer mapping service, and other similar services, for free driving directions and trip planners; occasional problems arise when software fails to choose best route between Point A and Point B as delineated by user, sometimes sending driver on longer journey than necessary; shortcuts are generally not given and drivers will do better using mapping services for trips over major thoroughfares, rather than small underused roads; listing of services noted; photos; drawing (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: FRANCE: Antiracism Campaign In Schools; CYPRUS: U.N. Extends Deadline On Peace Deal; THE HAGUE: American To Lead Tribunal; GERMANY: Dogs Bite Cars;.

headline: Iraqis in Exile Doubt Hussein's Speech Could Inspire Jihad
abstract: Iraqi exiles in Syria express doubt that Muslims will take up Saddam Hussein's call for jihad in response to American-led invasion of Iraq; there is widespread perception in Middle East that United States attack is modern crusade against Islam, but idea that Hussein could inspire religious zealots is considered farfetched (M)

headline: 7 Detained in British Anti-Terror Raids
abstract: Officials linked the operation arrests in Britain of North Africans charged with plotting attacks with the toxin ricin.

headline: Private Sector; Gifts Flow, but a Bit More Slowly
abstract: Chronicle of Philanthropy editor Stacy Palmer reports largest philanthropic gifts were smaller in 2002 than in recent years (S)

headline: WPP's Rating Cut But Outlook Rises
abstract: Fitch Ratings downgrades debt ratings for WPP Group but upgrades its rating outlook (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Lukoil's Net Rises
abstract: Lukoil, Russia's biggest oil producer, reports 7.2 percent rise in net income in third quarter of 2002, to $507 million (S)

headline: Pentagon and Companies In Agreement on Spectrum
abstract: Technology companies and Pentagon reach agreement to unlock swath of spectrum for next generation of wireless devices; companies say this would lift popularity of high-speed wireless Internet service, a bright spot in otherwise moribund industry; for military, agreement wards off emerging threat to their radar systems by setting detailed technical mechanisms to deal with interference (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BANK OF AMERICA,  Charlotte, N.C., said it had acquired Framework Inc., Tarrytown, N.Y., and will use its technology to speed the processing of home mortgages.    NEWELL RUBBERMAID,  Freeport, Ill., the housewares maker, said it would move its headquarters to Atlanta from Freeport, Ill.

headline: GEORGE LUCAS MOVES TO CONSOLIDATE HIS BUSINESSES
abstract: The filmmaker George Lucas is combining his movie production company, Lucasfilm, and related businesses. Lucasfilm's president, Gordon Radley, 56, said he was resigning to focus on other pursuits. Lucasfilm named the chief financial officer, Micheline Chau, 50, as chief operating officer. The other businesses are Lucas Digital, LucasArts Entertainment and Lucas Licensing. Mr. Lucas will remain chief executive and chairman of the closely held company, based in San Rafael, Calif.

headline: How Important Is Copy Protection?
abstract: In today's "State of the Art" column, I rounded up the online pop-music download sites: PressPlay, MusicNow, Rhapsody, RealOne and MusicNet on AOL.

headline: Top Music Executive Is Leaving Sony; After Tumultuous Year, He Plans to Start His Own Label
abstract: Thomas D Mottola, longtime chief executive of Sony Music Entertainment, says he is leaving to start his own record label; announcement comes after tumultuous year for Mottola, whose relationship with top Sony executives has been strained in recent months, particularly in light of huge financial losses in music division and shrinking market share; music division has lost more than $132 million so far in its latest fiscal year, largely because of higher artist costs; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: White House Tries to Show Benefits of Bush's Tax Plan  The White House rolled out details of President Bush's tax plan to show that it would help ordinary families and jobless workers. Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman, said the plan would provide 92 million taxpayers an average tax cut of $1,083 this year. In addition, he said 35 million investors would benefit from a plan to eliminate taxes on stock dividends.     Democratic lawmakers accused Mr. Bush of proposing tax cuts that favor the wealthy, and they offered a much smaller rival plan that focused on rebates for middle-income families, more help for jobless workers and tax breaks for small business. [Page A1.]

headline: U.S. to Send Nearly 2,000 Troops to Fight Militants in Philippines
abstract: The troops are expected to go to the southern part of Philippines in the next few weeks to fight Muslim extremists.

headline: Harry Potter, AWOL, Returns in June for No. 5
abstract: J K Rowling's book Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix, fifth in series, will be released in US and three other countries on June 21; book had originally been scheduled to appear last summer; announcement sends shares of book publishers Scholastic Corp and Bloomsbury Publishing up modestly; new book is expected to generate about $115 million in revenue for Scholastic in company's next fiscal year, which begins June 1; photo (M)

headline: Rights Group Calls for End To Inheriting African Wives
abstract: Human Rights Watch issues report condemning traditional African practice of wife inheritance, in which widow is transferred to male relative of deceased husband who typically takes control of property with or without her consent; custom extends across sub-Saharan Africa; its practice in Kenya discussed; traditional elders say it ensures that extended family will take care of widows, but critics maintain it strips women of their property rights and exposes them to sexually transmitted diseases such as AIDS (M)

headline: Iraqis Learn The Lessons Of How U.S. Fights Wars
abstract: R W Apple news analysis: Saddam Hussein has found ways around technologically superior adversary by waging war of harassment and delay and using advantage of war being on his home ground; tactic will likely not change outcome, but will prolong fighting, making it more costly financially as well as compromising US's already-tattered reputation in Arab world; unnamed Pentagon sources admit they underestimated capacity of paramilitary forces; knowing that regular forces will be overwhelmed, Saddam is fielding guerrilla defense led by about 60,000 fedayeen irregulars and other paramilitary forces; streets and alleys of Iraq's cities afford urban guerrillas opportunities to blend into crowds to operate, working against American desire to be seen as agents of liberation, not agents of conquest; fedayeen fighters change in and out of uniform, confounding Marines who are frustrated with enemy that employs vastly different rules of war (L)

headline: Kurds Plead for Protection Against Gas and Fault U.S.
abstract: Kurdish officials in Bardarash, Iraq, say United States has failed to respond to repeated requests for gas masks and chemical weapons suits for people of Kurdish-controlled northern Iraq; they view Iraqi soldiers on hilltop mile away with uneasiness; photo; map (M)

headline: U.S. COMBAT FORCE OF 1,700 IS HEADED TO THE PHILIPPINES
abstract: United States will send more than 1,700 troops to Philippines in next few weeks to fight Muslim extremists in southern part of country, opening new front in campaign against terrorism; Pentagon says first troops will be deployed within days; says US forces will not be limited to advisory role as they were in six-month mission last year, during which troops could fire only in self-defense; says operation will last as long as necessary to 'disrupt and destroy' estimated 250 members of extremist group Abu Sayyaf; officials say negotiations between two countries have been under way for months; say Abu Sayyaf's repeated attacks and bombing death of American Green Beret last Oct spurred Phillipine Pres Glora Macapagal Arroyo and Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld to agree on this plan, and that Pres Bush signed off on operation after being briefed by Rumsfeld; Pentagon official says reason for telling news media in advance is that mission is being mischaracterized by Pres Arroyo's spokesman Ignacio Bunye, who described it as 'exercise' resembling mission last year; photo; chart listing major events in American-Philippine relations from 1898 to present (L)

headline: Neither Side Yielding in Debate Over War With Iraq
abstract: The German leader and the U.S. secretary of state dug in their heels today with more uncompromising statements on Iraq policy.

headline: At Least 261 Die in Earthquake in Remote Western China
abstract: Severe earthquake in remote area along China's far western border kills at least 261 people and destroys thousands of homes and other buildings; epicenter is about 25 miles east of city of Jiashi, not far from old Silk Road city of Kashgar; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | France: Vivendi In Financing Deal
abstract: Vivendi Universal obtains three-year 2.5 billion euro ($2.66 billion) credit line from eight banks and plans to sell 1 billion euros of seven-year bonds to repay loans (S)

headline: Disney Breaks Ground for Hong Kong Park
abstract: Walt Disney Co breaks ground in Hong Kong for what executives say will be company's most culturally sensitive theme park; Hong Kong government owns 57 percent of venture; photo (M)

headline: An Iceberg of Irate Investors
abstract: Many investors who suffered big losses after stock market bubble burst are making claims against their brokers amid growing signs that arbitrators judging these cases are showing more sympathy to inexperienced investors than firms expected; trend, if it continues, is another sign that Wall Street still faces bills for 1990's market mania and may be held responsible for recommending risky high-tech stocks and funds; Francis Edward Wolfe's successful suit against Merrill Lynch cited; graphs of arbitration cases; photos (M)

headline: CNN Chairman Isaacson Resigns
abstract: Walter Isaacson, chairman and C.E.O. of CNN, resigned today, becoming the second key executive to leave AOL Time Warner in as many days.

headline: China Feeling a Need to Build an Oil Reserve
abstract: China remains world's largest economy without strategic petroleum reserve of its own; China's booming economy depends increasingly oil--more than one-third of its supply comes from abroad, mostly from Persian Gulf--and lack of reserve is national concern; China nearly doubled its oil imports in January, contributing to country's first monthly trade deficit since 1996; China has also been buying stakes in large oil fields outside Middle East, most recently in huge project in Kazakhstan, in hope of diversifying its sources of supply, but it will be years before many of those investments bear fruit; China has gone from being net oil exporter in 1993 to being fastest-growing importer; photo (M)

headline: Washington Post In Dow Jones Deal
abstract: Wall Street Journal's editions in Europe and Asia will shortly begin daily publication of small selection of news and opinion articles from Washington Post; announcement by Washington Post Co and Journal's parent Dow Jones & Co comes two weeks after Post's loss of its prime international platform, 50 percent stake in International Herald Tribune, which was bought out by its partner New York Times Co; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: GERMANY: Bank Chairman Resigns; IRELAND: Technology Loss Narrows; BRITAIN: Rate Increase Was Considered; BELGIUM: Brewer'S Profit Falls; GERMANY: Bmw Profit Rises;.

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: INDIA: Death Toll From Cold Rises; AFGHANISTAN: Judge Shuts Tv Channels;.

headline: Men's Shopping Magazine Is Under Study
abstract: Conde Nast Publications president-chief executive Steven T Florio says Conde Nast chairman S I Newhouse has approved men's version of Lucky, shopping magazine for women; says timing of first issue--and its name--is yet to be determined and no editor has been selected (M)

headline: Russian Veterans Push to Restore Name of City They Fought For
abstract: Veterans of the Battle of Stalingrad are pressing for the restoration of the name that came to symbolize the Soviet Union's stunning reversal of fortune.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: China Unicom Replaces Executive Director
abstract: China Unicom Ltd replaces executive director Tan Xinghui with Ye Fengping; Tan, also vice president, resigns (S)

headline: 3 in Hong Kong Agree to Face Charges in U.S.
abstract: Three men sought by FBI for allegedly plotting to trade drugs for antiaircraft missiles agree to their extradition to United States from Hong Kong; men reportedly told FBI undercover agents in Hong Kong that they hoped to resell Stinger missiles to Al Qaeda; men, two Pakistanis and an American, do not say why they have dropped their opposition to extradition, but officials in Hong Kong have stessed they would have no tolerance for terrorism; men are Ilyas Ali, Syed Saadat Ali Faraz and Muhammad Abid Afridi (M)

headline: Bush Proposes Big Increase In S.E.C. Budget
abstract: Bush administration proposes big increase for Securities and Exchange Commission budget; says it will seek budget of $842 million for year beginning Oct 1, or 92 percent above Congressional appropriation; SEC officials say increase will enable commission to add at least 710 new jobs to staff of 3,100 (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Truck Maker Posts Profit
abstract: Volvo AB returns to profit in fourth quarter after closing factory in United States and eliminating 7,000 jobs last year; net income put at 638 million kronor ($75 million); graph (S)

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: CONGO: Death Sentences In Slaying Of President; NIGERIA: A Leg For A Leg;.

headline: Stock Prices End the Day Mixed
abstract: Traders seemed to shrug off the investor-friendly elements included in President Bush's economic plan.

headline: Japan men decry lack of home-grown heros
abstract: TOKYO—  When Japanese men such as Ryuji Shinozaki go shopping, they aren't likely to see their peers among the pantheon of foreign models on billboards. On Japan's leading fashion boulevard, Omotesando, Japanese male role models are almost nonexistent. A recent survey of images from L'Oreal to Benetton to the Gap counted 17 white males, 16 white women, one black woman, one David Beckham, nine Japanese women, but not a single Japanese male face.

headline: Thousands of Kurds Flee Front-Line Cities Fearing Attack by Hussein
abstract: Kurdish civilians begin fleeing cities or safeguarding homes along front lines with Iraqi Army in northern Iraq, saying they fear conventional or chemical attack from Saddam Hussein as war draws near; they crowd into buses and taxis, or simply pile into cars, forming lines on highways, seeking what they hope would be safety in villages out of range of Iraqi artillery; exodus is apparent in cities of Kifri, Kalar, Dohuk and Chamchamal; in Erbil, largest city in northern Iraq, thousands flee; withdrawal is marked by anxiety but not panic; photos; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: GERMANY: Car Parts Maker Expands; BRITAIN: Engineering Executive Resigns; GERMANY: Sport Supplier Meets Goal;.

headline: Military Says It Can't Make Enough Vaccines for Troops
abstract: Col Erik A Henchal says Pentagon does not have vaccines to protect troops from some virulent biological agents because it has not been able to offer enough money to commercial pharmaceutical companies to produce them; says Army laboratory he commands at Fort Detrick, Md, has developed 20 vaccines for various deadly agents, but demand for such vaccines is not sufficient to prod commercial drug companies to produce them on large scale for civilian use; says new financing methods or perhaps production facility dedicated to military use might be needed; says anthrax and smallpox pose most serious biological threats to American troops, but terrorists may pursue other agents (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Monetary Policy Unchanged
abstract: Bank of Japan leaves its monetary policy unchanged; says it will continue leaving as much as 20 trillion yen ($166 billion) in surplus cash available, but that it might exceed that limit around end of fiscal year on March 31 (S)d

headline: U.N.'s Chief Inspectors Will Press Iraq For Hard Data That Could Avert War
abstract: UN weapons inspectors Hans Blix and Mohamed ElBaradei are encouraged after meeting with Iraqi officials about what Iraq must produce to prove there are no weapons of mass destruction; see hope for avoiding war, but only if Iraq makes serious move toward compliance with UN resolutions; call meeting with Gen Amir al-Saadi, Pres Hussein's top science adviser, useful; rallies both in support of peace and to demonstrate readiness for war are held in Baghdad; photos (M)

headline: A Technology Company Is Solid, Profitable and Risky
abstract: Market Watch column on QLogic, which makes switches and controllers that manage data flow bewteen computers and storage systems, and has remained profitable over last two years; graph (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Goldman Sachs Buys Bad Loans
abstract: Goldman Sachs completes purchase of nonperforming loans from Huarong Asset Management, one of four companies set up to dispose of $170 billion in bad loans at state-owned Chinese banks (S)

headline: Fighting Solo If Necessary
abstract: Military analysis; US will be prepared to attack Iraq with force of 150,000 by middle-to-late February, even if there is substantial allied resistance to invasion; allied criticism could make it more difficult to secure NATO support and complicate Washington's efforts to secure access to some bases in region; may also make it harder for US to share military burden and economic costs for occupying and rebuilding Iraq in event Pres Saddam Hussein is ousted; map; photos; diagrams (L)

headline: Military Now Often Enlists Commercial Technology
abstract: Many of information technologies that US forces would use if they attack Iraq have been developed in commercial sector, not by military itself, as in past; difficulty and cost of military development caused government research in communications technology to cease 20 years ago; civilian-developed systems have not yet been tested in battle; military lags behind large companies as users of Itronix's laptop, rugged computer that can withstand heavy rains and extreme temperatures; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: A Plea Of Not Guilty
abstract: Joyti De-Laurey, former secretary to American investment banker E Scott Mead at London office of Goldman Sachs, pleads not guilty to 21 counts of embezzling $7 million from Mead and two other bankers; not guilty plea appears to infuriate judge, who says De-Laurey's lawyers indicated to him earlier that she would plead guilty; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: KENYA: New Government To Tackle Prisons; CAMEROON: Urine Drinkers Are Warned;.

headline: New Leader In Korea Emphasizes Foreign Ties
abstract: South Korea's Pres-elect Roh Moo Hyun hails 'pivotal' role of foreign investment in building economy of Northeast Asia in speech intended to ease fears abroad about anti-Americanism in South Korea, which is Asia's third-largest economy; says importance of American and European Union investment in Korea cannot be emphasized too much, at it occupies 60 percent of all foreign investment in South Korea; notes foreign companies produce 10 percent of South Korea's gross national product and that foreign investors own 36 percent of shares traded on Korean stock market; graph; photo (M)

headline: Goldman Sachs to Acquire Additional Assets in Japan
abstract: Goldman Sachs Group will pay 45.4 billion yen ($384 million) for four hotels from Japanese retailer Daiei; also will buy 150.3 billion yen ($1.3 billion) worth of Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group's preferred stock; Sumitomo, in return, will guarantee up to $1 billion of Goldman's investment-grade credits; Goldman will also help Sumitomo Mitsui dispose of some of its bad loans; photos (M)

headline: DataBank; For a 2nd Week, the Market Pushes Higher
abstract: Perhaps investors have become as tired of falling markets as of the winter snows and are ready to bask in even slender rays of hope. They saw a few on Friday, and for the second consecutive week, all three major market averages pushed ahead, after declining the previous four weeks.     Iraq's vice president, Taha Yassin Ramadan, said on Iraqi television on Friday that his country was ''ready for dialogue with the American administration to build economic ties and cooperation'' if it dropped its plans to invade. That eased fears of war.

headline: Palestinian Gunmen Attacked Israeli Army Post
abstract: Two Palestinian gunmen killed an Israeli officer and a soldier in Nablus today before being shot dead.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Wind Power Increases
abstract: Wind power in Europe increases by 33 percent in 2002 to reach total capacity of 23,000 megawatts (S)

headline: Baghdad Bombed; Desert Skirmishes Stretch 350 Miles
abstract: The U.S. unleashed a thunderous bombardment of Baghdad as allied armies fought skirmishes against tenacious Iraqi resistance.

headline: At Least 16 Killed in Afghan Bus Explosion
abstract: At least 16 people, including women and children, were killed when their bus exploded on a bridge just outside the southern city of Kandahar.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: BMW Profit Rises
abstract: BMW reports record results for 2002 but says it expects earnings in 2003 to be flat; sold 1.06 million cars worldwide in 2002; profit rose 8.3 percent, to 2.02 billion euros ($2.14 billion) from year earlier, while revenue grew 9.9 percent, to 42.3 billion euros ($44.7 billion) (S)0

headline: Wall St. Down a 3rd Year, Leaving Fewer Optimists
abstract: US stocks plunge in 2002 amid fears of war and terrorism, weak economy, rising oil prices and dozens of corporate scandals; it is third consecutive annual decline, first time that has happened in 60 years; making matters worse, average stock fell further in 2002 than it had in either of previous two years; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index posts its worst year since 1974; Wall Street's mood is bleak; Wilshire 5000 drops 22.1 percent, S&P 500 index drops 23.4 percent, Dow Jones industrial average finishes down 16.8 percent, and Nasdaq composite index falls by 31.5 percent; graphs; photo (M)

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: Regional Market -- Connecticut; Tribe Invests Downtown In an Old Industrial City
abstract: Office building is rising for first time in decades in downtown of old industrial city of Norwich, Conn; Mashantucket Pequots are one of primary backers of $19 million Mercantile Exchange building; tribe has signed 20-year lease for building at $1.4 million per year; intends to move some of its offices to occupy about 30,000 square feet of building when it opens in November; map; photo (M)

headline: The Internet Widens The Butcher's Reach
abstract: Internet sites for buying restaurant-quality meats from meat distributors and well-known steakhouses noted (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Airline Loss Expected
abstract: Air Canada expects to report operating losses in fourth quarter and for 2002 as whole; Air Canada's domestic flights were average 67.4 percent full in December, down from 74.5 percent year earlier (S)

headline: Kurds and G.I.'s Rout Militants in North
abstract: Combined American and Kurdish military assault sweeps through remote mountain valley in northeastern Iraq, capturing series of villages from militant Islamic group and restoring swath of border territory to Kurdish control; photo (M)

headline: Hacker Laws For Europe Pose Problem For Protesters
abstract: Justice ministers of European Union agree on laws intended to deter computer hackers and spread of computer viruses, but legal experts say measures could pose problems since they could also outlaw people who organize protests online; agreement obliges all 15 member states to codify new criminal offense and calls on national courts to impose jail terms of at least two years in serious cases; critics from legal profession complain agreement makes no legal distinction between online protestor and terrorist, hacker and spreader of computer viruses that new laws are intended to trap (M)

headline: Who Will Put Iraq Back Together?
abstract: United States government contract officers plan in coming days to give American companies contracts to rebuild Iraq, task experts say could eventually cost $25 billion to $100 billion; Bush administration stresses American generosity and farsightedness; its decision to invite only American companies to bid has added to profound international divisions surrounding war; top priority is rebuilding of Umm Qasr, Iraq's only deep-water port; table of bidders; photos (M)

headline: South Korea, in Surprise, Demands U.S. Forces Stay in Place
abstract: The statement followed Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld suggestion of a realignment of American forces in Korea.

headline: Coping with terrorism : In Thailand, parents wonder just what to tell their children
abstract: BANGKOK:—  One August night in 2001, the nine-year-old son of Sharon Cox Bhasavanich asked his mother as she tucked him into bed in their Bangkok home if "planes flying in the sky could hurt us?"

headline: Wachovia Said to Be Near A Broker Deal
abstract: Wachovia Corp expects to announce acquisition of Prudential Financial's brokerage business; merger would create enormous firm with 13,600 brokers, rivaling Merrill Lynch; Prudential is expected to retain minority interest in business and keep its research operation (M)

headline: As the Hardships Mount, Venezuelans Consider Easing Strike
abstract: Leading members of coalition that called national strike aimed at forcing ouster of Pres Hugo Chavez of Venezuela say they are talking about easing hardship on Venezuelans, including partly lifting strike to allow businesses and factories to reopen; photos (M)

headline: Agrilink Foods to Close 6 Processing Plants
abstract: Agrilink Foods Inc, maker of Birds Eye vegetables, says it will close six frozen-vegetable processing plants and lay off about 260 employees to cut costs; also says it will change its name to Birds Eye on Feb 10 (S)

headline: Three Airlines Increase Fares To Help Cope With Fuel Prices
abstract: Three leading airlines--Continental Airways, American Airlines and US Airways--increase nearly all their fares by $10 each way; move, most significant attempt at fare increase since last summer, is effort to establish pricing power as fares have hit record lows; Continental says increase is necessary to help offset 'dramatically higher' fuel expenses (M)

headline: Shredders With a Taste For Plastic
abstract: responsible party: shredders with a taste for plastic**David Joachim, director of marketing at Royal Consumer Information Products, part of Olivetti Group of Italy, comments on company's development of shredder that shreds CD's as well as paper, which he oversaw; photos (M)

headline: Relatives of Sept. 11 Victims Face a Suspect in Germany
abstract: Relatives of some victims of Sept 11 terrorist attacks appear in court in Hamburg, Germany, to confront man charged with conspiring in those attacks; witnesses all express hope that their stories would be considered at sentencing by panel of five judges overseeing trial of Mounir Motassadeq, who is accused of aiding Hamburg cell of Al Qaeda involved in Sept 11 plot; photo (M)

headline: Mating a File Extension With a Media Player
abstract: Q. I have received some video clips, some of which I can open on my PC. What do the various format extensions mean, and how can I get my programs to open them? MPEG files seem to open with no problems, but I am stumped by AVI and WMV. And how does Apple QuickTime fit in? Is there a procedure for playing these mystery clips?    A. Video clips come in many different formats, and not all multimedia software installed on the computer can play every type of format. To play the various clips, you should look at the three-letter extension at the end of the file name, which can help you choose the right player software.

headline: Two Agencies Awarded Separate Accounts
abstract: Lowe & Partners Worldwide is awarded Electrolux Group advertising account; total spending is estimated at $70 million; Lowe also receives Carfax account; estimated billings $15 million to $20 million; Margeotes/Fertitta & Partners is awarded Food Network ad account; billings estimated at $5 million to $10 million; Independence Community Bank names Margeotes; billings estimated at $7 million (M)

headline: PRUDENTIAL FINANCIAL EXPANDS IN SOUTH KOREA
abstract: Prudential Financial agrees to pay about $400 million for fund management arms of Hyundai Group of South Korea; is buying Hyundai Investment and Securities Co and Hyundai Investment Management Trust (S)

headline: I.R.S. Offers Amnesty for Offshore Credit Card Accounts
abstract: Seeking to crack down on the use of credit cards linked to undeclared offshore accounts, the I.R.S. announced a one-time amnesty today.

headline: Monsanto Faces Federal Antitrust Inquiry
abstract: Monsanto Faces Federal Antitrust Inquiry*ª

headline: Agnelli's Brother to Steer Fiat and Holdings
abstract: Direction of embattled Fiat conglomerate takes abrupt turn with death of Giovanni (Gianni) Agnelli, patriarch of family that founded and controls it; family names Umberto Agnelli to replace him as president of holding company Giovanni Agnelli & Compagnie; photos; geneology table; graph of family's holdings (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Former Oil Chief Turns Himself In
abstract: Loik LeFloch-Prigent, former president of old French state-owned oil company Elf Aquitaine, surrenders to authorities after appeals court upholds his conviction and 30-month jail term for corruption; was in hiding when he was convicted on charges rising out of vast scandal at Elf, which was privatized in 1994 and now forms part of TotalFinaElf; court overturned conviction of ex-Min Roland Dumas; photo (M)

headline: White House Approves a Plan To Administer a Postwar Iraq
abstract: Senior US officials outline plan approved by Pres George Bush to create Iraqi Interim Authority immediately after Saddam Hussein is deposed; national security adviser Condoleezza Rice, in interview with Al Jazeera television, says Iraqis from all major tribal, ethnic and religious groups will be given authority over daily life in Iraq; one official says 'power ministries,' meaning military, intelligence and other institutions supporting Hussein, will be taken over by US military, dismantled and then reformed and rebuilt (M)

headline: Economic Scene; A study looks at squatters and land titles in Peru.
abstract: Alan B Krueger Economic Scene column on economic impact of giving property titles to urban squatters in Peru; study by Erica Field, PhD student in economics at Princeton University, shows that labor supply increased as result of land titling; finds two to three years after title reform came to neighborhood, families that were in untitled houses before reform worked 20 hours more per week, on average, than those from untitled houses in neighborhoods that had not yet had title reform; says results suggest that introducing title reform caused hours of work to rise by net 16 hours per week, or 17 percent, among those who initially lived in untitled residences; shows amount of labor supplied by children was 27 percent lower for families that were initially squatting in neighborhoods that introduced title reform early; says squatters without title devote extra time and effort to protecting their residences from intruders; from 1995 to 2001, more than 1.2 million households--6.3 million people--received title to properties they were inhabiting; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ACCPAC INTERNATIONAL, Pleasanton, Calif., a unit of Computer Associates International, Islandia, N.Y., acquired AGS Software, Toronto.    ELECTRONIC DATA SYSTEMS CORP., Plano, Tex., said it had won contracts worth a combined $10 million to help three shipyards in Germany to manage manufacturing.

headline: South Korean Leader Assailed on Funds Transfer to North
abstract: President Kim Dae Jung faced mounting pressure today to explain why nearly $200 million was moved to North Korea shortly before meeting with the North Korean leader in June 2000.

headline: North Korea Assailed for Withdrawing From Arms Treaty
abstract: North Korea's ambassador said that Pyongyang would consider any attempt to impose sanctions a "declaration of war."

headline: Untrained Afghan Police Force Needs to Be Overhauled, Amnesty International Says
abstract: Amnesty International releases report saying Afghanistan and international communities must make overhaul of country's police force an urgent priority to restore rule of law; point to depth of mistrust that has built up during 23 years of war toward unaccountable and unrepresentative police force (M)

headline: Whistle-Blower Changes Sides To Aid Hewlett, Once a Target
abstract: Court papers reveal that Phillip M Adams, former IBM engineer, sold Hewlett-Packard a software patch to remedy alleged flaw in floppy disk controllers of its computers and agreed to assist company in its defense against class-action lawsuits related to flaw; Adams was principal expert witness for plaintiffs' lawyers in class-action lawsuit related to same problem in computers made by Toshiba, which ended with $2.1 billion settlement in 1999; Adams's switching of sides prompts California state attorney general's office to accuse him and Hewlett-Packard of lack of candor and deception and is pursuing false-claims investigation against company; class-action lawyers in Texas feel jilted by Adams, and they are suing Hewlett-Packard; Adams, who received $27.5 million from Hewlett-Packard, contends he is acting in public interest by trying to fix problem that could have dire consequences (M)

headline: F.C.C. Expected to Extend Satellite Operators' Reach
abstract: Telecommunications industry experts expect Federal Communications Commission to announce decision allowing satellite voice and data companies to supplement their services with land-based wireless networks; conventional cellular companies bitterly oppose concept; FCC attempts to foster more flexible and efficient use of spectrum of radio waves; photos (M)

headline: 32 Friends On the Phone: Taking Turns Is Encouraged
abstract: Freeconference.com allows user to set up conference call for up to 32 callers; calls can be conversation so all can speak, or broadcast, in which only one caller speaks; users pay only long-distance charges for calling dial-in number; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Sotheby's Will Discontinue Auctions On Its Web Site
abstract: Sotheby's Holdings will stop holding online auctions on its Web site, which was built by and linked to eBay; alliance will end in May; Sotheby's lost about $100 million on Internet operations in about three years (S)

headline: Security Costs Add Burden To a City Short on Cash
abstract: Cost of extra security in New York City in last week as result of federal security alert is expected to run into many millions of dollars, including $1 million for police alone, at time of tight budgets for city and its emergency services, hospitals, utilities and transportation agencies (M)

headline: Foamex to Cut Jobs
abstract: Foamex International Inc reports loss of $16.4 million in its fourth quarter, down from loss of $29.4 million year earlier; sales rose 5.4 percent, to $327.3 million from $310.6 million; expects to eliminate 300 jobs, or 5.1 percent of its work force, by end of year (S)

headline: Ireland to Ban Smoking in Workplace (That Means Pubs, Too)
abstract: Ireland will ban smoking in all workplaces, including pubs and restaurants, starting in 2004; Health Min Michael Martin's announcement angers tobacco manufacturers and publicans alike, who call ban unenforceable and an infringement of personal liberties (M)

headline: CHIEF RESIGNS AT CENDANT DIVISION THAT INCLUDES AVIS
abstract: Cendant Corp says John Chidsey has resigned as chairman and chief executive of company's vehicle and financial services division; chief financial officer Kevin Sheehan will assume responsibility for vehicle unit; Samuel Katz, chairman and chief executive of travel services, will take over financial services (S)

headline: Plan Restricting Stock Options Stalls at S.E.C.
abstract: Proposal to give shareholders veto power over moves by companies to dole out stock options is stalled at Securities and Exchange Commission, and will not go into effect in time for annual shareholder meetings this year; plan had nearly universal support last summer, when tide of corporate scandal was at its height; Texas Instruments' directors approve sort of big stock option plan that proposal is intended to police; shareholder advocates--who object to investors' ownership being diluted when companies issue options in large volumes--worry that other companies will rush new option plans onto their books, in case rule goes into effect by end of year; rule, as proposed by New York Stock Exchange, would require companies whose shares are traded on exchange to put all new stock option plans to vote of their shareholders; rule would also stop brokerage firms from voting shares of customers who have not voted themselves; institutional shareholders, especially those managing public pension funds, applaud proposal, as do individual investors who filed comments with SEC; SEC spokeswoman says commission has been busy putting into effect rules mandated by new corporate oversight legislation passed by Congress last year; others blame Nasdaq officials for slowing down SEC approval process (M)

headline: Protesters Invade British Nuclear Plant
abstract: More than 30 Greenpeace protesters break into nuclear power station in eastern England in effort to demonstrate poor security at nuclear plants; members achieve break-in using less than $50 worth of ropes, ladders and climing hooks (S)

headline: The Fighting Is Close Up and Dirty, a Shell Blast, a Bandage at a Time
abstract: Stretch of road near Najaf, Iraq, has been scene of violent skirmishes for several days; members of 101st Airborne Division tend to several wounded Iraqis, as enemy mortar shells continue to fall; long lines of Iraqi men and women are questioned at checkpoint; men with past connection to military are pulled out for further interrogation; photo (M)

headline: Puzzle for Israel: What Does Sharon Want?
abstract: Analysis of long-running debate in Israel over what, precisely, Prime Min Ariel Sharon is after; his electoral victory puts him in posistion to do what his rightist Likud Party demands--preventing establishment of Palestinian state and expelling Yasir Arafat--but he is urgently appealing for seemingly crippled Labor Party to join new governing coalition; various theories discussed; photo (M)

headline: PERELMAN PLEDGES TO INCREASE FINANCING AT REVLON
abstract: Financier Ronald O Perelman agrees to provide as much as $215 million in financing for his cosmetics company Revlon; increases his financing from $150 million proposed in December (S)

headline: RIVERWOOD HOLDING TO BUY GRAPHIC PACKAGING, A RIVAL
abstract: RiveÈ

headline: Hopes Ebbing for Scottish Parliament
abstract: Grandiose, unfinished building in Edinburgh that will one day house Scotland's Parliament has become laughingstock, referred to by many as 'follywood'; projected cost has soared to $514 million, from $63 million four years ago, and target date for completion keeps moving forward; Scottish Parliament was created in burst of high expectations and nationalism, but public's giddiness has turned to impatience and frustration; most Scots have concluded that politics in Scotland is nothing more than politics as usual; legislatively, Scottish Parliament can make decisions on agriculture, education, health and housing, but has no say on military matters and social security; photo of unfinished Parliament building in Edinburgh (M)

headline: El Paso Settles California Energy Suits
abstract: El Paso agrees to pay more than $1.5 billion to settle California lawsuits accusing it of manipulating power prices during state's energy crisis; company will provide California with $900 million in natural gas over 20 years and pay $225 million now and $440 million over next 20 years (S)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Some Web merchants fill a void, and make a profit, by selling coffins and other funeral supplies online.
abstract: Online sales of coffins and other funeral supplies grow rapidly as consumers show increased interest in discount-priced, Web-based shopping and in its privacy; Funeral Depot sells coffins online in price range of $745 to $18,500; photo (M)

headline: RADIOSHACK'S PROFIT GAIN IS LESS THAN EXPECTED
abstract: RadioShack Corp says fourth-quarter profit rose less than expected; will report fourth-quarter sales on Jan 14 (S)4

headline: Nautica International Hires New Agency
abstract: Advertising: Nautica International H

headline: THREATS AND RESPONSES: OUT IN THE WORLD -- Kenya; Chilling Encounter With Man on Bus
abstract: Sister Mary Ellen Howard, 60, who has lived in Kenya for most of last 24 years and works with handicapped children in Nairobi slum, recounts conversation with angry Muslim man who changed seat when he learned she is American; interview; photo (S)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: HARDWARE JUNIPER NETWORKS POSTS PROFIT AS SALES RISE Juniper Networks, the No. 2 maker of equipment to direct Internet traffic, had a fourth-quarter profit of $8.45 million as expenses fell. Sales climbed 2.8 percent. Net income was 2 cents a diluted share, in contrast to a net loss of $5.13 million, or 2 cents a diluted share, in the year-earlier period, the company said yesterday. Revenue rose to $155.3 million from $151 million. First-quarter sales and profit, excluding certain items, will be unchanged from the preceding period, beating analysts' forecasts, the chief financial officer, Marcel Gani, said. Juniper, which trails Cisco Systems in sales of data-traffic routers, had losses in five of the six preceding quarters as customers slashed spending after overbuilding fiber optic networks. Shares of Juniper dropped 33 cents, to $8.90, in after-hours trading. Earlier, shares fell 46 cents, to $9.23, in regular trading.   (Bloomberg News) ADVANCED MICRO POSTS LOSS AFTER CHARGE Advanced Micro Devices, the No. 2 maker of microprocessors, posted a fourth-quarter net loss yesterday after a restructuring charge related to layoffs. The company reported a loss of $854.7 million, or $2.49 a diluted share, compared with a loss of $15.8 million, or 5 cents a diluted share, for the period a year earlier. Excluding one-time items like a $330.6 million restructuring charge, Advanced Micro would have recorded a fourth-quarter per-share loss of 68 cents. On that basis, analysts had on average forecast that Advanced Micro would post a loss of 42 cents a share, according to Thomson First Call. Advanced Micro shares fell 25 cents, to $7.20.   (Reuters) PC SALES INCREASE IN QUARTER Promotions and price cuts provided worldwide personal computer sales with an unexpected increase in the fourth quarter, according to figures released yesterday. Shipments increased 4.9 percent, to 38.8 million units, topping forecasts of 4.4 percent growth, according to I

headline: Streamlining Government, Putin Creates New Anti-Drug Force
abstract: Russia's Pres Vladimir V Putin streamlines government; abolishes border guards, tax police and clutch of other agencies and hands duties to cabinet-level departments; announces creation of new independent agency to combat illegal narcotics (M)

headline: When Military Contractors Offer Aid to Countries
abstract: Paul Sheridan letter on Feb 16 article on offsets offered by military contractors to foreign buyers deplores key role of machinery of war in United States economy

headline: Designers Lose a Free Oscar Plug
abstract: Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Science's decision to roll up red carpet at Academy Awards ceremony in wake of war in Iraq will cost fashion industry incalculable free publicity; academy president Frank Pierson says guests will be dropped off by limousines directly at entrance to Kodak Theater in Hollywood; will not stop for interviews or pause for photographs before they enter auditorium; ABC says Barbara Walters, who had planned hour-long pre-Oscars special of interviews with stars, will no longer do so; E Entertainment Television is still planning two-hour special with Joan and Melissa Rivers, traditionally positioned on red carpet to praise or leer at celebrities' outfits, but it is unclear what they will be able to critique; some stars have apparently chosen to make antiwar statement through jewelry; Global Vision for Peace, new group, says 10 Oscar-night guests agreed to wear dove-shaped gold and diamond pin it has commissioned; photo (M)

headline: GOODRICH TO CUT 500 JOBS AT UNIT IT BOUGHT LAST YEAR
abstract: Goodrich Corp will cut 500 jobs, or 8 percent of work force, in aircraft-control business it bought in October from TRW (S)

headline: Marketers Crank It Up For a New Generation
abstract: William J Holstein interviews author Alissa Quart concerning marketing of consumer goods to teenagers; photo (M)

headline: Panel Faults Bush on War Costs and Risks
abstract: The cost of postwar reconstruction of Iraq will be at least $20 billion a year and will require the long-term deployment of 75,000 to 200,000 troops to prevent widespread instability and violence against former members of Saddam Hussein's government, a panel of national security experts say in a new study.    The panel, consisting of senior American officials from Republican and Democratic administrations, was organized by the Council on Foreign Relations. It concludes that President Bush has failed ''to fully describe to Congress and the American people the magnitude of the resources that will be required to meet the post-conflict needs'' of Iraq.

headline: Full Text: In Wolfowitz's Words
abstract: Following is a full transcript from a speech yesterday by Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz to the Council for Foreign Relations in New York City, as transcribed by the Federal News Service.

headline: Bush Orders Start of War on Iraq; Missiles Said to Be Aimed at Hussein
abstract: President Bush ordered the beginning of a war on Iraq tonight, and his spokesman said that American forces had begun to disarm Iraq and would depose Saddam Hussein.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Network Appliance Profit Almost Triples
abstract: Network Appliance says third-quarter profit almost tripled, and sales rose faster than expenses; net income in quarter ended Jan 24 increased to $19.7 million from $6.98 million year earlier; sales rose 15 percent to $228.5 million from $198.3 million, outpacing 6.1 percent gain in total operating costs (S)

headline: THREATS AND RESPONSES: Briefly Noted; ARAB SUMMIT TO PROCEED
abstract: Arab League says it would proceed with meeting of Arab leaders in Sharm el-Sheik, Egypt, despite Iraq's request for two-week postponement to allow government to focus on United Nations weapons inspections; there is deep divisions among Arab leaders over crisis (S)

headline: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
abstract: NORTEL POSTS NARROWER 4TH-QUARTER LOSS; CABLE AND WIRELESS CREDIT RATING CUT TO JUNK; CORNING LOSS WIDENS TO $709 MILLION;.

headline: Democrats Try to Turn Debate Back to Home
abstract: Democrats in Washington seek to shift debate in Congress away from war with Iraq and toward domestic security; photo of Rep Nancy Pelosi and Sen Tom Daschle (M)

headline: DAIMLER SAYS CRUCIAL PAPERS WERE DESTROYED
abstract: DaimlerChrysler says assistant to billionaire Kirk Kerkorian destroyed documents company needs to defend itself against accusations that it deceived investors about 1998 merger of Daimler Benz and Chrysler; notes about premerger meetings between Kerkorian and Chrysler chief executive Robert J Eaton were destroyed in 2000, five days before lawsuit was filed; suit accuses Daimler Benz of lying to investors to gain support for its $35 billion acquisition of Chrysler; talks are basis of some fraud accusations; Tracinda Corp, controlled by Kerkorian, and other shareholdes sued DaimlerChrysler is November 2000, after chief executive Jurgen E Schrempp was quoted as saying that he had always intended to control Chrysler and operate it as unit (S)

headline: Endless Supply Convoy Is Frustrated Endlessly
abstract: Rapid advance of American forces through Iraq has left spearhead of army 300 miles away from its main base; as result, supply lines are stretched thin and are vulnerable to kinds of attacks that have left one convoy standing still for 3 days; Col John Pomfret, who is leading convoy, says firefights that have unfolded have been very close; Marines running convoys say they can fight their way through anything Iraqis can throw at them; with their supply lines reaching all the way back to Kuwait, experience of Pomfret's convoy suggests that Marines may be doing much more fighting than they bargained for; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Cult Surveillance Extended
abstract: A public security commission extended by three years its close surveillance of Aum Shinrikyo, the cult responsible for a nerve gas attack on the Tokyo subway in 1995, citing the risk that it may try to commit further massacres. The decision will allow security officials and the police to inspect cult sites and force it to report the names, addresses and other information of its followers every three months. ''It is determined that there is danger of the organization committing indiscriminate mass murder,'' said a secretary for the Public Security Examination Commission. The gas attack killed 12 people and sickened thousands.   Howard W. French (NYT)

headline: A Mission of Hope on a Mountain in Russia
abstract: Teams of rescue workers desperately searches for survivors of Karmadon Gorge avalanche in Russia's Caucasus Mountains; about 125 people vanished in avalanche, which occurred more than six months ago; volunteers continue their search, hoping for miracle; photos; maps (L)

headline: U.S. Won't Accept Refuge in Pakistan for Al Qaeda and Taliban
abstract: The U.S. will not accept that Al Qaeda and Taliban members can find refuge in Pakistan, the American special envoy to Afghanistan said today.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: New Market For Luxury Car
abstract: Toyota Motor Corp will start selling its luxury Lexus brand in Japan in 2005, part of company's efforts to strengthen its grip on domestic market; until now, Lexus cars have been sold only in United States (S)

headline: German Economy Stagnates, and Revival Seems Far Off
abstract: As Germans woke up to yet another dismal economic report today, a single question echoed: Can anything revive Germany?

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Guatemala: 6 Killed In Prison Riot
abstract: Obdulio Villanueva, soldier jailed in 1998 killing of human rights campaigner Bishop Juan Gerardi is one of six prisoners killed in Guatemalan prison riot possibly spurred by animosity toward officers implicated in slaying (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Growth Outlook Lowered
abstract: German government lowers its economic growth forecast for 2003 to 1 percent from 1.5 percent (S)

headline: Hong Kong's Leader Cuts His Pay in 'Hard Times'
abstract: Hong Kong's chief executive Tung Chee-hwa cuts his salary 10 percent, saying territory is facing worst economic situation in decades; says he is reducing his pay, and that of 16 of his ministers and close aids to help fight ballooning budget deficit; outlines plan to raise taxes, reduce government spending and build closer ties with China; photo (M)

headline: South Korea's New President Names His Economic Team
abstract: New South Korean Pres Roh Moo Hyun names economic team led by Kim Jin Pyo to try to stave off downturn (S)

headline: Trailer Factory to Close
abstract: Fleetwood Enterprises, leading maker of mobile homes, will close factory in Lumberton, NC, on March 3 because of falling sales; as many as 95 people will be laid off and 15 to 20 employees will be allowed to transfer to factory in Pembroke, NC (S)

headline: Penny-Stock Fraud, From Both Sides Now
abstract: Hartley T Bernstein, lawyer who pleaded guilty to securities fraud, conspiracy and perjury in May 1999, now works the other side of the fence, running Web site, StockPatrol.com, that alerts investors to fraud in penny stock market and helping federal investigators shut down frauds and build criminal cases against at least 34 people; was given probation at sentencing because of his contribution to federal case against Randolph Pace of Rooney Pace; his work on some of most notorious penny-stock manipulators of past two decades, including Stratton Oakmont, Biltmore Securities and Sterling Foster, has given him sharp eye for detecting flaws, fibs and fantasies in corporate documents; photos (L)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Election Day Warning
abstract: Iranian leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei criticizes 'irregularities' in choice of some candidates as voters go to polls to elect local councils (S)

headline: ENTERGY PROFIT RISES ON ENERGY-TRADING VENTURE'S GAINS
abstract: Entergy Corp, leading generator of nuclear power, says first-quarter profit will rise because of accounting change and gains from energy-trading venture with Koch Industries (S)

headline: Turkey Assesses Question Of Kurds
abstract: Analysis: Turkey's bitter history with Kurds is figuring prominently in its calculations over how to deal with Bush administration's request to use Turkey as base for thousands of combat troops if there is war with Iraq; Recep Tayyip Erdogan, leader of Turkey's governing party, says publicly for first time that future of Iraq's Kurdish area, which abuts border region of Turkey also heavily populated by Kurds, is weighing heavily on negotiations; hints at what Turkish officials have been saying privately for weeks: if war comes to Iraq, overriding Turkish objective would be less helping Americans topple Saddam Hussein, but rather preventing Kurds in Iraq from forming their own state; Turkish fear is that Kurdish autonomy in Iraq could revive similar dreams among 12 million Kurds living in Turkey; photo; chart with major events in Kurdish history, dating from 1843 to present (L)

headline: Weary Sailors Are Long Way And Long Time From Home
abstract: Weary sailors aboard USS Abraham Lincoln, one of nation's premier aircraft carriers at sea longer than any carrier since Persian Gulf war, struggle to maintain morale; carrier left home port of Everett, Wash, in July 2002 for six-month deployment to patrol no-flight zone over Iraq; officers worry about stamina of more than 5,200 sailors and aviators aboard; photos (M)

headline: Zor Orgun Journal; Afghans Make New Lives Among the Old Ruins
abstract: Old Afghan town of Zor Orgun, which was leveled by Soviet carpet bombing 20 years ago, is coming back to life as hundreds of refugee families return from Pakistan; many build new houses on surrounding open land, but others are rebuilding among ruins, raising town from dead; photo; map (M)

headline: In Replay of First Gulf War, Britons Are Killed by Allies
abstract: Two British airmen are killed after their Tornado is downed by American Patriot missile close to Kuwait border as it returned from nighttime bombing mission over Iraq; this is third air disaster for British since war began, with total death count of 16; none of deaths resulted from enemy attack; for British military planners, latest news is replay of experience of 1991 gulf war, when they lost as many servicemen to mistaken attacks on them by American allies as they did to enemy action; photo (M)

headline: Editors' Note; EDITORS' NOTE
abstract: Editor's Note: New York Atty Gen Eliot L Spitzer denies making jest quoted in Dec 22 article about site where talks that led to $1.4 billion settlement to revamp Wall Street research practices was held; account came from three people at meeting, who now say they are uncertain what was said

headline: Iraqis Join a Rally to Show That War Will Be Resisted
abstract: Thousands of Iraqis rally around nation in tightly marshaled show of definance for United States; Baghdad demonstration apparently was organized to show Pres Bush American troops may face resistance in Iraq; many at rallies were ordered to attend; rallies, despite curiously desultry moody, show Saddam Hussein has impressive organizational ability and power to compel compliance; photo (M)

headline: ADVANCED MICRO DELAYS RELEASE OF 64-BIT CHIP FOR PC'S
abstract: Advanced Micro Devices postpones release of its new line of faster chips for desktop PC's until September (S)

headline: Afghans Report 17 Civilian Deaths in U.S.-Led Bombing
abstract: Authorities reported today that at least 17 civilians died in raids the U.S. said led to the capture of 12 Taliban suspects.

headline: U.S., Britain and Spain to Make Final Push for U.N. Support
abstract: After today's talks, President Bush said that "tomorrow is a moment of truth for the world" in the effort to disarm Iraq.
