headline: A Proposal to Reduce U.S. Troops in Germany
abstract: Gen James L Jones, new supreme commander for US forces in Europe, is reportedly considering plan to scale back presence of American troops in Germany in favor of lighter, more mobile units that could jump from country to country on moment's notice; proposal is likely to win support from Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld, who has been advocate of making American forces lighter and more mobile; closest aides have argued that American bases overseas will become increasingly vulnerable, and should be replaced by forces that can move quickly across long distances from more secure redoubts (S)

headline: THREATS AND RESPONSES: Briefly Noted; TARGET PULLS CARDS
abstract: Target chain removes children's Valentine cards containing word 'Jihad,' from name of character in Scholastic's I Spy book series (S)

headline: The Good Bikers of Sichuan Roar Off
abstract: China has growing legions of not-so-elderly retirees who have joined motorcycle clubs; more than 100 couples and singles belong to club, which organizes three or four tours each month that last anywhere from day to more than week; photo (M)

headline: People
abstract: Brian Hefferman is named executive vice prr

headline: Indonesians Seem Unconvinced by Bush Arguments on Iraq
abstract: A group of Indonesian journalists and some community activists offered opinions that ranged from divergence to rejection.

headline: NATO: The Inside Story
abstract: NATO ambassadors gathered for a showdown over Iraq on Feb. 16, and the alliance's secretary general held a trump card.

headline: Technology Briefing: Hardware
abstract: CIENA LOSS WIDENS ON COSTS TO RETIRE DEBT; NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR WILL LAY OFF 500; INGRAM MICRO POSTS $10.3 MILLION LOSS;.

headline: Bombing in Israel Unites Victims Old and New
abstract: Karina Gupolov, who was wounded in suicide bombing in Netanya, Israel, year ago, returns to hospital to visit victim of latest suicide bombing there; tries to comfort Nihad Yassin, Israeli Arab who was wounded with three dozen others in latest bombing; Islamic Jihad claims responsibility for attack; calls bombing 'gift' to people of Iraq and says it has sent group of Palestinians to Baghdad with goal of carrying out suicide attacks against American and British soldiers; photo; map (M)

headline: American Is Killed in Kuwait
abstract: Murder of American civilian in Kuwait and wounding of second noted

headline: Your Taxes; Software or the Web? (And New Free Filing)
abstract: Fastest, easiest way for many Americans to prepare their own tax returns is to go online and file electronically; IRS is promoting plan called FreeFile to persuade more taxayers to complete their returns electronically; software that is loaded into computer, like Intuit's TurboTax and H & R Block's TaxCut, is generally slightly more expensive than online preparation, but may be worth it for complicated returns; drawing (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Industrial Output Rises
abstract: Brazil's production was up 5.5 percent in December compared with year earlier; manufacturing output rose by annualized 2.4 percent, compared with 1.5 percent in 2001; highest interest rates in four years are depressing local consumer demand and forcing companies to cut spending (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Americas
abstract: BRAZIL: A Deficit Declines; BRAZIL: Jet Order Reduced;.

headline: Vivendi Chief Visits Studio and Tries to Reassure Executives
abstract: Vivendi Universal chief executive Jean-Rene Fourtou meets with 300 senior executives at Vivendi Universal Entertainment, Universal Studios, Burbank, for first time since taking over company nine months ago; Fourtou and Vivendi Universal Entertainment president-chief operating officer Ron Meyer field wide range of questions, from when company plans to complete sale of its entertainment assets to sometimes stormy relationship with Barry Diller, who resigned last week as interim chief executive of Vivendi Universal Entertainment (M)

headline: Iraq Plotting To Use Garb Of the Allies, U.S. Says
abstract: Senior Defense Dept official says Pres Saddam Hussein is seeking uniforms that are 'identical' to those worn by American and British troops, so that atrocities carried out by Iraqi forces could be blamed on allies (S)

headline: Do It Yourself; Not a Professional? No Problem
abstract: Number of relatively low-priced electronic tools allow car owners to perform some of same diagnostic tests that professional mechanics run; photo (M)

headline: McDONALD'S NAMES VICE PRESIDENT FOR U.S. OPERATIONS
abstract: McDonald's Corp names Ralph Alÿ

headline: Text of Statement From Federal Reserve
abstract: Text of statement released by Federal Reserve after Federal Open Market Committee decides to leave interest rates unchanged

headline: Retailers Adjust Reluctantly To Era of Permanent Discounts
abstract: Analysts say fewer shoppers are interested in paying full price for merchandise because they have become accustomed to bargains, discounts that are further eroding reailers' profits in already lackluster retail environment; bored customers and uncertain economy have already driven down prices in last three months; graph; photo (M)

headline: MEMO PAD
abstract: East Coast blizzard causes airlines to temporarily relax strict policies that penalize travelers with nonrefundable tickets who change their flight plans; poll of business travelers finds they believe most important piece of equipment they need while abroad under present tense circumstances is cellphone able to make international calls; Air Transport Association reports that Pacific routes showed most robust increases in business for US-based airlines in January; Michael Boyd, consultant, predicts that 460 million passengers will take airplane trips in US this year, down from 520 million in 2000 (M)

headline: U.S. Lists Guatemala's Anti-Drug Cooperation as Inadequate
abstract: Bush administration says Guatemala is deeply mired in corruption and no longer deserves to be listed among allies of United States in fight against drug trafficking; says Pres Bush will 'decertify' Guatemala's antidrug efforts but waive penalties because of US's own vital interests (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Toshiba Loss Narrows
abstract: Toshiba loses 6.9 billion yen ($58 billion) in October-December quarter (S)

headline: Investing; Recent History Benefits A Preserver of Documents
abstract: Profile of Iron

headline: Change in Ownership, Not Point of View
abstract: James Poole acquires domaine name for Iraqi News Agency site after Iraqi Satellite TV fails to renew registration, and he uses it to attack Saddam Hussein (M)

headline: Deutsch May Get Show on CNBC
abstract: Donny Deutsch, chairman and chief executive at Deutsch in New York, is being considered as host of hourlong program on CBNC (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Yen weakens against dollar, closing at 118.11 yen; table; graphs (S)

headline: Full Text of Testimony Before the Senate Appropriations Committee
abstract: The following is the full text of testimony before the Senate Appropriations Committee by Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld, Gen. Richard Myers, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Homeland Security Secretary Tom Ridge, Paul Wolfowitz, deputy secretary of defense, and Dov Zakheim, the comptroller for the Department of Defense, as recorded by The Federal News Service.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Canon Outlook Raised
abstract: Moody's Investors Service raises outlook for debt rating of Canon Inc to positive, from stable, citing company's growing market share and excess cash flow (S)

headline: Philips Electronics Lost $3.4 Billion Last Year
abstract: Royal Philips Electronics lost 3.2 billion euros ($3.4 billion) in 2002 and 1.53 billion euros ($1.6 billion) in fourth quarter; sales in 2002 were 32 billion euros ($34 billion), 2 percent decline from 2001; photo of chief executive Gerard J Kleisterlee (M)

headline: Powell Urges European Allies to Settle Bitter Debate Over Iraq
abstract: The secretary of state told the Senate today that "we are reaching the moment of truth" in the trans-Atlantic debate over whether to go to war in Iraq.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Pact Between Rebels And Government
abstract: Information Minister Ramesh Nath Pandey announces that Nepal government and Maoist insurgents have agreed to 22-point code of conduct and release of prisoners of war in effort to further peace beyond cease-fire (S)

headline: Not Waiting for U.N. Report, Baghdad Assails the U.S.
abstract: Baghdad's foreign minister launched a scathing verbal attack on the United States hours before the report was delivered in New York.

headline: Scrawl To Screen, With a Pen
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column explores systems designed for taking handwritten notes and retrieving them later on PC or palmtop; reviews Microsoft's Tablet PC and systems by Seiko and Logitech; drawing; photos (M)

headline: Nikon Names McCann-Erickson
abstract: Nikon Inc names McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising as agency of record on its account, which had been handled by Fallon Worldwide; spending estimated at $18 million (S)

headline: Turkey Says It Won't Send More Troops Into Iraq
abstract: The head of Turkey's military said today that his country would not send new troops into northern Iraq, barring human catastrophe or open warfare between rival Kurdish factions.

headline: Monsanto Posts Profit as Sales Increase
abstract: Monsanto Co says fourth-quarter net income was $61 million compared to net loss of $104 million year earlier; sales rose to $1.22 billion (S)

headline: People
abstract: Matthew Bull is named chief executive at London office of Lowe & Partners, succeeding Chris Thomas, who resigned; Lisa Seward is named media director for North America, new post (S)

headline: HEWLETT-PACKARD RESTATES CASH FLOW BUT NOT EARNINGS
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co, in Securities and Exchange Commission filing, restates first-quarter cash flow from operations, reducing it 18 percent because of accounting error; cash flow from operations was $647 million (S)

headline: A Bit of History: Sometimes War Sends Shares Higher, Sometimes Lower
abstract: Brief history of fluctuations in stock prices during time of war as stock prices rise in US and around world during start of US invasion of Iraq (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Sri Lanka Young Still Forced To Join in Endless Rebellion
abstract: Boys and girls as young as 12 are forced to join Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eeelan in their 20-year fight for separate state for Tamils of Sri Lanka; some are taken by force from their homes, others go 'voluntarily' to spare their parents after Tiger cadres threaten them; human rights organizations, incuding United Nations, claim much of rebels' battle has been fought on backs, and bodies, of child soldiers; Tigers are in peace talks with Sri Lankan government and they inist they no longer have, or accept, children in their ranks; villagers in northern and eastern parts of country, where most Tamils live, whisper that children continue to be taken; complaints filed with international aid groups, as well as interviews with Tamils and community leaders in Tiger-controlled north and east, also indicate that child enlistment and abduction, while down from past levels, continue; photos; maps (L)

headline: TURKISH DEPUTIES REFUSE TO ACCEPT AMERICAN TROOPS
abstract: Turkish Paliament narrowly rejects measure that would have allowed thousands of American combat troops to use country as base for attack on Iraq; majority of lawmakers voting support measure, but abstentions prevent it from achieving necessary support of majority of lawmakers present; vote surprises Turkish leaders, stuns American officials, who had already begun having heavy equipment unloaded at Turkish ports in anticipation that measure would carry, and casts shadow over American-Turkish relationship; quashes possibility, at least for now, that Turkish troops will enter northern Iraq, prospect that many there, especially country's Kurds, regarded with dread; polls in Turkey indicate that as many as 9 out of 10 Turks oppose involvement in war against Iraq; photos (M)

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- TriBeCa; A Building for Dot-Coms Switches to General Users
abstract: Former AT&T Long Distance Building at 32 Avenue of Americas, owned by Rudin Management, is marketing building for general users instead of original plan to attract dot-com companies; two Deutsche Telekom units have acquired space in building, indication that there is still life in telecommunications sector (M)

headline: U.S. Says Iraq Retools Rockets For Illicit Uses
abstract: US officials say UN weapons inspectors in Iraq recently discovered new variety of rocket, seemingly configured to strew bomblets filled with chemical or biological agents over large areas; say warheads appear cobbled together from stockpiles of imported or home-built weapons, some which Iraq used with both conventional and chemical warheads; say weapon was discovered in last few months, since UN weapons inspectors returned to Iraq in November, and shows Iraq cannot be trusted to cooperate with inspectors; discovery is buttressed by information provided in detailed report by UN inspection team, which catalogs history of Iraqi weapons programs and UN attempts to enforce compliance with its disarmament resolutions over past 12 years; Sec of State Colin L Powell says chief inspector Hans Blix should have presented more of evidence during most recent appearance before UN Security Council; also cites Iraq's development of drone aircraft capable of dispensing chemical weapons as another example; hints US will release more information about prohibited weapons as Security Council debates resolution for military action in coming days (M)

headline: Who's Sneakier? Spy Toys Differ for Girls and Boys
abstract: Wild Planet manufactures spy toys that cater specifically to gender differences; photo (M)

headline: Yayori Matsui Dies at 68; Championed Asian Women
abstract: Yayori Matsui, journalist and campaigner for rights of Asian women, dies at age 68; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Says Video Was of Hussein but Is Unsure When It Was Made
abstract: The Central Intelligence Agency has concluded that Saddam Hussein himself was indeed on the videotape shown on Iraqi television after the opening attack.

headline: Lloyd's Sees U.S. Growth
abstract: Lloyd's of London, the unprofitable insurance market, said that premium income in the United States rose to a record $8.2 billion last year.

headline: Turkish Court Casts Shadow On Would-Be Premier's Role
abstract: Turkey's highest court rejects claim by Recep Tayyip Erdogan, victor in last fall's elections, that he is head of nation's governing political party; party, Justice and Development Party, quickly says it will move within days to re-elect Erdogan, laying to rest any question about whether he is in charge of country's most popular political faction; series of daunting legal problems rooted in Erdogan's Islamic past and his years as mayor of Istanbul have kept him from occupying any official position of authority in Turkish government (M)

headline: Turkey Seeks $32 Billion for Helping U.S. in an Iraqi War
abstract: The Turkish request is some $6 billion more than what American officials said was their "final" offer over the weekend.

headline: Airline Alliance Welcomes Korean Member
abstract: Executives from 15 international airlines gather in Seoul to welcome Asiana Airlines of South Korea to their marketing organization, Star Alliance, but most of conversation concerns possibility of war in Iraq and its impact on their business; photo (M)

headline: $102 MILLION OFFER FOR CALIPER TECHNOLOGIES
abstract: Caliper Technologies Corp, which makes tools for laboratory experiments, receives acquisition offer from LB Acquisitions, unit of Little Bear Investments; offer totals about $101.7 million; Caliper's net loss widened to $10.5 million in fourth quarter, from $8.02 million year earlier; revenue dropped 37 percent, to $4.93 million from $7.87 million (S)

headline: In Sign of Insurers' Woes, A.I.G. Raises Liability Reserves
abstract: The American International Group increased its reserves for liability claims by $3.5 billion today in what is likely to be the start of a wave of such increases.

type: Money and Business/Financial DeskMoney and Bus
headline: WHAT THEY'RE READING
abstract: Business executives comment on books they are reading (M)

headline: A Salesman for Bush's Tax Plan Who Has Belittled Similar Ideas
abstract: Pres Bush, in nominating Harvard economist N Gregory Mankiw as head of Council of Economic Advisers, has now replaced nearly everyone from his original economic team with people who at one time spoke out against kinds of policies Bush is prescribing; Mankiw wrote popular economics textbook Principles of Economics in which he ridiculed supply-side tax cuts of Pres Reagan as 'fad economics' conceived by 'charlatans and cranks'; Mankiw, if confirmed by Senate, would become one of three salesmen for even bigger plan by Bush to cut taxes by about $1.5 trilion over next 10 years and let government run big budget deficits for foreseeable future; Bush's decision to recruit Mankiw and other new members of economic team reflects pragmatic decision to install people who can project confidence at time when economy shows new signs of stalling and Democrats are gearing up for next election; Martin Anderson, senior fellow at Hoover Institute who served in Reagan White House and advised Bush during presidential campaign, criticizes Mankiw; administration officials dismiss criticisms of Mankiw; photos (M)

headline: Some Rates In the Gulf Have Doubled Overnight
abstract: Prices for insurance for ships, businesses, oil workers and journalists skyrocket as Persian Gulf region prepares for war; prices to cover ships and personnel rise to twice what they have been day before; coverage for tankers and cargo ships in gulf is being sold for seven-day voyages so that rates can be modified as conditions change (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL EDUCATION/ A SPECIAL REPORT : Many nations fall short in improving standards
abstract: PARIS—  In 1950, South Korea and Zambia were roughly at the same economic level. That Korea is one of the world's most economically advanced nations today and Zambia one of the most backward is due almost entirely to a half century of investment in education, development experts say.

headline: Bush, in Rebuff to Partners, Freezes Mideast Peace Plan
abstract: Bush administration decides not to put forth plan for peace settlement between Israel and Palestinians until after crisis in Iraq is resolved; European allies, Russia and United Nations have been pressing administration to adopt and publish plan formally and won assurances from Pres Bush in December that plan would be published as soon as Israeli elections were completed in late January, but he now regards that pledge as unrealistic with war on horizon; refusal to publish plan infuriates European allies, especially Prime Min Tony Blair of Britain (M)

headline: Conviction of France's Ex-Foreign Minister Upheld
abstract: A French court today upheld an appeal by Roland Dumas against his conviction in a corruption scandal.

headline: Market Place; Some Question Timing of Sears Credit Card Unit Sale
abstract: Sears Roebuck could be selling its credit card business at bottom of market; some consultants and analysts say overall industry has weakened as overextended consumers have fallen behind on their payments, but losses may be peaking; contend selling at trough would seem to be misstep, since Sears might fetch higher price for its unit if it waited for business to recover, but Sears portfolio may not be bottoming out as quickly as those of its competitors; photo (M)

headline: ChevronTexaco Picks WPP Units
abstract: ChevronTexaco Corp names offices of Young & Rubicam Advertising and Mediaedge:CIA, units of WPP Group, to share its global account; billings estimated at $95 million (S)

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS for PETER HAKIM; How Free Trade Will Alter a Hemisphere
abstract: Interview with Inter-American Dialog president Peter Hakim about potential effects of Bush administration attempts to create free-trade agreement with Central America's El Salvador, Costa Rica, Guatemala, Honduras and Nicaragua; photo (M)

headline: Election in Turkey Clears Way for Erdogan to Take Formal Control
abstract: Recep Tayyip Erdogan supports a measure that would allow American troops to use Turkey as a base against Iraq.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bid For Miner Raised
abstract: Sherritt International Corp raises its unsolicited bid for rival Fording Inc, increasing cash portion of its 1.77 billion Canadian dollars ($1.13 billion) offer; Sherritt and partner Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan are offering 20 Canadian dollars per share in cash, up from 17.63 Canadian dollars, as part of bid that values Fording at 35 Canadian dollars per share (S)

headline: Allied Plan Would Encourage Iraqis Not to Fight
abstract: American and British commanders say they are devising a strategy intended to defeat the Iraqi military without completely destroying it, and to limit damage to Iraq's infrastructure.    Lt. Gen. David McKiernan, the commander of allied land forces if the United States leads an invasion of Iraq, said he and other commanders were working out procedures for Iraqi units to signal their intention to stay out of the war.

headline: Technology Briefing: Hardware
abstract: HEWLETT SHARES FALL AFTER CASH-FLOW CHANGE; PHILIPS WILL CUT 1,600 JOBS AT CHIP UNIT; COMPUTER HORIZONS CHIEF INDICTED BY U.S.;.

headline: Reinsurer Offering Raises $221 Million
abstract: Endurance Specialty Holdings, Bermuda-based reinsurer, raises $220.8 million, as much as 15 percent less than planned, in initial public offering (S)

headline: Mexico Indicts Former Chief of Secret Police
abstract: Luis de la Barreda, former secret police chief in Mexico, is charged with murdering three leftists during 'dirty war' prosecuted by Mexican government from late 1960's into 1980's, in what may be beginnings of breakthrough for rule of law in Mexico; at least 275 people, perhaps twice that number, disappeared during dirty war, and de la Barreda is first secret police official charged with murder for crimes committed during that period; de la Barreda now stands formally accused of torture and killing of Jesus Piedra Ibarra, prominent member of radical left-wing group who vanished in 1975, and of playing a role in deaths of two other leftists (M)

headline: CASUAL MALE TO CLOSE OUTLET STORES AND CUT 500 JOBS
abstract: Casual Male Retail Group plans to close its Levi's and Dockers outlet stores as it focuses on selling clothing to tall and big men; will cut 500 to 600 jobs; plans to close 50 to 55 stores in next 24 months, with thirty remaining stores being sold or shut at end of lease terms (S)

headline: Tough Talk on Iraq Carries Cost for Blair
abstract: Prime Minister Tony Blair's moralizing diplomacy, his tough talk on Iraq and his steadfast loyalty to President Bush have gained him acceptance in the United States, but they have cost him popularity at home, opinion polls indicate, and hard-won influence in Europe.

headline: For G.I.'s, a Dusty Drive Across the Desert to the Euphrates and the First Iraqi Defense
abstract: American armored and infantry forces advance to Euphrates River, overwhelming resistance from Iraq forces; Army has first significant clashes, coming under fire from Iraqi forces near Nasiriya; battle provokes American airstrikes, and hundreds of Iraqi soldiers surrender; photo (M)

headline: Industrial Production Rises 0.7%
abstract: Federal Reserve reports that industrial production rose 0.7 percent in January, double the gain forecasters had predicted; Commerce Dept reports business inventories tripled expectations by jumping 0.6 percent in December; figures show that though consumers remain economy's main engine, companies are starting to contribute as well (M)

headline: Bank of America Reports Higher Profit
abstract: Bank of America Corp says fiscal fourth-quarter earnings increased 27 percent; net income rose to $2.61 billion compared with $2.06 billion year earlier; revenue was little changed at $8.8 billion; chief financial officer James H Hance Jr comments (M)

headline: How friendly can Europe be with the U.S.?: Chirac's outburst exposes contradiction within EU
abstract: PARIS:—  President Jacques Chirac's warning to the new Europeans of EU and NATO enlargement that they cannot side too much with America and fit his definition of membership in the family of Europe has exposed, with an outburst of pure rage, a profound, long-term contradiction that could tear the EU apart from within.

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: GERMANY: G.I. Shot Himself; BRITAIN: American To Run London Tube; SERBIA AND MONTENEGRO: No Limo Auction; DENMARK: Tanker Runs Aground;.

headline: 8 Palestinians Killed During Raid in Gaza Strip
abstract: Israeli forces stormed Gaza today, demolishing houses, killing eight Palestinians and arresting a founder of Hamas.

headline: Retail Executives Reborn as Consultants
abstract: Former Bloomingdale's chairman Marvin S Traub joins other retired retail executives to form new consulting group Financo Global Consulting, division of investment bank Financo Inc (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Bank'S Profit Falls; BRITAIN: Unilever'S Profit Rises; IRELAND: Utility Has Spanish Plan; THE NETHERLANDS: Bank Posts Gain;.

headline: U.S. Calls Decision by Hussein His 'Final Mistake'
abstract: The White House said that Saddam Hussein made his "final mistake" when he rejected an ultimatum ordering him to leave Iraq or face war.

headline: Hundreds of Thousands Mourn Murdered Serbian Leader
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of Serbs march through Belgrade to pay respects to assassinated Prime Min Zoran Djindjic, who is buried with military honors; Greek Min George Papandreou speaks at his graveside; vows Greece, which holds European Union's rotating presidency, will give his successor greater support; Djindjic's commitment to confront murky alliance of war criminals and racketeers that took control of Serbia under Pres Slobdan Milosevic earned him respect and may have cost him his life; mourners express hope that murder will unite politicians behind effort to weed out holdovers from Milosevic era, whom they blame for holding back development; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Putin Backs Belarus Union
abstract: President Vladimir V Putin, while in Minsk, voices surprising commitment to economic alliance with Belarus and calls for expeditious efforts toward making Russian ruble standard currency for both countries; skeptics believe relationship will fail to live up to Belarus President Aleksandr Lukashenko's vision (S)

headline: When marketers trip over trademarks, the fun begins.
abstract: University of Iowa Asst Prof Kembrew McLeod, who holds trademark on phrase Freedom of Expression, has sent AT&T Corp 'cease and desist letter' after AT&T began using phrase in some print ads; McLeod says consumers might infer link between company and his anti-corporate publication Freedom of Expression; says bigger idea behind his legal action is to object to corporate power over words, speech and even ideas; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Americas
abstract: BRAZIL: Loss By Electric Unit; BRAZIL: Profit At Jet Maker;.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Bardot Is Latest Mugabe Critic
abstract: Brigitte Bardot urges France to withdraw invitation to Zimbabwe Pres Robert Mugabe to attend African summit meeting in Paris, saying he has trampled on animal as well as human rights; her photo (S)

headline: Not Easy Breaking the Ice With This Crowd
abstract: Ron Gettelfinger, president of United Automobile Workers union, will speak at Economic Club of Detroit, which has not been addressed by UAW president in 10 years (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Jobless Rate Rises
abstract: Unemployment in Germany rose to 11 percent in January, up from 10.1 percent in December and highest level in five years; number of jobless people rose nearly 400,000, to 4.62 million (S)

headline: Iraqi Opposition Is Uneasy Over Delays and War Plans
abstract: Plans for meeting in northern Iraq of Iraqi groups opposed to Saddam Hussein are disrupted again amid new delay and signs of worry over American plans for war; there is some discomfort with elements of American war plans, and resistance to American proposals to have Turkish soldiers enter Iraq on humanitarian missions and plans for American military occupation in Iraq for as long as two years; photo (M)

headline: What Wedding Present to Buy For the Couple With Everything?
abstract: Items on gift registry for Summner M Redstone's wedding to Paula Fortunato noted; Redstone has told friends he does not want gifts; bride's sister set up registry; photo (S)

headline: Gunman Dies When Israelis Level Building
abstract: Israeli troops in the West Bank destroyed a three-story apartment building today with a tank shell and a bulldozer, killing a Palestinian gunman inside. Soldiers also shot and killed two militants carrying pipe bombs outside a Jewish settlement in the southern Gaza Strip, the army said.     The gunman had opened fire Monday night on Israeli soldiers in Hebron near the Tomb of the Patriarchs, sacred to both Jews and Muslims as the burial place of Abraham. One soldier was killed and five were wounded, the army said. The radical Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine and the militant Islamic group Hamas both claimed responsibility for the attack.

headline: Serb in Court in The Hague, Playing to a TV Audience at Home
abstract: Vojislav Seselj, one of Serbia's most hard-line and most articulate nationalists, appeared at the United Nations tribunal in The Hague yesterday to answer charges that he ran a band of volunteer fighters that killed and robbed non-Serbs during the Balkan wars of the 1990's.    With the abrasive style that first saw him jailed under the Communists in Yugoslavia, Mr. Seselj, who drew thousands of supporters onto the streets of Belgrade before he turned himself in to the tribunal this week, presented himself as a victim, rather than perpetrator, of the wars, and listed several objections.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Zlotnick Group opens Washington office; Jan Zlotnick will head office; Lewis & Partners is renamed LP Advertising; Townsend Agency is renamed Townsend Inc (S)

headline: THREATS AND RESPONSES: Briefly Noted; UTAH TAKES ON U.N.
abstract: Utah House passes resolution calling for US withdrawal from UN; one of reasons cited is failure to oust Saddam Hussein from Iraq in Persian Gulf War (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Agreement With Rebels On Civilians
abstract: Sudanese government and rebels agree to another year of independent monitoring aimed at keeping civilians safe while parties continue peace negotiations in Kenya; US Ambassador to Kenya Johnnie Carson lauds program (S)

headline: Pentagon Ready to Strike Iraq Within Days if Bush Gives the Word, Officials Say
abstract: American military officials say they have provided Pres Bush with options for attack against Iraq that could begin within days and without using Turkey as staging area for troops in north; Gen Tommy R Franks meets at White House to discuss war plans with Bush and his top national security advisers; Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld and Franks say Bush has made no decision on whether to order attack (M)

headline: A Stooped Icon of Angkor, Forever Sweeping
abstract: Profile of Chhoun Neam, 81-year-old sweeper at Ta Prohm temple in Siem Reap, Cambodia; he comments on his hard life, and his losses, especially of his two sons, taken by brutal Khmer Rouge during 1970's, never to return; photo (M)

headline: Saudi Prince Encourages Exile Agreement for Hussein's Departure
abstract: Saudi foreign minister Prince Saud al-Faisal hastily sets up meeting with Pres Bush to discuss prospects of persuading Pres Saddam Hussein of Iraq to go into exile; Saud is convinced that United States is moving toward war; senior Bush administration officials have signaled their willingness to consider some lenience for Hussein in order to avoid war (M)

headline: Staff of S.E.C. Is Said to Dilute Rule Changes
abstract: SEC staff reportedly will recommend softening proposed rules imposing new obligations on lawyers and accountants, following onslaught of lobbying since Congress enacted law in response to spate of corporate scandals; some of toughest proposals appear to be dead, watered down or postponed; they include requiring lawyers to make 'noisy' withdrawal from clients that refuse to address security law violations and restricting accountants from auditing tax shelters they created; former SEC chief accountant Lynn Turner finds it 'amazing' after so many scandals; Harvey Pitt, who remains as chairman more than two months after announcing resignation under heavy criticism, played active role in drafting new rules; Pres Bush has actually not yet nominated chosen successor William H Donaldson (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Oil To Leak For Decades
abstract: Scientists assert that sunken oil tanker Prestige will continue to leak fuel through its damaged hull for several decades; tanker went down November 2002 and spill continues to damage Spain's northwest coastline; ship still houses estimated 50,000 tons of oil (S)

headline: FEDERATED MELDS CATALOG AND WEB SITE UNIT INTO STORES
abstract: Federated Department Stores is folding Bloomingdale's catalog and Macy's Web site into its department store chains; company's Federated Direct division, which ran operations, is being closed; Macy's.com has about 100 employees and Bloomingdale's by Mail catalog has about 75; none of those jobs will be lost through changes, which take effect on March 1, and Federated does not expect any related costs (M)

headline: As Blix Report Nears, Debate Swirls on Iraqi Weapons
abstract: As U.N. inspectors prepare to present a pivotal briefing tomorrow, the state of Saddam Hussein's weapons programs remains a matter of heated debate.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Great-West Lifeco Offers $4.7 Billion for Canada Life  Great-West Lifeco has agreed to acquire Canada Life Financial for almost $4.7 billion in cash and stock, topping an earlier bid by Manulife Financial. If completed, the deal would create Canada's biggest insurance company. Canada Life had earlier rejected Manulife's offer as inadequate.     The battle for Canada Life comes after a series of mergers and acquisitions by life insurers. The trend has been reinforced in recent years by the conversion to shareholder ownership from mutual ownership of four of the five biggest companies, including Manulife and Canada Life. [Page C4.]

headline: ELECTRO SCIENTIFIC RESTATES RESULTS AFTER REVIEW
abstract: Electro Scientific Industries

headline: Hamburg Journal; For Cooking Up Music, Mixed Vegetables Do Fine
abstract: First Viennese Vegetable Orchestra, made up of nine avant-garde artists from Vienna, uses various vegetables as musical instrument; performance in Hamburg, Ger, described; photos; map (M)

headline: ALLEGHENY ENERGY TO SELL ITS STAKE IN POWER PLANT
abstract: Allegheny Energy, a utility owner that is selling assets to pay off debt, has agreed to sell its stake in a Pennsylvania power plant to the UGI Corporation for $51.3 million. Allegheny's share of the plant, the Conemaugh Generating Station near Johnstown, is 4.86 percent, the company said. Allegheny, based in Hagerstown, Md., received $2.4 billion in new loans yesterday to repay at least $1.64 billion in debt that had gone into default after losses in the company's energy-trading business last year. UGI is based in King of Prussia, Pa.

headline: There's a Futures Contract for Everything (Even Iraq's Fate)
abstract: Mark Hulburt column on prediction by two Stanford economics professors, Eric Zitzewitz and Justin Wolfers, that Standard & Poor's 500 index will drop 5 percent on day war starts in Iraq; notes that they based prediction on futures contract -- traded on Web site in Dublin -- that will pay $10 if Saddam Hussein is not Iraq's president on June 30 and nothing if he still is; contract was last traded at $7.50; graph (M)

headline: No Headline
abstract: Chronology of events in war in Iraq on Mar 20, 2003 (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Oil Sale Protest
abstract: Thousands of workers at two government-owned oil companies Hindustan Petroleum Corp and Bharat Petroleum Corp begin three-day strike to protest privatization of companies; workers fear that privatization will lead to job losses (S)/

headline: North Korean Fighter Intrudes on South's Airspace
abstract: There is a question of whether the flight was strategically timed to precede the arrival of Secretary of State Colin L. Powell in South Korea on Monday.

headline: An Ultimatum, Frayed French Relations and Stockpiling in Iraq
abstract: Roundup of Iraq-related events around world on Mar 16 (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Trying To Win Hearts And Minds
abstract: Chechnya's pro-Moscow officials close three military checkpoints and plan to close seven more in effort to win public support before March 23 vote on new constitution; some Chechens accuse Russian soldiers of engaging in extortion of Chechens seeking permission to travel (S)

headline: U.S. Courts Network It Once Described as 'All Osama'
abstract: Bush administration is courting Al Jazeera, Arab satellite network it once derided for broadcasting Al Qaeda tapes and anti-American commentators, as it fights propaganda war of Iraqi conflict; Al Jazeera is likely to become major source for Baghdad coverage now that most American television networks have left city; its real importance stems from its Arab audience, where pictures of heavy casualties caused by American bombing could arouse anti-American feelings; US hopes pictures of cheering Iraqi crowds will prevail; Al Jazeera reporters are getting choice spots with American military units and access to top administration officials; photo (M)

headline: Tyco Shareholders Vote to Keep Headquarters in Bermuda
abstract: Tyco International shareholders defeat motion calling on company to move its incorporation back to US from Bermuda; tax benefits are major factor in decision to stay (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Parsons Named Chairman As AOL Tries to Move On  AOL Time Warner named its chief executive, Richard D. Parsons, to succeed Stephen M. Case as chairman, completing the removal of the last executive from AOL in the company's upper management as it seeks to soothe the animosities lingering from America Online's acquisition of Time Warner two years ago.    For Mr. Parsons, the move completes the surprising consolidation of power in the last two years since the companies merged. Named co-chief operating officer at the time, he was largely pushed aside during the merger negotations and crucial decisions afterward. Now he faces the same tough audience that forced out the former chief executive, Gerald Levin, and Mr. Case. [Page A1.]

headline: Briefly Noted
abstract: SUICIDE ATTEMPTS AT GUANTÁNAMO Three more men have attempted suicide at the United States prison camp at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, in the past week, lifting the total to 19, the Pentagon said yesterday. The three were treated at the nearby American naval base and are back in their cells, said Lt. Cmdr. Barbara Burfeind. Also yesterday, Commander Burfeind acknowledged that some of the camp's detainees, who are generally terrorism suspects and are considered by the United States to be combatants, were being transferred to detention elsewhere.

headline: No Need To Wring Hands Over Retail Sales
abstract: Tom Redburn Economic View column disagrees with opinions of media and public that 2002 holiday sales were weak; forecasts they will show healthy growth of about 4 to 5 percent over previous year; sales graph (M)

headline: Who Shot G.I.? The Answer Gets Muddier
abstract: American military spokesman says man who shot at American patrol on Afghan-Pakistani border week ago, wounding one soldier, may not have been border guard, as first reported, even though he was dressed as one; opponents of American operation in Afghanistan criticize US for dropping bomb on area after attack (S)

headline: Antismoking Group Prepares for Review
abstract: American Legacy Foundation, which

headline: Bitterly Divided Security Council Meets on Iraq Resolution
abstract: The Security Council met today to begin considering a resolution drafted by the United States that would find Baghdad in breach of weapons restrictions.

headline: Same Suspects Tied to Mombasa and '98 Embassy Attacks
abstract: Investigators in Nairobi find evidence suggesting that some of same operatives of Al Qaeda involved in American Embassy bombings in Kenya and Tanzania in 1998 may have helped carry out Nov 18 attack on Paradise Hotel in Mombasa, Kenya, which killed 11 Kenyans, 3 Israelis and at least 2 suicide bombers; four Qaeda members were convicted in 2001 for embassy attacks, but American officials acknowledge that they never completely cracked Qaeda cell that carried them out; photos; map (L)

headline: What Are the Chances?
abstract: Rapidly evolving set of conceptual and computing tools allows mathematicians, engineers and insurance executives to assess risks of what are known as low-probability, high-consequence events, such as hurricanes, space shuttle failures and other disasters; field, known as probabilistic risk assessment, helps companies and government agencies decide whether to take certain chances; concepts were developed 40 years ago, but recent advances in computing power have increased use of such analyses and confidence in them; idea behind it is that mathematics can help determine chances of particular outcome based on what is known about smaller variables that lead to those outcomes; examples cited; photos (L)

headline: U.S. Is Calling Refusal of Exile 'Final Mistake'
abstract: White House says Iraq's Pres Saddam Hussein made 'final mistake' by rejecting ultimatum by Pres Bush to leave country with two sons or face war; Pres Bush meets with military advisers to discuss war plans as security increases significantly; spends day recruiting members for coalition, which Sec of State Colin L Powell says has grown to 45 nations, and contacting UN Security Council members opposed to military action; State Dept issues for first time list of 30 countries that have reportedly joined coalition; France makes slight shift in adamant opposition to military action; says it could assist American-led coalition if Iraq used chemical or biological weapons against American troops; Iraqi government issues statement inveighing against American, British and 'Zionist aggressors;' Hussein's older son Uday calls Bush 'unstable;' says he should leave US with his family; UN Amb Mohammed Aldouri calls ultimatum 'madness;' photos (M)

headline: Company News
abstract: McDONALD'S PLANS TO CLOSE MORE RESTAURANTS McDonald's said yesterday that it would close more underperforming restaurants in the United States and Japan. It did not say how many. The company also said it would retain its $1 Value Menu, which has increased business but decreased profit margins. James J. Cantalupo, the new chief executive, said that drastic changes at the company were not necessary but that small modifications like keeping restrooms cleaner and providing customer service were. Mr. Cantalupo also said that McDonald's would not provide quarterly earnings forecasts in 2003, but would focus on the long-term goal of rebuilding its business. In December, the company warned that it would not meet earnings expectations and would close 175 lagging restaurants. Sherri Day (NYT) LANDS' END APPAREL GAVE SEARS A LIFT IN FOURTH QUARTER Initial success with sales of its Lands' End apparel helped Sears, Roebuck to a fourth-quarter profit despite problems in its credit card unit. The company's net income rose 72 percent, although most of that was because of a one-time tax gain. Excluding noncomparable items, its income climbed 1.8 percent from the previous year. Operating income in the fourth quarter declined 15 percent from the previous year, as Sears increased its allowance for uncollectible credit card accounts by $150 million. Sears said that decline was offset by 10 percent higher operating income in its retail business, helped by improvements in margin and the acquisition of Lands' End last spring. (AP) FEDERATED TO CLOSE 11 STORES AND CUT 2,000 JOBS Federated Department Stores plans to close 11 stores and cut nearly 2,000 jobs this year, as it expects flat sales and earnings in 2003. Federated, based in Cincinnati, said it would consolidate its Rich's and Macy's department stores in the Atlanta area, resulting in the closing of seven Macy's stores in April and the elimination of 1,500 jobs. It also plans to close Lazarus stores in Blooming

headline: Sure, Sound off on Iraq, Just Not in an Interview
abstract: Career experts tell job seekers not to give their views about war in Iraq during job interview; recommend taking neutral-sounding stance if asked; photo (M)

headline: Business; Who's Blocking the Xbox? Sony and Its Games
abstract: Microsoft has sold only nine million Xbox game consoles, on low end of its projections, and continues to lose money on each one it sells, despite what many consider to be technological superiority to Sony's PlayStation 2, which is selling at record pace; main reason is that PlayStation 2 has 2-to-1 advantage over Xbox in terms of games that can be played on it; makers of video games are starting to produce more games for Xbox, but analysts and investors wonder how much time and money Microsoft is willing to invest before it starts to turn a profit; good news for Microsoft is that it is expected to widen its lead over Nintendo this year; graphs; photo (M)

headline: Bush Says War May Be Long, but Hussein Is Doomed
abstract: Interrupted several times by loud cheering and applause, the president acknowledged that there was no way to know how long the war would last.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Software Profit Increases 24%
abstract: Major Indian software exporter Infosys Technologies reports 24 percent rise in profit for third fiscal quarter ended Dec 31 to 2.56 billion rupees ($53 million); photo (S)

headline: A satellite broadcaster tries an anti-establishment approach to selling pay radio to consumers.
abstract: Crispin Porter & Bogusky creates advertising campaign for Sirius Satellite Radio, which seeks to lure customers willing to pay monthly fee of $10 or more for crystal-clear radio reception; subscribers of competitor XM Satellite Radio far outnumber those for Sirius, whose survival depends on enlisting many more customers; photo (M)

headline: On the Slopes, High-Tech Sensors Probe for an Avalanche
abstract: New technologies may help avert avalanche fatalities; developments range from detailed analysis of snow layers hidden beneath smooth surfaces to network designed to pick up low-frequency sounds of avalanches before humans can detect them; drawing (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Bank Acquisition
abstract: ING Group agrees to buy Entrium Direct Bankers of Germany for 300 million euros ($324 million) to strengthen its position as Germany's largest Internet bank; will make purchase from Capitalia of Italy (S)

headline: Enron's Outside Directors Win a Round in Court
abstract: Federal Judge Melinda Harmon dismissed fraud and insider trading accusations brought by investors against outside directors of Enron Corp, saying plaintiffs failed to demonstrate board members knew about any wrongdoing; Harmon allows plaintiffs to continue with claims that essentially amount to accusations that outside directors were negligent in their oversight of Enron (M)

headline: Treasury Financings Scheduled for Week
abstract: The Treasury's financings this week comprise the auction of three-  and six-month bills today and a four-week bill tomorrow.     By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 1.11 percent, the six-month bill was 1.11 percent, and the four-week bill was 1.13 percent.

headline: Reconstructing Iraq, The American Way
abstract: Richard S Lanier letter on March 23 article on Bush administration's decision that only American companies be allowed to bid on contracts to rebuild Iraq; says after all killing, it hardly seems right for US to declare that American companies will be only ones allowed to make killing

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Wages Decline
abstract: Total pay packets shrank in Japan at record pace in 2002 as companies slashed wages and replaced full-time workers with more part-time employees; wages for company workers dropped 2.3 percent, to 343,688 yen ($2,855), second consecutive annual decline (S)

headline: Retailers Said to Unite to Sell Music Online
abstract: Six of nation's largest music retailers plan to announce that they are joining forces to sell music that can be downloaded from Web; Best Buy, Tower Records, Virgin Entertainment Group, Wherehouse Entertainment, Hastings Entertainment and Trans World Entertainment unite to create service called Echo; music sellers search for new revenue sources to compensate for two-year decline in compact disc sales (M)

headline: Reluctant Saudi Arabia Prepares Its Quiet Role in the U.S.-Led War on Iraq
abstract: Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, worried about angering United States, is taking part in preparations for war in Iraq and will be involved, albeit quietly and obliquely, when it comes; war against Iraq is highly unpopular among Saudi citizens; Western diplomats say King Fahd's televised declaration that Saudi Arabia 'will not participate in any way' in war was meant for domestic consumption--with wink and nod at Americans (M)

headline: NEW PRESIDENT OF BURGER KING TO COME FROM YUM BRANDS
abstract: Burger King Corp names Robert Nilsen president, effective Feb 3; Nilsen was chief operating officer of Taco Bell, unit of Yum Brands (S)

headline: NEC Posts Smaller Losses for Fourth Quarter
abstract: NEC Corp. said its losses narrowed between October and December as chip prices rebounded. The results were in line with those at rivals Toshiba and Fujitsu.

headline: A Pivot Point for the Middle East
abstract: James Bennet analysis of obstacles on 'road map' to Israeli-Palestinian peace envisioned by Pres Bush, particularly Yasir Arafat's refusal to step aside as Palestinian leader and Prime Ariel Sharon's creation of new right-wing Israeli government with participation of two parties that oppose any Palestinian state (M)

headline: Hong Kong Officials Concede Other Carriers Are Out There
abstract: Government health officials in Hong Kong concede city harbors small but unknown number of carriers of mysterious kind of penumonia that World Health Orgn has labeled severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS; they hasten to add that moderate rate of new infections around world suggest disease is not as contagious as initially feared; local doctors have grown increasingly critical of government, and have been calling for more public warnings of dangers posed by SARS (M)

headline: Editors' Note
abstract: An article on the Executive Life page last Sunday discussed the growing willingness of companies to fill board seats with younger executives who have little or no board experience. The article gave as one example Nicole W. Piasecki, 40, a vice president of Boeing Commercial Airlines, appointed in June to the board of Weyerhaeuser, the forest products company.

headline: U.S. Envoy's Effort to Recruit Iraqi Exile for Possible Future Government Sparks Protests
abstract: Bush administration officials say Pres Bush's special envoy to Iraqi opposition leader Zalmay Khalilzad is quietly trying to recruit former senior Iraqi official Adnan Pachachi to help provide transition to democracy in event Saddam Hussein is ousted; effort has sparked opposition within administration and among other Iraqi exiles; Pachachi declared publicly in 1961 that Kuwait was part of Iraq and had no right to exist independently; renounced that statement in 1999; there is concern that effort to recruit Pachachi now would alienate Kuwait, essential base of operations in any gulf war; photo (M)

headline: Bombing Site Fuels Politics Of Bitterness
abstract: Iraqis observe anniversary of bombing in 1991 gulf war that killed 408 people, mostly women and children, at bomb shelter in Amiriya neighborhood of Baghdad; many fear similar losses if US attacks again (M)

headline: Bombers Put on Alert for Possible Deployment to North Korea
abstract: Officials said the move was designed to deter "opportunism" while Washington is focused on Iraq.

headline: Oil Prices Hit 2-Year High, as Iraq Tensions Grow
abstract: Oil prices rose today, building on a weeklong surge after OPEC failed to ease concerns about a supply disruption.

headline: Report by the Chief Inspector for Biological and Chemical Arms
abstract: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 14 — Following is a transcript of the statement given by the chief inspector for biological and chemical weapons, Hans Blix, to the United Nations today, as recorded by the Federal News Service.

headline: Economic Scene; It looks like red ink and the ills that can go with it are back to stay for a while.
abstract: Economic Scene: It looks like red ink and the ills that can go withï

headline: Arms Makers See Great Potential in India Market
abstract: Leading military equipment makers from around world are aggressively promoting their products to India's huge defense market, with its $100 billion in expected spending in next decade; companies converge in Bangalore for Aero India 2003, trade show held every two years for aircraft and military companies; manufacturers are also pursuing contracts to supply other Asian nations with combat aircraft; most aggressive battle at trade show is among military aircraft makers from Britain, Russia and US over multibillion-dollar order to supply 66 advanced jet trainers to Indian military; Lockheed Martin vice president Dennys S Plessas says his company sees significant opportunity in India; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: American In Sect Faces Trial
abstract: American Chuck Li of Menlo Park, California, goes on trial for participation in illegal broadcast of outlaw spiritual group Falun Gong messages over Chinese television; American envoys visiting him since his detainment in January say he is in good health (S)

headline: Favoring Change, China's New Leaders Move Cautiously
abstract: Pres Hu Jintao and Prime Min Wen Jiabao speak publicly for first time since legislature formalized their accessions as China's new leaders; they represent most sweeping transition since death of Mao in 1976, but their words signal that they will move only cautiously to carry out their own agenda; their addresses emphasize orthodoxies of their elders; their caution reflects pressure from senior party officials to do no more than tinker with mix of repressive political control and increasingly liberal economics that has transformed China from nation of poor peasants and state-owned factories into world's sixth largest economy; two men hold most powerful titles, but they do not yet run country; photo (M)

headline: Palm Changes System For Handwriting Input
abstract: Palm Inc develops new system that will eliminate use of Graffiti handwriting recognition software and let users write with more conventional characters; one reason for change is suit brought by Xerox charging patent infringement; Palm will introduce new system, Graffiti 2, in products later this year (M)

headline: From WorldCom, an Amazing View of a Bloated Industry
abstract: Market Watch column on bloated telecommunications industry as WorldCom Inc says it will write down value of its assets by $80 billion; says WorldCom's writedown has implications for others in industry and nation's economy over all; holds writedown is signal that others may follow from WorldCom competitors; says deflation in WorldCom's assets also indicates that rebound in telecommunications spending is further off than optimists think; adds WorldCom's announcement spells continued trouble for makers of telecommunications equipment; graph (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Heineken Sells Stake
abstract: Heineken will sell its 15 perent stake in Argentine brewer Quilmes International Bermuda; Heineken is selling stake in venture with Quilmes Industrial, or Quinsa, after Brazilian rival Cia de Bebidas das Americas, known as Ambev, wins approval from Argentine regulator to buy stake in Quinsa (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Results Slip
abstract: South Korea's Woori Finance Holdings reports net profit of 586 billion won ($489 million) last year, 100 billion below last year's net of 686 billion; Korea Exchange Bank reports sharp decline in profit, from 222 billion won ($185 million) in 2001 to 113 billion in 2002 (S)

headline: Bizarre Street Episode Claims a Young Palestinian Life
abstract: In Bethlehem, coincidental resemblance between cars leads to accidential shooting of Palestinian family by Israeli troops; 12-year-old girl in car is killed and three other family members are wounded; car was driving by moments after Israeli troops were involved in shootout with similar car carrying two members of militant group Hamas; Israeli captain says first Palestinian car fired on soldiers, after which Palestinian family drove into ensuing gun battle; Palestinian family says they heard no shooting as they aproached army vehicles; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Iona Reports Loss Of $308 Million
abstract: Iona Technologies reports net loss of $308 million for fourth quarter on revenue of $30.9 million; loss was $25.1 million in fourth quarter 2001 (S)

headline: Personal Data Is Pirated From Russian Phone Files
abstract: Russia's Mobile Telesystems acknowledges it has suffered huge security breach that led to pirated compact discs, purportedly containing its entire database of five million customes, appearing on streets of Moscow; breach may have not occurred at company; mobile phone operators and Internet services are required by law to hand over information about customers to police and government agencies like Federal Security Service; there is widespread speculation that low-paid employee at agency, presumably someone without Mobile Telesystems phone--may have sold data; Federal Security Service spokesman says agency knows nothing of matter; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Zurich; A Banking Center Is Trying to Overcome Its Staid Company-Town Image
abstract: Travel article on Zurich, Switzerland; city's highlights noted; photo (M)

headline: Kurds Say U.S. Gives Their Forces Air Support
abstract: American warplanes take advantage of newly acquired permission to cross Turkish airspace, pounding targets in and around Mosul in northern Iraq; heavy bombing comes as American Special Forces activity along front line continues to increase; Kurdish officials say they expect new military front to open on northern Iraq soon (M)

headline: G.M.'s Profits Almost Tripled Last Year
abstract: General Motors Corp says it nearly tripled its profits last year and beat Wall Street expectations in fourth quarter; results mean resumption of bonuses for workers; fourth-quarter net earnings were $1.02 billion compared with $255 million year earlier; revenue was record $48.66 billion; posts net earnigns of $1.7 billion for year on revenue of $186.8 billion; chairman John F Smith Jr comments; photo (M)

headline: French Risking Prestige as Talks Open in Ivory Coast Civil War
abstract: France initiates peace talks in Paris between rival factions fighting for control of Ivory Coast; hopes to end country's four-month civil war, extricate itself from dangerous and expensive military intervention and salvage its standing on world stage as supporter of developing countries (M)

headline: It's Never Too Late
abstract: Beth Fitzgerald letter points out advantage to electronic keyboard: using headphones allows her to practice and not disturb others in household (Jan 2 article)

headline: France and Germany Draw a Line, Against Washington
abstract: Pres Jacques Chirac of France and Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany issue blunt rejection of American impatience toward Iraq, saying any Security Council resolution for military action will have to await report of weapons inspectors; speak at daylong ceremony in Paris marking 40th anniversary of French-German cooperation treaty intended to set agenda for new stages of European integration; publish list of areas in which both countries seek closer cooperation; photo (M)

headline: Disaster Prompts Quick Shift of Coverage From Iraq Issue to Events at Home
abstract: Space shuttle Columbia disaster shifts news focus away from Iraq, which had been dominating news in recent months; many news outlets recall anchors and top reporters deployed to Middle East in anticipation of war; photo (M)

headline: Economy Saddled by Worry Over Security, Fed Chief Says
abstract: Alan Greenspan said today that the economy is laboring under geopolitical uncertainties, but it generally remains stable.

headline: Bush Moves to Prepare Public for a Harder War
abstract: President Bush pressed an effort on Sunday to temper public anticipation of an early, relatively painless victory.

headline: NBC President To Take Over At Sony Music
abstract: Sony Corp of America names NBC Inc president and chief operating officer Andrew Lack as chairman and chief executive of Sony Music Entertainment; he succeeds Thomas D Mottola, who was forced out; choice of outsider surprises many music industry insiders; photos; graph (M)

headline: Online Newspaper Shakes Up Korean Politics
abstract: Spunky news services on Internet are credited with helping change politics of South Korea, seemingly overnight; change is symbolized by election in Dec of Roh Moo Hyun, reformist who at 56 is youthful by South Korean political standards; his candidacy was propelled by huge national movement that began with demonstrations against presence of American military bases in South Korea; demonstrations were prompted by reports run in most influential of online newspapers, called OhmyNews, about two schoolgirls who were crushed to death by United States Army armored vehicle on patrol; Roh, after his election, granted OhmyNews first interview he gave to any Korean news organization; photo (M)

headline: Taming Roommate Chaos
abstract: Abby Ellin co

headline: Bertelsmann Investor May Not List Shares
abstract: BERLIN, March 6 (Dow Jones) — Gunter Thielen, the chief executive of Bertelsmann, indicated that the Belgian investor Albert Frere may not seek to list his stake in the German media giant in 2005 as expected.

headline: Swiss Company in Accord Over Asbestos-Related Suits
abstract: Swiss industrial-equipment maker ABB reaches $1.2 billion settlement with lawyers representing over 110,000 people who had sued company over asbestos-related claims; agreement includes placing company's dormant United States subsidiary Combustion Engineering into Chapter 11 bankruptcy; investors express relief that settlement was not more costly (M)

headline: Bomb Blasts Wound 9 at 2 Beijing Universities
abstract: Explosions apparently caused by homemade bombs rip through cafeterias at Quingha and Beijing universities, two of China's most prominent universities, injuring at least nine people; there are no immediate claims of responsibility and motives remain unclear; photo (M)

headline: Who Really Wins In a Pension Conversion?
abstract: Eric P Lofgren letter comments on March 9 article on conversion of traditional pension plans to cash balance plans

headline: Making Shoes For Managers On the Move
abstract: responsible party: making shoes for manar

headline: Channels Struggle on Images of Captured and Slain Soldiers
abstract: American television news organizations face first wrenching decision about how to use graphic video images of war with Iraq; they decide to withhold videotape of captured and killed American soldiers for most of day, respecting Pentagon request not to broadcast tape until families had been informed; tape was first aired on Arab satellite news channel Al Jazeera, which obtained video from Iraq television; photo (M)

headline: Saudis Stock Oil Reserve To Make Up for Iraq Loss
abstract: Saudi Arabia has amassed reserve of nearly 50 million barrels of oil that it plans to use to compensate for possible disruptions of Iraqi oil exports if war erupts in Iraq; Saudi stockpile has been built up over last three months as oil prices have climbed near their highest levels in years; Saudi Oil Min Ali al-Naimi says his country has plenty of spare capacity; price of crude oil for April delivery settles at $34.93 per barrel, down 45 cents, in New York trading; graph; chart; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Bush Expected to Propose Expansion of Savings Plans  The administration is working on a major shift in retirement savings plans that would enable most Americans to greatly increase the amount they could put away in tax-free accounts. The change, which would primarily benefit the affluent, is aimed at encouraging an increase in personal savings and at simplifying the maze of retirement savings choices.     The move would potentially increase tax revenues in the short turn, helping the White House hold down the deficit over the next few years, but it would cause a substantial drain on future tax revenues. [Page A1.]

headline: Attention, Skiers: Snowboarders Coming Through
abstract: National Ski Areas Assn reports that median age of ski resort visitors fell in 2002 as snowboarding gained popularity; graphs (S)

headline: Will He Star Again In a Buyout Revival?
abstract: Leveraged buyout firms, flush with cash after years of reduced activity, begin closing more deals; many have to recoup from previous acquisitions that failed; Thomas O Hicks, who runs Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, struggles to restore his and firm's reputation after losing about $1 billion for his investors after peak of 1990's stock market bubble; range of soured Hicks, Muse ventures is broad; Mr Hicks refocuses firm on buying companies at reasonable prices and expanding them to increase profits; current feeble economy offers unique opportunities with many struggling companies eager to discard parts of their businesses; photos; graphs of industry data (M)

headline: Rumsfeld Orders 35,000 More Troops Deployed Near Iraq
abstract: Sec Donald Rumsfeld signs mammoth deployment order sending about 35,000 new troops, half of them marines, to Persian Gulf, where troops, warships and aircraft are being massed to pressure Iraqi Pres Saddam Hussein to disarm (S)

headline: Jewish Museum in Poland: More Than a Memorial
abstract: Jewish group, with support of Polish government, is drawing up plans for $60 million interactive Museum of the History of Polish Jews, to rise just yards from memorial to Jewish victims of Warsaw ghetto; American architect Frank Gehry, son of Polish Jews, will design building; idea for museum grew in part out of searching of national soul that followed revelations two years ago that Jewish residents of town of Jedwabne were killed by Polish villagers, not occupying Nazis; museum is effort to show that for eight centuries, Poland was vibrant center of Jewish culture, and that some shred of Jewish life and Polish decency survived World War II; photos; map (M)

headline: For Old Friends, Iraq Bares a Deep Rift
abstract: Analysis of quickly-deteriorating trans-Atlantic relations exposed by American plans for war with Iraq; those plans have provoked something far beyond normal disagreements that sometimes take place among allies; Iraqi crisis has brought to surface something deep and fundamental in different views of Europe and United States; gap has opened up in wake of Sept 11 in European and American perceptions of danger; Americans intensely sense new vulnerability and urgent need for self-defense, while Europeans do not; several hundred thousand antiwar protesters expected on streets of London alone make clear that European public, from Britain to Poland, from 'old' Europe to 'new' Europe, is against war in Iraq; some optimistic diplomats say that over next few weeks trans-Atlantic gaps are going to be bridged and current disarray in NATO will disappear; such an outcome looks remote because one of reasons leaders of Germany and France have publicly defied United States is that it is popular to do so; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: SOFTWAREMICROSOFT TRIES TO STRENGTHEN POSITION In a bid to secure a central place in the new gadgets that are increasingly the preferred platform for digital media, Microsoft said yesterday that it would license its Windows Media technology to consumer electronics makers at lower prices and better terms than its main competitors do. Will Poole, corporate vice president of Microsoft's Windows New Media Platform division, said the goal was not to reap a huge profit but to ensure that PC's that run the Windows system work well with devices like camcorders, DVD players and portable media players that consumers want to use with them. The more prevalent its playback and security technology is on consumer devices, the better position Microsoft is in when it tries to sell its technology — and Windows systems — to companies that want to deliver material in digital form.   Amy Harmon (NYT).

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Yankee Candle Co says its founder, Michael Kittredge, has resigned as chairman and as member of board; chief executive Craig Rydin will succeed him as chairman (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Supermarket Bidder Drops Out; BRITAIN: Advertiser'S Profit Falls; IRELAND: Bank Merges Units;.

headline: Ending the Tax on Dividends: What, Why and How Much?
abstract: As the centerpiece of his economic plan, President Bush is about to propose that dividends paid to stockholders by corporations should be exempt from federal income taxes. Here are answers to some important questions about the issue.    Q. Who pays the taxes on dividends right now?    A. Any person who owns stock in a company, estate or trust and receives payments of cash, property or stock as a result must pay the tax. The rates are the same as for wages and other income. But individuals who own stock in an individual retirement account or a tax-deferred 401(k) plan only pay income taxes when money is withdrawn, which usually occurs many years after the dividends are paid.

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Bank Selects Chief; ITALY: Utility'S Profit Falls; ITALY: Loss At Fiat; THE NETHERLANDS: Upc To Take A Charge;.

headline: Citigroup Paid Executive More Than C.E.O.
abstract: Citigroup says in regulatory filing that executive Robert E Rubin, former Treasury secretary, earned $18.4 million last year; more than double compensation of company's chairman-chief executive Sanford I Weill (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank's Profit Rises
abstract: Britain's Standard Chartered says second-half profit rose better-than-expected 45 percent; net income increased to $428 million from $295 million year earlier; graph (S)

headline: Japan to Cut Its Financial Support to U.N.
abstract: Japan plans to cut its support to the U.N. by one-quarter in coming years, senior foreign policy makers said.

headline: For Card Holders, A Reprieve on Returns
abstract: Article reveals little-known benefits offered by credit, debit and charge cards concerning product warranties, returns and price adjustments (S)

headline: MediaTalk; Two Online Rivals Duel With Mocking Ads
abstract: Wall Street Journal Online, which charges users for access, mocks free sites in ad campaign that runs on CBS MarketWatch, a free site, but refuses to accept ad from CBS MarketWatch that would highlight Journal Online's decision to choose its site for advertising (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Economic Index Slips
abstract: Economic index that measures Japanese industrial activity falls 0.6 percent in December from November as retail spending slows (S)

headline: Rapper 50 Cent Has Top-Selling First Album
abstract: Rapper 50 Cent's album, Get Rich or Die Trying, becomes highest-selling first album on major label since such sales began being tabulated in 1991(S)

headline: Sharon Sees Political Motives in Arafat's Appeal
abstract: The Israeli leader clearly implied today that Yasir Arafat's recent cease-fire call was an attempt to influence Israel's Jan. 28 elections.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hotels.com Posts Big Profit; Shares Soar
abstract: Hotels.com, controlled by USA Interactive, posts profit of 17.7 million for fourth quarter, up from $4.8 million year earlier; revenue rose 92 percent, to $272.6 million; company's stock rises 11 percent; graph (S)

headline: A Sequel, Not a Rerun
abstract: There are more differences than similarities between the current conflict and the Persian Gulf war.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Panamsat Posts Higher Profit
abstract: PanAmSat Corp says profit rose to $23.5 million in four quarter from $3.2 million year earlier (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Telecom Write-Down
abstract: Australian telephone company Telstra and Hong Kong carrier PCCW write down value of their Reach undersea cable venture by $1.55 billion because drop in prices has cut revenue; graph (S)

headline: India, Out of Cheetahs, Seeks to Clone
abstract: Indian scientists ask Iranian officials to lend them pair of Asian cheetahs, which have been extinct in India for 50 years, for cloning; Asiatic cheetahs are critically endangered subspecies (S)

headline: Iranian Cleric Denounces Action Against a Dissident
abstract: Ayatollah Jalaledin Taheri, high-ranking reformist cleric, calls on Iran's clerics to break their silence about house arrest of Ayatollah Hossein Al Montazeri, dissident who challenged authority of country's supreme religious leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei; urges clerics to press for Montazeri's release (M)

headline: Former Money Manager Going to Prison
abstract: Federal Judge Leonard B Sand sentences former money manager Alan B Bond to 12 1/2 years in prison for cheating clients and taking kickbacks from brokers; orders Bond to pay restitution of $6.6 million (M)

headline: Powell in the Security Council: Will Echoes of Stevenson Fill the Chamber?
abstract: Upcoming appearance of US Sec of State Colin L Powell before UN Security Council, where he is expected to provide previously classified evidence about Iraq's weapons programs, discussed; appearance will likely be compared with probably most dramatic event in Council's history, when US Amb Adlai Stevenson in 1962 showed world photographic evidence of Soviet missiles in Cuba; incident recalled; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Sends 18 at Guantánamo To Afghanistan to Be Freed
abstract: United States military returns 18 prisoners from Guantanamo Bay detention site in Cuba to Afghanistan, saying they could not find evidence that they are guilty of anything (M)

abstract: Alan Cowell reviews book Turn Around: How Carlos Ghosn Rescued Nissan by David Magee; photo (M)

headline: Improved Tools Turn Journalists Into a Quick Strike Force
abstract: Reporters covering war in Iraq have new technology at their disposal, including compact satellite dishes, hand-held video cameras, lighter satellite phones and high-speed Internet lines; say smaller gadgets and bigger bandwidth have broadened their reach in way that is sure to change how people perceive war; some media critics say technology's potential benefits can be undermined by pressure it places on reporters to be filing continually simply because it is possible to do so; photos (M)

headline: Entrepreneur Said to Offer To Rescue Fiat With $8 Billion
abstract: Roberto Colaninno, Italian entrepreneur, proposes to creditor banks ambitious $8 billion plan to rescue Fiat group; proposal, in its broad outlines, calls for groups of investors led by Colannino to put $2.5 billion to $3 billion into Fiat, with company raising additional $4 billion through divestitures; Colaninno photo (M)

headline: Chávez Says Leaders of Strike Should Be Tried as Saboteurs
abstract: Venezuela's Pres Hugo Chavez, defying international criticism, says leaders of crippling two-month nationwide strike should be arrested and charged as saboteurs for wreaking economic and human damage in failed attempt to provoke his resignation; lashes out at critics, notably Cesar Gaviria, secretary general of Organization of American States, who condemned arrest warrants issued for opposition leaders Carlos Fernandez and Carlos Ortega; Fernandez is under house arrest and Ortega has gone into hiding; photo (M)

headline: Tyco Offers Plan for Raising $4.75 Billion
abstract: Tyco International announces plans to sell $3.25 billion in convertible bonds and to raise $1.5 billion more through one-year line of credit in effort to close $3.6 billion cash shortage this year (M)

headline: People
abstract: Stuart Grau, chief strategic officer at Avrett, Free & Ginsberg, is named to new post of president; Cabletelevision Advertising Bureau president-chief executive Joseph W Ostrow agrees to continue in post for two months as search for his successor continues (S)

headline: Sony Profits Climb 96% In Quarter
abstract: Sony Corp reports its profits doubled, to record 125.4 billion yen ($1.1 billion), in October-to-December quarter, as sales of its PlayStation 2 video games and string of hit movies offset lukewarm demand for its electronics (M)

headline: Turning the Desktop Into a Meeting Place
abstract: Robb Beal creates computer interface that unites broad range of Intenet information and services; system is called Spring; it facilitates communication between people and human-computer interaction by focusing user on representative icons of people, places and things that can be connected; photo (M)

abstract: David S North letter comments on March 16 article on challenging one's property tax assessment
