headline: North Korea Says It Is Withdrawing From Arms Treaty
abstract: North Korea set off a flurry of diplomatic activity and condemnation today when it announced it was withdrawing from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty.

headline: France Opposes Proposal For U.S.-British Rule in Iraq
abstract: European Union meetings end after two days, with French Pres Jacques Chirac saying he will oppose British idea for Security Council resolution that would give US and Britain right to govern Iraq; Britain continues verbal attack against France; Germany, France and Belgium plan separate meeting to discuss strengthening Europe's military capability; war in Iraq colors all aspects of meeting and has battered unity among EU members; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Software
abstract: MICROSOFT TO BUY SOME ASSETS OF CONNECTIX; REALNETWORKS AND ERICSSON CREATE ALLIANCE; MAPICS TO CUT 23% OF WORK FORCE;.

headline: Leading Mexican Drug Suspect Is Captured
abstract: Mexican law enforcement officials report arrest of Osiel Cardenas, one of country's most wanted drug lords, after shootout in Matamoris (S)

headline: Pension Insurer Cites $3.6 Billion Deficit and Suspects Worse
abstract: Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp, which insures retirement benefits for about 44 million Americans, reports $3.6 billion deficit, its largest ever, and says it is studying whether way businesses now calculate pension values is masking even deeper weaknesses in system; executive director Steven A Kandarian comments; photo (M)

headline: Senator Says New York Cities Paying Many Security Costs
abstract: Sen Hillary Rodham Clinton, complaining that federal money for security has failed to reach most communities in New York State, contends that local governments are bearing disproportionate share of cost of security since Sept 11, 2001; accuses Bush administration of failing to provide money to protect citizens in event of attack; photo (M)

headline: Looming Trade Penalties Could Sever a North Korean Link to Japan
abstract: Ferry that plies between Pyongyang, North Korea, and Nigata, Japan, carrying ethnic Koreans between their homes in Japan and relatives in North Korea, may be eliminated under sanctions being considered in Japan if North does not drop its nuclear weapons programs; conservatives in Japan regard ship as unwarranted lifeline for North Korea's recalcitrant Communist government, providing it with tens of millions of dollars raked off from vast empire of pinball and gambling operations operated in Japan by ethnic Koreans loyal to North Korea; liberals regard ferry as human rights issue, providing lone passenger link for divided families; photo; map (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Employers Take a New Role In Dealing With Uninsured  With rising health costs squeezing profit margins and growing numbers of people without insurance pushing costs even higher, employers are beginning to call for ways to deal with the problem of the uninsured.    Employers have viewed the uninsured as the government's responsibility. But some executives and benefits specialists are realizing that the 41 million Americans without health insurance are costing them money. [Page C5.]

headline: Iraqi Scientist Inquiry
abstract: The Bush administration expects that international inspectors will try to take Iraqi scientists and engineers out of the country starting next week to interview them about weapons programs, officials said.    Article, Page A12.

headline: Vietnam, Poor but Orderly, Is Now Tourists' Safe Haven
abstract: Vietnam, with its relative stability, draws security-conscious tourists; many tourists say they were interested in coming anyway and are drawn by country's near absence of Muslims, as well as country's controlled Communist society; even as Sept 11 marked sharp drop in travel to many other countries, Vietnam saw increase of 8.9 percent (M)

headline: Hollywood Investor Buys KirchMedia TV Unit
abstract: Bankrupt KirchMedia agrees to sell its television assets to Haim Saban, children's programmer who made his fortune by popularizing Japanese cartoons; will sell Saban control of broadcast group ProSiebenSat.1, which operates four major TV stations in Germany; financial terms undisclosed; Saban comments; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: TV Investigation Postponed
abstract: European Commission says it is suspending its antitrust investigation into French pay television company Canal Plus because of recent events in market; commission has been examining contracts between TV operation and Hollywood studios because it suspected that their long duration might stifle competition; concerns have faded since rival TPS has also signed contracts with movie studios (S)

headline: British Police Arrest Air Traveler With Grenade, but See No Terror Link
abstract: Authorities on heightened alert for terrorism arrest Venezuelan man carrying hand grenade in his bag at Gatwick Airport in London; one terminal is evacuated and flights are suspended; incident occurs on third day of one of Britain's biggest security crackdowns in response to possible attacks by Al Qaeda operatives; photo (M)

headline: IRISH LIFE TO SELL REMAINING U.S. INSURANCE OPERATION
abstract: Irish Life and Permanent to sell remaining US insurance business to Reassure America Life Insurance, Swiss Reinsurance unit, for $121 million (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: French Court Rejects Suit Against Yahoo
abstract: Paris court rejects lawsuit by French human rights advocates and Holocaust survivors who sued Yahoo for one symbolic euro; accused Yahoo of having condoned war crimes when it sold Nazi paraphernalia on its auction pages; French law forbids display or sale of racist material, but items were available to French users who clicked on to American pages; court says Yahoo did not seek to 'justify war crimes and crimes against humanity' when it sold items on its Web site (S)

headline: Saudi Arabia Says It Won't Join a War
abstract: Saudi Arabia says it would take no part in American-led invasion of 'brotherly Iraq' and warns against breakup of country in wake of war; United States conducted Persian Gulf war in 1991 against Iraq from Saudi Arabian bases, but kingdom now faces rising anti-American sentiment and is opposing military action against Iraq now (S)

headline: Boycott of PepsiCo Is Called Off
abstract: Boycott of PepsiCo Is Called Off A threatened boycott of PepsiCo was called off yesterday after Pepsi agreed to donate millions of dollars to nonprofit groups benefiting young people.

headline: Shortened Workweek Shortens French Tempers
abstract: French workers averaged fewer hours a week than those in most other developed nations in 2000, but many French workers complain about having to work too hard; French prefer to keep work in perspective, giving them what many people see as healthier balance to their lives; relaxed attitude may be attributed to fact that government gives citizens free health care and education, inexpensive and reliable child care, plus subsidies for all sorts of things; photo; France enacted maximum 35-hour workweek in 2000, year when French averaged 29.5-hour week, lowest in developed world (M)

headline: Mexican Energy Giant Lumbers Into Hazy Future
abstract: Long-term outlook is murky for Petroleos Mexicanos, state-owned company that controls Mexico's production of oil, natural gas and petrochemicals; company sends nearly all of its income to national treasury, financing roughly 40 percent of Mexico's federal budget; Raul Munoz Leos, Pemex director, is driving company to ever greater production of crude oil, and he estimates that output will grow to 4 million barrels a day in 2006 from 3.2 million in 2002; independent analysts predict that after 2010, production will level off, and then start falling steeply; Munox Leos says Pemex has significant number of rules and regulations from many government agencies that create 'very heavy bureaucratic problems in almost everything we attempt'; photo of Pemex refineries (L)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.25   4.25   4.75       Discount rate   2.25   2.25   N.A.       Federal funds   1.18   1.25   1.71       3-month T-bills   1.16   1.16   1.71       6-month T-bills   1.18   1.17   1.81       10-yr. T-infl.   1.87   1.85   3.22       10-yr. headline: U.S. to Allow North Korea Envoy to Meet Former U.N. Ambassador
abstract: North Korean diplomats today received approval to meet with Gov. Bill Richardson, Democrat of New Mexico.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Chemical Stake Sale
abstract: Christoph Blocher will sell some of his stake in specialty chemicals company EMS to increase its liquidity; company will also unify its share structure and issue dividend in 2002 for first time since 1998 (S)

headline: Shooting for Real: A Historical Sampler
abstract: Sampling of 'reality television' from Candid Camera to The Osbourne, noting development of technology over years

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Serbia And Montenegro: New Premier
abstract: Serbian Parliament approves nomination of Zoran Zivkovic to be new Prime Minister; Zivkovic, loyal ally to slain leader Zoran Djindjic, will preside over same cabinet and declares he will continue effort to eliminate criminal networks; police have detained 750 people in connection with assassination, however ringleaders of suspected Belgrade gang remain at large; photo (S)

headline: Assets Off Sharply At Magellan Fund
abstract: Magellan Fund of Fidelity Investments ended 2002 with $56.8 billion in assets, smallest total in five and half years as declining stock prices shrank what was once nation's largest mutual fund; Morningstar Inc says Magellan lost 24 percent, lagging 68 percent of similar funds; Financial Research Corp says investors withdrew $4.1 billion more than they put into Magellan from January to November, after $2.6 billion in outflows in 2001 (M)

headline: AOL and Harvard Plan Film Grants
abstract: AOL Time Warner and Harvard University are starting grant program to support documentarians seeking to make films about black experience in US (S)

headline: Volkswagen Sees Falling Profits And Frail Market
abstract: Volkswagen AG says its first-quarter profit will fall significantly below that of last year and that its full-year operating profit might also decline; gloomy outlook by chief executive Bernd Pischetsrieder leads to panicky sell-off of Volkswagen shares, which spreads to broader German market and shares of other carmakers; graph; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Economy in Worst Hiring Slump in 20 Years
abstract: The American economy has fallen into its worst hiring slump in almost 20 years, and many business executives say they remain unsure when it will end.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.25   4.25   4.75       Discount rate   0.75   0.75   1.50       Federal funds   1.19   1.27   1.78       3-month T-bills   1.13   1.14   1.67       6-month T-bills   1.16   1.17   1.78       10-yr. T-infl.   2.11   2.15   3.47       10-yr. T-note   3.93   3.94   5.07       30-yr. T-bond   4.86   4.89   5.46       Telephone bd.   6.15   6.10   7.60       Municipal bds.   5.09   5.11   5.35          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Mouse With Ear Appeal Can Tune In FM Stations
abstract: New two-button computer mouse by SmarTec doubles as digital FM radio receiver and can be used without connecting to Internet; photo (M)

headline: Deutsche Telekom Is Expected To Sell 6 Cable TV Networks
abstract: Deutsche Telecom is expected to announce agreement to sell six regional cable-television networks to group of American investors for 1.725 billion euros, or about $1.87 billion; group--Apax Partners, Goldman Sachs Group and Providence Equity Partners--is buying networks at significant discount to 5.5 billion euros that Liberty Media agreed to pay for business in 2002; Liberty deal was eventually blocked by German regulators (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Petrochemical Profit Rises
abstract: Reliance Industries, India's largest petrochemicals company, says profit for quarter ended in December doubled from year earlier, to 10.83 billion rupees ($225.62 million) (S)

headline: British Safeway Now Urges That Original Suitor Be Jilted
abstract: Safeway says it is no longer recommending that its shareholders approve deal that it reached two weeks ago to be acquired by William Morrison Supermarkets (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | France: Telecom Stock Sale
abstract: France Telecom, in effort ot turn around its debt, announces it will sell 15 billion euros of stock ($15.8 billion) to investors; chief executive Thierry Breton says capital will allow him to refocus management on running normal company; photo (S)/

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Austria: When In Vienna . . .
abstract: Austria requires immigrants to take German courses and classes on Austrian political and social system (S)

headline: ONLINE DIARY
abstract: Online Diary column; ProfQuotes is Web site that collects and disseminates notable quotations credited to academics; photoblogs use diary format and are updated with original photos instead of commentary; SIBL Project Web site keeps track of popular songs inspired by literature; miscellaneous Web sites noted; drawings (M)

headline: Israeli Raid Snares A Foe, but Leaves Family Motherless
abstract: The eight Makadmah children crowded into their parents' bed early this morning as the rumble of the Israeli tanks outside grew louder. Watching Palestinian television, they learned that the soldiers were demolishing the home of a neighbor, a known militant.    Then came an explosion, and the wall fell on them.

headline: The Right Goals For a Loan to Poland?
abstract: Glenn Cheney letter voices his opposition to loan by United States to Poland to allow it to purchase American F-16 fighter jets as reported in Jan 12 article

headline: Hamas Blames Israel for Gaza Blast That Killed 6
abstract: The incident happened hours after Israel's defense minister vowed retaliation for a Hamas bombing in Gaza on Saturday that killed the four Israeli soldiers.

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Ariba To Restate More Results
abstract: AribaÈ

headline: Another Executive Quits Merrill's Research Unit
abstract: Robert J McCann resigns as head of Merrill Lynch's investment research department and will be succeeded by Candace Browning; string of recent departures at department stirs concerns among Merrill's brokers about department's viability, but Merrill executives dismiss those fears; photo (M)

headline: EON LABS SAYS GENERIC MUSCLE DRUG TO BE DELAYED
abstract: Eon Labs Inc says generic version of Elan Corp's Skelaxin muscle relaxant will be delayed after regulators reject study of drug; Food and Drug Administration accepted Eon's application for drug in 2001; agency finads research unacceptable (S)

headline: Looking at Both Sides of the Pills
abstract: William J Holstein reviews book The Merck Druggernaut: The Inside Story of a Pharmaceutical Giant by Fran Hawthorne; photo (M)

headline: OCEAN SPRAY REJECTS NORTHLAND'S $800 MILLION OFFER
abstract: Ocean Spray Cranberries rejects Northland Cranberries offer to buy juice business and brand name for $800 million (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Central Bank To Limit Moves
abstract: Bank of Japan governor Masaru Hayami says central bank will not increase purchases of stocks or bonds; bank has promised to buy up to 2 trillion yen ($16.8 billion) in equities from Japanese banks to help them reduce their exposure to risk assets; less than half of that money has been used (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: More Charges Expected In HealthSouth Inquiry  Federal investigators are expected to file criminal charges against additional senior officials at HealthSouth soon, people involved in the inquiry said.    HealthSouth said that its financial statements should not be relied upon after federal investigators said they uncovered many fraudulent accounting practices. Also, Betsy Atkins, a director, resigned from the board less than three weeks after joining it. [Page C2.]

headline: Former Prime Minister Elected President in Czech Republic
abstract: Vaclav Klaus, forced to resign as prime minister in 1998 amid scandal over party financing, is elected during parliamentary session to replace old rival Pres Vaclav Havel; some experts predict that Klaus, right-wing free marketeer, could become more involved in day-to-day political fray than Havel, who has retired; photo (M)

headline: Judge Criticizes Letter From Bayer
abstract: Judge James B Klager asks district attorney to investigate letters sent by Bayer to thousands of residents of Corpus Christi, Tex, before jury selection in lawsuit involving its anticholesterol drug Baycol; says there are concerns that letters might constitute attempt to tamper with jury (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Financial Chief Urged To Quit
abstract: Hong Kong opposition politicians demand resignation of Financial Secretary Antony Leung questioning his personal car purchase five weeks before he announced tax increase on cars; Leung, who holds purchase was because wife was expecting new baby not to evade taxes, has offered to resign, but Hong Kong territory Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa has refused resignation instead issuing official reprimand (S)

headline: Big Sandstorm, 'Kuwaiti Crud,' Clogs the Lungs and Stops the Convoys
abstract: An enormous sandstorm swept through the Persian Gulf on Wednesday, limiting visibility to a few yards and grounding helicopters.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Offer for Global Crossing To Be Revised by Hutchison  Hutchison Whampoa of Hong Kong, which is trying to buy Global Crossing in a joint bid with Singapore Technologies Telemedia, is considering ways to revise its proposed deal after its bid for approval from a federal multiagency regulatory organization met with resistance, people involved in the matter said.    Hutchison Whampoa has considered several possibilities, including the appointment of prominent American politicians or businessmen to act as proxies on Global Crossing's new board, these people said. [Page C2.]

headline: New Evidence Raises Toll in South Korea Near 200
abstract: Fine-grained ash has yielded evidence of the deaths of another 50 people in the fire that raged through two subway trains last week.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Large Strike Averted
abstract: German government agrees to wage increases to avert strike by country's largest union (S)

headline: JOHNSON & JOHNSON SETTLES PATENT SUIT FOR $15 MILLION
abstract: Johnson & Johnson will pay $15 million and future royalties to settle lawsuit claiming it infringed patent for screw used in spinal implants; Interpore International sued DePuy AcroMed Inc unit of Johnson & Johnson, saying business used technology protected by Interpore patents (S)

headline: Iraqis Pull Back
abstract: Kurdish officials say Iraqi soldiers have pulled back from two front-line positions around strategic city of Kirkuk in northern Iraq; withdrawals appear to be organized effort to minimize risk of bombardments, rather than panicked retreats; photo (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of chart with March 2 article on business outlook for Morgan Stanley

headline: Profit Lower at Borland
abstract: The Borland Software Corporation, a maker of software used to customize computer programs, said that fourth-quarter profit declined despite a 14 percent increase in sales.

headline: CHARLES SCHWAB REPORTS A $79 MILLION LOSS IN QUARTER
abstract: Charles Schwab Corp says fourth-quarter loss widened to $79 million; revenue from customer trading fell 14 percent, pushing overall revenue down 6 percent, to $996 million, from $1.1 billin year ago (S)

headline: Questioning Terror Suspects In a Dark and Surreal World
abstract: Capture of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed provides American authorities with best opportunity yet to prevent attacks by Al Qaeda and track down Osama bin Laden; it also presents tactical and moral challenge regarding interrogation techniques used to obtain vital information; senior American officials say physical torture would not be used against Mohammed, regarded as mastermind of Sept 11 attacks; say interrogation would rely on what they consider acceptable techniques like sleep and light deprivation and temporary withholding of food, water and medical attention; several American officials say urgency of obtaining information about potential attacks and opaque nature of way interrogations are carried out can blur line between accepted and unaccepted actions; interrogations of important Qaeda operatives like Mohammed occur at isolated locations outside jurisdiction of American law; intelligence officials acknowledge that some suspects have been turned over to security services in countries known to employ torture; rights advocates claim such transfers violate American law and 1984 international convention against torture, which bans such transfers; photos (L)

headline: Newspaper Group Hires Chief Executive
abstract: Newspaper Group Hires Chief Executive.

headline: Breaking Into Sports, Weights Optional
abstract: Home Front column finds New York has more than 5,000 year-round, sports-related jobs from entry-level assistants to team owners; industry has $10 billion impact on metropolitan area economy; photo (M)

headline: Cost-Cutting Lets Daimler Post Profit
abstract: DaimlerChrysler reports fourth-quarter net income of 168 million euros ($181 million) compared with net loss of 39 million euros year earlier; 2002 net income was 4.72 billion euros ($5.1 billion) in contrast to loss of 662 million euros in 2001; auto sales dropped 2 percent in US in January, while Chrysler sales dropped by 12 percent (M)

headline: Growth and Employment in Services Rose Modestly Last Month
abstract: Institute for Supply Management reports non-manufacturing index for January rose to 54.5 from downward-revised 54.2 reported for December; nonmanufacturing employment index was 50.3 for January, pointing to growing pace of hiring over December's unrevised figure of 46.9; prices for services also continued to rise, with that index reading 57.0 for January, after upward-revised 55.3 in December (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: South American Nations Pursue Closer Ties
abstract: Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay form union to negotiate trade agreements with US; countries are already considering common passport for four nations (S)

headline: U.S. DEMANDS IRAQ SHOW COOPERATION BY THIS WEEKEND
abstract: Sec of State Colin L Powell says Pres Bush will press immediately for UN Security Council resolution authorizing possible use of force against Iraq if Pres Saddam Hussein still refuses to cooperate with weapons inspectors at end of coming week; appears to lay out acceleragting timetable in confrontation with Iraq, even as France, Germany and other members of Security Council press call for more time before considering use of force; dismisses in TV interview reports that France and Germany, and perhaps Russia, will recommend deploying UN peacekeepers in Iraq along with inspectors; says such action would be pointless; moves with others in Bush administration to pressure France and Germany over growing dispute within NATO on Iraq; dispute centers on refusal of both countries and Belgium to agree to Turkey's request for military equipment to prepare for possible war with Iraq; officials say next important date in quickening pace of events is February 14, when chief UN weapons inspectors Hans Blix and Dr Mohamed el-Baradei deliver updated report on whether Iraq is complying with inspections ordered by Council in November 2002; photo (L),

headline: Qalqiliya Journal; In the Man-Ravaged West Bank, a Petrified Zoo
abstract: West Bank town of Qalqiliya closes local zoo as conflict between Israelis and Palestinians has not only taken toll on animals, but has also prevented zoo from brining in any new animals; Dr Sami Khader, zoo's veterinarian and taxidermist, is embalming dead animals and exhibiting them in zoo's museum; photo (M)

headline: How Green Is Their Valley?
abstract: Profile of Green Valley, Ariz, retirement community of 17,283 in 2000 census with median age of 72; residents are living longer, more vigorous lives, but three-year rout of investment markets has taken its toll; some residents have been forced to tighten their belts or even move back with their children or into government-subsidized housing; photos; map (L)

headline: Analyst Questions Accounting Of British Supermarket Chain
abstract: Analyst Michael Dennis of French bank Credit Agricole Indosuez Cheuvreux is questioning accounting of British supermarket chain Safeway, which is subject of bidding war; Dennis expects rebates at Safeway to total as much as 50 million pounds ($80 million) for financial year that will end on March 30, or about 12 percent of pretax profit for period; is concerned about sharp rise in money owed to Safeway by suppliers, which has risen 153 percent, to 210 million pounds ($333 million), from 83 million pounds ($132 million) in 2001, at time when Safeway's sales are falling; Safeway spokesman Kevin Hawkins says company's accounting for rebates is in line with industry practices; William Morrison Supermarkets reports 14 perent rise in pretax profit, to 276.6 million pounds, for financial year ended Feb 2 (M)

headline: CORRECTION: CABLE TELEVISION
abstract: The weekly ''Most Wanted'' chart in Business Day yesterday carried incorrect rankings for cable television programs. They were based solely on households that subscribe to a given cable network, not the typical measurement of total TV households. A corrected version appears below.    Shows of at least 30 minutes duration, February 17 to 23. A ratings point is 1.07 million homes.    TITLE: 1. WWE Raw (Mon., 10 p.m.)  NETWORK: TNN  RATING: 3.3    TITLE: 2. SpongeBob (Sat., 9:30 a.m.)  NETWORK: NICK  RATING: 3.2    TITLE: 3. Trading Spaces  NETWORK: TLC  RATING: 3.0    TITLE: 4. SpongeBob (Sat., 9 a.m.)  NETWORK: NICK  RATING: 2.9    TITLE: WWE Raw (Mon., 9 p.m.)  NETWORK: TNN  RATING: 2.9    TITLE: 6. Fairly Odd Parents (Sat., 10 a.m.)  NETWORK: NICK  RATING: 2.9    TITLE: 7. SpongeBob (Wed., 6 p.m.)  NETWORK: NICK  RATING: 2.7    TITLE: 8. Fairly Odd Parents (Sun., 10 a.m.)  NETWORK: NICK  RATING: 2.6    TITLE: SpongeBob (Sun., 9:30 a.m.)  NETWORK: NICK  RATING: 2.6    TITLE: 9. SpongeBob (Sun., 9 a.m.)  NETWORK: NICK  RATING: 2.5    TITLE: Jimmy Neutron  NETWORK: NICK  RATING: 2.5    (Source: Nielsen Media Research)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Appeal On Microsoft Fought
abstract: Microsoft Corp and Justice Department ask Federal Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly to bar Software Information Industry Association and Computer and Communication Industry Association from appealing settlement of long-running Microsoft antitrust case, which she approved in November (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Construction Merger
abstract: Spanish builder Sacyr is in talks to merge with real estate developer Vallehermoso valuing Sacyr at as much as 1.27 billion euros ($1.4 billion) (S)

headline: Crisis in Italy's State Network Stirs New Claims Against Premier
abstract: Italy's Prime Min Silvio Berlusconi, media magnate, faces new accusations of conflict of interest, brought on by crisis at state broadcasting network RAI; his actual or potential control over six of seven national television channels that has allowed him great influence, but supplied ammunition to opposition to question possible hidden motives behind nearly every programming decision discussed; opposition accuses him of running public television into ground for his own benefit; cite dropping ratings of three public networks; critics point to possible abuses of state television since he took office 20 months ago; Berlusconi denies allegations (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: More Cash For Car Venture
abstract: Louis Schweitzer, chairman of Renault, told reporters in Moscow that the company would invest $250 million to expand Avtoframos, its car-assembly joint venture with the Moscow city government, and finance development of a new model, the X90. Avtoframos's output is now just 10 cars a day, all Symbol economy sedans.   Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Tougher Penal Code Is Sought
abstract: Rising crime statistics prompt Spanish government to seek overhaul of penal code that would stiffen penalties for drug trafficking, domestic abuse and other offenses (S)

headline: Surviving At Disney, Eisner Faces Difficult Year
abstract: Michael D Eisner faces difficult year as chief executive of Walt Disney Co, whose television, movie and amusement park businesses are all under pressure; company is considering sales of assets, including champion Anaheim Angels; recent changes to Disney's corporate structure have helped muzzle some of Eisner's harsher critics, like Stanley P Gold, investment adviser to family of Roy E Disney; photo; graph (M)

headline: Stocks Dive on Worries About Iraq and Corporate Earnings
abstract: The three leading stocks gauges fell more than 2.9 percent today, giving the stock market its second straight week of losses.

headline: Rome Journal; Every Stone Has a Story, and Graffitisti to Tell It
abstract: Rome, Italy, has become one big graffiti gallery; buildings, sculptures, subway cars and other surfaces bear works of graffiti artists who have proliferated to point that city has created special agency to fight them; photos (M)

headline: Fund Manager to Meet His Irate Investors in Court
abstract: Kenneth Lipper, money manager to stars before his hedge fund collapsed year ago, will try to persuade judge that he can pay his investors back; many of investors are furious, saying that plan favors some clients over others; Lipper startled financial industry when he announced last February that his Lipper Convertibles Fund lost $315 million, or 40 percent of its value; clients in his fund included Michael D Eisner, Julia Roberts and Mortimer B Zuckerman, and spanned upper reaches of society in Hollywood and New York; photos (M)

headline: Budget Official Is Bush's Choice to Lead an Embattled I.R.S.
abstract: Pres Bush names Mark W Everson, deputy director of White House budget office, to run Internal Revenue Service, reflecting administration's belief that embattled agency needs management help more than tax-policy expertise; Bush names Clay Johnson to replace Everson at budget office (M)

headline: Bank of America shifts campaign to 'higher standards.'
abstract: Bank of America is introducing advertising campaign with slogan 'Higher standards,' replacing 18-month-old campaign with theme 'Embracing ingenuity'; campaign was developed by Interpublic Group of Companies; combined billings estimated at $170 million; photo (M)
